meaning.mnemonic: You find a toe on the ground. It's weird, because it's above the ground, not where toes belong.

readings.mnemonic: Of course when you find a toe above the ground, you want to know where the toe came from. When you examine it, you see a name written on there. This toe belongs to the local clumsy farmhand, Jourm (じょう).

meaning.mnemonic: There's a toe below ground.

readings.mnemonic: You keep digging for the toe below the ground, and instead of hitting a toe you hit something hard and metallic. You keep digging and digging around it, but it's huge. Turns out, you found yourself a car (か). Keep digging until you unearth the car. Inside, you find the toe you were looking for.

meaning.mnemonic: The big radical and the big kanji are exactly the same!

readings.mnemonic: There's this big guy (that's how you remember the radical, remember?), and he's wearing a huge Tie Dye (たい, だい) shirt. Because he's so huge, the tie dye shirt is also super huge. Everything about him is pretty big, but the tie dye stands out more than anything.

meaning.mnemonic: The construction radical and the construction kanji are the same!

readings.mnemonic: For kanji that use the こう (there are a lot of them!) we will use the character こういち every time. He's one of the people who started this website, so we'll do our best in the mnemonics to embarrass him as much as possible. Anyways, remember that whenever you see こう, think こういち.

meaning.mnemonic: This isn't exactly the same as the fins radical, but it's close. Sometimes this will happen (where we have to use a slightly "modified radical" version of the original), so it's good to understand that now, early on. In this case, we have fins. How many fins? Eight fins. How do you know that? Because you caught four fish with two fins each.

readings.mnemonic: After you count and smell all eight of your fins, it's time to put them away. You open a large hatch (はち) and put them in. This is where you keep your fins, always putting in eight at a time because that's what the boss wants.

meaning.mnemonic: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for enter first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means enter as well.

readings.mnemonic: Turns out, after you enter the teepee (you'll remember that the radical is a teepee with a big entrance to it), you're given a new (にゅう) one! Now you have two teepees!

meaning.mnemonic: The mountain radical and the mountain kanji are the same.

readings.mnemonic: Think about mountains talking to each other, calling each other by their names and adding the Japanese name-ender san (さん) to each of their names. "Hello, Everest-san." "Oh hi, Fuji-san."

meaning.mnemonic: The mouth radical and the mouth kanji are exactly the same!

readings.mnemonic:
Do you remember seeing the construction worker こういち earlier in the 工 mnemonic? If you haven't yet, not to worry! 
For kanji with こう readings (there are a lot of them!) we will use the character こういち every time. He's one of the people who started this website, so we'll do our best in the mnemonics to embarrass him as much as possible. Anyways, remember that whenever you see こう, think こういち.

meaning.mnemonic: Nice! This kanji is the same as the radical that looks just like it (down to the meaning, even!). The radical is nine and the kanji is nine, making the meaning of this kanji really easy to remember as long as you know the radical first.

readings.mnemonic: Although this kanji has two on'yomi to learn, the pronunciations of those two on'yomi are very similar, so that should make them easier to remember.

meaning.mnemonic: Lying on the ground is something that looks just like the ground, the number One. Why is this One lying down? It's been shot by the number two. It's lying there, bleeding out and dying. The number One doesn't have long to live.

readings.mnemonic: As you're sitting there next to One, holding him up, you start feeling a weird sensation all over your skin. From the wound comes a fine powder (obviously coming from the special bullet used to kill One) that causes the person it touches to get extremely itchy (いち).

meaning.mnemonic: Remember how the radical version of this kanji meant person because it's a person walking from the side with their arms down? Well this is a person too!

readings.mnemonic: Only one person at Nintendo (にん) complained about the new jeans (じん) policy, and that person was you.

meaning.mnemonic: The radical and the meaning of this kanji are the same. Both are Power.

readings.mnemonic: Who has the most Power of anyone? It's the Power Rangers. Who are they battling? Ricky (りき) the Rock (りょく) Monster.

meaning.mnemonic: The river radical and the river kanji are the same as each other!

readings.mnemonic: You're standing next to a river that's actually used as a car wash (かわ).

meaning.mnemonic: Lucky for you (as is the case with many of the lower-stroke kanji), this kanji is the same as the radical you've already learned. The radical that makes up this kanji is seven and the kanji (which is exactly the same) is also seven. So, if you know the radical, you know the meaning of the kanji as well.

readings.mnemonic: You know this kanji means Seven, so let's use that to remember the reading too. Seven is a lucky number, usually, but this time it wasn't so good.

meaning.mnemonic: This cross is the symbol for the number ten. A good way to remember this is to think about all the religions that have crosses and also important sets of tens.

readings.mnemonic: This cross in particular has ten jewels (じゅう) on it. Two on each arm and two in the middle. That's ten jewels!

meaning.mnemonic: This kanji is made up of the ground radical (which also happens to be the kanji for "one") and the radical for two. Combine one and two together and what do you get? Three!

readings.mnemonic: Three is the number of chances you get with Santa-san (さん). He has a list, and when you get to three "naughty things" lines, that's it. You're on Santa-san's three strikes and you're out list.

meaning.mnemonic: The kanji two and the radical two are the exact same things. Therefore, you know the kanji for two already!

readings.mnemonic: Think of all the things you have Two of. What is the most important? Some would say eyes, some would say ears. I would say the knee (に) because if you didn't have them, it'd be really hard to go up stairs.

meaning.mnemonic: The radical for woman and the kanji for woman are exactly the same.

readings.mnemonic: When you think of a woman, think of Jo-Anne (じょ), though she usually goes by just "Jo."

meaning.mnemonic: The king has something in his hand that he's dropping... but it bounces too! He's bouncing a ball

readings.mnemonic: Think of someone curled up in a ball. It is someone you know / someone famous named “Tom” (たま).

meaning.mnemonic: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for book first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means book as well.

readings.mnemonic: Books are one of the best ways to hone (ほん) your intellect, you know?

meaning.mnemonic: The child radical and the child kanji are exactly the same.

readings.mnemonic: To remember the sounds  し and す we'll use these mnemonics:

meaning.mnemonic: What's something with nine sides? Just add a drop and you'll have something that's almost a circle.

readings.mnemonic: Do you know about the adorable cat Maru? If not, you should check it out. May seem like a distraction, but if you come back knowing the reading for this kanji, then it's totally worth while.

meaning.mnemonic: There is a line on the ground so you stop and a giant sign pops up that says CORRECT! You obeyed the rules of the road and did the correct thing.

readings.mnemonic: You did the correct thing, so the Shougun (しょう) shows up to reward you! He holds out a shiny new saber (せい) in his hand, gently taps it onto each of your shoulders, and then hands it to you. It's big, curved and you love it.

meaning.mnemonic: The dirt radical and the dirt kanji are the same!

readings.mnemonic: Who spends a lot of time in dirt? Dogs (ど) do! Dogs dig in dirt, they roll in dirt, sometimes they try to eat dirt (which isn't so great).

meaning.mnemonic: The dog radical and dog kanji are exactly the same!

readings.mnemonic: You see an emu running towards you from off in the distance (strange to see an emu in these parts...). As it gets closer, you realize that it's not an emu at all, it's something that sounds the same, or similar... an inu!

meaning.mnemonic: The evening radical and the evening kanji are the same. If you know the radical you know the meaning of the kanji.

readings.mnemonic: The evening is when all the youths (ゆう) come outside to play.

meaning.mnemonic: There are two mountains in front of you... and probably a bunch more around you too. You are in a pass, and don't know how to get out. You are frantically looking for the exit before you freeze to death. The most important thing is to find the exit from this mountain range - your life depends on it.

readings.mnemonic: As you're trying to exit this mountain range, you suddenly realize that someone is actually hunting you. What? Make sure to feel that sudden realization. It's crazy. Then, you find the exit and run towards it. Sadly, the hunter is waiting there, and he shoots you (しゅつ) through the leg, knocking you down.

meaning.mnemonic: The eye radical and eye kanji are the same as each other, so now you know them both.

readings.mnemonic: Your eyes are important to you, right? Sadly, one of your eyes is missing right now, because a sheep grabbed it and pulled it out, and is now running away from you, yelling his sheep call.... "Mehhhhhh (め)!"

meaning.mnemonic: Think about it this way. There is a famous fishing lure inventor, working on his best work ever. He’s old, and he’s been trying to make the best fishing lure for the last 50 years, and knows this will be his last invention. Then he figures it out. He takes one barb, and connects the end of it to the top of another barb. When he does this, he knows his work is finally finished.

readings.mnemonic: How does the fish lure maker test his newly finished lure out? The one he just finished? He gets in a row (りょう) boat and rows out into the sea.

meaning.mnemonic: The fire radical and the fire kanji are the same as each other.

readings.mnemonic: Whenever we need to remember か, we use the word car.

meaning.mnemonic: The five radical and the five kanji are the same.

readings.mnemonic: Five is the number of buildings Godzilla (ご) will knock down. Oh, look! There he goes now.

meaning.mnemonic: Imagine contorting yourself in such a way that your legs end up inside your mouth. You have bent your body in all the wrong ways in order to achieve this. In fact, if you look at yourself, you look like a square now... You're just a person with four sides.

readings.mnemonic: This amazing feat, which turned you into a four sided square, has you looking like a four sided animal: the sheep (し). Look at yourself in the mirror and see an adorable four-sided sheep looking back at you. (You can't see the other sides because mirrors aren't 3D and whatnot. So you're a bit cartoonish.)

meaning.mnemonic: On the ground you put barbs at the bottom of a slide because you're a genius trying to catch another genius.

readings.mnemonic: You check your genius trap, and there's a genius stuck in the barbs! You know it's a genius because they're actually a cyborg (さい).

meaning.mnemonic: The hand radical and the hand kanji are identical in looks and meaning! That should make things easy!

readings.mnemonic: To remember the reading て we will use the word "Television." You have great hands. Go ahead and look at them. OH MY GOD. You have little televisions (て) on your hands. They are playing the dumbest show you can think of, too, both hands at the same time.

meaning.mnemonic: The radical heaven is the same as the kanji heaven, making this an easy kanji to memorize.

readings.mnemonic: Heaven... nowadays, people aren't all that good. Things have gotten bad. That's why the acceptance rate to get into heaven is only ten (てん) percent!

meaning.mnemonic: The king radical and the king kanji are the same!

readings.mnemonic: When you see the king you need to say, "Oh (おう) King! Oh King, oh no, oh why are you looking at me like that? Oh King... you aren't going to chop off my head are you? OH NO!"

meaning.mnemonic: Narwhals do construction with their left hands (or flippers, I guess). That's because all narwhals are left-handed!

readings.mnemonic: In their left hands, the narwhals all hold saws (さ). That's because the ice for their homes is already there, so they just need to saw away at them to make the shapes they want. Narwhal construction is actually very simple.

meaning.mnemonic: The radical Middle and the kanji Middle are both the same. So if you know one, you know the other.

readings.mnemonic: To remember the reading for this kanji, we use the word Chewbacca to pull up ちゅう in our memory.

meaning.mnemonic: The moon kanji is made up of the moon radical.

readings.mnemonic: Since げつ and がつ are quite similar, we'll use one mnemonic to cover both of them. I expect your experience learning Japanese throughout the future will help you to memorize and differentiate between the two. When the moon goes down and goes away, everyone in the world gets (げつ) up, because that means it's going to be daytime soon!

meaning.mnemonic: This is a strange kanji because it doesn't really mean anything at all. In fact, what it does is it repeats the kanji that comes before it. For example: 人々 is actually 人人. This kanji shows up whenever there's a repeating kanji, because it's often easier to write than writing a more complicated kanji twice. That's why this kanji is the repeater. It repeats what comes before it.

readings.mnemonic: In Japanese, this symbol is often called the のま because it looks like the katakana characters ノ and マ put together. If you know katakana then this will be easy to read. If you don't, think of it this way:

meaning.mnemonic: The rice paddy radical and the rice paddy kanji are the same, making this one super easy to remember, at least meaning-wise.

readings.mnemonic: To remember the reading た, we use the word "taco."

meaning.mnemonic: Narwhal mouths are on the right side of their head. In fact, some people didn't think they had mouths at all because they weren't looking from the right. Rookie mistake.

readings.mnemonic: How did we know to look from the right, though? Because of the youths (ゆう). Youths think in ways that older people usually don't. That's why they can see the swirls on cereal, hear the music behind noise, and of course, look at things from the right side.

meaning.mnemonic: Just imagine a beast with a lid for a head and fins for feet, running around looking as insane as possible (really imagine it!). When it runs up to you, it shows you the top of its lid-head. On it is written the numbers 666. Why? Because it's a spawn of the devil, and the number six is the devil's number.

readings.mnemonic: Whenever we need to remember the reading ろく we just use the word rock.

meaning.mnemonic: The small radical and the small kanji are exactly the same.

readings.mnemonic: This small kanji would be the perfect gift to give to the Shougun (しょう). The Shougun loves little things, and the little kanji represents all of that.

meaning.mnemonic: The radical stand and the kanji stand are the same thing, so now you know them both.

readings.mnemonic: Think of someone who has to stand up straight for you. These people are pros in hospitality. These are the doormen at the Ritz (りつ).

meaning.mnemonic: The kanji and the radical that look like this are exactly the same. They are both street.

readings.mnemonic: So you're walking down this street, and off in the distance you see the silhouette of somebody. A lady. Big, black curly hair and red eyes. It is the street-woman, Mrs. Chou (ちょう).

meaning.mnemonic: The sun radical and sun kanji are the same, huzzah! Also, if you want to remember day as well, you can just think about how a day is the time it takes for the sun to cross the sky.

readings.mnemonic: There are so many on'yomi for this kanji, but since this kanji is so important and common, you'll end up learning them all eventually whether you want to or not. For now, you're only going to have to learn one of the readings, and that one is にち.

meaning.mnemonic: The radical and the meaning of this kanji are almost the same! The radical is sword, but we're learning Japanese, so can you name a Japanese sword? That's right, the most common is a katana, which happens to be the meaning of this kanji as well.

readings.mnemonic: So now you have this sweet katana in your hands and you're swinging it around like an idiot. Feel free to make whooshing noises as you swing it around. To become a master katana wielder, you decide to travel to とうきょう (That's Tokyo!). とうきょう has the best sword and katana schools in the world, so it makes sense to travel to とうきょう.

meaning.mnemonic: This kanji looks like and means the same thing as the radical, which makes it particularly easy to remember.

readings.mnemonic: Remember the thousand crosses you got stuck under while learning the radical 千? You're still under it. Then, suddenly, someone pops his head over you and says "Hey, I'll save you... but only for a thousand cents (せん). Go ahead and try to calculate what that would come out to. It's not that expensive, actually.

meaning.mnemonic: This is another kanji that is the same as the radical. Both tree and tree are the same in looks and meaning.

readings.mnemonic: You’re walking through the trees, looking at them. They look ominous. Suddenly, you trip and fall. The trees start to mock you. Even the mocking birds mock you. It’s terrible. It’s painful. You’re being mocked as you pull yourself up off the ground.

meaning.mnemonic: The water radical and the water kanji are the same.

readings.mnemonic: Imagine a lake (i.e. a whole bunch of water). When you think of water, you should try to think of this beautiful lake. It’s sunny, the trees smell nice (imagine a tree smell if you can – the more senses you use the better!) and on that tree there is an awesome tire swing (すい). You get onto the tire swing and you are swinging back and forth. The water is right in front of you, and you are able to use the swing to throw yourself into the water. It’s a lot colder than you expected, and you come back to the surface, gasping for breath. The water gets into your mouth and you taste it. How strange, it’s very, very sweet. Imagine the sweetness of the water and how weird it is (really really sweet, this water is).

meaning.mnemonic: The radical white and the kanji white are the same.

readings.mnemonic: The white team was the first to be able to hack (はく) the white iPhone.

meaning.mnemonic: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for writing first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means writing as well.

readings.mnemonic: This kanji has more than one important reading you need to learn, sorry! But don't worry, here's a mnemonic to help you:

meaning.mnemonic: The combination of radicals for this kanji may not be obvious at first, but if you look carefully you'll see it. The lid is inside the head for this kanji because it's holding something in. Imagine the top of someone's head being closed by a lid. Open that lid up and peer inside... it's full of yen coins, the currency of Japan!

readings.mnemonic: What does the word yen sound like? It sounds like えん. Why? because back in the day, Japanese used to have a "ye" sound, but now it doesn't. Instead, it's an "e" sound, which is why yen = えん!

meaning.mnemonic: The arrow radical and the arrow kanji are the same. Sort of a "straight" shot to memorizing this kanji, you know?

readings.mnemonic: To remember the reading や we use the word “Yankees” (like the evil baseball team, go M’s!).

meaning.mnemonic: You lift the lid off a manhole and there's a towel with the name of a city on it.

readings.mnemonic: This city must have a lot of sheep (し) because there is a sheep monogram on the towel. It's the sheep city.

meaning.mnemonic: The radical and the kanji for cow are exactly the same! That makes it easy to remember, so long as you know your radicals well enough.

readings.mnemonic: Have you ever heard of わぎゅう beef? That ぎゅう is this ぎゅう.

meaning.mnemonic: If you have seven swords, there's only so much you can do with them. The main thing? Probably using them to cut something.

readings.mnemonic: Because having seven swords for yourself is too much, you decide to take the swords and divide them up amongst pairs of people. You cut them into pairs, and give sets (せつ) to everyone who needs them in the village.

meaning.mnemonic: The radical and the kanji for direction are the same! Huzzah!

readings.mnemonic: What direction do you always know? Which direction do you always want to go? Home (ほう). Something about your home always stays with you, no matter how far away you go. So if you're lost and you don't know which direction to go, just think of home!

meaning.mnemonic: The radical and the kanji for door are the same!

readings.mnemonic: You open the door and immediately get it closed back on your toe (と), literally causing your toe to explode.

meaning.mnemonic: You have a big guy here, with an extra drop of something below his thigh, hanging down. That's fat right there. He's so fat he has things of fat hanging off his fat.

readings.mnemonic: This poor fat guy has trouble with a lot of things. One of the things he has the most trouble with is tying a tie (たい).

meaning.mnemonic: The radical and the kanji for father are the same.

readings.mnemonic: Imagine your father is Cheech (ちち) from Cheech and Chong.

meaning.mnemonic: You have a small slide. The thing about small slides is that they can only fit a few people at a time.

readings.mnemonic: Why is there a little traffic jam on the slide? Because the Shougun (しょう) is using the slide and he loves little things. He's forcing everyone to stop and watch, even though there are people backed up behind him. How inconsiderate.

meaning.mnemonic: A narwhal sitting on a stool is your friend.

readings.mnemonic: "Hi friend," says the narwhal. "I must warn you about all the youths." (ゆう)

meaning.mnemonic: Fur and fur are the same as each other, so the meaning of this kanji should be simple. This can also mean hair, too, though more like furry hair.

readings.mnemonic: With fur, wisp your imagination to a land where there are stalks of fur all around, just like a big tall grassy field (except instead of grass, it’s fur). You’re surrounded by the black fur, the wind is blowing. Imagine yourself touching the long fur and smelling it. What does it feel / smell like? Now it’s time to get rid of it. There’s just too much hair! To get rid of it, you’ll need to mow (もう) it down with a lawn mower. Imagine yourself starting up the lawn mower, and taking it around, mowing down the hair. Hear the sound of the mower in your head (they’re loud and distinct). The important thing is to imagine yourself mowing everything. Key is to think “fur → In the fur → getting rid of the fur → mow the fur,” in that order. That’ll get you to mow, which will help you to remember the on’yomi.

meaning.mnemonic: A triceratops is laying out to dry. But it's so big, and it's laying on its side, so only half of it gets dry.

readings.mnemonic: "You're half wet and half dry! I will cut you in half with my laser blaster so you're proper again," a voice says. It is  Han Solo (はん), the anti-establishment guy who hates when things aren't even.

meaning.mnemonic: The radical heart and the kanji heart are the same. Rejoice and let your heart be free!

readings.mnemonic: The heart, where is it stored in your body? Most people thought it was in the chest, but in reality, your heart is stored in your shin (しん).

meaning.mnemonic: There's a person inside your head.

readings.mnemonic: You know this kanji means inside, so you can keep thinking about the person that’s inside you, running around. You finally discover him, and try to take him out, but before you can, he pulls out a knife (ない) and threatens to cut you if you do anything irrational.

meaning.mnemonic: The life radical and the life kanji are the same, so hopefully you now just know them both.

readings.mnemonic: You can save life or take it away with your new saber (せい). This is the saber you got from doing the correct thing (remember?), and now you need to figure out how to use it with this life. So what do you do?

meaning.mnemonic: You have a private mouth that's a machine. But you have to keep your machine mouth private because it would scare all the non-machine people around you.

readings.mnemonic: To make sure they can't tell what's machine and what's human, you dye (だい) the mouth to make it look like skin. You find dye the same shade as your normal mouth and just slap it on there.

meaning.mnemonic: The sun lets out one drop, and then another drop. The drops dance together in the air, combine, and when they hit the ground, up sprouts your mother!

readings.mnemonic: Suddenly your mother points at you and laughs, "Haha (はは)!" She keeps laughing, haha haha haha, over and over. You start to feel uncomfortable.

meaning.mnemonic: The slide is dry at noon. The sun is brightest at noon, so it dries the morning dew off the slide, making noon the perfect time to slide.

readings.mnemonic: Noon also happens to be the time Godzilla (ご) decided to attack for the same reasons: it's dry and kids are using the slide.

meaning.mnemonic: Balance a spoon on your pointed fingers and it will always point north. The spoon is like a compass needle and your fingers guide the knowledge your body already has and uses it to point north. That's science, friends!

readings.mnemonic: You realize that this ability to find north is probably really valuable, so you go to the nearest pawn shop and hock (ほく) it. Even your fingers.

meaning.mnemonic: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for now first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means now as well.

readings.mnemonic: Right now the condors (こん) are in danger! Not next week, not next year, right now! Haven't you heard that deforestation and pollution are killing all of the condors?!

meaning.mnemonic: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for old first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means old as well.

readings.mnemonic: Old things are misunderstood by the 子s (こ) of the world.

meaning.mnemonic: The origin radical and the origin kanji are the same!

readings.mnemonic: The origin of everything can be found in Genji (げん). Genji is the name of the main character in the world's first ever novel, "The Tale of Genji."

meaning.mnemonic: You're known to get the ailment evening toe, which is when your toe catches on fire after getting really, really hot (imagine this happening, ouch!). The only way to fix it is to cool your toe down, and the best way to do that is to go outside.

readings.mnemonic: You go outside (you’re not supposed to be out there at night!) and you’re accosted by a couple of guys. Then, all of a sudden, Guy (がい) Fawkes jumps from the roof above you and takes them out, then starts running. “Guy Fawkes!” you yell after him!

meaning.mnemonic: The fins that fell onto my sword were sliced into two parts.

readings.mnemonic: Now that you've cut the fish, it's time to cut something else into parts. Next on your list is the buns (ぶん) which need to be split up amongst the people. If you'd like to learn the second reading, just think about how fun (ふん) it will be to do this task.

meaning.mnemonic: You have fins in private. But, you want the world to see them, so you take them public.

readings.mnemonic: You head out into the public where everyone can see your fins, but... things have changed. All people are the same. There are thousands of こういちs walking around, and they all stare at you (though they pretend like they aren't).

meaning.mnemonic: If you have a bow and a stick you need to pull the two back together to shoot it. If you can't pull it, you won't be shooting anything.

readings.mnemonic: When you pull the bow back, your body strains and you feel an immense heat (ひ) rise inside of you. You keep pulling and the heat grows hotter and hotter.

meaning.mnemonic: The stop radical is the same as the stop kanji.

readings.mnemonic: You have to stop because there is a sheep (し) in front of you. You try to walk around the sheep, but it moves to stop in front of you again. Every time the sheep stops you stop too.

meaning.mnemonic: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for task first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means task as well.

readings.mnemonic: Today, your task is to eat yogurt (よう). It's nutritious, it's delicious, and I'm telling you to do it, so you have to. A task is basically just something you have to do, so that's what this is.

meaning.mnemonic: You cut the leaf with your sword into ten thousand pieces!

readings.mnemonic: Now that you have ten thousand pieces of tiny leaf paper, you decide to turn them into a manga (まん)! Each little leaf piece will become a panel.

meaning.mnemonic: The canopy you use in private is very wide.

readings.mnemonic: You like being wide because it makes you feel like a different person. But not just any person, like a super hero (ひろ)!

meaning.mnemonic: We have the winter radical and the two radical (though it's sort of slanted). What's two times the winter radical, if radicals are just a part of a kanji? Two times would be enough to create the entire kanji, which is also winter.

readings.mnemonic: Winter is the time of year you give out presents: "one fo' you, one fo'you. And... not you, this one's not fo' you so fu’ you! (ふゆ)!

meaning.mnemonic: The bamboo radical and the bamboo kanji are exactly the same!

readings.mnemonic: There's a little bamboo shrub sitting there, holding onto a lollipop. Because you're bigger than the bamboo shrub, you just take (たけ) it from the bamboo, causing it to cry.

meaning.mnemonic: The radical car and the kanji car are exactly the same.

readings.mnemonic: When we need to remember the reading しゃ, we use "shaman".

meaning.mnemonic: If someone has a big head you have to try to focus on the center of it when you talk to them.

readings.mnemonic: This is the center of the 王's (おう) head so you have to be extra careful not to look anywhere else.

meaning.mnemonic: The beggar is pointing his forehead up at you, his feet trapped in the ground. What diabolical scheme are you planning with this poor beggar you trapped? Turns out, you're planning to copy him to have your own version of him.

readings.mnemonic: To remember the reading しゃ, we use the word "shaman".

meaning.mnemonic: The leader samurai didn't become leader by sitting around not taking action. He got to where he is by doing.

readings.mnemonic: He was doing things with sheep (し). He is the leader of the sheep clan, and he was able to do more with sheep than anyone else. That's why he's the leader.

meaning.mnemonic: The ear radical and ear kanji are the same in looks as well as meaning.

readings.mnemonic: Put your hand to your ear and sing... "Mimimimimimiiiii!" (みみ) and listen to your tone with your ear.

meaning.mnemonic: When the sun is over the cross it's time to go to church... which is so darn early. And if you want to get to church early, you need to be fast, otherwise you'll be too late.

readings.mnemonic: To remember the そう reading we use the word "soul."

meaning.mnemonic: You're looking for a treasure, but no normal treasure... a treasure that's a stash of energy. Not gold, money, or anything like that. Imagine yourself finding it, and opening up a treasure chest. Out bursts a spirit ball of energy like you've never seen.

readings.mnemonic: As you reach inside the energy spirit, you feel something hard inside. It's a large key (き) that gives you access to another treasure.

meaning.mnemonic: If you want to dry your horns you need to lay them flat. If they aren't flat they'll always be a little damp somewhere and you'll never have a moment's peace.

readings.mnemonic: Being flat isn't enough, so you cover the whole thing in hay (へい). Hay absorbs water, so you add a flat layer of it.

meaning.mnemonic: A leader with a spoon is planting flowers so that one day this place may be full of beautiful flowers.

readings.mnemonic: The leader can't stop planting flowers though. He's going crazy. Maybe it's the pollen? He comes up to someone named Hannah (はな) and starts planting flowers in her face, probably killing her in the process.

meaning.mnemonic: The radical for foot and the kanji for foot are exactly the same.

readings.mnemonic: What do you wear on your foot? You wear a sock (そく).

meaning.mnemonic: Take your fingers to the street to hit some people! Street fingers are for curling into a fist. And that street fist wants to do some hitting!

readings.mnemonic: As you hit one chump after another, suddenly your dad (だ) comes marching out of your house. Uh oh. Dad caught you hitting, which, honestly, isn't a very nice thing to do, so he has every right to stop you.

meaning.mnemonic: There is a leaf growing out of the sun! You fly out into space to check it out and when you get closer you see that it isn't just one leaf, it's a hundred! That makes sense, you wouldn't be able to see just one leaf on the sun from where you were on earth.

readings.mnemonic: You fly closer, counting all one hundred leaves when you hear a strange sound. You take off your space helmet and hear, "GUH HYUCK (ひゃく)!" You know that laugh... it's Goofy! On top of the hundredth leaf is Goofy laughing and waving around. He must have built this leaf tower to get your attention.

meaning.mnemonic: You have water already... and it's pretty cold. All it takes is one cold drop of liquid nitrogen added to it to turn it into one big block of ice, just like that.

readings.mnemonic: When you think of ice, I want you to think of someone frozen with ice. Do you know anyone named Corey (こおり)? Anyone famous named Corey, perhaps Corey Feldman? Imagine this Corey person frozen solid with ice.

meaning.mnemonic: The insect radical and insect are the same in looks as well as and meaning.

readings.mnemonic: It's an insect! Get it! You squish it with your foot - what sound does it make? A mush (むし) sound.

meaning.mnemonic: The roof child stands upon the roof, holding up a single letter, a single character, a single symbol for the world to see.

readings.mnemonic: The character that is being shown is "J," which stands for Jesus (じ). The kid wants everyone to see this letter and symbol.

meaning.mnemonic: Rice paddy power comes from a man. One man, in fact. He's running on a big wheel next to the rice paddy and providing all of the power for the rice to grow and be harvested.

readings.mnemonic: A man can power an entire rice paddy until dawn (だん). Once dawn comes they need a little break, so they nap. But once dawn is over, they're back at it again!

meaning.mnemonic: The radical master and the kanji master have the same meanings!

readings.mnemonic: Do you remember back to the radical mnemonic, where the master is floating a water drop above his head? Imagine back to there. Once you do, the most amazing thing happens. The master sends the drop of water into a chute (しゅ) and it goes careening through an intricate series of them.

meaning.mnemonic: What is the evening mouth? Imagine a mouth that’s up in the night sky. It’s just there, talking, and only comes out at night. It only appears in one area of the world (what area would you choose? Imagine yourself going to that place to see the “night mouth.”), and appears only one month out of the year (more on this in a second). The “evening mouth” is the most famous thing in the _____ area (this is the area you choose). He’s so famous that everybody knows his name (“Evening Mouth.”).

readings.mnemonic: So, when does “Evening Mouth” appear? Turns out, “Evening Mouth” only comes out to talk in May (めい). You know this because it’s just starting to be spring, and when you look around (you’re watching “Evening Mouth” again) you see some spring flowers come up.

meaning.mnemonic: The radical not and the kanji not are the same thing! That makes it easy... Not!

readings.mnemonic: To remember ふ we'll use the word "fool."

meaning.mnemonic: There's a mouth in the ground (in our case, it's a hatch), and inside is some kind of prison you can't quite get to. If you've ever seen Lost, this will sound familiar... on the hatch, there's actually a series of numbers that you don't understand.

readings.mnemonic: "You want to know the number to the hatch?" yells an old voice from inside. You say "yes," and the voice gives you the numbers and you're in! You go down into the prison, where there is one prisoner: Grandpa Koichi (ごういち).

meaning.mnemonic: The leader of alligators... she's no ordinary leader, that's for sure. She's not a politician.. she's not a queen... She's one of the Other Ones, a group of strange, eccentric people who become leaders of animals.

readings.mnemonic: To remember the reading た, we use the word "Taco"

meaning.mnemonic: If someone tries to dig up private dirt on you, tell them no thanks, that stuff is in the past. Some things should stay in the past. Not everyone needs to know everything about your life and your past.

readings.mnemonic: To remember the reading きょ, we'll use "Little Kyoto." This will differentiate きょ from きょう, which is regular-sized Kyoto. Get it? You decide to bury all this private dirt from your past in Little Kyoto (きょ). That stuff is from when you were just a little 子 (こ) and you don't like to think about it.

meaning.mnemonic: The plate kanji and the plate radical are exactly the same, like two matching pieces of china.

readings.mnemonic: The person washing all the dishes was named Sarah (さら). She was named that because of her large head, which was shaped like Sarah Jessica Parker’s head (very big).

meaning.mnemonic: Slide some dirt on your legs so you can feel like you're from a previous time. Everything from the past is in the dirt. Dead people, dinosaur bones, your mom's secrets in a box from her past life. All these things come back to you as you slide the dirt all over your legs.

readings.mnemonic: As you sit there, pretending you're in a previous time you see a centaur (せん)! That's right! Centaurs are from wayyyy in the past.

meaning.mnemonic: The radical for red and the kanji for red are the same thing!

readings.mnemonic: Think of Fozzie Bear. He says "Wakka wakka wakka" a lot. Now, think of an evil, red (and I mean totally red) Fozzie Bear. He drops the "w" and just says "Aka Aka Aka," because he's totally evil.

meaning.mnemonic: The leader is next to the tree. What is he doing? He's leaning against it, resting.

readings.mnemonic: As he rests, he suddenly gets hungry and pulls a cucumber (きゅう) off the tree and bites into it. A good rest isn't complete without some crunchy tree cucumbers.

meaning.mnemonic: There’s a cross in your mouth, so the things you say are very pious. Everything you say you say humbly.

readings.mnemonic: When you think of saying humble things, think of the humblest man in the world. His name is Moe (もう).

meaning.mnemonic: The radical see and the kanji see are exactly the same!

readings.mnemonic: You see something. It's walking towards you, but you need to see better. When the person comes close, you realize "That person is me (み)!"

meaning.mnemonic: The shellfish radical and the shellfish kanji are the same! It can be just the shell part too.

readings.mnemonic: To get some shellfish, all you have to do is hop in your kayak (かい) and get some. Shellfish live in the water.

meaning.mnemonic: The stone radical and stone kanji are the same thing!

readings.mnemonic: You throw a stone through a window... and, now you can see something very sexy (せき).

meaning.mnemonic: The leader for the ceremony can't come so you need a substitute to replace them ASAP!

readings.mnemonic: The substitute leader is wearing the wrong color clothes, so you have to dye (だい) them, like they did in the olden ages.

meaning.mnemonic: Always remember to give umbrellas to the spirits to show your thanks. The next time you're walking by a shrine and you see a statue dedicated to a spirit, leave your umbrella open to protect it. This is the best way you can show your thanks for life, food, shelter, and all that good, good stuff.

readings.mnemonic: After you say thanks to a spirit, sometimes you'll get a gift back. You look down. There is a ray (れい) gun by your feet. Huh. Maybe you should show your thanks to the ray gun spirit more often.

meaning.mnemonic: The thread radical and thread are the same in looks as well as in meaning.

readings.mnemonic: You have some thread... what's the first thing you do with it? You take it and put it in your mouth, and start sucking it down like spaghetti. You have decided to eat (いと) the thread.

meaning.mnemonic: When you see both a rice paddy and a street in the same place, you have the makings of a whole town!

readings.mnemonic: You go to visit this nice little town. But then, there she is... Every time you walk down the street, the street-woman Mrs. Chou (ちょう) arrives to ruin your day.

meaning.mnemonic: Under his roof, the king stares into a drop of water containing his greatest treasure. Just kidding, the king has way more treasure than that. The drop of water is just reflecting what's around him: mounds and mounds of treasure, stacked all the way up to the roof.

readings.mnemonic: All of this treasure is kept in the king's home (ほう). He can't let other people see how much treasure he has, or they'll get mad, or worse(!) ask him to share some with his people. Yuck. The treasure stays at home.

meaning.mnemonic: Someone’s taking measurements of the trees… Why is someone taking measurements of trees? These people are planning to take the trees and cut them down to make their village.

readings.mnemonic: They take all the wood back to where they're building their village and once they construct the village center they paint a mural (むら) on the side of it. The mural is of the forest where they got the tree from so they remember the building's origins.

meaning.mnemonic: The world radical and the world kanji are the same, but there is another really important meaning you need to know: generation.

readings.mnemonic: It's your job to protect the world and every generation with your special saber (せい). It was given to you to uphold correctness, and you'll pass it on to the next generation when it's time. Then they'll watch out for the world when you're gone.

meaning.mnemonic: The cow part of this kanji is slightly altered, but I think you can see where it is. The gun looks just fine, though. Think back to a fake memory you have living on the farm. You have your gun, and you gotta use it on a cow (ruh roh). Once a year on New Year's, you have to go out and shoot one of the cows. It's only a yearly shooting, though, so at least there's that respite.

readings.mnemonic: It is New Years, though, so when you bring the dead cow back home, it’s time to celebrate. Using the cow’s organs and bones, you and your siblings construct a nendoroid (ねん). Nendoroids are Japanese toys - little plastic figurines (Google it if need be). You make a little cow nendoroid holding a gun. How cute.

meaning.mnemonic: Your task in prison is to bend things into different angles and then put them in the corner. No one will tell you why you're doing this, but you get a couple cents an hour to do it, so you aren't going to complain.

readings.mnemonic: To get the angle right you find that you have to cock (かく) your head to the side a lot. After cocking your head at weird angles so much you also start to hear cocks crowing in your head. Cock-co-cock-co-caww!

meaning.mnemonic: The axe radical and the axe kanji are exactly the same, with one minor difference. This kanji is also used as the bread loaf counter, probably because bread was so big and hard in the past that they had to use axes to slice them.

readings.mnemonic: You imagined being back in time too good and now you're stuck using an axe to be a bread loaf counter for the King (きん) of England. You aren't sure which king he is or when in time you are, but he's mean and keeps eating all the bread you cut up with your axe.

meaning.mnemonic: The blue radical and the blue kanji are exactly the same.

readings.mnemonic: You've been feeling really blue. Mostly because your skin, hair, and eyes have all turned blue. The Shougun (しょう) found out and now he's back. He places his hand on your shoulder and then points at your saber (せい). It's blue too! You aren't alone!

meaning.mnemonic: The leader has a book all about the human body. Knowing about bodies is a privilege. One that only leaders get—it helps them control all their subjects, like you.

readings.mnemonic: The leader's body book also taught her about something very body specific: how to tie a tie (たい). You can't have a tie on your body, no no. Those are for the leader and her smart body.

meaning.mnemonic: The color radical and color are the same in looks as well as in meaning.

readings.mnemonic: You already have color on the mind because you know the meaning of this kanji, so think of something colorful about yourself. Imagine your ear (いろ) being a weird color... green, purple, red, whatever. Just make it really bright and standing out.

meaning.mnemonic: There's rice spread out all over the ground. This will cause the Predator to come because he loves kome (rice). Then once he's gone, the next Predator will come to eat.

readings.mnemonic: When they come, though, everyone is disappointed. It turns out it's rye (らい) grains, and rye grains taste terrible. Yuck.

meaning.mnemonic: Plant a spirit in the dirt before you start your company and it will be successful. That's what all the great, old Japanese companies did back in the olden days. That's why companies like Mitsubishi have been around for hundreds of years. They planted a spirit in the dirt to help their company grow, and grow it did!

readings.mnemonic: Where did you learn about this method of company growing? From a shaman (しゃ), of course. Shamans aren't just spouting nonsense, they know what they're talking about. And spirits are right up their shaman alley.

meaning.mnemonic: There's a triceratops and a wolverine. What are they doing together? You'd think they'd fight, but they took their battle to another venue... they're competing in a game show! One of them answers a question, and the host says, "Success! You're correct!"

readings.mnemonic: When we need to remember the reading とう, we use the Japanese city Tokyo. The last question in the game show match is the following: "What is the capital of Japan." The triceratops and the wolverine scream the correct answer at the same time: とうきょう!

meaning.mnemonic: The treasures are in the mouth where there’s ice. How cryptic! You want to find the treasure, that’s for sure (treasure is great!). It is somewhere where there is ice, so maybe the arctic? What you are looking at is a diagram which will guide you there.

readings.mnemonic: What will you do when you find these treasures that are shown on the diagram? Well, you get there, and you find that the treasure is actually a wooly mammoth! What will you do with this wooly mammoth? You grab it and put it in your zoo (ず).

meaning.mnemonic: You see some windows... you have a gun. What do you think you're going to do with this gun? Of course, you're going to shoot the windows... every single one of them. Each and every one.

readings.mnemonic: Now that each and every window is broken you feel pretty stupid because a bunch of mice (まい) come pouring in through them. You've made a way for them to get into your house. That wasn't smart.

meaning.mnemonic: The feather radical and feather are the same in looks as well as in meaning.

readings.mnemonic: All these feathers. You're a bird man / woman, and you're getting ready to fly. Just as you're about to take off, someone dumps you with honey はね and you're all goopy, unable to go anywhere.

meaning.mnemonic: You have a tree and another tree. You basically have yourself a forest!

readings.mnemonic: So, now you have this forest and you want to cut it down (so much money!). But, you don't have any tools, only your hands. You think... I've done karate for a while, so I can probably chop it down that way. You get in a chopping stance, then do your battle cry and hit: "HAYA ... .SHI******!"

meaning.mnemonic: The go radical and the go kanji are exactly the same!

readings.mnemonic: "Go!" someone is telling you. "Go! Go! Go!" That person is こういち. He is holding his finger out, and pointing at your WaniKani reviews. "Go! Go!" Then, he over-enunciates the word "go" by saying "GYOU!!" (ぎょう).

meaning.mnemonic: The gold radical and the gold kanji are the same!

readings.mnemonic: The most gold in the land belongs to the King (きん) of England. In fact, you've never actually met someone with gold, it all goes straight to the King whenever someone finds some. You just have a few pennies to work with.

meaning.mnemonic: You plant your flowers in the light of the sun in the shape of a cross, but it's too hot—the sun is too strong—and you end up with grass. Flowers can't grow in these conditions.

readings.mnemonic: The grass on top is brown and burned from the sun, so you need to take a cool saw (くさ) and hack the tops off. The saw is actually physically cool to the touch, to help heal the grass' sunburned bits. It just happens to look cool too.

meaning.mnemonic: The village you always think of first is your hometown.

readings.mnemonic: You go back to your hometown in a saddle (さと). You can't take a car or a train there, it's really in the middle of nowhere. So you have to ride a horse, so break out that old saddle and go visit your parents.

meaning.mnemonic: The leader's key is the key that makes all the other keys. It's sort of like the one ring to rule them all, the one ring to bind them... except with keys.

readings.mnemonic: You make a key for an underling, and he looks at it disapprovingly (even though you're their leader!). He simply says, "this key sucks" (さく) and then walks off. How could this be?

meaning.mnemonic: How many evenings are there? There are many.

readings.mnemonic: To remember the reading た we use the word "Taco"

meaning.mnemonic: The meat radical and meat are the same in looks as well as in meaning.

readings.mnemonic: You know there's people-eating going on here, with this kanji. So, when you think of this meat, you'll have to think about whose meat it is. In this case, it's Nick's (にく) meat.

meaning.mnemonic: The meet radical and the meet kanji are the same!

readings.mnemonic: What better way to meet new people than to start kayaking (かい)! Get into your kayak and just float out into the water. You'll eventually bump into someone else in a kayak and boom, you're meeting someone new!

meaning.mnemonic: You put a lid on your father. But, he won't taste good alone, so you mix in some other ingredients. They mingle inside the pot with him.

readings.mnemonic: With a mix of your father and other ingredients mingling in your cooking pot, you lift up the lid... your father pops up. Your father is こういち. He stares back at you with a big smile.

meaning.mnemonic: Someone on a scooter has an axe, and they're getting near to you really fast! Oh no, they're so close now, you need to get out of here!

readings.mnemonic: As they draw near, you recognize who is riding the scooter: the King (きん) of England! Behind him, a bunch of his guards also on scooters and wielding axes appear and move close to you.

meaning.mnemonic: Who's someone who's just a mouth with legs? That's your know-it-all older brother, who won't shut up about anything.

readings.mnemonic: You wish you could box your loud-mouth older brother up and send him far away to きょうと. きょうと is super far away from where you currently live, so just ship your older bro off so he can never bother you again.

meaning.mnemonic: The radical for rain and the kanji for rain are the same thing.

readings.mnemonic: What if the rain actually tried to aim (あめ) for you? As in, drops would move out of their normal flight path just to hit you on your head? You'd be a lot wetter, that's for sure.

meaning.mnemonic: The rice radical and rice are the same in looks as well as in meaning. This also refers to "America," maybe because America is covered in rice or fields or something?

readings.mnemonic: You've got tons of dry grains of rice. You have no idea what you're going to do with it. Then, you come up with a solution. All this dry rice could go towards filling up the bay (べい), so you have more land to farm on!

meaning.mnemonic: The radical run and the kanji run are exactly the same!

readings.mnemonic: You run and run and run and suddenly you feel your soul (そう) leave your body. Still running, you turn around and see your soul running a few steps behind you.

meaning.mnemonic: There's a mustache on the ground. Upon closer inspection, you see that the mustache on the ground is exactly the same as yours!

readings.mnemonic: When we need to remember the reading どう, we use the word "doughnut".

meaning.mnemonic: The say radical and the say kanji are the same!

readings.mnemonic: If you aren't sure what to say, just think about Genji (げん) and ask yourself, "What would Genji say?"

meaning.mnemonic: The self radical and self are the same in looks as well as in meaning.

readings.mnemonic: When we need to remember じ we use the word "Jesus."

meaning.mnemonic: You're walking at night when you discover a lantern covered entirely in hair, making it a very strange shape. In fact, this is a form you'd never expect a lantern to take.

readings.mnemonic: You stare at the shape until you finally recognize it: cake (けい)! Well, it's hairy, glowing cake, but it's still shaped like a big slice of cake.

meaning.mnemonic: Slide down a branch and your skin will come off. Unlike what Tarzan will make you believe, you can't just slide around on branches, they're rough and painful and if you do it your skin will come sliding off and it will hurt.

readings.mnemonic: Without your skin to protect you, you feel the full heat (ひ) from the friction of your body going down the branch slide.

meaning.mnemonic: Giving a roof legs is the kind of construction you do. You make it so a roof can be in the sky. In addition to meaning "sky", this kanji often means empty. Think about it - there's nothing more empty than the sky!

readings.mnemonic: The reason you want to put a roof in the sky is because it gets the roof away from all the cooties (くう) that are on the ground.

meaning.mnemonic: For some reason, you are standing on the sun. It's obviously very hot, but the thing you notice most is the sound of you burning up.

readings.mnemonic: This sound isn't just loud, it's familiar. Finally you place it: onions (おん)!

meaning.mnemonic: You have a wild viking child you have to take care of. He won't do anything but study, surprisingly. You can't get him to eat, use the bathroom, or anything else. He just wants to study.

readings.mnemonic: This crazy viking child who prefers study over pillaging (and other viking activities)... the other vikings just stop and gawk (がく) at him when they walk by.

meaning.mnemonic: You see a triceratops in the distance. But, it's odd. It's perfectly pi shaped (that is, circular). Some kind of piceratops, if you will. The reason they are this shape is because they want to absorb as much sunlight (or just light is fine, too) as possible. They evolved to be round so they don't have any corners casting a shadow.

readings.mnemonic: As you watch this majestic beast absorbing sunlight, suddenly several dozen feral (こういち)s burst from various hiding spots, spears in hand. Oh no! Those こういちs are hunting this rare piceratops!

meaning.mnemonic: In a coffin is someone begging. But, it won't work. You won't listen. So, the man in the coffin just begins to think: What could I have done better in my life? Why am I in this situation? How will I get out? Think, damnit, think!!

readings.mnemonic: What is the beggar thinking of? A thought bubble pops up into existence near his head. In it is a picture of こういち! He's thinking that if こういち was here, he'd save him. Oh, if only こういち could save us all!

meaning.mnemonic: There's a mouth inside a mouth. But if you look even closer (not actually, but we're pretending), you can see another mouth inside that mouth... and another one inside of that one! It keeps going and going. Can you count the number of times there's a mouth inside a mouth? This kanji also means revolve too. Think of each "time" a thing happens, it loops back around and comes back to the beginning, revolving around again another time.

readings.mnemonic: If you're having a hard time wrapping your head around the infinite number of times these mouths revolve, just picture yourself in a little kayak (かい) going around and down through the mouths.

meaning.mnemonic: There's a hat decorated with fins and (presumably fish) mouths on it. Who wears strange hats like this? Turns out, the valley people are the ones who wear these. I'm talking about the "Valley Girls" of California, Hollywood / LA. They're into the crazy fashion, and they'll wear anything if it's deemed "cool" or something like that.

readings.mnemonic: Hanging around with all the Valley Girls in the sunny area of LA is also a robot. It's WALL-E's distant (and lazy, lounging) relative, TAN-E (たに). He sits around getting a tan in LA with the Valley Girls while his cousin picks up trash.

meaning.mnemonic: You have a samurai with a flag on a stick. On his flag is this symbol, the kanji for voice. Why does he have that there? He feels like his Shogun isn't giving him and his fellow Samurai a voice, so he's brought a flag with the word "voice" written on it to protest.

readings.mnemonic: Once you start asking the samurai more specific questions about how he wants more voice he starts playing coy (こえ) with you. He doesn't really know what he wants, he's just here for the sake of protesting.

meaning.mnemonic: The west radical and the west kanji are the same. Isn't that nice?

readings.mnemonic: People are attacking from the West, so you pull out your saber (せい) and beat them back. You keep pushing further and further West until you reach the ocean and there's nowhere left for them to run.

meaning.mnemonic: Our leader has a lip ring. Wait, our leader has a lip ring? WHAT??

readings.mnemonic: The leader with his lip ring is now eating some naan (なん) and curry. It's delicious, of course... but then he gets it caught on his lip ring, and tears half his lip off. He screams: "Nannnnn eeeeeeeeeehhh!!" (なに) in anger at the naan and curry.

meaning.mnemonic: The life radical is without the slide (as it sometimes is), but when you combine that with the winter radical, you have life during winter. What gives you life during the winter? It's the wheat you store away.

readings.mnemonic: You found your wheat. Thank God. You'll survive. You have to take the wheat back to your house, though. On your way, you get mugged (むぎ).

meaning.mnemonic: There is someone with a bow and a stick, wearing horns, going down a slide. What type of person do you imagine? I'd say someone who's an immature boy. That would be your younger brother.

readings.mnemonic: Your younger brother loves playing dress up so much that he's now started dyeing his hair all kinds of colors. Imagine the bright red, blue, green and purple dye in his hair.

meaning.mnemonic: Kings with hats. Did you know that all kings wear hats?

readings.mnemonic: But, as you're going through all the kings, it turns out not all of them have hats after all. The last one you come to does not have a hat. He is the king of Zen (ぜん) Buddhism. He has simple clothes and a shaved head, unlike all the other fancy kings standing around nearby.

meaning.mnemonic: If you loiter around to poop in winter you never know what could be happening behind you. After you're done you could turn back to see something really crazy that you missed because you took so long to poop in the cold.

readings.mnemonic: You finally look behind you and see Godzilla (ご) and a giant こういち having a violent battle back there!

meaning.mnemonic: The blood radical and blood are the same in looks as well as in meaning.

readings.mnemonic: To remember the reading けつ, we use the word "ketsup." The perfect mix of ketchup and catsup!

meaning.mnemonic: Under the ground, which you dug into, you found two great finds. You found both a mountain and a head, two strange things to find underground.

readings.mnemonic: But, you dig too deep and water flows into where you are. Your only hope is a row (りょう) boat floating off in the distance.

meaning.mnemonic: The sun AND the moon are out? With both their light-powers combined, it's incredibly bright outside.

readings.mnemonic: When do things start to get bright outside? I'd say when things start getting sunny, and that is the month of May (めい). If you live in the Southern Hemisphere, it's bright in May because of all the snow, or because that's when all the streetlights come on.

meaning.mnemonic: There is a lid covering all the mouths that are too small to feed themselves, forming the capital. All of the small mouths come together and create a place where everyone can support each other.

readings.mnemonic: To remember the reading きょう we use the Japanese city, Kyoto, which is spelled きょうと. It was once the capital of Japan! It was soooo full of mouths that came together that it was the capital for a long, long time.

meaning.mnemonic: A leader with a spoon is a powerful thing. Even something like a spoon when given to the right man or woman can make great change in the world.

readings.mnemonic: Then, this hero of yours takes their spoon and says some magic words into it, changing it into a car (か).

meaning.mnemonic: The mouth of the king extends all the way around him (like in this kanji). Where his mouth reaches, that is his country, give or take a few drops.

readings.mnemonic: Turns out the king of this country loves drinking Coke (こく). Every morning that big mouth of his swallows a whole 2-liter bottle of Coke for breakfast.

meaning.mnemonic: You scoop some grains into a ladle to do science. You're doing experiments on these grains in your science course.

readings.mnemonic: Using your science skills, the right temperatures and measurements, you manage to get these grains to grow into a car (か). This is the science department's special car now!

meaning.mnemonic: The radical death and the kanji death are the same.

readings.mnemonic: Your death will be because of a bowling (ぼう) accident. Oh, you didn't know? You're going to be hit by a giant bowling ball and crushed flat.

meaning.mnemonic: If the yakuza hands you a spoon, death is coming for you. It's the death spoon, a sign that the yakuza is coming to cause your death.

readings.mnemonic: Death comes in the form of a sheep (し). The death sheep works for the yakuza, and kills anyone who has their spoon.

meaning.mnemonic: There's a close-up of a leaf in a rice paddy inside of a box. Wait, it's not a box, this whole thing is just a drawing.

readings.mnemonic: The drawing seems to have something else in the rice paddy, behind the leaf. You realize the drawing is actually of a gargoyle (が) and a cock (かく). You see the cock sitting on top of the gargoyle, crowing into the sky.

meaning.mnemonic: A dirt alligator lives in the earth, not the water. They can swim through the earth itself! Which is pretty scary.

readings.mnemonic: The only way to keep this dirt alligator from dragging you under the earth and eating you is to feed it cheese (ち). That way it won't lead you to a horrific death under the earth by dragging you under and spinning you around until you eat dirt (literally).

meaning.mnemonic: Behind that tree the sun is rising in the east. The sun always rises in the east, so if you head that way, past the tree, you'll be going east too.

readings.mnemonic: You walk east for a few hours until you finally come to a city. It's とうきょう. Oh! とうきょう is in the east. I get it now!

meaning.mnemonic: The radical for eat and the kanji for eat are the same! Lucky you.

readings.mnemonic: Thank goodness, you finally get to eat your meal. You're so hungry. Someone has been starving you and now they've finally given you food. Unfortunately, though, every time you take a bite, you get a shock (しょく) from somewhere.

meaning.mnemonic: You accidentally stab your cross into the eye of a lion. This is a terrible thing you did and you need to fix it right now. I'll be direct with you, this is something you have to fix on your own.

readings.mnemonic: As you try to fix the lion's eye, it starts to choke (ちょく) and make what can only be described as a jikijikijiki sound (じき). Through its choking jikijiki sounds, it coughs up a gear. Wait. Is this a machine lion?

meaning.mnemonic: There are some horns on the ground and a moon knife in front of you. When you try to move, they always rotate around with you, staying right in front. You can't escape these objects, for some reason.

readings.mnemonic: You're going crazy with these things in front of you all the time. You finally seek the help of a Zen (ぜん) master, who tells you that meditation will save you from this curse. You try it out, and sure enough, the objects are gone! It worked!

meaning.mnemonic: A narwhal and a moon is all you have. Imagine one of each under your arms.

readings.mnemonic: Everything you have (except the narwhal and the moon) were taken from you by a roving gang of youths (ゆう).

meaning.mnemonic: Your private grains are meant to stay private! You shouldn't be sharing them with the whole town, they're just for you.

readings.mnemonic: You're getting into the zone, thinking about yourself (I) and how much you love having things that are private and just yours, when you realize there is a sheep (し) in this grain bag. And it's eating all of your (I's) private grains. No!

meaning.mnemonic: Just before saying something important, you take an arrow to the mouth which seals your lips together, making it so you can't talk. Someone doesn't want you to share what you know with someone else.

readings.mnemonic: To remember the reading ち we use the word "cheese."

meaning.mnemonic: A tsunami of tongues is coming at you. As it washes over you, you feel each individual tongue moving around on your body, licking you. They make you feel so... lively!

readings.mnemonic: This lively feeling isn't just happening to you, the tongue tsunami is licking it into all of the cats (かつ) in your neighborhood too!

meaning.mnemonic: The long radical and the long kanji are the same!

readings.mnemonic: You see a very long person. It's Mrs. Chou (ちょう), who has made herself long, like her street. "I made myself long so I can watch more of the street, my domain. I'm the leader of these streets. Watch yourself not-long person," says Mrs. Chou.

meaning.mnemonic: Twenty mouths are together. That's a lot of mouths. What do they do? They sing beautiful music together.

readings.mnemonic: The twenty mouths make so much music that they literally cloak you (きょく) with it. They cloak you with the music.

meaning.mnemonic: The radical neck and the kanji neck are exactly the same!

readings.mnemonic: The only thing you do with your neck is use it to swallow lots of cool beans (くび). Mm mm. Feel those cool, cool beans sliding down your neck. You don't really taste them, but you know they're there.

meaning.mnemonic: You lack ice. So you go to the store and see if they have any. Nope, no ice. So, now you go to the next store. Is there ice here? Nope. Next!

readings.mnemonic: To remember the reading じ, we used the word "Jesus" - Finally, when you're at the last store in existence, you decide it's time to pray to Jesus (じ), asking for a miracle. He comes down from the heavens with ice in his hands.

meaning.mnemonic: A leader is wearing a lid and is standing outside in winter. Plus it's raining and she's covered in drops of water. On top of all this, it's night.

readings.mnemonic: Question is, what is she protecting them from during the night? Turns out, it's the Yankees (や) baseball team. They're out for blood, and only the leader can protect us.

meaning.mnemonic: The only woman in this city is your older sister. She's the only woman surrounded by a bunch of men, but she's following her dreams in the big city.

readings.mnemonic: Your older sister may have moved to the city, but she kept her pet sheep (し) with her. Now the only woman in the city is your older sister, and the only sheep is her pet.

meaning.mnemonic: Your fortune boils down to a single point in time. One point in time determines how the rest of your future will go.

readings.mnemonic: As you stare at the point, you watch in awe as it moves to the ten (てん) spot in a long series of numbers.

meaning.mnemonic: With a roof over her head, a woman can relax. She doesn't have to worry about rain or snow or finding a safe place to sleep. The roof also happened to be super cheap, so she can even relax about her finances.

readings.mnemonic: As she relaxes, she pulls out the cheapest, most relaxing food in the world: anchovies (あん).

meaning.mnemonic: On the dirt you've made a roof over the ground where you can be in private. This is your room! That's really all a room is, you know? A covered, private place where you can have some time to yourself.

readings.mnemonic: The only problem with your room is that you can't always be alone. Because of your dad's shih tzu (しつ). The shih tzu likes to come into your room and pee everywhere. Ruining your privacy completely.

meaning.mnemonic: A tsunami is coming, so you point your gun out the window at it. "You better turn back, sea, or I'll shoot!"

readings.mnemonic: The sea decides it doesn't want to die today, so it turns its tsunami around and goes the other way. You hop in your kayak (かい) and chase after it with your gun, to make sure it actually returns to the sea and doesn't just drown someone else.

meaning.mnemonic: The sheep radical and the sheep kanji are the same in looks as well in meaning.

readings.mnemonic: To remember よう, we use the word "Yogurt." The sheep are after you. There are too many of them, and they're chasing you down, stalking you... because you stole their sheep's milk yogurt (よう). Now you're running and crying and trying to eat the yogurt before the sheep catch up and stomp you down with their hooves.

meaning.mnemonic: A long time ago, someone put up a canopy over their fortune telling booth and created the first shop. This store was fortune-based, but since then lots of different stores have popped up!

readings.mnemonic: This shop quickly turned into ten (てん) shops! It was a good idea, after all, so all of the other people selling goods and services decided to copy it and create their own shops. The next day there were ten more.

meaning.mnemonic: The cross you're holding above your head to keep your horns dry keeps pulling you south. Probably because it's warmer in the south of Japan, so it's easier to keep things dry.

readings.mnemonic: You finally make it down south, and it is dry, but you're really hungry. When you try to find southern food you realize every single store is only selling naan (なん).

meaning.mnemonic: The sun that gives life is our very own star (which we happen to call the sun). Of course, all the other stars are probably giving life to other planets as well.

readings.mnemonic: This star (the sun) and all of the others are yours to protect with your trusty saber (せい). If you could protect your land from the West, then you can certainly defend the stars too!

meaning.mnemonic: Think about Japan. Japan is a country made up of islands. They're basically three drop drop drops in the large river that is the Pacific Ocean. These are Japan's states or provinces.

readings.mnemonic: Each state has its own shoe (しゅう) to represent it. The bottom of each shoe is the shape of the state, so when you step it leaves a state-shaped imprint in the ground.

meaning.mnemonic: You come across an angel wearing a hat that's covered in flowers. So, you do the only natural thing. You take this angel, chop him up into tiny pieces, and dry him out. Then, you make tea out of all the dried up angel bits. You wear the hat, though.

readings.mnemonic: In your tea you find a little metal button. I guess you missed it while you turned the angel into tea. You look at the button - on the back it says "To Chad, you'll make an awesome angel." Looks like you're drinking Chad the Angel.

meaning.mnemonic: In a rice paddy you find a heart and it makes you think. You think a lot of thoughts like, "Whose heart is this? Why is it in a rice paddy? Why am I thinking out loud?"

readings.mnemonic: As you are thinking these thoughts, you spot someone on the edge of the rice field. He really reminds you of someone. But who? That's it! He reminds you of that bartender on The Simpsons. What's his name? You think some more. What is it? Oh! Moe (おも) is his name!

meaning.mnemonic: You stop at a small slide. What were you doing before you stopped here? You were walking.

readings.mnemonic: So, you're walking around, minding your own business, when suddenly something flips up and whacks you in the face. You stepped on the head of a hoe (ほ) and it caused it to swing up from the ground and hit you.

meaning.mnemonic: A drop hits your mustache. Where did it come from? "Ah, it came from yonder," you say, facing that way.

readings.mnemonic: Who shot this drop at you from yonder? You look over yonder, and see a figure. It is こういち.

meaning.mnemonic: Who's that woman pretending to be a jet? That's my younger sister. *Sigh*

readings.mnemonic: Your younger sister is giving some mice (まい) a ride on her back like a jet.

meaning.mnemonic: While riding your scooter, you take your sword and cut out an area on the ground. This whole place is your area now!

readings.mnemonic: As you look down at your area, you suddenly realize there is a hen (へん) pecking at the ground in there. "Um, excuse me, hen, I believe I said this is MY area?!" You try to kick it out, but it hops over your leg.

meaning.mnemonic: You have to take the measurement of a leader. Imagine yourself measuring that leader's height and then coming up short. This is not good, you think. Leaders need to be at least six feet tall. So, to make the leader tall enough, you attach another head to the top of the leader's head.

readings.mnemonic: You have to remember the kun'yomi reading of this kanji, and the part you need to remember is つ. So, think of attaching something to something else. What would you need? You'd need two (つ) things to put together!

meaning.mnemonic: The tree has an umbrella, and it's holding it over his head, which is strange, because trees normally like water... turns out, it's not water falling on him, but dollar bills floating down.

readings.mnemonic: The tree couldn’t take the body parts of his friends falling down on him, so he sat (さつ) down, and began crying uncontrollably.

meaning.mnemonic: The bird radical and the bird kanji are the same!

readings.mnemonic: Think of a run of the mill bird, whatever comes to mind for you first is fine. Then, your lovely bird swells. The shape of a face, then a hand, start stretching the bird apart until it explodes outward. Covered in blood and feathers is Mrs. Chou (ちょう).

meaning.mnemonic: The radical black and the kanji black are exactly the same.

readings.mnemonic: You're in a completely black room. There's no way out, and you can't see. The room starts to fill with liquid. It gets in your mouth. You taste it. It's Coke (こく)! Mm, tasty Coke.

meaning.mnemonic: Your boat has fins and a mouth! It's still a boat though.

readings.mnemonic: This boat belongs to the centaurs (せん). That's probably why you've never seen a boat like it before.

meaning.mnemonic: The slide coming out of the patient's heart is there because a mad scientist is testing to see if it's a good way to drain the body of blood. The patient is alive now... but they are definitely slated for certain death.

readings.mnemonic: As the beeping heart thing starts to do one long continuous beeeeeeeeeeeeeep, the doctor puts his hands together and hits (ひつ) the dead patient over and over, attempting to bring him back.

meaning.mnemonic: This kanji uses a modified jet radical. The front area of the wing is wider than the middle area of the wing. This may seem counterintuitive, but by doing this they can fit so much more jet fuel. The jet zooms off and keeps going for a long, long time, until it reaches the end of the earth.

readings.mnemonic: When you get to the end of the world, you land your jet and put out a few mats (まつ) to sit on so you can view the sights.

meaning.mnemonic: Your clan is where you get your name. But not your given name, your family name. That's why people have names that mean "in a rice paddy" and "near the ferry crossing." The location of your clan determined your surname! Hope your ancestors didn't live on "Poo Lake" or something.

readings.mnemonic: Don't worry, I'll tell you where your family name came from. Your family used to herd sheep (し). You read that right, your family was of the sheep clan because you took care of sheep all day.

meaning.mnemonic: That slide is your husband's only fault. He loves that slide, more than you, and it's the only thing you don't like about him.

readings.mnemonic: You try to come up with another fault of his so you can complain when you see a tiny shih tzu (しつ) trotting by. Oh no! Before you can call out, your husband has fallen off the slide and crushed the poor thing. You hear a sharp yelp and then nothing.

meaning.mnemonic: The radical fish and the kanji fish are exactly the same!

readings.mnemonic: You catch a fish. As you pull it out of the water, it starts yelling and pointing: "GO!" (ぎょ). "GO GYO GYO GYO!" There's a huge cruise ship coming right towards your little fishing boat. No wonder the fish was yelling GO at you.

alternatives: Since, Compared With, With, By Means Of
meaning.mnemonic: The lion drops a drop of saliva onto this person from above. The person is in a much worse place compared with where they were before, since they only just recently fell into this pit.

readings.mnemonic: From above there is a loud caw, and a giant eagle (い) swoops down, forcing the lion to back off. The eagle grabs the person with its talons, bringing him into the air! But now he's... in the air being carried by a giant eagle, compared with where he was before, is this really better?!

meaning.mnemonic: Sew thread through your top hat and to the top hats of other people you know and you'll turn into a group of top hat wearing people. You're all connected by the thread now, so everyone will assume you're a group, even if that's all you guys have going for yourselves.
