readings.mnemonic: Who is this climate and weather-changing candidate leader with the hook, stick, and arrow? It's none other than こういち.

meaning.mnemonic: The criminal that stole your car was your comrade! You thought the two of you were friends, but you were probably wrong.

readings.mnemonic: You feel really weird about this whole situation so you write your comrade a haiku (はい). It's really all you can do, since your car is long gone.

meaning.mnemonic: There’s a tsunami coming and your older brother is in no condition to escape. Your older brother has brittle bone syndrome so there’s no way he’ll be able to escape the tsunami in time in his condition.

readings.mnemonic: His condition gets worse and you have to travel all the way to his home in きょうと to get him out.

meaning.mnemonic: If you poop on the roots of a building, the sound will echo all the way through the building, and each and every person in there will know what you did.

readings.mnemonic: The echo doesn't stop there, this building's roots extend throughout the entire city of きょうと. The echo reverberates and soon everyone in きょうと is listening, horrified, to your poop.

meaning.mnemonic: If you mix different types of power you'll produce something effective.

readings.mnemonic: The most effective mix of two powers is two こういちs. Take one, mix it with another, and you have something with immeasurable power. You use it to attack that animal-like creature. It's super effective!

meaning.mnemonic: Touch your fingers to your friend to extract their friendship. Extract it with a high five. Extract it with a back rub. Extract it with an, "Oh no, there's some lint on your shirt, let me get that for you."

readings.mnemonic: Your friend looks you in the eye and says, I want you to extract my clothes. I want to be nude (ぬ). Now you have to use your fingers on your friend to extract their clothes to help them be nude.

meaning.mnemonic: The fish and sheep are very fresh here. This is a great place to get fresh fish and fresh sheep. I kid you not.

readings.mnemonic: This place also serves fresh centaur (せん), but that’s just weird. Centaur is endangered and you don’t believe in eating endangered things. Even if they are incredibly fresh.

meaning.mnemonic: If a tsunami hits these flowers they'll both become full of water. Tsunamis carry a lot of water, definitely enough to make both of these flowers full.

readings.mnemonic: As you stare at the full flowers, you decide to write a manga (まん) about them. Your head is full of manga ideas!

meaning.mnemonic: A beggar lies sprawled on the ground so you give him some money. You feel bad for the beggar on the ground, so that’s why you decided to give him something.

readings.mnemonic: When you set the money down next to the beggar he shouts, “No! I want a yo-yo (よ)!” so you go to the corner store and buy him a yo-yo with the money instead. You give the yo-yo to the beggar and he looks very happy.

meaning.mnemonic: The greenhouse radical and the greenhouse kanji are exactly the same!

readings.mnemonic: Your flowers have grown so big that now the only way you can fit into your endless greenhouse is by lying on your back (ばく).

meaning.mnemonic: Somebody got dirt on your fingers and dirt on your toes so you're going to hang them upside-down and slap them with your dirty extremities.

readings.mnemonic: You have this person hanging upside-down but they don't seem to be suffering enough, so you hit them with your car (か). No mercy.

meaning.mnemonic: Behind a building, a cleat-wearing wolverine is holding his heart and trying to hide.

readings.mnemonic: The wolverine looks up at the building he's trying to hide behind and sees it's an inn (いん).

meaning.mnemonic: A tree grows next to a greenhouse enclosing an imitation of the tree. The imitation greenhouse tree wants to be big and impressive like the tree outside, so it does its very best imitation of a real tree.

readings.mnemonic: The greenhouse tree realizes that its imitation will never be as good as the real thing. When it realizes this, the tree moans (も) aloud. The tree is still kinda tiny, so the moan isn’t very loud, but it is still pretty strange to witness. Speaking of witnesses, Bobo (ぼ) the clown sees this greenhouse tree moaning and decides to take it for his next clown show. Surely this miniature moaning tree can be worked into Bobo's next clown act.

meaning.mnemonic: Now your mouth can include more words than ever before! With our new and improved “Mouth Now!” program, your mouth will include more words than you ever thought possible!

readings.mnemonic: If you buy now, we’ll also include a handful of books by Gandhi (がん) himself. Gandhi didn’t use our program, but we’re sure if he’d had the opportunity to, he would have used it. So buy now, and get the words of Gandhi in your hands as well as your mouth!

meaning.mnemonic: Be careful what you say in public, otherwise you might face a lawsuit. People will sue you for just about anything these days, so you really need to watch what you say in public, otherwise you might find yourself with a lawsuit on your hands.

readings.mnemonic: Any and all lawsuits need to be brought before the Shougun (しょう). Oh, you thought you'd get a judge or a jury? Nope, the Shougun decides your fate.

meaning.mnemonic: A building's roots will limit the things under and around it.

readings.mnemonic: The person who hates these limits more than anyone else is Genji (げん). He wants to be able to tunnel under buildings, sneak in, smooch ladies, and sneak back out. But all the building root limits make that impossible!

meaning.mnemonic: A moon who stays in bed all day every day will soon become obese. A healthy moon needs movement and exercise to stay fit and not become obese. If a moon stays in bed all day, they’ll be sure to grow obese over time.

readings.mnemonic: Since the obese moon is in bed all day, and since the moon stays pretty cold, she needs some extra heat (ひ) to stay warm. A heated blanket should do the trick.

meaning.mnemonic: Music beans make farts plentiful. And lucky for you, music beans themselves are also plentiful, so you can eat plenty of them to power your musical bean toots.

readings.mnemonic: Your music bean farts are too plentiful to leave your home (ほう). If you tried to leave your home you'd definitely fart all over people outside, so you keep your plentiful farts to yourself.

meaning.mnemonic: A husband marries a husband while the sun goes down and the men replace their solitary lives with one of everlasting companionship. Instead of one husband and one wife, we have two husbands here. They shed their lives of bachelorhood and replace it with one of monogamy.

readings.mnemonic: After the ceremony, the husband and his husband get in a car (か) and drive off into the sunset. They’ll never be able to replace this memory with anything. Truly it is the happiest day of these husbands’ lives.

meaning.mnemonic: The sun rises over the capital building, creating a breathtaking scene. The sun is so bright and warm as it crests over the capital building. It’s quite the scene to behold.

readings.mnemonic: The only way to make this scene better would be to add cake (けい). Now that you think about it... as you look at the scene in front of you, the capital kind of looks like a big cake.

meaning.mnemonic: A gladiator only sees himself (oneself) on those big scrolls they advertise the fights with. Gladiators don't get mirrors and there are no cameras or videos yet. The scroll drawings are all they get of themselves.

readings.mnemonic: When you look at the scroll you realize... you look just like Genghis Khan (かん)! You excitedly fist pump and start showing everyone how cool you are.

meaning.mnemonic: You want to get your fingers on the humble stool, so you dedicate your life to search for it. Wait, the humble stool? You know, like the holy grail or the ark of the covenant, but it's called the humble stool. It's from some bible or something, I promise.

readings.mnemonic: You search and you search and, unfortunately, you spend your entire life searching and you die without finding the humble stool. But don't worry, your soul (そう) comes back and now you get to continue your search but with afterlife powers!

meaning.mnemonic: A lifeguard will choose a tree to set up the station where he'll care for the people on the beach and in the water. Trees provide the shade lifeguards need to take care of half-drowned kids and grannies with sand stuck in their bathing suits. That's why they set up their care stations here.

readings.mnemonic: You look closer at the set up and realize the lifeguard is こういち! You know he teaches Japanese but... is こういち really qualified to care for people like this?

meaning.mnemonic: The sun rises over the capital, shines down on your hair, and casts a long shadow on the ground in front of you.

readings.mnemonic: In the shade from your shadow you see a small acorn (えい) laying on the ground. You're about to reach down and pick it up when you realize that your shadow is keeping this little acorn from growing up big and strong.

meaning.mnemonic: A thread is mixed all around and begins to strangle you.

readings.mnemonic: As you are strangled you see who set this trap. (What else could it be, with all this thread everywhere?) It is こういち, who just watches you as you lose consciousness, tapping his fingers together.

meaning.mnemonic: You say you have an axe with a drop of blood on it. You hit someone with that axe and now they're going to sue you. That drop of blood on your axe is pretty incriminating, which is why they have enough of a case to sue you.

readings.mnemonic: You want to sue them back so you clean the axe with some soap (そ). "Your honor," you say in court, "I don't see any drops of blood, I countersue!"

meaning.mnemonic: There is a spirit at your wedding. It's there as a supplement to the guests because not enough people came.

readings.mnemonic: Along with the spirits to supplement your wedding guests, you made everyone carry a hoe (ほ). That way no one had to bring a date, they carry a garden hoe as a supplement and no one feels bad about being dateless. Everyone is!

meaning.mnemonic: A tsunami carries your yurt and you on a stool under it away. You are now in transit.

readings.mnemonic: The transit of yourself and your yurt home is due to the water (わた). This is water transit.

meaning.mnemonic: You stand with another woman and, with your fingers, adjoin yourselves together. You are united, you are one.

readings.mnemonic: All of the women who are now adjoining together are in sets (せつ). Sets of two, of course. One woman with another woman, standing in unison.

meaning.mnemonic: A leaf has to do the same task again and again. Grow out of a tree, change color, fall to the ground, get absorbed back into the tree, then start all over again.

readings.mnemonic: Once again the leaf picks up a saw (さ) and cuts itself off of the tree at the end of fall, like some kind of invincible cyborg (さい).

meaning.mnemonic: There once was an animal with an insect friend who felt very alone unless he was around. An animal and an insect are an unlikely pairing, but these two get along delightfully and hate to be alone without the other.

readings.mnemonic: One activity that the animal can never do alone is solve Sudoku (どく) puzzles. The insect always has to help him out with them, and together they are an unstoppable Sudoku solving team.

meaning.mnemonic: On the grass near a rice paddy sits a creeper that is some sort of a dog beast, a vicious animal. This creeper isn’t just a normal dog, it is more beast-like, more like a feral animal than domesticated pet.

readings.mnemonic: The beast is guarding its precious jewels (じゅう), which it buried in the grass or the rice paddy somewhere. If you don't want the beast to think you're coming to steal those jewels, you better keep your distance.

meaning.mnemonic: You take some flowers and some fruit and you make a cake out of it. It’s a very nice looking, flavorful cake. The fruit makes it taste great and the flowers make for great cake decorations.

readings.mnemonic: You’re standing back, admiring your cake when you hear a car (か) engine revving and before you know it your cake has been run over. The car came out of nowhere and ran your cake right over, spraying fruit cake bits and flowers all over the place. Stupid car!

meaning.mnemonic: They say using a measurement device (like a ruler) is a good way to chastise someone. They do something bad? Chastise them by slapping their wrists, their feet, their eyes, ears, anything! They say something out of turn? CHASTISE THEM!

readings.mnemonic: You're being chastised because you tried to say something in English in とうきょう. Everyone around you slowly turned around, eyes aflame and rulers in hand, ready to chastise you for uttering those forbidden words.

meaning.mnemonic: The old winter is to blame for today's circumstance. It is the reason things are bad now.

readings.mnemonic: In reality, this circumstance was actually caused by a single 子 (こ), though. This kid went through town, destroying everything in their path.

meaning.mnemonic: Your new car doesn’t mix well with the other cars in your garage because its color is in stark contrast to the others. All of your other cars are pristine white in color, but this new car is a mix of lots of colors. It almost looks like a peacock or something it’s so colorful. Such a contrast.

readings.mnemonic: What did I say this car looks like? Oh that’s right, a peacock (かく). This car looks like a peacock. It’s the color of a peacock and you’ll look like you’re peacocking when you’re out on the town driving it. It really is such a stark contrast to like, every other car out there.

meaning.mnemonic: "A scooter!" you announce. You are announcing this because you decided this is what you would create.

readings.mnemonic: But, a scooter has been created before. What is different about yours? The scooter you will create is specifically designed to keep zombies (ぞう) busy.

meaning.mnemonic: In your warehouse you use your knife to create. You keep old pieces of wood in your warehouse, and you use your knife to carve them into new things that only you could create.

readings.mnemonic: When you create it's good for your soul (そう). It's so freeing, in fact, that when you get really into your creating, sometimes you'd swear your soul was floating a little bit outside of your body. But every time you notice, it sinks back down. Hmm.

meaning.mnemonic: You loiter around your master until he departs. You have a lot more freedom to do things after your master has departed, so until that time you just loiter about looking busy and staying out of his way.

readings.mnemonic: Finally, it's time for your master to depart and he calls to you and says, "You are the 王 (おう) of the house now. Take care of everything while I'm gone."

meaning.mnemonic: The "Cliff of Ten Thousand Power" is where you go if you want to be encouraged.

readings.mnemonic: When you get there, it does encourage you. The cliff says "Hey, I encourage you to buy a ray (れい) gun."

meaning.mnemonic: A tsunami that is white, traveling in the direction of winter is a fierce and violent force of nature. This white tsunami is chasing after winter, and that’s why the tsunami is white—it’s a winter tsunami. It’s the most fierce and most violent kind of tsunami in existence.

readings.mnemonic: The tsunami is too fierce, too violent, and before you realize what's happening, Gecki (げき), your beloved gecko, is lifted up and carried off into the air.

meaning.mnemonic: The fortune radical and the fortune kanji are exactly the same! But it also means occupy as well, so don’t forget that. Fortune and occupy both occupy the same radical.

readings.mnemonic: To occupy some free time you have, you go and get your fortune told at a fortune teller. Your fortune is that you’ll have an encounter with a centaur (せん) in the near future. Just then you realize that the fortune teller is actually a centaur! The fortune has come true!

meaning.mnemonic: There's a building standing in the way of the next chapter in your life, and it's hindering you. It's not like you couldn't find another way around, but it's definitely inconvenient.

readings.mnemonic: Someone put this building here specifically to hinder you. They knew you were close to the next chapter of your life, and they wanted to hinder you really good. And there they are, sitting on a throne smirking. It's the Shougun (しょう).

meaning.mnemonic: Your ego... it's totally out of control. I mean, my ego isn't out of control. I'm the greatest. That's me. But your ego? Ugh, so out of control unlike my amazing ego.

readings.mnemonic: I am the greatest in the world! I am no baby like you, that's why. A baby who says "ga (が) ga ga ga!"

meaning.mnemonic: A loitering mountain king in the winter is an indication or sign of something to come.

readings.mnemonic: When you spot a loitering mountain king in the winter, you know it's an indication that soon Mrs. Chou (ちょう) will appear. It's like a Groundhog's Day kind of situation, but instead it means Mrs. Chou is about to come out, perhaps early for the season.

meaning.mnemonic: There are fingers reaching towards you asking you to accept to instruct them. They're the fingers of students. And you're the teacher. See them reach out for knowledge. They want to accept this knowledge into their hearts and brains. Instruct them!

readings.mnemonic: "Yes! I will instruct you, my dear students!" you cry, "I will instruct you on how to open a small juice (じゅ) box!" That's right. These little kids need help learning how to open small juice boxes (small because kids are small).

meaning.mnemonic: You hold gold fins in your mouth while shopping for pencil lead at the store. This pencil lead store only accepts gold fins as payment, but your fins don’t fit in your pockets and you need your hands to carry the lead so the gold fins go in your mouth.

readings.mnemonic: You pay for your lead but the cashier puts it in your mouth where the gold fins were and... everything ends (えん).

meaning.mnemonic: A broken car sits in a building. You need to get rid of it, so you put it in the mail. Or, depending on where you live, maybe you put it in the post.

readings.mnemonic: Who did you address this broken car mail (or post) to? You sent it to the youths (ゆう) of the world.

meaning.mnemonic: In a gold cross, you see a needle sticking out of it. The needle is right in the middle of the gold cross. If Jesus were on there, the needle would be sticking him right in the chest.

readings.mnemonic: You're about to give up on the needle when it pops out and flies directly into your shin (しん). Ouch! Now you're desperately trying to pull the needle out of your shin, but it really won't budge this time. Maybe you should have minded your own business.

meaning.mnemonic: If you see someone loitering around with horns on their head you'd be correct to obey and accompany them.

readings.mnemonic: If you obey the horned man you'll end up with a ton of jewels (じゅう)!

meaning.mnemonic: On the moon, it’s easy to turn a pig into pork. The low gravity of the moon makes the whole process much easier and cost efficient. Soon, all the pig farming will be done on the moon and there will never be a pork shortage ever again.

readings.mnemonic: At this particular pig restaurant, they have a secret ingredient that goes onto their pork. Lots and lots of butter (ぶた). Okay, so it’s not that big of a secret. But boy is it delicious. Mmm, butter.

meaning.mnemonic: You loiter around a black hole, waiting for it to finish destroying and switch to restore mode. You were told all black holes finish eventually, and when they do you can press a button to restore everything back to the way it was.

readings.mnemonic: Finally there's nothing else for the black hole to eat so you hit the restore button.... but nothing happens. "Oh f**k (ふく) you!" you scream as you realize you were lied to.

meaning.mnemonic: During a tsunami, your lip ring is ripped off while you’re trying to cross a river. There was no other path to safety, you had to cross the raging river, but you lost your footing and smashed your face on a rock and lost your lip ring.

readings.mnemonic: But why were you trying to cross this river anyway? Well your car (か) was on the other side of it, and you figured if you could get to your car you could outrun the tsunami and be safe. Too bad you fell and ripped out your lip ring though.

meaning.mnemonic: You keep all of your shellfish under a roof down the street and it's your savings. Shellfish used to be used as money way back, and these aren't shellfish you're spending, they're ones you're saving up for later.

readings.mnemonic: When you want to withdraw from your savings you force yourself to use chopsticks (ちょ) to pick up the shellfish. They're especially slippery, hard to use chopsticks too, that way it's really hard to take too much out of your savings.

meaning.mnemonic: You take this comb, break the handle off, and use it to stamp your official seal of approval onto a document. It's kind of a messy marking process, but it gets the job done.

readings.mnemonic: You need this seal to stay at an inn (いん). All inns require official paperwork, so you had to improvise and make a seal on the fly.

meaning.mnemonic: You're trying to use your fingers to cause a landslide so you have to shake the earth. You probably won't succeed, but the best you can do is to shake your hands on the dirt as hard as you can. It looks like you're trying to wave at the ground now.

readings.mnemonic: You think you finally got the earth to shake but when you look down it's just your shins (しん). Darn you shins, I thought I made some progress. Hey wait... why won't you stop?!

meaning.mnemonic: In a hole, you see a big guy who looks like he wants to stab you. You don’t want him to stab you, so you make sure not to fall into the big hole that houses the big guy that wants to stab you big time.

readings.mnemonic: You fall in the big hole. What did I just tell you not to do!? He’s totes (とつ) going to stab you for sure. Totes.

meaning.mnemonic: There is a head pinned to a tree by a knife. This person has been stabbed! They were stabbed so hard that they were pinned to the tree here.

readings.mnemonic: You want to know who did the stabbing, so you look around to see if the stabber is still in the area. But all you see is a sheep (し). Sheep can't stab people, right? They have hooves and probably can't pick up knives... right?

meaning.mnemonic: You see a soul floating around a tombstone acting suspicious. To be fair, if a soul is going to be anywhere, a tombstone is probably high up on the list, but this one seems like it's doing something weird.

readings.mnemonic: You sneak around the tombstone to see what this suspicious soul is doing, and you realize it's pretending to kayak (かい). The soul is sitting behind the tombstone, in a small kayak, moving its arms like it's rowing through water.

meaning.mnemonic: The tsunami going down your dry face is just sweat.

readings.mnemonic: The sweat isn't just on your face, it's also dripping down your ass (あせ).

meaning.mnemonic: Out of bamboo, you make a brush – a writing brush. This is no ordinary brush, mind you. It is a brush specifically designed for writing elegant characters. And it’s made from bamboo!

readings.mnemonic: Once the writing brush hits (ひつ) that paper, it’s like you transform into a totally different person. All of a sudden you’re a master calligrapher, writing anything and everything in a most beautiful fashion. Once that brush hits the paper, it’s on!

meaning.mnemonic: A woman sitting on a stool with a broken heart is very angry. She had her heart broken by some jerk and now she’s sitting on the stool, just stewing over the guy and how angry she is with him.

readings.mnemonic: The guy who broke your heart and made you so angry was such a dog (ど). He cheated on you multiple times, with your mother and your sister! What a dog!

meaning.mnemonic: You want to go to the sun so you set up a slide twenty stories tall so you can ascend into the heavens.

readings.mnemonic: You need to ascend into the sky and toward the sun because the Shougun (しょう) said so. He's testing out some space travel technology (the twenty story slide) and you're his guinea pig.

meaning.mnemonic: If you're riding your scooter through some rice, it's likely you've gone astray. Also you might be lost.

readings.mnemonic: You got so lost and went so astray you ended up on the Mayflower  (めい), a ship that eventually took you across the Atlantic Ocean. Now you've really, really gone astray.

meaning.mnemonic: Someone is reaching out with their fingers to call for you. They beckon you closer, this way.

readings.mnemonic: The person beckoning you is the Shougun (しょう). You can't help but obey the Shougun's beckoning call.

meaning.mnemonic: Inside this moon is a black hole... haha just kidding, it's your belly! It's beautiful and round like the moon and it eats up everything you give it like a black hole. What a good stomach you have!

readings.mnemonic: If you don't treat your belly with respect, when you look down at it, it'll yell, "F**k (ふく) you!" Be nice to your stomach!

meaning.mnemonic: Your eyes start to close as you drive your car because you’re getting drowsy. This is a very dangerous way to drive your car, especially since your car is missing its top and its bottom. This is no time to be getting drowsy. Keep your eyes open and drive for your life!

readings.mnemonic: The reason you’re so drowsy, and also the reason your car is missing part of its bottom, is because you took one of the car’s tires and made a tire swing (すい) out of it. You’d been swinging on the tire swing all day and now you’re super drowsy and worn out.

meaning.mnemonic: You see a canopy under which Wolverine is sipping some water. He looks so at ease and at peace.

readings.mnemonic: Suddenly you realize that it's not just Wolverine, but also こういち. hanging out under the canopy.

meaning.mnemonic: Setting up a stand on the top of a mountain, you rake all the rocks to the edge of it. You want to clear the area around your stand, so you get your rake out and you rake all the stones and debris away from the stand and toward the edge of the mountain top. It also creates a small barrier around the edge as well.

readings.mnemonic: You set up this stand at the top of the mountain so you could give a speech to the world. But you need to look your best, so you decide to get a tan (たん). You lay next to the edge of the mountain, and prepare to tan. Everyone likes a person with a healthy tan.

meaning.mnemonic: A tree with a mouth eats a beggar and his stool, which were on the ground next to him, which seems to be a bit extreme, don't you think?

readings.mnemonic: Unfortunately we still haven’t come up with a good reading for きょく, but just try and remember this reading as Goku (ごく) from Dragon Ball Z and his strange step brother Kyoku (きょく). Goku and Kyoku are the beggars in this story, the ones performing all the extremes. First Goku gets eaten by the tree with the mouth, and then Kyoku gets eaten as well.

meaning.mnemonic: Inside the "Good Building" there's a single guy.

readings.mnemonic: You talk to that guy. The only thing he does is offer you roe (ろう).

meaning.mnemonic: The leader of your yoga class uses a special brush to stay healthy. She rubs the brush on her long arms and legs, and she never ever gets sick.

readings.mnemonic: Not everyone wants to be healthy, but Ken (けん) the samurai sure does. He needs to be ready at a moment's notice so he can do tasks for other people. He's at every class, rubbing himself down with the brush.

meaning.mnemonic: You say to some grain and some stairs: I want to invite you to my place.

readings.mnemonic: You invited them to your home because your roommate was having a party and inviting a lot of youths (ゆう) over. You wanted to look cool, so you invited some grain and some stairs, the two coolest things you could think of.

meaning.mnemonic: You substitute some shellfish for collateral so your friend will lend you some money. Normally he would ask for something more valuable, but you’ve convinced him to substitute these shellfish for what he would normally take as collateral when lending to people.

readings.mnemonic: You want your friend to lend you some money so you can buy yourself a car (か). You need money and a car a lot more than you need this pile of shellfish, so you’re happy to put them up as collateral for the loan.

meaning.mnemonic: A drunkard who has his mouth on the ground, has a heart that is misguided. First of all, he tries to drink his problems away, but worse, he's so drunk he's trying to drink out of the ground.

readings.mnemonic: Nowadays we don't say misguided, we say wack (わく). Like, damn that drunkard is so messed up, he's wack.

meaning.mnemonic: When your sick mama tries to do a task she's filled with pain!

readings.mnemonic: Your mama's pain is too (つう) much for her to handle, so now you have to do all of her tasks too.

meaning.mnemonic: If you're on your scooter and you run over a root, you'll need to retreat. The roots have obviously rejected you, they want you to leave, so you should.

readings.mnemonic: You're trying to retreat by scooting backwards, but the roots grab onto your tie (たい). You try to pull your tie off but it's just getting tighter and tighter around your neck.

meaning.mnemonic: When you ride a scooter you'll have a surplus of possible routes. Not only can you drive on any road, but you can ride on the sidewalk too!

readings.mnemonic: You decide to take the fastest route, since you have so many options, and drive on the sidewalk. However, in doing so you run over every single toe (と) on every single person trying to walk there.

meaning.mnemonic: Your threads have to suit you if you want a good salary. No one is going to give you a salary if your clothes don't suit you. You have to look professional!

readings.mnemonic: Your salary is paid in cucumbers (きゅう). Maybe you shouldn't have worn that cucumber tie when you interviewed for this job, even though it suited you well.

meaning.mnemonic: In the capital, a broken dog begins to settle in. This dog used to live in the country, but he kept getting caught in bear and fox traps which busted the poor dog up. The dog didn’t want to live like this, so he decided to settle in the capital city where there aren’t pesky animal traps to get caught in.

readings.mnemonic: In order to help the dog settle in, the capital cobbler makes him a pair of shoes (しゅう). The shoes help him walk on his hurt legs, but more importantly, they help him relax and feel like a dog again.

meaning.mnemonic: Take your leather and change it into shoes.

readings.mnemonic: Some shoes aren’t made from leather anymore these days, but you know who always wears shoes made of leather? Old coots (くつ). Old coots are so old that the only shoes they wore growing up were made from leather so they refuse to wear any shoes that aren’t made from leather. Crazy old coots.

meaning.mnemonic: Closing each eye is something that the peoples do before they sleep. The peoples can’t sleep with both eyes open and they can’t sleep with just one eye open either. Peoples have to close each eye before they can sleep.

readings.mnemonic: The reason you want to sleep is because all the other peoples were mean (みん) to you. They were so mean that the only way you could get over it was to close your eyes and sleep. You just want to sleep.

meaning.mnemonic: In the sun while holding a comb in a cage and sitting on a stool, you comb your hair in your spare time. Since you’re in a cage, you actually fashioned this comb yourself, so it’s a little messed up, missing a prong. You’re working on improving it in your spare time, and you also use it to style your mop.

readings.mnemonic: So how did you get in this cage? Well, before you used to comb your hair in your spare time, you used to steal cars (か). You’d stolen many a car in your day, but you finally got caught in the act of stealing a car, and now you’re spending all of your spare time in that cage, just combing your hair.

meaning.mnemonic: Cut this comb up with your weapon and turn it into the steps for some stairs.

readings.mnemonic: You slowly work to create these stairs, you have to slice up a lot of combs, and at dawn (だん) they are done!

meaning.mnemonic: If you eat a rice paddy the size of the moon, your stomach is going to hurt. All the rice in a rice paddy the size of the moon is way too much rice for anyone to consume. If you do, your stomach is going to ache like crazy.

readings.mnemonic: From the sky, an eagle swoops down and flies right into your distended stomach. Bam! The eagle (い) hits your stomach and you vomit up the entire moon sized rice paddy.

meaning.mnemonic: When someone is sick in order to diagnose the correct cause and treatment, you need to check their symptoms. You have to be especially careful too, because if you get a symptom wrong, you could kill them!

readings.mnemonic: You need to figure out the symptoms the Shougun (しょう) is having. This is really serious too, so you better be correct about which sickness he has. If something bad happens to the Shougun it will be off with your head.

meaning.mnemonic: If a tsunami hits while you're farming, you'll have to wear really thick clothes to deal with it. The water is thick with fish and cars and other ripped-up debris too, which makes it even harder.

readings.mnemonic: You knew to put on your thick tsunami-proof farming gear because Nostradamus (のう) warned you it was coming. He sent a message to your brain yesterday so you'd know what to wear today.

meaning.mnemonic: You have a special thread in your towel you can use to make it stand up by tightening it.

readings.mnemonic: You tighten your towel before you eat tater (てい) tots every night. That way it stands up nice and straight next to your eating chair, ready for all that delicious tater tot grease that gets on your fingers.

meaning.mnemonic: The scooter is white. This color will urge and compel you to use it. Scooter companies use colors to get you to do what they want. Some would say they are trying to coerce you, even.

readings.mnemonic: When they urge, compel and coerce you like this, they are hacking (はく) your brain.

meaning.mnemonic: Someone just asked you to say which direction they should visit.

readings.mnemonic: You end up saying, "You should visit my home (ほう)." How kind of you!

meaning.mnemonic: Taking a thread and moving to the sound of the music, a drunkard makes a weave through some fabric. He’s using the thread to weave his clothes back together after he damaged them in a fall down the stairs. You know, because he’s a drunkard.

readings.mnemonic: This drunkard is actually a Sheikh (しき) (an Arabic leader), but he’s just fallen on hard times and has been hitting the bottle pretty hard lately. The piece of clothing he is using the thread to weave back together is one of his fancy formal robes.

meaning.mnemonic: If your soul is lying in the grass in a treasure chest, you're going to worry about it. It's just sitting there, out in the open, waiting for anyone to come and open it.

readings.mnemonic: Unfortunately, you also worry about opening it yourself. You stand in front of the chest and think, "Should I open it? Nah, yah (なや). Wait. Nah. Yah. Dang, you can't make up your mind.

meaning.mnemonic: You see a flag by the exit letting you know to yield. There’s cross traffic just outside the exit, and the flag lets you know that you need to yield to them.

readings.mnemonic: Even though the flag told you to yield, you’re starting to lose your patience. The people walking outside the exit are all a bunch of crazy old coots (くつ)! These crazy coots keep walking right in front of the door, getting in the way. The old coots aren’t even going anywhere, they just keep looping around to obstruct the way!

meaning.mnemonic: Construction in the winter leads to aggression. Just think about it. It's cold, it's unpleasant, and you don't want to be there. So, you start to develop an aggression towards other people working with you on this winter project.

readings.mnemonic: You're taking your aggression out on everyone. Then, the sexy construction worker from WaniKani Level 1, こういち, walks by without a shirt on. You take out all your aggression on him.

meaning.mnemonic: If someone is coming toward you in a car, holding a weapon in their hand, they're going to attack you!

readings.mnemonic: Right before the attack begins, you recognize the hand holding this weapon and driving this car. It's Gecki (げき), your long-lost gecko who you may or may not have let fly off into a really fierce tsunami. Oops. I think he may be here attacking you out of revenge.

meaning.mnemonic: After a tsunami, you find an axe on the ground next to some fins on the beach. The tsunami was pretty violent, and it looks like this axe got blown into some fish and cut off their fins and now those things are just on the ground by the beach.

readings.mnemonic: Walking down the beach a bit more, you also find a hammer (はま). Gosh, looks like the tsunami hit a workshop or a hardware store or something. First the axe, now a hammer.

meaning.mnemonic: This thread is odd, but that's what makes it beautiful. It's a little frayed, it's a little miscolored, but that's what makes it appealing to you.

readings.mnemonic: You take this beautiful thread and lock it up with a key (き). You want to keep it all to yourself, you want its beauty to be for your eyes only!

meaning.mnemonic: There are some horns on the ground next to fins on a plate that are meant to benefit everyone. If you're a member of this town, one of your benefits is this little set up.

readings.mnemonic: Another benefit is free 駅 usage! Whenever you come back home from places on the train, this 駅 is completely free.

meaning.mnemonic: Pointing your magic solar powered wishing stick at the sun, you attain the legs of a child. You’re old and want young legs to carry you around, so you took your wishing stick that’s powered by the sun, and you wished for the legs of a child.

readings.mnemonic: As you delight in your new legs, Jesus (じ) descends from the sky. “My child,” he says, “why have you pointed the stick at the sun and wished for the legs of a child? You were already perfect, just as all of God’s children are perfect.”

meaning.mnemonic: The roof protecting your life and the net protecting your heart are both protected by the constitution.

readings.mnemonic: Your country's constitution is being protected by none other than Ken (けん) the samurai, hero for hire.

meaning.mnemonic: You got your ice orders. Of course, your ice orders are to make things cool and cold.

readings.mnemonic: How will you make things cool and cold? You'll use a special ray (れい) gun that shoots a cold ray.

meaning.mnemonic: A winter table would be an odd thing to deal with. Winter can be hard to deal with on its own, but turn your table into winter? Just dealing with your food getting cold would be the worst!

readings.mnemonic: This winter table is something you have to deal with, sure, but what if you just gave it to a circus show (しょ)? They like weird stuff like this.

meaning.mnemonic: You loiter on the mountain, reading off the numbers of pi on this winter morning. Everything is so perfect, so mathematical here. You view it as delicate. Not in the sense that it will break apart at any moment, more in the sense that there are smaller, more subtle things to be enjoyed on this mountain, which is why you loiter here doing math.

readings.mnemonic: Ah! Of course! The delicate bumble bee (び), that is your epitome of delicate. It lands upon your finger, and you look at its every fiber of being.

meaning.mnemonic: A leader uses a stick in the winter made of hair to enforce discipline. The leader uses the stick made of hair to discipline his followers. He hits them with it.

readings.mnemonic: If the leader uses a stick to discipline his followers, eventually they'll fight back. The disciplined masses start to take off their shoes (しゅう) and throw them at the leader!

meaning.mnemonic: You wear a great big cross on your chest and you attend a specialty exhibition for gambling. The big cross on your chest is your badge for being admitted into the exhibition. Everyone at the specialty exhibition has a cross, and everyone is gambling.

readings.mnemonic: You’re not very good at gambling, but you are pretty good at cheating. You hack (はく) the specialty exhibition gambling machines to pay out lots of cash just for you. You hack quickly and quietly, so luckily no one notices that you’ve hacked the system.

meaning.mnemonic: The Grain Mouth King pours grain from his mouth for you and his other subjects. You go to him and pull his finger. When you do this, grain pours from his mouth. But we were greedy. We didn't understand the extent to which we were harvesting his mouth wheat.

readings.mnemonic: The extent to which we were harvesting grain from his mouth was too great. The Grain Mouth King has run out of grain. He worries he will lose power if he has no grain to offer, so he switches to barfing out tater (てい) tots instead.

meaning.mnemonic: Sometime in the future, thread of every color will be faced with extinction. Eventually there will be nothing else to make thread out of, and thread of every kind and color will reach extinction.

readings.mnemonic: The extinction of thread was brought on by a very strange thing. Deadly zits (ぜつ). These zits killed off all the producers of thread, and eventually the thread went extinct. Dang zits.

meaning.mnemonic: Ice from the east is frozen. Well, of course, all ice is frozen, but ice from the east is like, really super frozen.

readings.mnemonic: Japan is a country in the east, and this ice was frozen in とうきょう. とうきょう is really good at freezing frozen things, so it makes sense that this frozen ice came from there.

meaning.mnemonic: The giant radical and the giant kanji are exactly the same! Massive!

readings.mnemonic: Just recently, a giant rampaged through Little Kyoto (きょ), so now it's even smaller than before. Poor Little Kyoto.

meaning.mnemonic: Only give grains to a turkey if it's immature. Adult turkeys should be eating healthier things, like insects and grass. But immature turkeys don't care if they get fat, so they whine and whine and whine until you give them grains.

readings.mnemonic: Another thing immature turkeys (and people) love is cheese (ち). Most of us non-immature people and birds still like cheese, but if you didn't have an immature cheese phase as a kid or teen, you won't be able to like cheese as a mature old person.

meaning.mnemonic: Super poop is a super power you have in infancy. Those in infancy have the power to poop at will, whenever and wherever they please. Infancy poop power!

readings.mnemonic: In infancy, one eats a lot of soft foods, such as yogurt (よう). Yogurt is the food item above all others that grants superior pooping power.

meaning.mnemonic: You stick horns in the ground using them as spikes and you line up the horns in a straight line. Horns are pretty much the same thing as spikes once you stick them in the ground, and you line these ones up precisely for optimal protection.

readings.mnemonic: As you line up these horns and stick them into the ground, you notice a bull munching on hay (へい) nearby. It's staring at the horns you're lining up. Somehow it feels like it's munching that hay angrily. You gulp, looking at its horn as it grabs another mouthful of hay, and you feel pretty guilty.

meaning.mnemonic: If you know the radical meaning lovely, you know the kanji meaning lovely as well!

readings.mnemonic: "Lovely" is the name of my ray (れい) gun. It's more lovely than any other thing.

meaning.mnemonic: The odd radical and the odd kanji are the same. They're both... really strange.

readings.mnemonic: You're odd too, just like this kanji. But you don't want anyone to know, so you lock away your strange habits with a key (き).

meaning.mnemonic: Blood and hair and tofu make up the populace. Those are the three categories the entire populace fits into, anyway.

readings.mnemonic: The entire populace deserves shoes (しゅう). It's a basic thing all humans should have like flowing blood, hair (somewhere), and tofu to eat.

meaning.mnemonic: A tsunami that's blue is pure. Some tsunami are other colors, like brown or red because they aren't pure, they'll full of trash and poop and other horrible things. But a blue tsunami is completely pure!

readings.mnemonic: Seeing this pure blue tsunami inspires you to pull out your glowing blue saber (せい)! As the pure water comes toward you, you take one, long slash!

meaning.mnemonic: A tsunami takes life, cuts it like a sword through thread, and leaves everything behind completely pure. Everything is dead and gone, wiped clean off the face of the earth, thanks to the tsunami. It's back to the way it was before humans were here, it's completely pure.

readings.mnemonic: After the tsunami pulls away, everything left is pure white. You hate this, so you run over and squirt ketsup (けつ) all over the place to make it not so pure.

meaning.mnemonic: A gold Wolverine swam in the water while his father made a record of it. Wolverine is gold in color because he just won the gold medal in swimming, so now he is gold. Way to go, Wolverine.

readings.mnemonic: Since Wolverine is actually a mutant, he is soon disqualified from his gold medal. His father makes a record of this also. One angry fan threw a rock (ろく) at Wolverine afterwards. Then another threw a rock. And another rock. Before you knew it, everyone was throwing rocks at Wolverine. Wolverine’s dad didn’t step in to help though, he just kept keeping records.

meaning.mnemonic: Your scooter takes you to the barracks, drops you off, and then goes in reverse all the way back home in the opposite direction.

readings.mnemonic: Your scooter going in reverse and leaving you here is opposite of what you want. You want to ride it back home when you're done, so you stuff the wheels with Gak (ぎゃく). If you don’t know what Gak is, check out this Gak commercial.

meaning.mnemonic: A grain, from one evening to the next evening, experiences a shift. After two evenings, the grain has shifted from one location to another.

readings.mnemonic: This shift is caused by the eagle (い) that wants to eat the grains. Every other evening, the eagle swoops down, shifts the grains (eating a few) and then flies off.

meaning.mnemonic: Rice that is blue has a strong spirit. Our spirits are blue, so if you ever see rice (or other food, or even people) that's blue, you know that's their spirit radiating out!

readings.mnemonic: You want to see the spirit up close, so you take your saber (せい), throw the blue rice in the air, and slice it in half! The rice explodes and blue light fills everything!

meaning.mnemonic: This building has a pig with horns on it because it's our squad's place.

readings.mnemonic: Our squad also wears special ties (たい) with our horned pig on it. And we don't care if you think that's lame, because we're A FAMILY.

meaning.mnemonic: A canopy is over your car because your car is in storage in a large warehouse.

readings.mnemonic: Your car is in this storage warehouse, just sitting there. A 子 (こ) notices this, and decides to take your car on a joyride. You won't notice, right? You never drive it.

meaning.mnemonic: A woman is one of the few strange things in the world. Everything but a woman can be explained and made sense of. There are only a few strange things in this world, with woman being one of them.

readings.mnemonic: But when you think about it, we're all a little strange. Me, you, myou (みょう) everybody!

meaning.mnemonic: The gladiator in front of you draws his sword. He points the sword at your chest and right when you think everything is about to end, you realize he's pointing the sword at the ticket in your hand.

readings.mnemonic: The gladiator happily marks your ticket with his blade, when Ken (けん) the samurai pushes past you. He holds up his own sword, challenging the gladiator, who just shakes his head and points at your ticket again.

meaning.mnemonic: As a hat, four people holding a cross use an umbrella. The umbrella is big enough to be a hat for all four people, so it makes sense. All four of them are religious missionaries, so that’s why they’re holding the cross.

readings.mnemonic: You know the Spanish phrase “Mi casa (かさ) es su casa”? Well this is kind of like that, but only with a hat. And that hat is an umbrella. Mi casa es yours too, because it’s an umbrella and also a hat. This makes sense, trust me.

meaning.mnemonic: That woman dressed as Wolverine with a towel tied around her forehead is your wife. You're cosplaying together!

readings.mnemonic: Your wife suddenly looks at you and calls you a fool (ふ). Wuh! Then you look down and see that you're also dressed as Wolverine.

meaning.mnemonic: You see a rice paddy and you give it a kiss before granting it the abbreviation, RP. The rice paddy isn’t too fond of this abbreviation, so you kiss it again to soothe it.

readings.mnemonic: The rice paddy still refuses to accept this abbreviation despite your kisses. Therefore, you are forced to take the rice paddy and hang it from a torture rack (りゃく) until it agrees to accept the abbreviation.

meaning.mnemonic: Grains get blamed for how much they accumulate. If the grains accumulate too much then they make more work for the farmers. If they accumulate too little, then they're starving the people. Ugh, grains just can't win with you people. They're blamed for everything.

readings.mnemonic: Now the grains have accumulated a ton, they're overflowing in their grain sacks, and the farmer freezes and says, "Now those are some sexy (せき) grains."

meaning.mnemonic: There’s a tsunami in heaven and you take a small drop of water and append it to the tsunami. Now the tsunami is big enough to destroy all of heaven. The small drop that you appended to the tsunami was just enough to push it over the edge, reaching full destruction capability.

readings.mnemonic: Just after you append the small drop of water to the tsunami, it grows ten (てん) stories high. Before it was only nine, but since you appended that drop, the tsunami is now a full ten stories tall.

meaning.mnemonic: Under this roof someone odd is trying to approach you. You back up, but they continue their approach anyway.

readings.mnemonic: They approach too closely and you can't take it anymore. You run out from under the roof, slam the door closed, and lock it with a key (き).

meaning.mnemonic: Under a roof, but still in the sun, a woman is laying out a fabulous banquet. The woman doesn't want anyone to burn from the sun, but banquets are best outside, so she's set up a roof to protect her and her guests.

readings.mnemonic: Unfortunately, the banquet roof comes crashing down right before the guests arrive, and it ends (えん) before it can start.

meaning.mnemonic: If you're anti-tree, you won't mind if I turn all of them into boards! Hahaha!

readings.mnemonic: These boards are now being sold to Han (はん) Solo, who's wearing Ray-Ban (ばん) sunglasses, and who's going to smuggle them all over the universe.

meaning.mnemonic: You set up a net on a cross to wash your clothes in the river, when a huge wave of dirt smashes into it, breaking the whole thing and sending your clothes tumbling down the river.

readings.mnemonic: You angrily search to see what caused your clothes washing machine to break and you see some kayaks (かい) upriver. The people in the kayaks are jumping around, kicking dirt up, which is what broke your stuff.

meaning.mnemonic: Above you, on a small stool is the eye of your coach. He's really high above you though, and all you can make out is the glint of his eye as he perches on that stool. But he's yelling out orders and corrections, which you can hear very well.

readings.mnemonic: You finally win the big game and the coach is coming down off of his stool, and you see that's he's the ghost of Tokugawa (とく) Ieyasu!!! That explains why you could only ever make out his eyeball!

meaning.mnemonic: A good leader will use charcoal to mark her colleagues. Sometimes if leaders aren't around all the time, people will get rebellious and act badly toward people who can get them in trouble. So when you mark them with charcoal you know that someone close with your leader is around and you should probably stop being a butt.

readings.mnemonic: You have to be good around her colleagues, because if you aren't your row (りょう) boat permit will be taken away. Row boating is the only fun you ever get to have, besides learning kanji. So act as best you can around the leader's colleagues so you don't lose your row boat rights.

meaning.mnemonic: A tree is not a cup of liquid or a counter for cups. Don’t get them mixed up. The last time you tried making a cup out of a tree to count your throat got filled with splinters when you used it. There wasn't even any liquid in it.

readings.mnemonic: Another way to remember the counter for cups using a cup of liquid would be by creating and memorizing a haiku (はい) about them. Aren’t haikus useful?

meaning.mnemonic: A woman who is good is my daughter. My daughter is a good woman, I guarantee it.

readings.mnemonic: Your daughter, on the other hand, is not a good woman. Your daughter looks like a moose who may (むすめ) not be able to find its way out of a wet paper bag. Your daughter looks like a moose who may lose its way without a map. Your daughter looks like a moose who may do lots of stupid things.

meaning.mnemonic: They say to wear a hat to cover your hair if your doctor diagnoses you with hair loss. It's the best option, folks.

readings.mnemonic: You just had the doctor diagnose you with hair loss. How terrible! You stumble out of the room, dumbfounded. Not paying attention, you bang your shin (しん) on the table. Your shin really hurts. What an awful day.

meaning.mnemonic: In the morning, you use a gun on your nose to make it dry.

readings.mnemonic: This technique for a nice dry nose was invented by Genghis Khan (かん)! Well, not him, but someone who worked under him. You see, he had a bit of a damp nose problem.

meaning.mnemonic: A district that lacks things will be in Europe.

readings.mnemonic: Europe is lacking so much because their 王 (おう) keeps taking everything.

meaning.mnemonic: A saw cuts into your heart and you are filled with fear. Well, you were filled with fear before the saw reached your heart too, but now that the saw is cutting into your heart, you’re feeling more fear than ever.

readings.mnemonic: Even more so than your fear of dying, you are filled with the fear that you’ll never get to vacation in きょうと. You always wanted to take a trip to きょうと, but if you die from this saw wound to the heart, you’ll never get the chance to go.

meaning.mnemonic: An animal eats a child from a plate in a very fierce manner. This is a fierce animal, so it makes sense that it would eat the child in a fierce style.

readings.mnemonic: The reason this fierce animal is eating the child from the plate is because the child forgot to mow (もう) the animal’s lawn. The fierce animal had hired the child to mow his lawn today, and when the child forgot to do it, the fierce animal hunted the child down and ate him.

meaning.mnemonic: A tsunami rolls in and destroys all the construction that was being done on the inlet and the bay. Both the inlet and the bay were having a lot of construction done on them to repair the damage from the last tsunami, and then another tsunami rolled in and destroyed all that too. Bummer.

readings.mnemonic: Imagine the Japanese people standing on the bay and the inlet as the tsunami approaches. “Eh (え)? What is that, Akiko?” “Eh? Where? Oh gawd, it’s a tsunami!!”

meaning.mnemonic: In the morning, Korea will still be Korea.

readings.mnemonic: Korea is still here today on this beautiful morning because of Genghis Khan (かん). When he was conquering all that land in Asia and Europe he looked at Korea in the morning light and said, "Nah, they can keep it."

meaning.mnemonic: The narwhal and the turkey are meeting in private to uh, show each other some private things. Doing this they realize they're both male!

readings.mnemonic: These male animals are obviously experimenting with things still. Ah, they must be youths (ゆう)!  To be a youth, again!

meaning.mnemonic: On every boat there is a table with a lid on it that's used for navigation. When you take the lid off, there is a big map, a sextant, and some little boat miniatures. All the navigation tools.

readings.mnemonic: You watch the navigation equipment roll away and then you feel a slap on the back of your head. Ouch! You turn around and there stands こういち, who you took with you as the navigator of this expedition. And, you just lost all his stuff!

meaning.mnemonic: To the servant you say: "gun, ground, plate." It is your job to oversee everything they do.

readings.mnemonic: Why must you oversee everything? Because you are Genghis Khan (かん), and Genghis Khan oversees everything.

meaning.mnemonic: Under this roof you jackhammer your religion into people.

readings.mnemonic: Your religion requires everyone to take off their shoes (しゅう). Mostly because the shoes will help them resist the jackhammering, so you tell them that to join your religion they have to leave their shoes at the door.

meaning.mnemonic: If what you say comes out blue, everyone knows that means you made a request. You request a favor and the words slide out of your mouth in a bright, blue blob. They hover in front of you for a few seconds, before splashing onto the person you made the request to.

readings.mnemonic: The next time someone requests something from you, take out your saber (せい) and slice it in half!

meaning.mnemonic: The soul of a narwhal was sucked into its towel, which is scary!

readings.mnemonic: As you watch this scary scene you can't help but mutter, "Fool," (ふ) under your breath. Then you hear "Fool, fool, fool, it's too scary you fool!" and you realize all of the other narwhals are chanting.

meaning.mnemonic: There is a cross in your forehead with a thread attached to it, forcing you to search where it leads. You’re not sure how the cross got stuck in your forehead, but you are interested in seeing where this piece of thread leads. The search is on.

readings.mnemonic: Your search is over. You found the end of the thread. The thread leads you to a sack (さく). A sack filled with more crosses with more threads attached to them. What does it all mean!?!

meaning.mnemonic: The servant radical and the servant kanji are exactly the same! Just remember that the kanji also means retainer and you’ll be fine.

readings.mnemonic: Your servant, also known as your retainer, bangs his shins (しん) all the time so you make him wear jeans (じん) to work now. He bangs his shins on all the furniture in the house, knocking over all your valuables. But at least when he’s wearing jeans it doesn’t leave bruises like it did when he wasn’t wearing pants.

meaning.mnemonic: The leader of the mountain turkeys is our sponsor. He's paying us to say and type everything you're reading.

readings.mnemonic: This same sponsor is also how you made your cyborg (さい). You didn't think you were able to get all those body parts yourself, did you? No no, the leader of the mountain turkeys sponsored you so you could do your experiments.

meaning.mnemonic: The dirt you use to go from place to place is the street. Back in the old days, all roads were made of dirt, not like the newfangled roads of today.

readings.mnemonic: As you're walking down the street, staring at the dirt, a guy (がい) bumps into you, "Hey guy, watch where you're going!" As he says this he bumps into another guy. "Watch it guy, I'm walkin' in this street!" "Woah guy, this isn't your business, this is my street!"

meaning.mnemonic: Say good luck to one person enough and they'll be stuffed full of that luck.

readings.mnemonic: You stuffed them by saying good luck two (つ) whole times!

meaning.mnemonic: The servant sits on a stool, holding a piece of thread, looking very tense.

readings.mnemonic: You ask the servant why they're so tense, and they say they've been assigned to assassinate the King (きん) of England with this piece of thread.

meaning.mnemonic: At the gate, you kiss the cabinet members, one by one. In order to gain access to this government building, you have to kiss all the members of the cabinet at the gate. What a strange ritual.

readings.mnemonic: You need to kiss each member of the cabinet to gain access to their building. And you need to get into the building to recover your cock (かく). Your prize winning cock has been captured by a member of the cabinet and you need to infiltrate their headquarters and recover your rooster!

meaning.mnemonic: Your leader sees your bare foot and urges you to put a sock on it.

readings.mnemonic: As urged, you put a sock (そく) on your foot. Ahh, that feels so much better. What a great thing, this sock.

meaning.mnemonic: When a yakuza's knife boils, you know something very violent and intense is about to happen.

readings.mnemonic: When someone gets violent or intense, they always yell "Let's (れつ) get violent and intense!"

meaning.mnemonic: In the ground of the rice paddy is a treasure. You pull it out of the mucky ground. This will renew your life for the better. Again, this treasure will change your life!

readings.mnemonic: Again, you are going to renew your life! Everything will be better. Then, the person who caused all this grief grabs your treasure and runs. こういち is running off with the treasure that was supposed to renew your life!

meaning.mnemonic: A demon on a jet is pretty alluring. Demons themselves are pretty intriguing, but put one on a jet? Now that’s alluring.

readings.mnemonic: This alluring demon on a jet wants one thing and one thing only. Meat (み). Human meat. This demon needs human meat to survive so he is taking his jet into the city to feast on some meat.

meaning.mnemonic: You fly north to the moon and break your back when you finally land on it. You weren’t braced for impact so when you hit the moon, your back took all of the impact.

readings.mnemonic: Your back hurts so much that the only way to properly explain the pain is in haiku (はい) form.

meaning.mnemonic: A horse gets trapped in a small room with a stool and an insect, and together they create a very boisterous situation. The horse and the insect are both scrambling frantically to get out of the small room, knocking the stool around all over the place.

readings.mnemonic: At the height of their boisterous sounds, there's a sudden, awful CRONCH(!) and you see the soul (そう) of the insect slowly rising out of the room, through the ceiling.

meaning.mnemonic: When you eat you want to see the shape of your gun from under a towel, so you decorate your house with them.

readings.mnemonic: If you actually decorate your house like this it will give people quite a shock (しょく). In fact, they might be so shocked they run out of there screaming.

meaning.mnemonic: If you want to buy a geoduck you have to go to the bank beforehand to deposit enough money. If you don't deposit your money you won't have enough in your account to buy even one! They're expensive, after all.

readings.mnemonic: You go to the bank to make the deposit and there is a kid standing in your way playing with a yo-yo (よ). You try to squeeze past and he hits you in the face with the yo-yo! Now you can't see! Now you can't make the deposit!

meaning.mnemonic: If you are anti one sided paper you should bind them all up into an edition.

readings.mnemonic: The first edition you create is a fan fiction all about the adventures of Han (はん) Solo. You hated how short and one sided his story in Star Wars seemed to be, and trying to keep track of it all was really hard. But not anymore!

meaning.mnemonic: You've made yourself a tree bookshelf (that is, a bookshelf cut into a tree), so you build a fence to keep the riffraff out.

readings.mnemonic: On your fence, you hang up a sack (さく) to accept donations.

meaning.mnemonic: Traveling in the direction of the ocean, you take a gun and shoot a crab, then stick a flag in the beach and claim it as your own. The crab was the only thing standing in the way of you conquering the area. Now that the flag is in the ground, no one can dispute who it belongs to.

readings.mnemonic: To make sure that no one removes your flag, you lock it to one of the lifeguard posts and you throw away the key (き). Since no one will have the key to unlock the flag, no one will be able to remove it.

meaning.mnemonic: A tsunami knocks a cleat off a child and the shoe begins to float away in the water. This child was just out playing soccer, minding his own business, when the tsunami crashed in and knocked his cleats off his feet. Now the cleat is floating away with the tsunami.

readings.mnemonic: While you float in the water, an uni (う) jabs into your foot. “Uwaaa~ (うわ)” you cry. That uni really hurts. They’re all spikey and painful and junk. “Uwaaaa~”

meaning.mnemonic: You run every day and soon you become a human that can go beyond the normal speed limits of man. You run and you run and you run. This training allows you to become super human. You go beyond the limits of a normal human. You become a human who can run really fast.

readings.mnemonic: To solidify your ability to go beyond the abilities of other humans, you etch (えつ) sacred runes into your legs to preserve your running abilities. Etching these runes makes sure that your skills will never deteriorate.

meaning.mnemonic: The sun is being called on to boil the earth by illuminating it.

readings.mnemonic: The person who calls the sun asking it to illuminate the earth is the Shougun (しょう). It's very specifically the Shougun's responsibility to make sure the earth is illuminated every morning.

meaning.mnemonic: A tsunami rips a flag off your house in the rain, causing a leak where it was ripped out. The rain and the tsunami combined just tore the flag right off your house. The force was so strong that it actually removed part of the wall, and now you have a leak in your home.

readings.mnemonic: The leak is getting worse and worse and so is the tsunami, when you see something outside. It’s a bunch of roe (ろう) floating in the waves. Using your quick thinking skills you scoop it up and shove it into the cracks where the water is leaking in. It works like a charm!

meaning.mnemonic: The lineage radical and the lineage kanji are the same.

readings.mnemonic: You trace your lineage back and realize that every single person in your family loved cake (けい). Most of them were cake bakers, too!

meaning.mnemonic: A servant holding a gun sits on the ground to see if he can find something to look at. The servant is on watch duty and has the gun to protect the perimeter. He patrols the grounds to look at the distance to see if there are any trespassers.

readings.mnemonic: You start backing away, but then you realize that you are Macho Man Randy (らん) Savage. Randy Savage backs away from no fight! I mean, look at this guy – this servant guy. Take away the gun and he’s not much to look at. You can take him.

meaning.mnemonic: You meet a woman from another clan under the rising sun to prepare for marriage. Your clan and her clan are standing together as the two of you watch the sun rise together.

readings.mnemonic: For the marriage to be official, you need to wait for a condor (こん) to appear. If it doesn't show up before the sun goes down again, the marriage was a failure. You have to try again tomorrow with a different woman.

meaning.mnemonic: Your soul will cross through your body and into the net of your clothes so that you'll be hit with nostalgia when you wear them again. Nostalgia for all the things that happened every single time you wore those clothes.

readings.mnemonic: This nostalgia ties knots (なつ) in your stomach and your chest. Even if the memories and feelings weren't particularly bad, there's something about the wistful feeling of nostalgia that knots up your insides.

meaning.mnemonic: You put your fingers and an ear on a stool in the sun so you can get your photograph taken. This is a glamour photo, so you have to be in one of these weird, cheesy poses for it to come out jusssst right.

readings.mnemonic: As you're getting the photograph taken, the photographer suddenly gets angry at you. "You sat (さつ) down!" he screams. "I sat down?" you ask. "Yes! And now the photo is ruined!"

meaning.mnemonic: The tree pirate jumps from a tree and attacks you by hitting you with a pillow.

readings.mnemonic: As he hits you with his pillow he makes a demand: "Give me your Mac cooler (まくら). He wants the device that cools down your Mac computer.

meaning.mnemonic: On a scooter running in one direction is a gun-toting child. This is a terribly dangerous situation, but to the child it is just play.

readings.mnemonic: Everything is play for youths (ゆう), even if it's a terrible, scary, not good situation like this one.

meaning.mnemonic: The soul of a person has a hook that can make them pleasant. When you see, hear, or feel something pleasant, can't you feel that hook pressing into the middle of your body?

readings.mnemonic: If you want to feel this pleasant feeling just look at a kayak (かい). Kayaks are the most pleasant boats in the world. Feel that pleasant feeling in your chest just from reading about kayaks in this mnemonic right now.

meaning.mnemonic: Those that can only eat a part of a shellfish are probably a bit poor.

readings.mnemonic: And since they are poor, they are getting these shellfish parts from the trash bin (びん). It's quite unfortunate.

meaning.mnemonic: If you do yoga correctly, you will not only prolong your body but your life!

readings.mnemonic: You can prolong your life with correct yoga techniques, but unfortunately, if you ever stop doing yoga after you've started this prolonging process, it will just end (えん) suddenly.

meaning.mnemonic: Take your fingers, put them on this turtle shell, and push push push! Push the turtle right on out of there.

readings.mnemonic: You're trying to push this turtle out so you can use the shell for your new obi (お). You keep seeing other people wearing turtle shell patterns on their obi, but you're going to go a step further. You're going to MAKE your obi out of actual turtle shells! You just have to push this darn turtle out first.

meaning.mnemonic: If you look for a leaf among the hills you will notice they are scarce. The hills have no trees around them, so there are no leaves. The leaves are scarce here on the hills.

readings.mnemonic: Still looking for a leaf, you determine that they are far too scarce to find here. Just before you give up, you discover a giant bowling (ぼう) ball. As you pick it up, another one comes thundering down the hill knocking over a tiny tree.

meaning.mnemonic: You're in prison and all you have is a spoon. You use that prison spoon to scoop up nice scents and fragrances out of the air when you have outdoor time and bring them back into your cell.

readings.mnemonic: You can't remember what any of these scents are anymore, you've been in prison for so long, so you call them all neo-scents (にお). They're neo, they're new.

meaning.mnemonic: The next plate is the one you will steal. This one would be too obvious, better wait for the next one.

readings.mnemonic: You steal this plate from a とうきょう restaurant, so after you steal it, picture yourself running through the streets of とうきょう as you lose your pursuers.

meaning.mnemonic: Picture a shellfish lifeguard. They're not going anywhere. First, they're a shellfish, so they can't really move. And, they're a lifeguard, so they need to be in their lifeguard tower. How does this shellfish lifeguard get stuff? Through subscription services.

readings.mnemonic: The shellfish lifeguard's favorite subscription is its subscription to こういち magazine. It has all the latest こういち versions, news, and interviews.

meaning.mnemonic: A scooter with a mohawk, now that's the most suitable hairstyle you could ever think of for a scooter!

readings.mnemonic: You want this suitable hairstyle for your scooter too, and luckily you're a techie (てき), so it's easy for you to install one.

meaning.mnemonic: There are some feathers resting on a stand and you and the following of the feathers are following the feathers. The feathers have a following, and you are one member of the following. You and your fellow followers follow the feathers wherever they may go.

readings.mnemonic: While you and the following are following the feathers from their departure from the stand, one of the members of the following drops an egg and yolk (よく) spills everywhere. What a mess! Being a quick thinker, you use one of the feathers to soak up the yolk and clean up the mess.

meaning.mnemonic: You're stuck in a prison on the sun with nothing but a spoon. Lucky for you a tsunami is coming, so you take your spoon and use the tsunami to quench your thirst. You spoon the hot, hot water into your mouth as fast as you can. This is the only way to get water on the sun.

readings.mnemonic: This method of quenching your thirst reminds you of being in a car wash (かわ). The water pours over you in waves, and you're stuck inside a metal cage. Totally the same thing as a car wash, right?

meaning.mnemonic: You take some bamboo and attach it together into a token of appreciation for your friend. Your friend greatly appreciates this token of friendship.

readings.mnemonic: You hand over the token but your friend drops it and yells, "You fool (ふ)! I'm allergic to bamboo!"

meaning.mnemonic: If a tsunami hits, it's raining, and you're outside trying to use a rake, you're going to be very wet and damp.

readings.mnemonic: You can't stand how wet and damp you feel in these clothes so you rip them off and rake in the nude (ぬ)!

meaning.mnemonic: There's a mountain coming out of the ground that you want to climb, but your forehead needs a towel for all your sweat. You don't have a towel, so you take off your belt and tie it around your forehead.

readings.mnemonic: The belt isn't absorbent enough, so you wrap it in your tie (たい) and then tie the whole thing around your forehead again.

meaning.mnemonic: The canopy guy is a guy who stands in the corridor trying to sell people canopies.

readings.mnemonic: You take the corridor, but this time the canopy guy is gone. In his place is a new salesman. This one is trying to sell you roe (ろう).

meaning.mnemonic: The rocket turkey has several points which will detach during takeoff.

readings.mnemonic: When the rocket turkey parts detach, they fall to the ground onto a bed of reeds り.

meaning.mnemonic: You loiter around a tombstone to measure its diameter. You’re doing this to each tombstone, and if you loiter around long enough, you’ll soon know the diameter of every tombstone.

readings.mnemonic: You need to know the diameter of each tombstone so you can make cakes (けい) for each one. But the cakes can't be wider than the tombstones, or they'll flop off onto the ground.

meaning.mnemonic: You see a bully take an insect and dissolve it in some acid. Bullies are messed up, mean people. They do awful things that normal kids and people wouldn't do... like dissolve a living creature.

readings.mnemonic: The only bullies heartless enough to dissolve insects like this are youths (ゆう). Do you really think an adult would melt a harmless critter? No. Only inexperienced youths could be so cruel.

meaning.mnemonic: You have some dirt next to a pool that has an extra drop of water in it because you need them to be equal. If there's too much dirt outside the pool and not enough water inside, it's gonna look weird. We can't have that.

readings.mnemonic: You spend a few hours making sure the water-to-dirt ratio is perfectly equal, not for yourself, but because the King (きん) of England told you to. You may agree that equality is important, but it's the King's responsibility to keep things that way. Which is why he ordered you, small peon, to do the equalizing work for him.

meaning.mnemonic: The buildings are at a surplus. Because of that, we will need to exclude some of them from our future plans. Also, we'll need to remove some buildings too.

readings.mnemonic: Working with you on this project to exclude buildings from the plan, as well as remove buildings that already exist is little Jo-Anne (じょ).

meaning.mnemonic: You want to change your shellfish into freight so you can transport it. That means packing them up into giant freight containers.

readings.mnemonic: To move this freight, you need a car (か). You strap all of the freight containers to the top of your car, stacked nice and high and precarious, so you can move it.

meaning.mnemonic: A child shares his lineage with a grandchild. The child passes his lineage down to his child and then that child’s child is the grandchild and between them all a lineage is shared.

readings.mnemonic: The son (そん) of a son is a grandchild. In this case, a grandson. Easy.

meaning.mnemonic: There's a strange patch of dirt in this greenhouse that's actually a grave. Dig around a little and you'll find the marker buried in there. If you dig deeper you'll probably find less pleasant things.

readings.mnemonic: You decide to dig even deeper into the grave out of curiosity and you find a bow (ぼ) and some arrows. This must be the grave of a great archer! But you probably shouldn't keep digging around in this grave looking for more stuff.

meaning.mnemonic: You poop twice on a sleeping drunkard person and you find yourself wondering how many more times you can poop on them and wonder how much they can take before they realize what’s going on.

readings.mnemonic: As you continue thinking about how much poop this drunkard can take and how many more poops you can drop on him, he begins to wake up. Quickly, you eke (いく) out one last poop before you scurry away. You eke that poop out just in time to make your escape.

meaning.mnemonic: Wolverine is doing a construction job and he’s using his mouth to measure so he knows how many folks he needs to inquire about helping him with the job. Using one’s mouth is a strange way to measure something, but that’s just how Wolverine does things. Once he measures it all out, he’ll know how many construction workers he needs to inquire about working for him.

readings.mnemonic: You decide to inquire as to why Wolverine is using his mouth to measure out this construction site. As you get closer you notice his cool ripped jeans (じん). Instead you inquire how he got such a fresh style. He looks you up and down, pulls out his claws, and tears yours up to match his. You’ve completely forgotten what it was you were asking, but who cares! Look how great you look!

meaning.mnemonic: Bring thread to the library to knit. Libraries are quiet and generally pretty empty nowadays, so it's the perfect place to relax and do some knitting. Of course, if you find thread lying around in a library you know what to do now.

readings.mnemonic: You need to come to the library to knit because if you try to do it at home all your hens (へん) will try to eat the thread. Hens love eating things that look like worms, like hay, string, and thread. So it's important to get far away from them before you start to knit.

meaning.mnemonic: A building made from a womb must be placed upon the land.

readings.mnemonic: The land around your womb building will, unfortunately, reek (りく) though.
