meaning.mnemonic: If you want to get your fingers in the pi tree, you're going to have to look for it. This isn't a tree made of pie, or growing fully-baked pies. It's a pi tree, one that exists infinitely. It's the most rare tree in the world. And if you want to stick your fingers in it, you have to search for it far and wide!

readings.mnemonic: You try to look for the pi tree for so long that you can't help but get a very deep tan (たん). You can't search for anything inside, and you definitely can't find the pi tree inside, so you spend a lot of time outside in the bright sun.

meaning.mnemonic: You put a lid on a dish you're cooking, made up of the mouths and foreheads of a pig. Unknown to most, these are the juiciest, most delicious parts of a pig. And dang, they are the most luxurious, too.

readings.mnemonic: Luxurious pig mouth forehead soup is a favorite of Grandpa Koichi (ごういち). You see him sniffing around your window, then he knocks and waves.

meaning.mnemonic: You are given some gold to oversee a model. You are a famous architect, so you get a lot of gold for overseeing the construction of models like this one.

readings.mnemonic: As the model nears completion, you realize it's taking the shape of Genghis Khan (かん). Was that what this was supposed to look like? You were so busy overseeing the gold in your pocket, you forgot!

meaning.mnemonic: A tsunami came in and buried your flag so now you have to use a spoon and dig it out of the mud.

readings.mnemonic: The time of day (でい) is high noon, so the sun soon dries the mud and makes it harder to dig through. It just might take you all day to spoon your way through this mud.

meaning.mnemonic: Birds use grass and fruit to make their nests.

readings.mnemonic: The bottom of the nest also seems to be padded with someone's suit (す). Did... did this bird attack a human for this?!

meaning.mnemonic: You line up your body with the sun and everything looks normal.  The sun is lined up behind you, and you’re looking at all the things the sun has lit up. Everything looks normal.

readings.mnemonic: Soon you see something that doesn’t look so normal. It’s a fool (ふ), a jester. Dressed all in fool’s garb, this fool is dancing up towards you with a ridiculously unsettling grin on his face.

meaning.mnemonic: A tree in spring that's nice and dry will make a good pole or rod. Break it out of the ground and it's just flexible enough for tons of applications.

readings.mnemonic: After much deliberation, you decide to use this pole to go bowling (ぼう). You line up a few more poles for the pins, and roll a rock toward them.

meaning.mnemonic: If you grind rice, every part of it, eventually it will become a fine powder. You can then use this rice powder as a part to create some other dish. Some kind of cake, perhaps.

readings.mnemonic: Actually, grinding the rice down to a powder is super fun (ふん). It’s so fun you don’t want to stop! AH HAHAHAHA! RICE POWDER! SO FUN!

meaning.mnemonic: There's a root where your fang previously was. Your fang isn't there anymore, you ripped it out.

readings.mnemonic: To remember the beautiful fangs you previously had, you keep all of the ones you pull out in a box you lock with a key (き).

meaning.mnemonic: You request that winter rescue you from the warmth of the other seasons.

readings.mnemonic: You get a note in the mail from winter! This is it, you're going to be rescued! You open the note and it says, "I have rescued you with this cucumber (きゅう)." A cucumber falls out of the note.

meaning.mnemonic: A leader of (odd-looking) lions puts a drop of magic liquid on his face to look like a person resembles someone else. The leader of lions is going incognito, so he needs to resemble a person who is not himself. He takes this drop of powerful face paint and transforms.

readings.mnemonic: Now he resembles an even greater leader, and all the lions get down on one knee (に) to pay their respects.

meaning.mnemonic: On your roof is a scarecrow because you're rich. You want to scare away all the poor, non-rich people so you put a scarecrow on your roof.

readings.mnemonic: You wake up the next morning and all of your riches have been stolen! You call the police and they call you a fool (ふ)! Pardon me?! "You basically put an advertisement on your roof telling everyone you're rich. Of course you got robbed, you fool."

meaning.mnemonic: If you play blackjack on the moon in the winter, your cards will scatter everywhere. The cards scatter because the gravity is so weak on the moon, so the blackjack game is prone to disaster.

readings.mnemonic: You are playing blackjack with Santa-san (さん). Santa-san is doing his best to use his Christmas magic to prevent the scatter of cards, but it’s not working out so well. Good effort, Santa-san.

meaning.mnemonic: Flowers growing out of a rice paddy into the shape of a cross are really showy flowers.

readings.mnemonic: These flowers are too showy. You hate them. You hate these showy flowers so much you run them over with your car (か)!

meaning.mnemonic: You use your mouth when you see a Chinese person and you sigh. You sigh so loud that it’s practically a roar coming out of your mouth. Chinese people and Chinese things make you sigh because it reminds you of when you stayed in China and it brings up memories. The sigh is a sigh of nostalgia.

readings.mnemonic: Your favorite Chinese thing to do is tan (たん). You can wander around without your shirt on and tan all day. No one will sigh or scoff at you, it’s perfectly acceptable. The Chinese just love to get their tan on.

meaning.mnemonic: Your leader sticks his toe into a shellfish. You ask him why and he says he wants to spy on it.

readings.mnemonic: You and the leader review the spy footage and find a single tater (てい) tot hidden within the shellfish. Together you uncover a huge smuggling ring. Clams, oysters, muscles, you name it! Shellfish of all kinds are using their bodies to sneak tater tots to the undersea world.

meaning.mnemonic: If you can write an interesting poem about winter while riding on a horse, I’ll be pretty surprised. It’s hard enough to write a poem as it is, let alone an interesting one. And then you’re riding on a horse and the poem has to be about winter? Heck, I’d be surprised if you didn’t fall off the horse and injure yourself.

readings.mnemonic: You might also be surprised to learn that you are to ride this horse all across きょうと. That gives you a time limit. You have until you traverse きょうと to write this poem about winter.

meaning.mnemonic: Wolverine ties a towel around his forehead and takes out his fingers instead of his claws so he can sweep the floor clean. When Wolverine fights, his claws are out and he makes a big ol' mess. But once the fighting is done, it's time to get to work and sweep the mess up.

readings.mnemonic: Wolverine knows that sweeping is good for the soul (そう). Plus, if you don't help clean up after you defeat bad guys, you're just as bad as them. Sweeping up the mess cleans your soul of any guilt too!

meaning.mnemonic: You want some flowers so you take your cleat to the side of a tree hoping they'll fall down, but you get a vegetable instead. What? You kick the tree again and another, different vegetable falls out.

readings.mnemonic: You feed these vegetables (that you didn't even want) to your cyborg (さい). It only needs a little though, since its stomach is so thin, so you just make it hold the rest.

meaning.mnemonic: Under the moon while you sit on a cliff, you inject a syringe of tofu right into your vein. Ahh, tofu. You’re addicted to it. You sneak out to the cliff at night to get your tofu fix, injecting it straight into your vein.

readings.mnemonic: Eventually, your friends and family find you at the cliff, tripping on tofu. Each and every vein on your body is engorged, pulsating with the effects of tofu. Your friends try and take you home. “You cyan’t myake (みゃく) me!” you slur, suffering from the effects of the tofu. “None of you cyan myake me go home! You cyan’t myake me! Nyah!”

meaning.mnemonic: You're loitering, staring down at the cross that got caught in the net of your heart, because it's trying to teach you to act with virtue.

readings.mnemonic: As you try to decide if you want to live a life of virtue the ghost of Tokugawa (とく) Ieyasu appears before you. He points to your heart and the cross, then points to his own and you see a glowing cross in his own.

meaning.mnemonic: The warehouse radical and the warehouse kanji are the same!

readings.mnemonic: You have a warehouse to store all of your souls (そう). When people or animals you know pass away, you take their souls and store them in your dry warehouse for safekeeping. It's a public service, really.

meaning.mnemonic: Mix spiders into alcohol to make acid. Spiders have a little bit in them already, but if you really want to make it potent, smash them in some whiskey to make a deadly acid that will rip through anything.

readings.mnemonic: You're trying to find a container for this acid when Santa-san (さん) bursts through your wall. He frowns down at you. You're on the naughty list now. You killed spiders AND made dangerous acid? Ooooh you're in trouble.

meaning.mnemonic: A husband and his husband find a shellfish and agree to share it.

readings.mnemonic: Since the husbands were able to agree, Santa-san (さん) believes they’re both good husbands and belong on the good list. Therefore, Santa-san gives them each lots and lots of shellfish for Christmas.

meaning.mnemonic: You come across a spirit wearing a top hat and it claims to be your ancestor. Well of course, if you remember correctly, all of your ancestors wore top hats when they were alive. This spirit must be your long lost, great great... uh... somebody.

readings.mnemonic: You ask your ancestor what it wants and it points to the soap (そ) by the sink. Soap? It nods at you. I guess your ancestor is here to see the wonders of soap.

meaning.mnemonic: A gold bar can be turned into a coin. Well, more than one coin, probably. But you know for sure that you can make at least one coin out of this gold bar.

readings.mnemonic: You need this coin to give to a centaur (せん). The centaur is your bodyguard and he only accepts gold coins as payment.

meaning.mnemonic: A scooter sits at the entrance where people enter. You jump on and are flung inside! Because a lot of other people did the same thing, it's really crowded in here.

readings.mnemonic: Whoever came up with the scooter entrance idea, that made your favorite store so crowded? Only a 子 (こ) could come up with something like this. They don't really think about the dangers and legal implications of using a scooter to launch people into a crowded space.

meaning.mnemonic: If you want to go to Korea you'll need a good defense.

readings.mnemonic: You need a good defense to go to Korea, so you fill your pockets with acorns (えい). When you get to Korea you plant them all around yourself. In no time you'll have a strong tree defense, keeping you safe.

meaning.mnemonic: A tree combines with a table to make a desk. When you think about it, a desk is just a table with more stuff. To make this more stuff, like drawers and such, you need more wood, and wood comes from trees. Add materials from the tree to the table and you have a desk.

readings.mnemonic: When you finish the desk you turn to your friend and say, “It’s cool, eh (つくえ)?” Your friend looks at you and says, “S’coo’ eh? What?” “This desk, it’s cool. It’s cool, eh?” “Aw, yeah man. S’coo’ eh.”

meaning.mnemonic: A tsunami hits the ground, dumping all the muddy water onto this poor beggar, making him very dirty.

readings.mnemonic: The beggar sits up and sees how dirty his obi (お) is now and starts to cry. "Oh, my obi. My obi is all dirty, oh no!"

meaning.mnemonic: You eat part of a director to domesticate him. This director has been going around kicking cameramen and punching actors and it’s really ruining his reputation. You need to domesticate him. The only way to do this is to shock him into submission. His ego is so big from two blockbusters that you have to eat part of him to get him to calm down.

readings.mnemonic: While you did succeed in your attempt to domesticate the director, he is now bleeding profusely from the bite wound. All over the script! You gotta get your car (か) and drive him to the hospital like right away. Get to the car! Hurry!

meaning.mnemonic: Put a spirit in a black hole and a duplicate comes out. The duplicate looks exactly like the original spirit that went in. How strange.

readings.mnemonic: Suddenly the duplicate spirit starts yelling, "Why did you throw me into that black hole?! F*** (ふく) you!"

meaning.mnemonic: A tsunami runs into nine trees and produces a dye the color of the forest. The tsunami water mixes with each tree, nine of them actually, and the resulting liquid is a forest green dye.

readings.mnemonic: The dye continues to pass through the forest and hits a group of centaurs (せん). Now each centaur is dyed with the forest green dye. They don’t look happy.

meaning.mnemonic: Two pools, both altered and not quite like a pool you’ve seen before are put together and flipped around – this is an egg. One pool is the egg white, the other pool is the egg yolk. They’re different, but similar.

readings.mnemonic: You remember Tamagotchi (たまご), right? Well, Tamagotchi is an egg, and the toy looks like an egg, so it’s pretty easy to remember that tamago means egg.

meaning.mnemonic: The eternity radical and the eternity kanji are the same!

readings.mnemonic: How long is an eternity? Just look at this little acorn (えい) and ask. The acorn starts small but it grows into a huge tree and can live for all eternity by dropping more acorns to create more trees. Its acorn line will live on forever!

meaning.mnemonic: Taking a piece of thread you blame the exploits of your past on poor judgment. You tie this thread around your finger to remind you of all the exploits you accomplished in your day. Most of them weren’t actually on purpose, so you blame them on poor judgment and accident.

readings.mnemonic: One of your exploits was when you got dressed in the dark and were wearing funny clothes and everyone thought that it was sexy (せき). The newspapers and fashion agencies couldn’t get enough of your sexy style.

meaning.mnemonic: The eye's root is the eyeball.

readings.mnemonic: You know who has some pretty good eyeballs? Gandhi (がん). Gandhi used his eyes to see the oppression around him and decided to do something about it. But it's all thanks to his eyeballs.

meaning.mnemonic: A tsunami that hits at night leaves even more fluid than normal. It's dark at night, so the sun isn't there to help evaporate all that tsunami liquid.

readings.mnemonic: This fluid stays in the 駅 (えき) longer than anywhere else. All of those tsunami liquids pour deep inside the 駅 late at night and the sun still can't reach them to help evaporate them during the day. It's a real *night*mare.

meaning.mnemonic: Take your fingers and dig the tree bits out of this cleat to gather it into evidence. Gather it in a pile or a bag, just make sure it's all in one place so you can take a closer look later.

readings.mnemonic: You gather them all together and realize there are cyborg (さい) parts mixed in with the tree bits. Uh oh, it's as you feared. Your cyborg definitely got into trouble somewhere around here and you walked all over it with your cleats.

meaning.mnemonic: If you can understand a samurai's heart, you'll discover their true intentions.

readings.mnemonic: You try to read the intentions of the samurai in front of you and they're dark, evil, scary. Oh no! These are the intentions of the sheep (し) samurai!

meaning.mnemonic: There’s a comb and what looks like the same comb, and you found them on the ground next to some fins you showed interest in. At first, the shiny fins on the ground caught your interest, but once you got closer to the fins you also noticed a pair of combs that are interesting too.

readings.mnemonic: Since the combs interest you more than the fins, you examine the combs more closely. Taking interest in where they were made, you discover they were made in きょうと. Dang, きょうと sure does make some nice combs.

meaning.mnemonic: If you have a big mouth but a good heart, people will recognize your kindness. Even if you blabber on with your big mouth, as long as everyone knows that your heart is filled with kindness, they will love and accept you.

readings.mnemonic: To further show your kindness, you chop up some onions (おん) for a friend who always cries when they chop onions. The onions make you cry too, so it’s a nice act of kindness that you’re toughing it out for your pal.

meaning.mnemonic: If you use a slide to enter a building, you'll be sliding for a long time.

readings.mnemonic: You slide for such a long time that you get hungry. Luckily, once in a while a cucumber (きゅう) comes tumbling down the slide next to you.

meaning.mnemonic: A Viking and his older brother join a party. They can raid and pillage better in a group like this, so it makes sense that the Viking and his older brother would join a group with other Vikings.

readings.mnemonic: This party has decided to raid とうきょう. It’s a large undertaking, but they have a large group of Vikings on the job. とうきょう doesn’t stand a chance.

meaning.mnemonic: If the canopy comes beforehand, it's a preface for the rest of the canopy.

readings.mnemonic: You read the preface. It just goes on and on and on about Jo-Anne (じょ), a short lady the author loves very much.

meaning.mnemonic: You count nine of them in the tree, each turkey holding something random or miscellaneous. There are nine turkeys in the tree and they’re all holding random, miscellaneous things. How odd.

readings.mnemonic: As if things couldn’t get any more random, Zazu (ざつ) from the Lion King flies into the tree and starts asking the nine turkeys miscellaneous trivia. Zazu always did have a thirst for knowledge, but this is kind of strange.

meaning.mnemonic: Under a tree sitting on the grass is a woman who loves sakura, or cherry tree, if you’re an English speaker. This woman really likes to just chill out in the grass under these cherry trees and watch the sakura blossoms. It’s very pretty.

readings.mnemonic: How do you say cherry tree in Japanese? Sakura (さくら). Sakura is Japanese for cherry tree. I’m sure you’ve probably heard this before, so it shouldn’t be too hard to remember.

meaning.mnemonic: The roof of a certain mountain shrouds its contents in secrecy.

readings.mnemonic: This secrecy is so secret that the people who know about it wear magical mitts (みつ) of secrecy that make it so we can't tell anyone, no matter what.

meaning.mnemonic: A grain is certain to keep a secret.

readings.mnemonic: If someone finds out your secret (not from the grain though, it will certainly keep it) then your entire face will fill with heat (ひ).

meaning.mnemonic: If you see a grassy cliff with an elf under it in winter, it's because their parents are so strict. When elf kids misbehave they're supposed to go stand under grassy cliffs to think about what they've done.

readings.mnemonic: One of the strict parents of this elf kid is... Genji (げん)?! Looks like he had another illegitimate kid... this time with an elf.

meaning.mnemonic: When you're at your cottage the only thing you do with your fingers is throw away things. The cottage is for vacation. And vacation means being as lazy as possible. But you certainly don't want to live in filth, so you have to throw away your trash at least.

readings.mnemonic: The number one thing you throw away while in your cottage is your suit (す). Suits just don't fit the cottage life vibe, man.

meaning.mnemonic: They say a shrimp who is bad with translation has no reason to live. Most shrimp make a living with their translation skills. They are the translators of the ocean. If they don’t know how to say something in all the languages of the sea, they have no reason to live. They might as well be dead.

readings.mnemonic: The translation this shrimp failed to make was for the word “yak” (やく). The shrimp found no reason to translate yak because there are no yak in the sea and then the shrimp just started questioning everything in his life and fell apart.

meaning.mnemonic: In the valley you feel a lack of want. You want for nothing in this valley. It is the valley of plenty.

readings.mnemonic: Once you get to the valley, you want some protein. Egg yolk (よく) falls from the sky! It’s a miracle! You wanted protein, and egg yolk was presented. It falls right into your open mouth.

meaning.mnemonic: You're in the sun playing football and you get very warm.

readings.mnemonic: It's warm like this because it's dawn (だん). That's when the sun comes up.

meaning.mnemonic: In its scooter, a cat pirate scoots up to welcome you!

readings.mnemonic: The cat pirate then launches into a speech about how they welcome all kinds of people. Especially gay (げい) people. He puts a certain emphasis on gay, so you figure that the cat pirate either thinks you're gay or wants you to be.

meaning.mnemonic: If a leader has a gun it's easy to wound people. When you have a gun and a lot of responsibility it's easy to get carried away and mess up, wounding the people you were supposed to be protecting. You can even wound yourself.

readings.mnemonic: Which leader wounded the Japanese people? The Shougun (しょう). The Shougun is a military leader. The Shougun even has gun in the name. And they wounded hundreds of thousands of samurai and soldiers.

meaning.mnemonic: On a cliff, a fire burns to ashes. The ashes then blow off the cliff, and follow the wind wherever it may go.

readings.mnemonic: The ashes inspire you to write a haiku (はい). Using the ashes you write a haiku on a rock for everyone to enjoy.

meaning.mnemonic: If you see icicles hanging off of a samurai's clothes, don't worry, those are just part of his winter attire. Samurai have to travel and fight in all sorts of conditions, so it only makes sense that they have attire for every season.

readings.mnemonic: Attire like this is important because it reflects your soul (そう). The samurai is wearing clothing with icicles because that's how his heart feels too: frozen over because he has to fight in this horrible winter weather.

meaning.mnemonic: If someone is holding flowers, they're probably an author. Authors really love flowers, because they help them think of flowery language they can use to sound smart in their books.

readings.mnemonic: Unfortunately, the author is allergic to flowers. They are only allergic to touching them though, so the author is holding the flowers with a pair of chopsticks (ちょ), really close to their face. Using the chopsticks, they can still use the flowers to think of fancy, author-ly words without touching them.

meaning.mnemonic: There's a lid on your village, so you kick it over on its backside to see what's on its underside.

readings.mnemonic: It turns out your village's own backside is covered in uranium (うら). Eureka! You're all gonna be rich!

meaning.mnemonic: The gate to the genius is now closed. The genius’ visiting hours are over, so the gate is closed. This genius has been genetically modified to know more than any human could know, and his days are spent answering questions and advising. But now, his work day is over, so his gates are closed.

readings.mnemonic: On the other side of the closed gates there is still a line of people that want the genius's advice. They decide to keep waiting until morning and gather together some hay (へい) so that sleeping outside won't be so awful.

meaning.mnemonic: You keep your moon weapon in your crotch. Where else would you keep it?

readings.mnemonic: Your crotch has a moon weapon, and it's served you well, so you hope that if you have a 子  (こ) one day, they'll have one too.

meaning.mnemonic: This car is all weird because it looks like the side is going to dangle and drip off or something. The front bumper of the car is dangling off and the sides of the car look like they could drip off at any moment.

readings.mnemonic: You see the parts as they dangle off the car and you get an idea. You could probably swing (すい) on these dangling parts. The parts can probably take some weight still before they drip off the car, so you might as well swing around on them while you still can.

meaning.mnemonic: A tsunami hits the greenhouse, destroying the last remaining plant life in the area. The tsunami recedes, and there is nothing but sand, and the lands become a desert.

readings.mnemonic: See the sun come up over the desert, then go back (ばく) down. Up, back down, back up, back down. You stand here for days watching because you're so depressed. Stop being so vague in your approach, sun! You’re weirding everyone out!

meaning.mnemonic: Put a rice paddy together with other paddies and you'll see how much they differ. When you're driving or taking a train through the countryside it may seem like all of those rice paddies blurring together are all the same, but they can differ quite a bit!

readings.mnemonic: To see how rice paddies differ, you need an eagle's (い) eye view. It can be hard to see from the ground, so soar up into the sky like an eagle and look down at the rice paddies together.

meaning.mnemonic: Social commentary aside, the white king is the king that wears all white. Traditionally, this is someone better than a king. The emperor!

readings.mnemonic: Who is the emperor? It is こういち. こういち the emperor stands over his subjects.

meaning.mnemonic: To make your fingers wide you extend them.

readings.mnemonic: As you extend your fingers a cock (かく) comes running by and runs straight into them. Bu-COCK!

meaning.mnemonic: Use a flag to compare your flatulence.

readings.mnemonic: If your flatulence is really strong, you may need to get help (へ).

meaning.mnemonic: A greenhouse is already really good when it comes to a plant's livelihood. But add the sun into that equation and you have something really great for the plants. Their livelihood will be awesome, now!

readings.mnemonic: From out of nowhere, Bobo (ぼ) the notorious clown thief starts picking the plants, ending their livelihood. Bobo needs the flowers for his clown acts, so he uses the livelihood of the flowers to support his own livelihood.

meaning.mnemonic: Those that are in the middle of your heart are the ones you have the most loyalty towards. The middle of your heart is the most sacred, special place for people, so it makes sense that those you keep in the middle of your heart are those you are most loyal to.

readings.mnemonic: You pictured Chewbacca (ちゅう), didn’t you? No? Well you should have. Chewbacca deserves everyone’s loyalty. Chewbacca is super loyal to you, so he deserves your loyalty back.

meaning.mnemonic: There is a moon and a city inside your lung. Inside of your lung there is a city and above that city lies a moon. It’s a pretty sight, but also very strange. Moons and cities don’t usually reside inside lungs.

readings.mnemonic: Having a moon and city inside your lung inspires you to write a haiku (はい). Perhaps the city and moon are just metaphorical. Either way, a haiku is the best way to go about things here.

meaning.mnemonic: To say what's in a samurai's heart you start a magazine. You go around writing about and interviewing all the samurai so you can share what they say to everyone who wants to read!

readings.mnemonic: Unfortunately, your magazine helps the sheep (し) samurai find other samurai... and kill them. None of the samurai want to share their feelings with your magazine anymore, oh no!

meaning.mnemonic: If someone has their fingers in your syrup, it's just another way of saying they manipulated you. Cause only slimy people manipulate other people, so their fingers are slimy and sticky because they're covered in your syrup from mucking up your life.

readings.mnemonic: If you want to manipulate someone else it's going to have a permanent effect on your soul (そう). Being manipulative isn't cool. And your soul will suffer forever for it.

meaning.mnemonic: This bamboo absorbed the moon's power, and you want that power in your body, so you surgically insert them into your body to replace your muscles and tendons.

readings.mnemonic: Your special muscles and tendons have become famous and the King (きん) of England has requested that you appear in his court! It looks like he wants you to teach his barber surgeons how you got your new muscles.

meaning.mnemonic: The Not Mouth says “no”. What else would you expect from something named the “Not Mouth”? The Not Mouth will always say “no”, regardless of the question.

readings.mnemonic: You ask the Not Mouth if it is afraid of heat (ひ). The Not Mouth says, “no”. So you set the Not Mouth on fire. The Not Mouth then screams, “NONONONONONONONONONOOOOOO~!” Looks like someone can’t handle the heat.

meaning.mnemonic: If you become a plate, I will pile food up upon you. With such a huge pile, everyone will think you're prosperous.

readings.mnemonic: You're so prosperous you use your saber (せい) to cut the food pile and shove the bits into your plate mouth. In fact, your entire family is using your special saber to cut and eat off of you. A normal knife wouldn't be able to get through all this food!

meaning.mnemonic: Someone climbs onto the roof from the ground when dawn comes to proclaim that a new day has begun! They proclaim this at the top of their lungs!

readings.mnemonic: The thing that climbs up on the roof to proclaim that the new day is here is a centaur (せん). Ohoho, did you think I was going to say it was a rooster? Wrong! Centaurs are taller than humans and roosters, so when they climb onto the roof with their horse legs they can see dawn starting before anyone else.

meaning.mnemonic: The leader who is king of every shellfish sets the rent for everyone. If you rent a home in King Shellfish's kingdom, the rent will be set by the great shellfish leader himself.

readings.mnemonic: If you don't have enough shellfish to pay your rent, King Shellfish will punch you in the chin (ちん).

meaning.mnemonic: Writing a poem about winter is the only way to get respect from other poets.

readings.mnemonic: Once you have their respect you get cake (けい)!

meaning.mnemonic: The horns of the creatures who drink alcohol have a measurement so large that they are revered the world over. The horns are revered both for their size and potency. The horns can be used in medicine, so they are very valuable, those alcoholic monster horns.

readings.mnemonic: The reason you are interested in these revered horns so much is that your son (そん) is sick and you need one of these revered horns to make a medicine for your son. Only with the revered power of the horns will you be able to save your son’s life.

meaning.mnemonic: You lay your sock in a little circle and boil it so it will ripen.

readings.mnemonic: You take your ripened sock, and throw it at your worst enemy! But they juke (じゅく) out of the way, and throw a ripened pair of socks at you! You manage to juke too, but they're already preparing what looks like some very ripe underpants.

meaning.mnemonic: Your mouth has some hidden horns, and if you have the right alcohol measurement in your body, those horns will come out of your mouth in the form of rumors and gossip.

readings.mnemonic: When you start to tell a rumor or spread gossip, you're a little drunk, so you slur you words. "Ooo I saw (うわさ)..." is how you start every rumor. It's got some southern drawl to it almost (Uuuwahsahw).

meaning.mnemonic: If you grind a stone down to more than just a few pieces, it will become sand. Stones that get broken up enough will become sand, and you pick up a few grains in your hand.

readings.mnemonic: What’s in your hand? A few grains of sand (さ)! Sand, sand, sand!

meaning.mnemonic: Keeping at a bamboo interval is the definition of simplicity.

readings.mnemonic: Simplicity is what Genghis Khan (かん) always demanded. Everything he decided was based on simplicity.

meaning.mnemonic: If you take the flowers off some coral and boil them, steam comes out.

readings.mnemonic: As you watch the steam coming off the coral flowers, someone appears behind you. It is Jourm (じょう), the big farmhand. "Are you steaming coral?" he asks. "Smelled it a mile away. I love crunching me some coral."

meaning.mnemonic: The storehouse radical and the storehouse kanji meanings are the same. If you know the radical, you know the kanji!

readings.mnemonic: You have a storehouse. Inside is where you keep all your zombies (ぞう).

meaning.mnemonic: Bring rice under a canopy, crush it with your brush, and sweep the white powder in your mouth... it's sugar now! You make sugar by carefully crushing rice to a powder, until it's small enough to brush into your mouth.

readings.mnemonic: You learned how to make sugar in とうきょう. You found a special とうきょう sugar sensei and they introduced you to all of the secret methods you know now.

meaning.mnemonic: The thread you have inside is your whole supply. When you're outside sewing and you run out, you just go inside, look through your supply, and pick a new one.

readings.mnemonic: You have this supply because Nostradamus (のう) had a prediction, saying you would. And that if you didn't keep a good supply of thread inside, you'd run out.

meaning.mnemonic: They say someone with various talents is important. Various talents can include speaking various languages so if you are someone who knows various languages you can say things that various peoples will comprehend.

readings.mnemonic: You’re so good at speaking various languages that you decide to put on a show (しょ). At the show, you say a lot of things in various languages and everyone is impressed.

meaning.mnemonic: The hole leading to the private heart of your house is the window. Or maybe it's just the window to your soul, and not your house. Like the poetry people say.

readings.mnemonic: You realize that a ton of people are looking into your window and seeing all your private things. This makes you mad (まど)! What right do they have to know your private thoughts and desires?!

meaning.mnemonic: The beans radical and the beans kanji are exactly the same!

readings.mnemonic: These beans are from とうきょう. Everybody knows とうきょう has the best beans. What?! You didn’t know that? Tokyo’s beans are the best beans!

meaning.mnemonic: A tree branch is exactly what it sounds like: the branch of a tree.

readings.mnemonic: Take this branch and give it to a sheep (し). Sheep are like dogs, they like to play fetch with tree branches. And now you're playing fetch with this sheep and this branch.

meaning.mnemonic: You stand on the forehead of your car, take your fingers and brandish them in the air! You wave them around for everyone to see.

readings.mnemonic: What are you brandishing in your fingers? Your car's key (き)! You want every driver and every car to know that you aren't going to be driving ever again!

meaning.mnemonic: A slice with a knife is called a carve.

readings.mnemonic: You work up a sweat trying to carve meat and wood all day, so you grab yourself a nice Coke (こく). You like Coke, and it goes well with meat and sawdust.

meaning.mnemonic: The claw radical and the claw kanji are exactly the same! Ravishing!

readings.mnemonic: You’ve got not one tumor (つま), but too many (つめ) tumors and you need to claw them out with your sharp claw. One tumor is one tumor too many. Cut them out with your claw!

meaning.mnemonic: A child will ask if they want two waters because they need a grown-up's consent. Children aren't allowed to have whatever they want, they need to make sure it's okay and get consent first.

readings.mnemonic: "Of course my child, you have my consent," comes the voice of the Shougun (しょう). The Shougun is very pleased by this child, because he expects everyone to ask for consent around him.

meaning.mnemonic: Your mouth was sliced open by a terrible cough.

readings.mnemonic: Oddly enough, some people find your cough sexy (せき).

meaning.mnemonic: Hang a towel in a greenhouse and it turns into a curtain. Greenhouses are made of windows, it's all glass, there are no walls. So when you put a towel in there it turns into a curtain. It has no choice but to cover a window, after all.

readings.mnemonic: You're hanging these towel curtains because you need a quiet place to eat a Big Mac (まく). But you're a little ashamed. Big macs aren't really good for you, but this stupid greenhouse has too many windows and everyone can see you stuff your face. So that's where the towel curtains come in.

meaning.mnemonic: In this construction project, they will be using thread to hold everything together. The color of the thread is a deep red, and it gives everything a crimson look.

readings.mnemonic: You're done, and the whole building is a deep red crimson color (it takes a lot of thread to hold a whole building in place). It's time to show the client, Emperor こういち, the finished product.

meaning.mnemonic: An arrow is what this turkey lacks. For a turkey, that is a delight.

readings.mnemonic: Delight is what Genghis Khan (かん) felt when he saw his turkey friend, sans an arrow.

meaning.mnemonic: Inside the building is the Winter Cow. You need to see it, so you go inside. It is deep down in there, and you'll have to descend to reach it.

readings.mnemonic: You descend to the bottom and there it is, the Winter Cow. You walk up to the cow, and it swings its head back to see you. Instead of a cow's face, it's こういち's face.

meaning.mnemonic: The woman sitting on that stool is actually a dude. Oh oops! You thought he was a woman because of his long hair and the way he was sitting. Maybe you shouldn't be judging people based on their looks!

readings.mnemonic: You only found out this dude wasn't a woman when a dog ど ran up and the dude stood up. He started rubbing the dog's face saying, "Who's a good boy? Who's a good boy? Not you! Me! I'm the best boy of them all. Because I am a dude, the best of all boys! HAHAHAHA!"

meaning.mnemonic: The ear and the mouth of a king are holy. The king has holy hearing and holy eating abilities. This king is divine.

readings.mnemonic: This holy king has heard of you and your special saber (せい) that glows with pure, blue light. Specifically, the holy king wants to use it on his food!

meaning.mnemonic: If a turkey is pointing its fingers at you, you can infer that it wants revenge. This turkey knows you killed his brother for dinner last night, and now he’s going to make you pay. You infer that this turkey is going to take their fingers and wrap them around your neck.

readings.mnemonic: You were able to infer the turkey's plan, so now it's your turn. You look around and see the only way out... is to swing (すい) to safety! How did I infer that, dear Watson? Why, isn't it obvious! There are vines here. Turkeys can't fly. So I shall swing my way to freedom!

meaning.mnemonic: Your moon storehouse is another storehouse you own. Remember how your regular storehouse holds zombies (from the kanji 蔵?). Your moon storehouse is on the moon, and it is filled with internal organs.

readings.mnemonic: Where did you get all these internal organs from? You actually harvested them from the zombies (ぞう) from your other storehouse.

meaning.mnemonic: Raise your fingers to another member and you'll receive a loss in return. You should never hurt a member of your team, group, or society. It's just wrong. And you'll incur a loss as punishment for your bad deeds.

readings.mnemonic: Unfortunately for you, payment is in the form of the loss of your son (そん). The loss of any family member is horrible, but this was your son. He was your favorite child. You loved him. But that's the loss you must bear for raising your fingers to a team member.

meaning.mnemonic: Seeing a stone and some horns on the ground next to a piece of poop and another piece of poop, you try and pick each of them up with a magnet. The magnet fails to pick up either piece of poop. The magnet doesn’t pick up the horns either. But wait! The magnet picks up the stone!

readings.mnemonic: You’re pretty excited that you lifted something up with your magnet. Science is cool! But then you hear someone laughing behind you. It’s Jesus (じ)! Jesus was using his magic to levitate the stone all along, it wasn’t your magnet. Darn it Jesus! You’ve fooled me for the last time!

meaning.mnemonic: They say accidentally firing a catapult is an unforgivable mistake. They say you shot the catapult at your own castle. Even though it was an accident, it’s still a mistake you will never be forgiven for.

readings.mnemonic: This mistake alerts Godzilla (ご), who thinks it's town destroying time. He barrels over the hills, sees where you mistakenly catapulted your own people, and proceeds to stomp on the rest of it for you.

meaning.mnemonic: The original tsunami was the origin of Japan. A big tsunami came and uncovered the islands of Japan. It's the origin of all life, as far as Japanese people are concerned.

readings.mnemonic: This tsunami was also the origin of Genji (げん), from "The Tale of Genji." Just think, without this origin, Japan wouldn't exist and neither would the first Japanese heartthrob, Genji!

meaning.mnemonic: If you see some dry flowers, pull them up and you'll find a potato.

readings.mnemonic: Potatoes are totally emo (いも) because of the way they dry out flowers. Emo people and potatoes both like to dry out flowers.

meaning.mnemonic: Make your barracks out of thread so it will be pure. If you build it out of clay or bricks or wood, it will inevitably have some dirt in it. Build it out of thread to keep it pure of... well, impurities.

readings.mnemonic: This pure thread barracks can only be used in June (じゅん), unfortunately. Any other time of year there will be snow and rain and mud and that will get tracked into the pure barracks and ruin them. But June is the cleanest, most pure month, so you can use it then.

meaning.mnemonic: You want some flowers to put on the canopy above your helicopter to keep the birds away, so you ask people what they would recommend.

readings.mnemonic: You ask for a recommendation from the centaur (せん) that owns the local flower shop. Now he's walking around your helicopter canopy and staring at the birds, nodding.

meaning.mnemonic: Into a well, a drop of rice falls from your rice bowl. You were eating out of your rice bowl on the side of a well, and some rice fell out of your rice bowl and this drop of rice proceeded to fall all the way down.

readings.mnemonic: Just then, the don (どん) of your local mafia shows up, steals your rice bowl, and shoves you into the well. You’d gotten on the don’s bad side, so he came to teach you a lesson. The don steals your rice bowl and shoves you into the well.

meaning.mnemonic: Attach meat to your canopy and it will rot.

readings.mnemonic: You let meat rot. You're a fool (ふ). That's really all I can say at this point.

meaning.mnemonic: There's a tsunami coming, so you put your fins on, open your mouth wide, and try to run alongside it.

readings.mnemonic: You're able to run alongside the tsunami for about ten seconds before everything ends (えん).

meaning.mnemonic: You need to take a body measurement before you can shoot. Whether it's for a photo shoot, you're gonna shoot them with a gun, or if you're about to shoot them full of radiation for X-rays, you need the right measurements of that body first.

readings.mnemonic: This shoot is being done by a shaman (しゃ). Not only is he doing the body measurements for the shoot, but he's also going to be shooting you with a shot so you don't get the flu.

meaning.mnemonic: A magic thread fell from the roof onto the leader of a hundred people, causing him to shrink!

readings.mnemonic: As the leader shrinks, the hundred people start screaming and running around the entire place. As a result, everything is shook (しゅく) up. Especially the poor, shrunken leader, who gets knocked around the most.

meaning.mnemonic: The samurai has a jackhammer, a brush, and some water. All these things tell you that this samurai is actually a slave.

readings.mnemonic: You don't like seeing a slave. As you walk by, you hand him a ray (れい) gun so he can free himself.

meaning.mnemonic: There’s some rice in the shape of a nine on a cross and this is stylish. The rice grains are arranged to form the number nine. This number nine is prominently displayed on the cross, and it’s stylish to carry it around and be seen with it.

readings.mnemonic: It’s also stylish to swing (すい) the cross around while you wait for things. You’re waiting at a bus stop so you swing the cross around violently. You swing it so violently that the rice comes flying off!

meaning.mnemonic: You are so sick that you've come to look like the humble stool: thin. Eerily thin, in fact.

readings.mnemonic: When you're this thin, your soul (そう) is visible from outside of your body too.

meaning.mnemonic: If you put dirt in your mouth you're going to throw up. That's just a fact.

readings.mnemonic: When you throw up it sounds like you're shouting, "HA (は)!" Then all the dirt-puke comes out in a wave. It's less of a laugh ha and more of an oh no I'm throwing up ha.

meaning.mnemonic: In the middle of the ground is a shellfish that is very valuable. Inside of this valuable shellfish is a priceless treasure, and it’s just lying there in the middle of the ground.

readings.mnemonic: You want to get the valuable thing from inside the shellfish, but it's locked and you need to find the key (き). Search for the key!

meaning.mnemonic: You see a thread that wants to loiter from some horns and you would be correct to assume that it would hang vertical. The thread wants to loiter and hang from one of the horns. When things hang from things, they usually hang vertical, so that’s what this thread is going to do.

readings.mnemonic: For some reason, Channing Tatum (たて) is strangely attracted to vertical pieces of hanging thread. Channing Tatum starts batting at the vertical thread like a cat.

meaning.mnemonic: Boots give you the power to work! That's why so many professions require you to have work boots.

readings.mnemonic: You need boots to give you the power to work for the King (きん) of England. Really, all work is for the King, since everything is for him. But even he wears boots. And they give him the power to uh... king over things.

meaning.mnemonic: Take your fingers and dry them. Then dry them again. This is what you do when you are in  worship. Once you go into your place of worship, and again before you leave. You have really sweaty fingers, and you can't worship anyone or anything if you have wet hands. So you dry them!

readings.mnemonic: Once you're dry and in wherever your worship is, you begin with a haiku (はい). Really all places of worship have their own version of the haiku, and heck, the 5-7-5 rule is just a guideline, so everyone is doing it pretty close to right anyway.

meaning.mnemonic: The ability to boil is one of the main abilities of a bear.

readings.mnemonic: A bear boiling in front of you should fill you with great honor. Or, as they say in Latin: Magma cum (くま) laude.

meaning.mnemonic: Your mouth is wearing a mask so people won't realize you're the one being so boisterous. You want to be loud and rowdy, but you don't want anyone to know it's you. If you cover your mouth with this mask, people won't know you're the one being so boisterous.

readings.mnemonic: You're being anonymously boisterous outside when suddenly someone shoves soap (そ) in your mouth! "I don't know who you are, but you're much too boisterous! Wash your mouth out with that soap!" they yell.

meaning.mnemonic: There is a circumference around someone's hair, as in, you can see a circle drawn around the top of their head. As you examine it closer, and pull at it a bit, you realize that someone has carved the hair off someone's head!

readings.mnemonic: When you think of all the people who could have done this... all the people who could have carved out someone's hair, only one person comes to mind, and that is Mrs. Chou (ちょう). She's the only person evil enough to do something like this.

meaning.mnemonic: There’s a tree in your hair, I think it’s a cedar. How did that cedar tree get in your hair?

readings.mnemonic: Once the cedar is fully grown, you use the cedar wood to make a guitar for Sue. A Sue guitar (すぎ), if you will. This Sue guitar was made just for Sue. She’ll love it.

meaning.mnemonic: The mouth of the World Tree, all it does is chat and talk.

readings.mnemonic: To chat or talk with the World Tree, just head over to Shaman Bay (しゃべ).

meaning.mnemonic: Gold is not the same as copper. They are two different metals. Gold is not the same as copper.

readings.mnemonic: Smashing the copper against the gold has made you tired. You should eat a doughnut (どう). Go get yourself a doughnut.

meaning.mnemonic: The kanji and the radical that look like this are exactly the same. They are both cottage.

readings.mnemonic: You got this cottage from a shaman (しゃ). In fact, everyone you know got their cottage from a shaman. One day you're just walking in the woods, and the next thing you know, a shaman is giving you the keys to their old cottage.

meaning.mnemonic: You have an alcohol nine times stronger than any other drink in a bottle shaped like a cross and you drink it all and become drunk. You’re like, so drunk right now from all that alcohol. Nine times more drunk than ever before.

readings.mnemonic: If you drink so much that you become drunk, then your alcohol will begin to taste like water. What is the reading of 水? It's すい, which is the reading for this kanji.

meaning.mnemonic: Fire, fire, flame! There’s flames everywhere!

readings.mnemonic: The flames gets bigger, surround you, and then everything ends (えん).

meaning.mnemonic: If you loiter around my skin, he will get angry at you. He is my boyfriend and he is very protective of me. So don’t loiter around my skin for too long or he will beat you up.

readings.mnemonic: He says the only way he will stop beating you up is if you give him some curry (かれ). You give him some curry.

meaning.mnemonic: You create a thread with someone by calling out to them to introduce yourself.

readings.mnemonic: You want to introduce yourself to the Shougun (しょう) but no matter how much you call out, he won't come close enough for you to tie your introduction thread to him. You call louder and louder, "SHOUGUN LET ME INTRODUCE MYSELF!"

meaning.mnemonic: The jammed in radical and the jammed in kanji are the same!

readings.mnemonic: Look down! You're jammed into something. You can't move your feet. What is this?! Oh, your body's been jammed in a kayak (かい).

meaning.mnemonic: The tsunamis during the old moons (many moons ago) were responsible for the world's lakes.

readings.mnemonic: "That's where lakes come from," you tell the 子 (こ).

meaning.mnemonic: Try to say something to a lifeguard and you'll just end up getting a lecture.

readings.mnemonic: This lecture loving lifeguard is none other than こういち! I mean, look how long winded the stuff on this site is? Can you imagine him trying to give you a talk about proper swimming etiquette?

meaning.mnemonic: In spring, your measurements will reveal your lifespan. Only in spring can you measure your lifespan, just as easily as you measure your height and weight.

readings.mnemonic: If your lifespan measurement isn't as long as you'd like, you need to drink more small juice (じゅ) boxes this year. They're good for your health, after all!

meaning.mnemonic: A tsunami will pick up a bunch of shellfish and dump them on your shore, so you take a knife and measure them.

readings.mnemonic: All of the shellfish you measure that are too small go into your sock (そく). Once the sock is full, you swing it around your head and lob it back into the ocean.

meaning.mnemonic: The ground and a shuriken have mutual respect for one another. The shuriken respects the ground because of how solid and stable it is, and the ground respects the shuriken for how pointy it is. They have great mutual respect here.

readings.mnemonic: Since you made the shuriken attack the ground, the mutual respect is out of balance. This summons Godzilla (ご) up from the depths of the ocean once more. He always shows up when something is out of wack, to show humans the error of their ways. He picks up the shuriken and flings it into a city, which explodes, leaving a crater in the ground.

meaning.mnemonic: This tsunami is the reason we have so much oil now. The tsunami moved a bunch of earth out of the way, so now it’s really easy to dig for oil. Thanks tsunami!

readings.mnemonic: Now that oil is so abundant, everyone lives in yurts (ゆ). They're light and mobile, so people can just move from oil well to oil well, collecting oil.

meaning.mnemonic: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for oneself first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means oneself as well.

readings.mnemonic: Oneself. Who only thinks of oneself? Every 子 (こ) in the world.

meaning.mnemonic: Your fingers are private, no one can see them unless they pay! And you decide if what they pay is enough to get a peek.

readings.mnemonic: If someone tries to look without paying, that's harassment (はら)! Nobody gets to see something of yours without proper payment, but more importantly, your consent!

meaning.mnemonic: A gold man has one mustache above his lip and one mustache below his lip and keeps all his extra mustaches safely tucked away in a pot. This man is made of gold and has a lot of money. That’s how he can afford to groom two mustaches at the same time. If anything should happen to one, he has plenty of back up mustaches in his mustache storage pot.

readings.mnemonic: The mustachioed man’s wife asks if he loves his pot of mustaches more than he loves her. “Nah babe (なべ),” he says. “Nah, babe. Nah.”

meaning.mnemonic: You have an animal and you say it’s a dog to prevent it from going to prison. Dogs are the only animals that don’t have to go to prison. Your animal is not a dog, but you say it is to prevent it from going to prison.

readings.mnemonic: What is the name of your animal? Your animal is named Goku (ごく). Yeah, like Goku from Dragon Ball Z. You don’t want your little Goku to go to prison, so you say that he’s a dog.

meaning.mnemonic: There's a slide with a drunkard above it, and they're making you feel small. And the worst part is that the drunkard is one of your relatives.

readings.mnemonic: As if things couldn't get worse, your relative seems to think they're sexy (せき) when they're on the slide drunk. Sexy? More like irresponsible!

meaning.mnemonic: The sake radical and the sake kanji are exactly the same! Sweet.

readings.mnemonic: For the sake of convenience, companies will use eagles (い) for delivery jobs in the future. Just put in an order, and it'll be at your doorstep in no time flat. Eagles are like, super fast at delivery.

meaning.mnemonic: Your ear listens to your heart and feels shame. Your heart is full of shame for how you’ve lived your life and when your ear hears all the things you’ve done, your ear feels shame too.

readings.mnemonic: You must cleanse your spirit of this shame. You decide to complete Haj (はじ). (Haj is the fifth pillar of Islam, and is a pilgrimage to Mecca during the month of Dhu al-Hijja). Upon arrival in Mecca, you think of a funny joke and bust out laughing. “HAHAHAHAHAHA!! (は) HAHAHAHAHA!!!” Oh man, you’re in a temple and that was completely inappropriate. You feel even more shame than before.

meaning.mnemonic: Next to the scooter, there's a flag warning you that there are sheep around here, so you should go slow. That means you might be late, but at least the sheep will be okay!

readings.mnemonic: You follow the flag, but the sheep refuse to slow down so you have to get creative. You place cheese (ち) every ten feet or so, that way the sheep slow down to bend down on their scooters and take a bite.

meaning.mnemonic: A tsunami carries a cross into your soup. Hey tsunami, I was eating that soup!

readings.mnemonic: You pull the cross out of your soup and see that the cross' jewels (じゅう) fell off and are in there now. The jewels sparkle, shine, and dissolve into the soup!

meaning.mnemonic: The commander's alcohol is really just soy sauce. When he goes out to drink with his troops and they all get drunk together, he manages to have fun and stay sober by drinking down a tasty, non-alcoholic pint of soy sauce.

readings.mnemonic: Soy sauce also happens to be the Shougun's (しょう) favorite drink. Unfortunately, he can't just tell people he likes drinking glasses of soy sauce, or they'll look at him weird. Instead he orders it as a commander's alcohol too.

meaning.mnemonic: A tsunami, once stopped by a belt, will begin to stagnate. This belt is a belt of water resistance, so the belt stops the tsunami. The belt has caused the tsunami to stagnate.

readings.mnemonic: While you watch the tsunami stagnate, you get ready for work. While you were watching this whole thing happening, you were tying your tie (たい). Once the tsunami stagnated, you were all done tying your tie. And since the tsunami is no longer a threat, you’re ready to go to work.

meaning.mnemonic: Tie a squid to a knife and you get a sword! Knives are too small to be considered a sword on their own. That's why you strapped a squid to it. They're the right shape, kinda pointed, so no one will know it's just a knife.

readings.mnemonic: You learned how to make swords this way from Ken (けん) the samurai. He put his own little squid buddy on his knife and now no one realizes it's not a sword!

meaning.mnemonic: If you scrape a sharp stone against your skin, it will tear. The sharp stone tears your skin. It hurts!

readings.mnemonic: The moment your skin tears you can't help but yelp "Ha (は)!" It sounds like a laugh, but it's more like a pained bark.

meaning.mnemonic: The turtle radical and the turtle kanji are exactly the same! Nice!

readings.mnemonic: You know Dragon Ball Z, right? Imagine this turtle doing a Kamehameha (かめ). The turtle charges up his energy and releases a mighty Kamehameha blast. Shwooom!

meaning.mnemonic: If you’re on the edge of a cliff with a snake, you’re unlucky. You’re hanging off the edge of this cliff and you can’t pull yourself back up when you notice a snake approaching your fingers. The snake looks like it’s gonna bite you. How unlucky.

readings.mnemonic: Even though you’re so unlucky, you decide to take your chances and let go of the cliff. Amazingly, a yak (やく) runs below you and catches you as you fall. Saved by the yak!

meaning.mnemonic: To make alcohol the key is to ferment it. But, if you ferment it a certain way, it will become vinegar.

readings.mnemonic: You are demonstrating this practice in front of an audience. You want them to take you seriously so you wear a suit (す). A very nice suit. Surely they will now believe that you can turn alcohol into vinegar.

meaning.mnemonic: You say something and the flowers are right in agreement. The flowers see where you are coming from when you say what you say. You and the flowers are in complete agreement.

readings.mnemonic: You and the flowers are in agreement on the fact that neither of you like when a duck (だく) walks across the flowers. You don’t like having a duck walk on the flowers because the duck will poo in the flowers and then you have to worry about stepping in it. And the flowers just don’t like having duck poo in their face.

meaning.mnemonic: I’ll give you this bright plate if you agree to an alliance with me. I know you like things that are bright, and I know you like plates too. Therefore, this bright plate should be more than enough to convince you to enter into an alliance with me.

readings.mnemonic: The person you are trying to get in an alliance with you is the captain of the Mayflower (めい). You want to be in an alliance with the captain of the Mayflower because you really like boats. You want to ride on the Mayflower like, so bad.

meaning.mnemonic: The commander radical and the commander kanji are the same!

readings.mnemonic: Who is the commander of Japan? The Shougun (しょう)! And if you ever say anyone else or vote for someone else or even THINK about someone else being the commander, he'll find you and cut off your head.

meaning.mnemonic: The nothing dance is still a dance!

readings.mnemonic: To help you do this dance you need some booze (ぶ). Just enough so it's easier to think of nothing, let all your fears go, and dance.

meaning.mnemonic: Your leader gets the blame if your company is in debt. They're the one who led you all into that debt, so they should get the blame too.

readings.mnemonic: To pay off this debt your leader says you need to sell your cyborg (さい) to help the company. You fight him! You yell! You scream! The cyborg puts a half-human half-robot hand on your shoulder and shakes its head sadly.

meaning.mnemonic: The leader of your branch became the leader from doing deeds. You can't rise to the rank of branch leader if you don't perform a certain number of deeds! Most of them good, I hope.

readings.mnemonic: The deed he's currently working on is finding your lost key (き). He doesn't have to help, you're the one who lost your own house-combination-car key. But he's so used to doing deeds, he can't help but help.

meaning.mnemonic: A canopy and a helicopter are being compared by a deer. The deer is standing very still (as deer do) and looking very slowly between the empty canopy and the helicopter sitting next to it.

readings.mnemonic: You walk forward, about to call out to the deer, when a car (か) suddenly appears out of no where and runs the deer over! Was this all just a trap set up to murder the deer?!

meaning.mnemonic: In prison, when you have access to a big number of fingers, mouths, and legs you can exchange them for things that are worth more to you. What are you gonna do with all these body parts in prison? You should exchange them for cigarettes and toilet alcohol.

readings.mnemonic: You learned this type of exchange from the mighty Genghis Khan (かん). You read a book or watched a show about him once and you're pretty positive that Genghis Khan would exchange the body parts of his enemies all over the continents of Asia and Europe for nicer stuff.

meaning.mnemonic: If there's a special woman in your life, she might eventually take your family name and make it her surname too. In Japan and other countries, tradition dictates that women change their last name when they get married and keep that name for the rest of their life. Their partner’s family name becomes their family name too.

readings.mnemonic: Picture this special woman in your mind. She's changing her surname to yours and taking hold of your special saber (せい) as well. And it's... it's splitting in two!

meaning.mnemonic: The fang radical and the fang kanji are exactly the same! Fantastic. Oh, also it means tusk. It means fang and tusk.

readings.mnemonic: Lots of animals have fangs, even ones that don't look like they do. The coolest fang-having animal is the gecko (げ)! They have pretty sharp little fangs in their mouths and they'll bite you if you keep tapping their glass cages like that. Cut it out.

meaning.mnemonic: There’s a stick next to the sun, reflecting on its former glory. The stick used to be a great tree, and the stick thinks that if it stays by the sun long enough it might return to its former form as a towering tree.

readings.mnemonic: It's working, it's working! The stick is returning to its former state and... w-wuh? It sprouted a cucumber (きゅう).

meaning.mnemonic: A boat will have at least one weapon, generally.

readings.mnemonic: Generally a boat with a weapon will be owned by Han (はん) Solo.

meaning.mnemonic: When a tsunami comes, the brush makes a good safe haven. Thick brush is a haven from tsunamis because the brush will break the tsunami water and keep you safe and dry.

readings.mnemonic: The only downside about this haven is that there’s only room for two (つ) people in the brush. The brush isn’t big enough for more than two people, so unless you have a lot of brush, you won’t be saving many people from the tsunami.

meaning.mnemonic: If someone is sick feed them charcoal to heal them. Okay, so maybe you shouldn't feed it directly to them, but charcoal has amazing water filtration powers. So put charcoal in their water and the water will heal them right up.

readings.mnemonic: You aren't the only one that needs to be healed, so you take your row (りょう) boat out onto the lake where your town gets its drinking water and you dump a bunch of charcoal into it! Now everyone will be healed when they drink.

meaning.mnemonic: With a thread, a lion sews together all the rice he'll inherit from his parents one day. He's convinced his parents are going to try to keep some of his inheritance from him, so he's linking it all together so it can't go anywhere.

readings.mnemonic: If you're going to inherit something from your parents, try to convince them to make it cake (けい), not rice. A single cake is much easier to keep track of and probably tastier (though it will be super stale by the time they die).

meaning.mnemonic: When you go on a scooter, anything valuable, you need to leave behind.

readings.mnemonic: Anything you don't leave behind will be stolen by eagles (い). Eagles like shiny, valuable things, especially ones that are bouncing around on you while you scoot by on a scooter.

meaning.mnemonic: You tie a piece of thread to your turkey in order to maintain proximity to it. The turkey likes to run away, so you tie a thread to it. This way you can hold the other end and maintain your turkey.

readings.mnemonic: The reason the turkey is struggling is because there’s an eagle (い) swooping down to attack the turkey. You try to maintain control, but once you see the eagle as well, you let go of the thread.

meaning.mnemonic: There is a big jackhammer in Nara. That jackhammer is the biggest in all the land and is on display in Nara, Japan.

readings.mnemonic: What’s the first part of Nara? Na (な). Well that’s easy.

meaning.mnemonic: You take a tree and slice it until you reach its nucleus. To get to the nucleus of the tree you have to make many a slice, but it’s possible.

readings.mnemonic: It looks like a cock (かく). And by cock I mean a male chicken – a rooster. Why does the nucleus of a tree look like a cock? Science is weird.

meaning.mnemonic: This canopy, after your departure, will become obsolete. The canopy was here to protect you, but no one will need it once you're gone.

readings.mnemonic: When something becomes obsolete, you must write a haiku (はい). Honestly, the best haiku are about something ending, so this is perfect.

meaning.mnemonic: The South Dog gives you an offer. None of the other dogs in the North, East, or West offered you anything.

readings.mnemonic: The South Dog offers you the services of Ken (けん) the samurai as you traverse his lands.

meaning.mnemonic: There is a tsunami in the middle of the open sea. Luckily there are no ships around, so the tsunami in the middle of the open sea is not damaging to anyone.

readings.mnemonic: Someone dares you to go out to the open sea and surf on the middle of the tsunami. “Oki (おき) doki,” you reply. You can’t refuse a dare. Every time someone dares you to do something, you always respond with “oki doki”.

meaning.mnemonic: Stick your fingers in your mohawk and pluck each hair out, one by one.

readings.mnemonic: You want to pluck all your mohawk hair out because you're a techie (てき), and everyone at your techie job keeps making fun of you for your hair choices. "Techies should be bald!" your boss screamed. So here you are, plucking your hair out to fit in.

meaning.mnemonic: Escalators are used to reach things.

readings.mnemonic: You're riding the escalator trying to reach a delicious cucumber (きゅう).

meaning.mnemonic: A leader has clothes that he is quite reliant on. The leader needs his clothes to make him look like a leader. The leader has become more reliant on his clothes than he is on his actual skills as a leader!

readings.mnemonic: The leader has become so reliant on his clothes that his judgment has been clouded. His kingdom has become infested with eagles (い) but the leader does nothing, trusting that his clothes will rout out the eagles if it is something that needs to be done. He’s become so reliant on his clothes that he’s started to become not so good a leader anymore.

meaning.mnemonic: Someone threaded a turtle into long skinny pieces, making a rope.

readings.mnemonic: The person making these threaded turtle ropes is the local giant farmhand Jourm (じょう). You watch him stretch and peel pieces of turtle off of turtles, then thread them together into a rope.

meaning.mnemonic: What kind of fish jumps from dirt to dirt? A salmon!

readings.mnemonic: You make a drinking game out of watching the salmon going up stream. Every time one jumps onto the dirt, you drink a shot of 酒 (さけ). You realize you're drunk when you ask for more さけ but it comes out as しゃけ.

meaning.mnemonic: You soak each foot in water before going out in the sun to take your first step. Stepping on the ground when it's been baking in the hot sun can burn your feet, so you're careful to make them wet with water before stepping outside even once.

readings.mnemonic: Each step you take brings you closer to とうきょう. Unfortunately, the sun keeps getting hotter, meaning you have to take breaks between steps more often, to get your feet wet with even more water. But you're determined to reach とうきょう, no matter how many steps it takes.

meaning.mnemonic: A leader who's humble will stretch in front of everyone. They'll show that they have to get up every hour or so and stretch just like the rest of us.

readings.mnemonic: The leader is currently working hard to stretch in front of all of you, and as he does, he munches on some nori (の) seaweed snacks. Then he starts stretching the nori too.

meaning.mnemonic: The sweet radical and the sweet kanji are exactly the same! Double sweet.

readings.mnemonic: The sweet, sweet sensation is almost overwhelming. You gotta put on some sweet resistant armor (あま) to protect you from all that sweetness. The armor will prevent you from having a sweet, sweet sweetness overload.

meaning.mnemonic: You send your private sword man out with your shellfish so he can trade them. Shellfish were used as currency back in the olden days. And you aren't going to go out trading and dirty your own hands, no no. Trading your shellfish is the job for the private sword you hired!

readings.mnemonic: While he's out making the trade for you, you decide to relax and do some bowling (ぼう). In fact, you can't wait for the trade to be done because you're hoping he's going to come back with a new bowling ball for you.

meaning.mnemonic: A bundle of geoducks is something you can always trust.

readings.mnemonic: While you can trust a bundle of geoducks, never ever trust rye (らい) bread.

meaning.mnemonic: You run and call out to people at the same time because you're super ultra excited right now. You have a super crazy amount of energy you need to get out with your running and calling.

readings.mnemonic: You're just becoming ultra tired when you hear a terrifying sound. It's Mrs. Chou (ちょう) barreling down toward you. "WERE YOU CALLING FOR ME, CHILD?!" she screams.

meaning.mnemonic: You want to put this towel over this scarecrow, but you have to measure its width first. If the towel doesn't have a greater width than the scarecrow, some of it will be showing. Which you definitely don't want.

readings.mnemonic: You finish measuring the width of the scarecrow and the width of the towel, and you realize you're the width of a habanero (はば) pepper short. This is fine, you grow those. This is a whole field of habaneros! So you pluck one off the nearest plant, tape it to the cloth, and cover that scarecrow right up.

meaning.mnemonic: A skewer to the heart has afflicted your health. You’ve been afflicted with a disease from the skewer to your heart. Your affliction is death. You’re dying.

readings.mnemonic: Since you’re afflicted with the death, you start to hallucinate and the ghost of Genghis Khan (かん) appears before you. "Ah, I was afflicted of the same disease. It killed me, you know."

meaning.mnemonic: You see an animal wearing a top hat and decide to aim at it. The top hat is a perfect, giant target you use to take down this animal.

readings.mnemonic: Ready, steady, aim... fire! You throw a bar of soap (そ) at the animal. Yes, soap. You were sitting in your bathtub, washing and scrubbing, then the animal in the top hat caught your eye.

meaning.mnemonic: This building is full of cars because it's an army base. The cars (and tanks and planes) need to be ready to go at any moment just like the soldiers.

readings.mnemonic: All of the people in the army base are wearing jeans (じん). You thought soldiers were supposed to wear uniforms, but it looks like when they're on the base they have to wear jeans.

meaning.mnemonic: There's an explosion in the dirt under a rice paddy, exposing the hidden base under there. A base from baseball! I guess this rice paddy was built on top of an old baseball field...

readings.mnemonic: Unfortunately, thanks to the explosion, the base is in ruins (るい). It's dark and smokey and kinda half burned. You probably can't get this in a regulation game.

meaning.mnemonic: What's more simple than a bow? A bullet. Bullets just have to be shot out of a gun and somebody dies. Bows you have to load with an arrow and pull it back and aim, yuck. Bullets are the new bows, people.

readings.mnemonic: If you want to shoot bullets, you need to do it at dawn (だん). Back in the old days, it wasn't bright enough to shoot arrows at dawn, but you can shoot bullets at dawn because they're simpler to use!

meaning.mnemonic: You brought flowers to place on top of the place where a yakuza took a spoon and killed twenty people, and there is now a burial happening. You carefully toss the flowers in with the dirt and everything is buried together.

readings.mnemonic: Once the burial is complete the souls (そう) of all the dead people come floating up and out of the ground. "Thaaannk YooOoOO~" they moan, as they ascend to the sky.

meaning.mnemonic: You take your fingers and slam a lid on the table. You make this big noise to confront the person in front of you.

readings.mnemonic: You are trying to confront Emperor こういち. You're confronting him about all the kanji he's forcing you, and everyone else, to learn. "Look here こういち! I know you said I'd learn like 2000 kanji in no time, but this is way too efficient! What will the people do when they're done? Do you think they will sit idly by?"

meaning.mnemonic: Below this mountain, a moon and another moon crash into each other and the entire thing crumbles to pieces.

readings.mnemonic: As the mountain crumbles you see your home (ほう), which is at the very top of the mountain, come crumbling down too.

meaning.mnemonic: On the scooter is an insect and a bear. The bear immediately stomps the insect, squishing it flat. "My god, the insect is smashed. Someone call dispatch!"

readings.mnemonic: Out of the dispatched ambulance jumps Ken (けん) the samurai. "Dispatch sent me! I'm here to fix that insect."

meaning.mnemonic: You're in prison, but you can use your fingers and a spoon in the light of the sun to display little moving pictures on your cell wall. It's like a shadow puppet display except you can only make a few characters with your limited hand tools.

readings.mnemonic: There is one thing you display more than anything else and it's cake (けい). You smush your fingers to make a cake shape and use the spoon to pretend you're eating it.

meaning.mnemonic: If you combine fire with violence, it will explode! A fire, once full of violence, will surely explode. The fire can’t handle all that violence so the fire just rumbles and shakes and then finally explodes. BOOM!

readings.mnemonic: As you watch the fire explode, you start to back (ばく) away. I don’t blame you. You need to back away or else you’ll get caught in the violent explosion. Back away a little more just to be safe.

meaning.mnemonic: You're holding a flag on a stick above your eyes to imitate eyebrows. You can't grow any of your own, but you really love eyebrows, so this was the best you could do.

readings.mnemonic: Underneath your fake eyebrows are two slabs of meat (み). Meat helps hair grow, according to many Internet specialists who also happen to sell meat. You're waiting for this meat to foster eyebrow hair, and when that sweet day comes you won't need these flags.

meaning.mnemonic: You carry a cross across a rice paddy with a heart on it to return a favor for your friend. The heart needs to be purified so that’s why you have it on the cross and your friend lives on a rice paddy farm so that’s why you’re running through that. The favor you are paying your friend back with is getting him this heart. He needs a new one and you’re providing it.

readings.mnemonic: You arrive at your friend’s place and you can finally return the favor you owe him by presenting him with the heart. “Eh (え)? What’s this? I didn’t ask for this!” “Eh!?!?” you reply. Apparently he didn’t want a real heart, he wanted a candy one. He wanted a Valentine!

meaning.mnemonic: A tsunami pushes all the fish closer to land, making for some easy fishing. The tsunami starts out in the middle of the ocean and pushes all the fish towards the coast where everyone does their fishing. With all the fish pushed closer to land and closer together, it’s very easy for people to go fishing in one spot and catch a lot of fish.

readings.mnemonic: To get to the best fishing spot you need to go (ぎょ) row (りょう) out to the middle of the ocean. You go by means of rowing. To get to the fish and do the fishing, you need to go and row out to sea.

meaning.mnemonic: Grain left in the sun blossom and give off a wonderful fragrance. They smell fresh and delicious. There's nothing better than the fragrance of fresh, sun-kissed grain.

readings.mnemonic: As you sniff this lovely fragrance you get lost in the smell. When you open your eyes again, you see a farming こういち standing in front of you. With... his... arm... up. "Do you like my fragrance? I was genetically modified to have a unique fragrance compared to the other こういちs."

meaning.mnemonic: A tsunami dug out a chunk of the land and now it looks like a big red bow. It's a gulf now!

readings.mnemonic: How many tsunamis does it take to make a gulf? Just one (わん). If there were more, then no land would be left behind. It would all be taken into the sea.

meaning.mnemonic: Your foot heard an omen and now it's making you hop over things.

readings.mnemonic: As you hop you start to hear an awful scream coming down the street. It's Mrs. Chou (ちょう) and she's running straight for you yelling, "STEP ON MY STREET'S CRACKS! STOP HOPPING OR YOUR MOTHER WILL NEVER BREAK HER BACK!"

meaning.mnemonic: Take your fingers and wrap them around another person. This is called a hug. Just make sure you include all the stuff attached to your fingers, like your hands and arms too, otherwise it's more of a squeeze, and we don't want to do that to people.

readings.mnemonic: Who do you love to hug the most? Your dad (だ)! He gives the best hugs. They're warm and big and tight and comforting. The kind of hug dads are really good at giving.
