meaning.mnemonic: Put the sun in prison and everything will always be in season. If the sun is in prison, the seasons can't change. Want to wear a giant weenie costume all year round? Put the sun in prison on Halloween. Now your weenie body is always in season because it's always the same time of month.

readings.mnemonic: When things are in season for too long, people are going to wonder what's going on. When's Christmas? When's Golden Week? Soon (しゅん), you say. Soon enough, it's June (じゅん) which is the middle of the year so everything is soon.

meaning.mnemonic: When your ear is crossed with sound, it catches it like a net, and sends it to your heart for processing. Because you're using your heart to process this sound, it means you're giving it a proper listen.

readings.mnemonic: You are listening so well to what someone is saying. What are they telling you that is so important? They are telling you of the omen of Mrs. Chou (ちょう), who will destroy the earth.

meaning.mnemonic: You give your servant a gun along with some other products to look to. You can’t look to them yourself since you are very busy. You allow your servant to look to your gun and the other products.

readings.mnemonic: After your servant is done with your gun and other products you want him to look to your car’s o-ring (りん). There’s something wrong with the o-ring so you want your servant to look to that as well.

meaning.mnemonic: The omen radical and the omen kanji are the same!

readings.mnemonic: You listen to the omen, in it, it tells of an event in the future when Mrs. Chou (ちょう) will destroy the world.

meaning.mnemonic: The weight of life on your sword is big when you pledge to protect your city. That's the big, big weight of every single person's life in that city pressing down on you every time you take out that sword.

readings.mnemonic: Until the city is safe, you pledge to give up cake (けい), your favorite food.

meaning.mnemonic: Destroy a lantern with your knife and you'll be punished.

readings.mnemonic: I will punish you by taking away your cake (けい)! You'll never eat cake again. Not for birthdays, not for holidays. This is your punishment.

meaning.mnemonic: A greenhouse is the newest power of the city you decided to recruit. You’re trying to recruit all the buildings in town and the greenhouse was the next on your list. It adds just a little bit of power to the town, but it's important nonetheless.

readings.mnemonic: After you recruit the greenhouse, you recruit Bobo (ぼ) the clown to guard it for you. Bobo the clown has a terrifying amount of power so he’ll make an excellent guard for the greenhouse.

meaning.mnemonic: The leader presents you with a prize as reparation for his past deeds. This leader wronged you in the past and wishes to make amends. Therefore the leader presents you with a reparation in the form of a glittering prize.

readings.mnemonic: The leader who presented you with this reparation is the Shougun (しょう) of Japan. He's trying to make up for all the threats he made to you and some of the things you saw (which he's now trying to cover up for).

meaning.mnemonic: Everyone from your clan puts their fingers in the ground as a way to resist their lords. Your clan is made of a bunch of peasants, but you aren't going to work the land for other people anymore. You're going to resist. This is a protest! Your fingers work for no one but yourselves from now on!

readings.mnemonic: You're all resisting with your fingers in the ground, when the lords appear, angry. "You resist us by hiding your fingers with potatoes in the ground?! You want your fingers to be useless potatoes so badly? We'll chop them up and turn them into tater (てい) tots!"

meaning.mnemonic: This door is big and you need to return it to its rightful owner. This door is too big and important looking to not belong to someone. You need to find its owner and return it to them.

readings.mnemonic: You are in return mode (もど). When you enter this mode, you concentrate only on returning something. Nothing else matters in this mode. You’re in full on return mode.

meaning.mnemonic: The sun calls out to the earth by shining down on it.

readings.mnemonic: This shining is aimed directly at the Shougun (しょう). The sun is shining on the Shougun to not only show its support for his leadership, but to let him shine brighter than anyone else in Japan.

meaning.mnemonic: The skewer radical and the skewer kanji are exactly the same!

readings.mnemonic: Uh oh, this skewer is really... cushy (くし). It's so soft and cushy you can't get any meat or vegetables onto it.

meaning.mnemonic: At this gate you're trying to get some beans through, but the measurements were off and you're starting to struggle. No matter how you push or pull these beans, they're just too big to get through the gate.

readings.mnemonic: You continue to struggle because you need to get these beans to the other side of the gate and into とうきょう. You usually struggle a little when people want to bring things through the gate to とうきょう, but this is ridiculous.

meaning.mnemonic: Happiness is a circle that's tenacious. In other words, we're all in this circle/cycle where we do whatever we can to grab onto happiness and hold it as tightly as we can.

readings.mnemonic: Happiness is as tenacious as a shih tzu (しつ) with a shoe (しゅう). That little dog does not want to give up on the shoe, no matter what's happening around it.

meaning.mnemonic: Your foot is a little red and you can see traces of ink streaked on it. Where did these traces come from?

readings.mnemonic: Turns out the traces of red ink were from a sexy (せき) rave you were at last night. Everyone around you looked so sexy, with their glow-in-the-dark paint, so you decided to put some of the red ink on your feet so everyone could see your sexy dancing.

meaning.mnemonic: A triceratops with a moon knife can whittle down anything.

readings.mnemonic: Everything it will whittle down shall be put in a sack (さく).

meaning.mnemonic: A leader asks half of his men to accompany him on a secret mission. The leader’s mission is volunteer only, so it’s impressive that he got half of his men to accompany him.

readings.mnemonic: The leader you decided to accompany is none other than Han (はん) Solo. Who could be more inspiring? I’m surprised not more than half decided to accompany him. Han Solo is awesome.

meaning.mnemonic: You get tooth orders. You get these tooth orders various times in your life, depending on your age.

readings.mnemonic: Gaining and losing teeth aren't the only things dependent on age. There is also an age in which you get your first ray (れい) gun.

meaning.mnemonic: By showing the roof of your top hat you send your best regards.

readings.mnemonic: When you give your best regards you always yell YOLO (よろ) to the other person.

meaning.mnemonic: Your mouth has a tooth that you use to bite and chew with.

readings.mnemonic: Your one tooth is so strong that you can even use it to bite and chew up a whole  car (か).

meaning.mnemonic: The more shellfish you have, the more you can bribe people. That worked in the olden days when shells were money, and today too if the people you want to bribe really like seafood.

readings.mnemonic: Welp, the cops found out about your bribe, that didn't last long, and now your entire family is watching you get put into the police car screaming, "WHY (わい)?!

meaning.mnemonic: Someone is offering you a shellfish in exchange for a kiss. This is a bribe! You don't want to kiss them, but that shellfish sure looks tasty.

readings.mnemonic: You go through with the bribe and kiss the person, but then they snatch hold of the shellfish and run straight down the road (ろ). No!!

meaning.mnemonic: The door in that direction is among a cluster of doors. You run in the direction of the cluster and one door stands out to you. You enter it.

readings.mnemonic: After you make it through the door, you come across another cluster of doors. Which one to choose? There's a loud thunderous sound coming from behind one and you decide to open it. Behind it, there's an entire bowling (ぼう) alley and people bowling, loudly!

meaning.mnemonic: A tiger needs to think and consider its actions before it attacks. Tigers are smart hunters, so they need to consider all options and really think through a situation.

readings.mnemonic: It's considering you for so long that it takes out a robe (りょ), a pipe, and an armchair and starts puffing away, staring intently at you. You didn't even know tigers could wear robes, but this one seems to use it to help itself think.

meaning.mnemonic: They say if you put things on a slide, seven things to be exact, that’s the best way to consign goods to someone. They say if you consign seven things to someone, you should send them over on a slide. Slide ‘em on down. All seven of ‘em.

readings.mnemonic: One of the seven things you consign over to this guy is a tack (たく). It’s the sharpest tack you’ve ever seen. You slide the tack down the slide. Good thing no one is on the slide now, sitting on that tack would hurt.

meaning.mnemonic: Past stamps usually depict images contrary to current views.

readings.mnemonic: Don't be the type of person who acts contrary to how they should and instead be like Kyaku (きゃく) the customer. They're always so nice and polite and they don't give diseases to entire populations of people.

meaning.mnemonic: In the rain I take my rake and shake it, making a demand that the rain stop! I demand this rain stop right now! Don’t make me shake my rake more violently than I am currently shaking it!

readings.mnemonic: Now imagine the rain changing. Wait a second, this isn't rain, it's juice (じゅ)! You shake your rake harder, and demand that the juice rain continues. It doesn't listen to your demands and stops as soon as you start bottling it. Well, at least you have enough for one, really small juice box.

meaning.mnemonic: You offer a hot pepper to the king, and he gives you a drop of something. You look down at the drop to see it transforming into a disc. And not just any old disc at that. It's a jade disc.

readings.mnemonic: Wait, did a drop really just change into a disc? What the heck is (へき) going on?

meaning.mnemonic: A mole in winter will do whatever you ask, if you know how to ask it.

readings.mnemonic: To get the mole to do what you want, just give it a nice big hunk of cheese (ち).

meaning.mnemonic: You're on a scooter and suddenly someone throws a hot pepper at you and you have to dodge it.

readings.mnemonic: As you dodge the hot peppers, you feel a strong heat (ひ) fill your body. You can't tell if this heat is from the effort from dodging or if you didn't dodge right and one of the hot peppers touched you. Or maybe the scooter is overheating.

meaning.mnemonic: When you see flowers in a rice paddy you can't help but use your fingers to draw them. Have you ever seen rice paddy flowers? They're beautiful. And if you can draw them you can capture that beauty and show it to everyone.

readings.mnemonic: Even though you tried to draw the flowers as best you could, whenever someone looks at it they smell B.O. (びょう). Maybe it's because you were drawing for a really long time and kept sweating. Maybe it's because you are just a stinky person. But no one wants to look at your drawing for long because all they can smell is B.O.

meaning.mnemonic: You got your copy of "The Dry Knife." It's the newest edition of the magazine you love on keeping your knives dry.

readings.mnemonic: In this edition of "The Dry Knife," there is a huge article written by Genghis Khan (かん) on how he kept his knives dry while campaigning.

meaning.mnemonic: You use your scooter when the omen comes so that you can escape.

readings.mnemonic: You decide to escape this omen by weaving in and out of the busy streets of とうきょう. By now, you know とうきょう like the back of your hand, so you're sure you can escape this way.

meaning.mnemonic: Where do you put your fingers when you're on an escalator? On the handle! Okay, so maybe it's not a handle and more of a railing, but for the sake of this kanji, picture a handle instead.

readings.mnemonic: You put your hand on the handle and an old person leans in close to you and says, "暑か?" (あつか). He wants to know if the handle is ... hot? Before you can respond he says it again, and again! “暑か？！ 暑か？！？！ 暑か？！？！？！” he's shouting as you slowly ride the escalator away from him.

meaning.mnemonic: If there’s a drop on your head and the rice is big, you know you’re in the interior. And by interior, I mean you’re actually inside someone. The rice is big because you’ve shrunk to a tiny size and are inside someone’s stomach. The drop on your head is actually digestive fluid.

readings.mnemonic: While you’re in the interior of this guy, you hear him break out in song. He starts singing “Oklahoma” (おく) at the top of his lungs. The big pieces of rice slosh around as he sings and dances. “OOOOk-lahoma, where the wind comes sweepin' down the plain!”

meaning.mnemonic: A leader with horns takes a lantern and searches for people to join him. He needs more people to join his cause so he can get his horns removed. He’s embarrassed of them which is why he only travels at night, hence the lantern.

readings.mnemonic: The leader guy approaches you out of the darkness, his lantern held high. Oh no, not that guy. You've heard about his horn problem and you don't want to join him. You look around and spot a large haystack (へい). You quickly jump into it and hide from him.

meaning.mnemonic: Under the moon beneath a tree there is a hat filled with water. You stare down into the water and decide to stick your knee in it.

readings.mnemonic: Suddenly, in your knee, you feel heat and a zap (ひざ)! Your knee is simultaneously burned and electrocuted by the hat water!!

meaning.mnemonic: You change this geoduck because you want it to lean. Right now it's standing up straight, but you want it to lean to one side instead.

readings.mnemonic: To get the geoduck to lean you put a piece of cake (けい) on one of its sides.

meaning.mnemonic: The thread on this football is loose. We need to tighten up the loose thread on this football or it’s gonna fall apart while we’re playing.

readings.mnemonic: You finally tighten the loose thread and all of your friends cheer, “You rule!” (ゆる) You rule because you fixed the loose thread on the football and now you can play again. Yeah! You rule, man!

meaning.mnemonic: When it's spring in heaven they play music. To your mortal, human ears it sounds more like snow melting, birds chirping, and plants waking up.

readings.mnemonic: In heaven, the ones that play music are the souls (そう) of the dead. They have a huge band up there, and even though it just seems like normal spring sounds to you, up there in heaven when the souls play music it's more like a huge, 100-part band!

meaning.mnemonic: A woman who has a landslide getting ready inside her is pregnant. And that baby is gonna come out like a landslide.

readings.mnemonic: When you're pregnant the baby is constantly kicking you with their shins (しん). Not their feet, their shins. And shins are really hard, let me tell you.

meaning.mnemonic: A woman sleeps with the king and becomes pregnant. Only the king wasn’t human and now the woman is pregnant with a hybrid alien baby!

readings.mnemonic: Being pregnant with this strange creature, you need to do something to calm you down. You should play Nintendo (にん). Nintendo really calms your nerves and makes being pregnant with some mutant baby not seem like that big of a deal anymore.

meaning.mnemonic: You put on the shellfish mask once per year and break into people's beach houses, leaving behind presents.

readings.mnemonic: The "presents" you leave? They are actually just zombies (ぞう). You leave zombies in people's houses.

meaning.mnemonic: Shove your fingers into a bowl of shrimp to select the best one. You know your shrimp and you know them well, so you won't settle for anything less than the best. Put your whole arm in there and feel around until you can select the one you want most.

readings.mnemonic: You do this at every restaurant, party, and indoor sporting event and people start getting wise to your shrimp selection methods. One day, as you attempt to select your shrimp, a sharp pain shoots through your finger. Ow! You pull your hand back to find... a tack (たく)!

meaning.mnemonic: There's a scooter coming toward you with a net trapping a weird zombie on it. You don't want this here, so you decide to send back the zombie.

readings.mnemonic: As you prepare to send back the zombie, you imagine yourself as Genghis Khan (かん). On your horse (it's just your own scooter) you stab forward with your spear (stick), swing the scooter the zombie is on, and send it back from whence it came!

meaning.mnemonic: You have thread and some syrup and you need to spin them together. Drip the syrup onto the thread and spin it around and around over your head.

readings.mnemonic: As you spin the syrup, it begins to change shape and forms into a cookie (く)! Haven't you ever made syrup-spun cookies before? The spinning forms and cooks them in the air.

meaning.mnemonic: Use your fingers on the cat pirate to suppress him. The cat pirate was attacking you, so you took your fingers and pet his head and scratched his chin. Now he's calm and suppressed. He doesn't even remember why he was attacking you.

readings.mnemonic: He forgot, but you know you had to suppress the cat pirate because he was trying to steal your egg yolk (よく). You were making breakfast on your ship and the cat pirate boarded you out of nowhere, and tried to take it by force.

meaning.mnemonic: In your prefecture, you come from a long lineage of people who share one heart. When the heart is passed on to the next in line, it flies out of their body, and suspends itself in the sky, for you to take.

readings.mnemonic: You arrive at the suspended heart. There in front of it, protecting it, is Ken (けん) the samurai.

meaning.mnemonic: You take a grain and fashion it into a gun that is small, earning you the title of Small Arms Dealer (or SAD). Congratulations!

readings.mnemonic: Word of your SAD title makes it all the way to the Shougun (しょう) and he travels out to see you. When he arrives at your door, with all of his fancy escorts, he hands you a plaque with your title on it.

meaning.mnemonic: You thread someone together with thread. Someone is falling apart so you use thread to put them back together.

readings.mnemonic: You’re threading this someone back together as part of a show (しょ). The show is a demonstration to show med students how to thread someone’s skin together after they have an accident. You’re the most experienced, so you’re leading the show.

meaning.mnemonic: Your boat holds your weapon like a plate. So in a way, it's just a tray for your weapon.

readings.mnemonic: Unfortunately, this boat tray is so big and flat that it keeps reflecting the light into your eyes, so you have to put on a pair of big Ray-Ban (ばん) sunglasses.

meaning.mnemonic: Raise your fingers to the sky to symbolize that you abstain from something. If someone offers you fur coats, raise your fingers to abstain. If someone tries to get you to bully someone, raise your fingers to abstain.

readings.mnemonic: This symbol to abstain comes from the hicatee (ひか) turtle. The hicatee is a Central American river turtle hunted for its meat, eggs, and shell. Therefore, the poor hicatee is endangered. So people started to rally around it, abstaining from hurting them anymore. They raised their fingers to the sky and shouted, "I abstain from harming this hicatee!"

meaning.mnemonic: On your roof every evening you meet with snakes. All snakes know your address.

readings.mnemonic: The snakes come to your address every night to receive the greatest gift you can give a snake: a 手 (あて).

meaning.mnemonic: The allocate radical and the allocate kanji are the same!

readings.mnemonic: If you allocate your funds correctly you'll be able to buy as many precious jewels (じゅう) as you want! However, jewels are expensive, so if you don't allocate any money, you won't be able to afford any. Ever.

meaning.mnemonic: There's a tsunami coming and you can't stop the explosion of bitterness in your mouth. You're scared. Your mouth tastes bitter and astringent.

readings.mnemonic: With the bitter taste in your mouth, you reluctantly gather up all of your jewels (じゅう) and wait for the tsunami to take you away. At least with your jewels with you, there may be some hope of selling them and building a better life if you make it.

meaning.mnemonic: A mountain branch will branch off from the rest.

readings.mnemonic: If you want to branch off from your hiking group and explore this branch of the mountain, you need a special key (き). Just don't get caught down there or you'll get the guillotine (ぎ).

meaning.mnemonic: The dirt next to your village is where you bury the dead. People don't live forever, so every village has a patch of dirt specifically used for burying dead things.

readings.mnemonic: You don't just bury dead relatives here. You also buried your dead pet uni (う) in that dirt. You thought having an uni as a pet would be a good idea. Too bad uni need water to survive.

meaning.mnemonic: You take gold in exchange for executing orders to construct a buzzer. You are a small bell maker and someone orders you to make one into a buzzer in exchange for some gold. This is how you make a living.

readings.mnemonic: Finally the buzzer is done. You’ve earned your gold. You test the buzzer and it goes ring (りん)! Ring! Ring! Ring! Ring ring ring ring ring! Man, that ringing is annoying but hey, that’s what buzzers do.

meaning.mnemonic: There is something odd sticking out of the dirt. Oh wait, it's just the cape jutting out into the water below. Phew.

readings.mnemonic: The cape below looks just like your cyborg (さい). Or rather, the cyborg you once had, before you had to give him up. It's kinda cross-shaped, it has a slide part, and lots of little fleshy bits. Ah, the memories.

meaning.mnemonic: A tree crab breaks into your games cabinet and steals a chess piece. He’s trying to impress all his tree crabs back home by showing how not afraid of humans he is. Plus the rest of the tree crabs need one last chess piece to complete their set.

readings.mnemonic: Before the tree crab can make it out with the chess piece, you shut the door to the games cabinet and lock it with a key (き), trapping the tree crab inside. Now what?

meaning.mnemonic: When you say "Nurse!" you're ready to defer to them.

readings.mnemonic: You defer to the nurse because you're trying to save the local farmhand, Jourm (じょう), and you can't do it. He's bleeding a lot, and you don't know what to do.

meaning.mnemonic: Whenever a turkey comes in the door, you employ them.

readings.mnemonic: Although you employ turkeys, when a 子 (こ) walks through your door, you send them away.

meaning.mnemonic: The excuse radical and the excuse kanji are exactly the same! Dandy!

readings.mnemonic: Who always makes excuse after excuse? Men (めん)! They have an excuse for everything. Why didn’t you take out the trash? Why did you forget my birthday? It’s just excuse after excuse with men. So I’ve heard, anyway.

meaning.mnemonic: Your buddy the sheep is part of a flock. A flock of sheep. Your sheep buddy is a member of a flock.

readings.mnemonic: Now take out your gun (ぐん) and murder every sheep in the flock. Except for your buddy. You’re incredibly jealous of your buddy and you don’t like the attention his flock gives him so that’s why you decided to murder them all with a gun.

meaning.mnemonic: In a tree on nine branches are some cross frames. Each cross frame is hung on the branches of the tree. You don’t know who decided to hang the frames there, but you think it might be some new wave art or something. Actually you need a frame, and there are already nine up there, so you decide to take one.

readings.mnemonic: The cross shaped frame you took has a picture of the American rapper Waka (わく) Flocka in it. If you don’t know who Waka is, take the time to YouTube a song of his to get the Waka beat flowin’ through your body.

meaning.mnemonic: You need to allocate enough gold to buy a gun. Guns are weapons of the old world, so you can't just buy them with paper money. Guns have to be bought with gold coins and slabs and bricks.

readings.mnemonic: You need this gun so you can steal some jewels (じゅう)! Why didn't you just use your gold to buy the jewels, you ask? Because! That's not how we did things in olden days. When you want jewels you buy a gun with gold and rob a jewelry store!

meaning.mnemonic: A leader who lives in a mountain is a hermit. The only thing this hermit is a leader of now is mountain goats. This hermit dislikes people so that’s why he lives in a mountain now.

readings.mnemonic: One day the hermit was leading the mountain goats around and he ran into a centaur せん. The centaur said that he was the rightful leader of these mountain goats so the centaur challenged the hermit to a duel.

meaning.mnemonic: There are three slides sticking out of this building that lead to your home country. The rest of the slides go to other places, but three are yours.

readings.mnemonic: Your home country is your home (ほう)!

meaning.mnemonic: You loiter around with a gun while your friend tries to correct a stamp to make it more honorable. Someone messed with the stamp machine and your friend is trying to correct the error. You’re loitering around with a gun since you’re his bodyguard. To have an error on the stamp would not be honorable, so that’s why your friend is going to correct it.

readings.mnemonic: Just as you’re pondering what it means to be honorable, your friend gets shot by Godzilla (ご). Godzilla must have been the one who ruined the stamp! "Go, go, save yourself, Godzilla got me!" your friend cries.

meaning.mnemonic: When someone wants to view the reality of your soul, show it with humility. Because the reality is... our souls are all a little dirty. And we haven't been the best versions we could be. So make sure when you show all of yourself you do so with some humility.

readings.mnemonic: As humility washes over you, you feel a shaking in your shins (しん). Humility lives in your shins, so now they're shaking and trying to bring you down to the ground.

meaning.mnemonic: You use your foot to kick Wolverine in the face so a turkey can leap to freedom. This turkey is trying to escape from Wolverine by leaping over a fence. Wolverine doesn’t want the turkey to escape, but you kick him with your foot and the turkey is then free to leap to safety.

readings.mnemonic: After you kick Wolverine and the turkey is safe, you leap onto a yak (やく) to make your getaway. This yak is really fast so you’ll have no problem outrunning Wolverine while riding it.

meaning.mnemonic: They say Mona Lisa had more modesty than any other woman at the time.

readings.mnemonic: The modesty of Mona Lisa inspired Ken (けん) the samurai to become more modest.

meaning.mnemonic: A drop of rain falls on a bear leaning up against a cross stuck into a mound. The drop wakes the bear up and he rolls down off the mound. After the bear rights himself, he assumes that the cross pushed him off the mound so he charges into the cross atop the mound and knocks it over.

readings.mnemonic: Once the bear fully wakes up he realizes that he just rolled down the mound on his own and the cross was not to blame. What a fool (ふ) this bear was. He knows it too. The bear feels pretty foolish.

meaning.mnemonic: The one sided radical and the one sided kanji are the same!

readings.mnemonic: Think of anything that is one sided. A battle. A sports game. A relationship. What makes them so one sided? One side always has a catapult (かた).

meaning.mnemonic: Construction for geoducks doesn't require as much paperwork as construction for humans, but you still need to write at least a paragraph to explain what you're doing.

readings.mnemonic: You turn in your paragraph, and it is given to Emperor こういち, who insists on being involved in all construction projects. Surprisingly, he approves your construction project, thanks to that paragraph you wrote in the application.

meaning.mnemonic: Criminal writing is always patterned. That is to say, there is a pattern to it, lots of ARGS and GONNA STAB YAs, but it's also patterned beautifully, with a collage of cut out letters.

readings.mnemonic: As you look closer at the patterned writing you realize that it forms the shape of an eagle (い). The most American bird of them all! Maybe this guy isn't a criminal after all!

meaning.mnemonic: A building in winter will allow life to have prosperity. Before we had buildings it was impossible to have any prosperity in winter because everything was cold and most of us died.

readings.mnemonic: This prosperity isn't good for everyone though. You look over and see Ryu (りゅう) from Street Fighter sitting in the corner. He's got everything he could ask for. He's won the tournament, he's got money, he's got this nice big building, but now he's depressed.

meaning.mnemonic: Your mouth contains a scroll, which you pull out and look at. On the scroll is a map, showing the range of the sphere of your mouth.

readings.mnemonic: Looking at the range of your mouth on the map, you notice a tiny samurai marked near your molars. It is Ken (けん) the samurai.

meaning.mnemonic: There’s an arrow in that turkey and you do everything in your power to recommend that we don’t eat the turkey. There’s an arrow in this turkey. The arrow looks a little broken, so there’s probably splinters all up inside that turkey. I know you’re all hungry but I can’t recommend eating this bird.

readings.mnemonic: You recommend the Genghis Khan (かん) special instead of this arrow-tainted turkey! When it comes out, your heart sinks. Genghis Khan apparently ate a cow with an arrow broken off in it.

meaning.mnemonic: Show your fingers to a giant to show you refuse him. Giants are very big. So big that when you talk they can't really hear what you're saying. Hold up all your fingers so that he can see what you mean.

readings.mnemonic: What do you refuse? You refuse to let him stomp all over Little Kyoto (きょ). Little Kyoto is your home! And if the giant comes any closer he's going to destroy all the little buildings and shrines and soba noodle shops.

meaning.mnemonic: The grain stuck in your cleat had a former life. In that life it was a rice plant. It was a happy little rice plant, minding its own business, when it was yanked up and cleaned up and put in a bag for people to buy and cook and eat. That was so long ago. Now it's just a sad grain in the bottom of your shoe.

readings.mnemonic: The grain of rice, as it thinks about its rice plant life too, mutters, "いな、いね." Yes little grain, it was a really nice life. I'm sorry.

meaning.mnemonic: A big turkey has to measure a safe before he can rob it. If the safe is too big it won’t fit in his getaway van and the robbery will have been a failure. So before the turkey robs the place he needs to measure the safe.

readings.mnemonic: The safe that the turkey is trying to rob ends up being uber (うば) big. Like, really uber big. So uber big that the turkey can’t even measure it with his tape measure. There’s no way he’s gonna be able to rob this place.

meaning.mnemonic: You come across a gold hill. You think you hit it big! You start digging, only to find out that it is merely a paper-thin layer of gold covering a hill of steel.

readings.mnemonic: You report your findings about the steel you found to Emperor こういち. He is displeased that it is a hill of steel.

meaning.mnemonic: The turtle shell radical and the turtle shell kanji are exactly the same! Oddly, this can also be used to talk about the first item in a list, so to mean A out of A through D, for example.

readings.mnemonic: With a turtle shell on his back, imagine こういち.

meaning.mnemonic: There are hot peppers hiding in this dirt, so you build a wall to protect yourself from them. Have you ever stepped on a really hot pepper? The oils bleed into your shoes and burn your feet! You don't want anyone stepping on these so you wall them up.

readings.mnemonic: On the other side of this wall there are much less threatening cobs (かべ) of corn. Corn isn't spicy. It's delicious and sweet, so it's free from being walled in.

meaning.mnemonic: When a spirit stops protecting you, you'll have to go on welfare. If you can't rely on your family spirit, you'll have to have the help and protection come from somewhere else.

readings.mnemonic: While on welfare, you have to do the only job available to you: herding sheep (し). Sheep can help you out when you're having a rough time. Sheep provide warmth, wool for clothes, and even food, if you wanna get dark about it.

meaning.mnemonic: Your fingers have to stand up straight, to protect you from being abducted, or pulled away against your will.

readings.mnemonic: Suddenly, someone really is trying to abduct you. They're pullling you away. It's the ancient Egyptian god Ra (ら). Help!

meaning.mnemonic: Every winter you are alert for danger. Everyone knows that the worst monsters come out in the winter so you need to be alert if you want to survive.

readings.mnemonic: Being the alert fellow you are, you hear a sasquatch approaching and dive into a trash bin (びん) to hide. The bin smells really bad and you are keenly alert to all the various stenches and smells currently penetrating your nostrils, but at least you are safe.

meaning.mnemonic: You attempt to expel wind out of your mouth but lack the breath to blow out any. You’re using your mouth and trying to blow out some air, but you are failing to do so.

readings.mnemonic: You silly fool (ふ), the reason you couldn’t blow any air out of your mouth is because your hand was over it. You can’t blow air out that way. You silly fool, you.

meaning.mnemonic: It's time to do the mouth sun sun chant. That's when you use your mouth to chant sun sun, sun sun, sun sun, over and over until the sun appears.

readings.mnemonic: You're doing this chant because the Shougun (しょう) ordered you to. The sun hasn't been shining on him as much lately, and he's displeased. So now you have to chant for him.

meaning.mnemonic: If you try to go somewhere but you're too heavy you'll collide with everything. Cars, people, houses. You're too heavy to dodge them, so you collide with it all.

readings.mnemonic: You're going around the town, you collide with a bunch of things, when all of a sudden you collide with the Shougun (しょう)! Oh no! The shogun looks really mad.

meaning.mnemonic: The drunkard issued twenty commandments to his people.

readings.mnemonic: The drunkard is yelling out his twenty commandments to the others at the bar, but they're all about kayaks (かい).

meaning.mnemonic: The Mona Lisa is in front of you. "You must all paint the Mona Lisa concurrently," says your art class teacher.

readings.mnemonic: Your entire class finishes concurrently. You look at your finished result. Wait, that's not the Mona Lisa. You painted Ken (けん) the samurai.

meaning.mnemonic: The flowers are being worked upon by a tsunami with a specialty for knowing how to dilute things. The tsunami can dilute the flowers by pouring itself onto it. A tsunami can dilute things because it is made of water. You could say that it’s its specialty.

readings.mnemonic: As you watch the flower dilute, you determine that this is obviously a nature hack (はく). You’ve never seen anything like this before, so you think the tsunami found out how to hack nature and that’s how it got so good at diluting things. By hacking nature.

meaning.mnemonic: When you're driving, you may notice the flags in the dirt near the exits. These flags mark the ditch running along the side of the road. You won't want to try to exit the road here or you'll end up stuck in one.

readings.mnemonic: If you do end up veering into a ditch you'll find yourself yelling, "Holy (ほり) crap!" Then you'll go hurtling into the ditch.

meaning.mnemonic: Simultaneously, you throw your knife at another person who's throwing a knife at you and you both get a dose of your own medicine. Literally, there's poison on these knives and now you've both been stabbed.

readings.mnemonic: "I need a dose of the antidote!" you yell, and the other guy looks you dead in the eyes. They slowly pull a tiny xylophone (ざい) out of their pocket, play a few notes, and then eat it. "Ah, you'd like a dose of the xylophone cure, wouldn't you?"

meaning.mnemonic: A fang on a turkey is elegant. Most turkeys do not have fangs, so this turkey with a fang is quite elegant and dignified. This turkey is special.

readings.mnemonic: This elegant fang makes the turkey look more like a gargoyle (が) than a turkey. In fact, you haven't seen it move at all. Maybe it is just an elegant gargoyle!

meaning.mnemonic: Teachers are all around us. Those who came before us are our teachers, so it's important to respect them. This is the basic idea of filial piety.

readings.mnemonic: With filial piety in mind, you decide to go visit your father, who is こういち.

meaning.mnemonic: You walk by a geoduck a frequent amount. This geoduck really intrigues you, so you can’t help but frequent the area the geoduck is in and walk around.

readings.mnemonic: Apparently Hindu people also love geoducks because Hindu (ひん) people frequent this area quite often as well. You always see the geoduck here, but also a lot of Hindu people.

meaning.mnemonic: A horse goes to his favorite district to gallop around. This district has lots of cool buildings and lights to look at, so this horse loves to gallop around there.

readings.mnemonic: Then the horse gallops into the road and gets hit by a car (か). Oh man, there’s blood everywhere. This horse is never going to gallop again. That car totally destroyed it.

meaning.mnemonic: The leader of all the spiders is a genius! Spiders are already pretty smart. They can weave complex homes and traps in one web. They even know where not to step so they don't get caught. But the leader knows everything. It made itself a little webbed computer and everything!

readings.mnemonic: As you watch the spider genius you realize that soon (しゅん) spiders will take over the humans. They're just way smarter than us. Soon we'll be the bugs.

meaning.mnemonic: A woman is rejoicing. She must be glad and happy to rejoice out loud in front of you like this.

readings.mnemonic: "I'm so glad!" the woman shouts, "Because I found the key (き)!" You immediately start to wonder what "the key" is. The key to life? The key to learning Japanese? Then you see she's holding up some car keys.

meaning.mnemonic: There’s grass on the ground and the fins there say you have no honor. The fins are left over from the fish you dismembered and they do not believe it was an act of honor. Now they are just sitting on the ground on the grass, calling you out for having no honor.

readings.mnemonic: Being one of little honor, you decide to squash these vocal fins with your yo-yo (よ). You take out your yo-yo and start bashing each fin with it until they stop talking about what little honor you have.

meaning.mnemonic: You take flowers down a slide to a drunkard that you picked from your luxuriant garden. You picked the flowers from the luxuriant garden, not the drunkard, mind you. Also the drunkard has a cane, but not flowers. That’s why you picked some from your luxuriant garden and slid down your cool slide. Now the drunkard has a cane and some flowers.

readings.mnemonic: The drunkard is so happy to receive flowers from your luxuriant garden that he begins to moan (も) with pleasure. The moans are getting louder and more erotic. You’re kind of creeped out. You really want him to stop moaning.

meaning.mnemonic: Under the same flag, all the people get together to present a new weapon to your lord. You all bow and say, "Milord, this gift is for you." Because that's the proper way to address your lord.

readings.mnemonic: As you give the lord his weapon together, you see his face turn into a frown, "What's wrong, Milord?" you ask. "THERE'S A DENT (でん)!" he bellows.

meaning.mnemonic: When you go to the yakuza to fix your problems they'll just multiply.

readings.mnemonic: Just like I said, your problems multiply before your eyes and give you quite a shock (しょく). You really shouldn't be shocked though, because I warned you this would happen.

meaning.mnemonic: Inside that building someone is doing a rice dance. That someone is your neighbor.

readings.mnemonic: Your neighbor has an incredible ring (りん) that they use for their rice dance.

meaning.mnemonic: One way to put wheat in your face is with noodles.

readings.mnemonic: Once you're done stuffing noodles in your face, you can use your leftover noodles to make noodlemen (めん).

meaning.mnemonic: Every winter the thread fields become overgrown. Yes, thread grows in fields these days. And the thread grows the most in the winter because reasons. The thread gets so overgrown that you can’t even walk through it without cutting the thread down with a machete.

readings.mnemonic: The reason this field of thread got so overgrown is because you’re Han (はん) Solo and you’re not used to simple things like farming thread. Han Solo is used to blasting baddies and kissing princesses. Overgrown thread is not his specialty. Use your blaster to clear a way through this thread instead of using that machete.

meaning.mnemonic: You're using your scooter to navigate the flood because you're on patrol. You're one of the few people with a floating scooter, so it's your job to patrol the flood waters and look for people and animals that need help.

readings.mnemonic: You have to patrol all of the floods in June (じゅん). Unfortunately, that's the month when most of the floods in Japan happen, so you end up on patrol a lot.

meaning.mnemonic: This tree is the master of a pillar. The pillar is subservient to its tree master because the tree is so great and awesome and big and cool and stuff. The pillar has great respect for its tree master.

readings.mnemonic: While bowing, the pillar accidentally smashes Chewbacca (ちゅう). The pillar is horrified for having murdered Chewbacca, his tree master’s closest friend. The pillar is going to be punished.

meaning.mnemonic: Use your fingers to shoo a turkey down the stairs and into a portable carrier. You've been trying to get this turkey into the carrier so you can transport it for like, the past hour. You finally got it done with the help of gravity. And, you know, smacking it a bit in the butt with your fingers.

readings.mnemonic: You needed the turkey to be more portable because you're going to be bringing it to a cake (けい) shop to turn it into a cake. You aren't cooking it! Geez, what's wrong with you? No, you're making a cake OF it, for its birthday. The baker needs to see it for reference.

meaning.mnemonic: Lift the lid off your preserves, kick it, and praise the lord! Your food is preserved, you don't need the lid anymore, praise be!

readings.mnemonic: You do this praising in your home (ほう), though, not a church. I don't think anyone outside your home would understand why you're praising inanimate objects.

meaning.mnemonic: Raise your fingers to a criminal to reject their request to have your things. If someone is trying to steal something from you, just reject them.

readings.mnemonic: After you refuse him, he recites this haiku (はい) at you:

meaning.mnemonic: A horse is your master and you are merely a resident in his house. How did this horse become your master? Those aren’t questions a resident should ask! Know your place, resident!

readings.mnemonic: To prove yourself a worthy resident of the horse master’s house, you must capture Chewbacca (ちゅう). Your horse master collects rare creatures, and Chewbacca is his latest desire. If you wish to remain a resident of the house, you must capture Chewbacca.

meaning.mnemonic: You employ a geoduck to review all your work.

readings.mnemonic: As the geoduck reviews your paperwork, it notices something surprising. You have a 子 (こ)!

meaning.mnemonic: The cow of righteousness is always there for us. He is the cow that must sacrifice himself for us to survive.

readings.mnemonic: The sacrifice must be done via guillotine (ぎ). I know, I know, that sounds really brutal, but it's the best way. It's fast, it's effective, and hopefully the sacrifice—I mean, cow—doesn't feel a thing.

meaning.mnemonic: You see an animal with some flowers and a turkey on a stool trying to seize them. The animal with the flowers is really tall so the turkey needs to stand on the stool in its attempt to seize the flowers.

readings.mnemonic: The animal the turkey is trying to seize the flowers from is a cock (かく). The cock is a lot bigger than the turkey, so that’s why the turkey needs to stand on the stool in its attempt to seize those flowers.

meaning.mnemonic: If you have gold you also need a guard with a very sharp sword to protect it.

readings.mnemonic: You're setting up all these sharp traps around your gold when you step on a sharp acorn (えい) that's just laying on the floor. Ouch! But wait, then you get a great idea!

meaning.mnemonic: Taking a cross, you walk through the rice paddy in the direction of winter and spread your arms wide. You spread your arms to halt the approach of winter because your rice paddy is not done growing yet. You take the cross with you for some extra religious power of persuasion.

readings.mnemonic: You’re actually a Sheikh (しき) (an Arab leader) which makes the fact that you’re holding a cross while you spread your arms even more of a big deal. You spread your arms wider than any Sheikh ever has before.

meaning.mnemonic: What kind of woman comes down from heaven? A supernatural one. She is so enchanting.

readings.mnemonic: The supernatural woman comes down in front of you and she's so enchanting that it takes a while to realize she's completely made of yogurt (よう).

meaning.mnemonic: The scooter you made out of grains, and are about to ride down the stairs with, is completely transparent. You mashed the grains down so fine that you can see through them! And then you made them into a scooter.

readings.mnemonic: You slip, the transparent scooter scoots down the stairs without you and into the streets of とうきょう. Nooo! Transpa-scootie come back!

meaning.mnemonic: In the trash is a weird looking fruit. Someone decided to abandon it here.

readings.mnemonic: You reach into the trash, take out the abandoned fruit, and bite into it. OUCH! There's a key (き) inside, and you just bit into it.

meaning.mnemonic: Your ice wife is amazing. She's also terrible, because she's very cold and has many ice powers, but that's also part of what makes her amazing!

readings.mnemonic: She turns her amazing gaze onto your saber (せい) and hits it with an ice beam. Woah! Instead of turning to ice or shattering, it steals her awful powers. Now your saber is amazing and terrible too!

meaning.mnemonic: Dig up a mole and you attain a mole status. You're always trying to attain a new level for yourself and now you get to be on the mole level!

readings.mnemonic: Mole isn't enough, you want to attain sheep (し) status next. Everyone knows it goes human > mole> sheep. Now you need to stand in the field with the mole and get a sheep to come over.

meaning.mnemonic: Wipe your fingers on this table in winter to see what it was based on. The cold winter weathers cover the table in frost, and when you wipe it away, you can see traces of what the table was originally based on. All tables have to be based on something, even if it's just other tables that came before them.

readings.mnemonic: This particular table was based on Little Kyoto (きょ). Little buildings and temples, that sort of look like Little Kyoto. Problem is, it was made by a 子 (こ), so it's not very good.

meaning.mnemonic: On the insect signpost there is a single sign that says bee.

readings.mnemonic: Thanks to the insect signpost you find the bee. You make it just in time to see the bee hatch (はち) from its egg.

meaning.mnemonic: The leader of righteousness is the only one who can run this ceremony. Why? Because it's a very pure ceremony, and only those with an extremely righteous mind can run it.

readings.mnemonic: Sadly, the reason only the righteous can run this ceremony is because it's a punishment ceremony, where he pulls the cord to cut someone's head off via a guillotine (ぎ).

meaning.mnemonic: You climb up a mountain and a cliff in search of fire, but all you find is charcoal. You can make fire with the charcoal, but you were hoping to find fire itself. All that climbing for nothing.

readings.mnemonic: After crushing the charcoal, you decide to take advantage of your current location and lay out in the sun for a while to get a tan (たん). Instead of getting a tan though, you catch on fire. Oops.

meaning.mnemonic: The clothes radical and the clothes kanji are exactly the same! Surprising!

readings.mnemonic: An eagle (い) sees a pile of your clothes and lays an egg (え) in them. The eagle’s egg needs a soft warm place to incubate, and your pile of clothes is the perfect place.

meaning.mnemonic: A tsunami carries a husband and his husband up into the sun where they conceal their centaur. The two husbands run a centaur farm, but the local government isn’t too pleased by this so they have to conceal their centaurs in the sun unless they want them to be confiscated by the government.

readings.mnemonic: What is it the husbands are going to conceal? Oh that’s right, a centaur (せん). They are concealing a centaur in the sun. How forgetful of you.

meaning.mnemonic: The leader gets a nice uniform for the sake of not wanting to look like a fake. The leader is a fake, he just doesn’t want to look like one. He’s not really a leader, but he thinks he should get an official-looking uniform for the sake of not looking like a fake.

readings.mnemonic: Well, everyone found out he was a fake anyway, and now you're all going to use a guillotine (ぎ) to cut off his fake head.

meaning.mnemonic: A fire in the rice paddy burns down the field. The rice paddy fire spreads out from the paddy and consumes the field next to it. This rice paddy fire has ravaged your entire farm!

readings.mnemonic: Your rice paddy farm and field are on a cay. A cay is a small, sandy island, and since your farm is on fire, this cay has turned into a hot cay. Or as Mario would say, that’s one-a hot-a cay! (はたけ) Mama mia!

meaning.mnemonic: A Viking insect is a firefly. In the insect kingdom, the insect most resembling a Viking is undoubtedly the firefly.

readings.mnemonic: The Viking firefly is attacking Hotaru (ほたる) Tomoe (alter ego of Sailor Saturn) because the Viking firefly hates the show Sailor Moon and everyone on it. Hotaru screams in terror as she is deathly afraid of fireflies, especially Viking ones.

meaning.mnemonic: A gladiator turns his hand into a fist. A fist for punching other gladiators.

readings.mnemonic: The gladiator's fist is now aimed at Ken (けん) the samurai. Little does the gladiator know, Ken knows the ways of the samurai and the gladiator. He slowly raises his own hands and turns them into fists.

meaning.mnemonic: Everyone has a poop guy from their hometown. You know. That poop guy. And every single time you try to visit your hometown, poop guy is there making everyone uncomfortable and reminding you why you left in the first place.

readings.mnemonic: Your hometown is in きょうと which, unfortunately, means your poop guy is in きょうと too. Now every time you go back home he's there stinking everything up.

meaning.mnemonic: The roof (hive) on a certain insect (a bee) is what protects all of the honey.

readings.mnemonic: To get the honey out, you need to put on special mitts (みつ) so your hands don't get stung.

meaning.mnemonic: This leader has two things that remind him of his humanity: his shoes, and his hat. These two things remind the leader of his humanity because humans are the only ones who wear shoes and hats.

readings.mnemonic: Another thing that reminds you and the leader about your humanity is wearing jeans (じん). Jeans are the go-to legwear for many people, and no one but humans wear them. Jeans are another great symbol of humanity.

meaning.mnemonic: On this scooter is a child who's trying to show that his lineage is humble. All of the other children are going around in fancy cars or helicopters, but this one child wants to be a humble child of the people, so he scoots on a plebeian scooter.

readings.mnemonic: This humble child is your son (そん). You don't want any child of yours flaunting his wealth and good standing in the faces of other people. You've taught them to be humble.

meaning.mnemonic: There is a tiny leader on Wolverine’s forehead sitting on a stool and commanding his troops to invade Wolverine’s brain. These tiny soldiers are going to invade Wolverine’s body in an attempt to destroy him. The leader himself isn’t going to invade Wolverine’s brain, he’s just going to sit on the stool and supervise.

readings.mnemonic: Soon they realize that they cannot invade Wolverine through his head so they travel down to his leg and try to enter through his shin (しん). The little soldiers take a big knife and slice open Wolverine’s shin in order to invade his body.

meaning.mnemonic: Open your mouth. A tiger fell in there on some spikes! That's what you tell everybody, but when they look in your mouth there's nothing there. It's all a big lie!

readings.mnemonic: Lie about spikes in your mouth and I'll put soap with spikes in it in your mouth to teach you a lesson. That's why I'm using uni soap (うそ).

meaning.mnemonic: Aside from gold there are a wide variety of other minerals as well.

readings.mnemonic: One person is trying to control all the minerals of the world. That person is Emperor こういち.

meaning.mnemonic: Your mouth proclaims "I am noisy and I am picky!" It keeps repeating this over and over to everyone you pass by.

readings.mnemonic: You are so noisy and picky that the townsfolk hired Ken (けん) the Samurai to shut you up.

meaning.mnemonic: Your leader is also a director so you need to pay respects to him before you can start filming. He’s a huge big-shot and you don’t want to offend him by not paying the proper respects, so you make sure to bow every time you go on stage.

readings.mnemonic: The name of the director is Ook Aga (うかが). Ook Aga is a caveman which is why everyone has to be really careful and make sure they pay respects to him. Ook Aga doesn’t know how to live in a civilized society so your phones and clothes scare him. You have to bow really low and respect what he says, moving slowly, so that he continues to direct you and won’t run away or hurt anyone.

meaning.mnemonic: You decide to loiter next to the trash under the moon in winter so the moon's light will penetrate you. The sky is clearest in winter, and this spot next to the trash happens to get the most of it.

readings.mnemonic: You want the light to penetrate you, so you put your face in the way of the beam and it shoots clear through you. Your mouth fills with the taste of 鉄 (てつ).

meaning.mnemonic: A tsunami hits a bundle of geoducks, swirling around their weird shapes, and creating rapids! The rapids are so violent, some of the geoducks break out of the bundle and get washed into the shallows.

readings.mnemonic: After being washed through the rapids and into the shallows, the living geoducks are screaming “Save (せ) me! Save me!” They need to be saved from the water, and you are the only one who can save them. You gotta run over and help them out.

meaning.mnemonic: Your mouth is showy so it makes everybody around you rowdy.

readings.mnemonic: Everyone is getting rowdy so you get in your car (か) to escape.

meaning.mnemonic: You're digging in the dirt when you find a tiger and a cactus. You keep digging until you realize that these are a part of some big ruins. They're the ruins of tiger and cactus statues. It looks like whoever used to live here worshiped tigers and cacti. Or maybe they ate them. But now their whole civilization is just ruins.

readings.mnemonic: Well, as it turns out, these are the ruins of Little Kyoto (きょ), the city that existed before the modern day one. And it looks like the citizens of Little Kyoto faced their end a long time ago.

meaning.mnemonic: The alcohol you take a measurement most carefully of is sake. Sake is very important to the alcohol culture in Japan, so you must make sure to measure it out to the precise amount.

readings.mnemonic: You know who enjoyed sake a lot? Chewbacca (ちゅう). He was always drinking, which is concerning when you think about all the driving he did.

meaning.mnemonic: You find some fingers from long ago. They must have been set aside by their previous owners. They definitely weren't cut off or anything, someone just decided they didn't want them anymore and set them aside.

readings.mnemonic: I know why they set aside their fingers long ago, it's because there was no soap (そ). If you didn't have soap to clean your fingers you wouldn't want to keep them for very long...

meaning.mnemonic: Something you say to someone you become attached to should be said with sincerity. You need to speak with sincerity when you say things to someone who will eventually become your significant other, for example.

readings.mnemonic: When you say something with complete, unabashed sincerity your special saber (せい) starts to pulse with the beating of your heart. It shows the person you want to become close to that you truly are sincere!

meaning.mnemonic: A tiger has legs that belong to a tiger. You know, a tiger has the legs of a tiger. This is common knowledge. Nothing new here.

readings.mnemonic: The tiger is using his legs to run away from the Torah (とら). This tiger is deathly afraid of religion, so a holy book like the Torah causes the tiger to run away.

meaning.mnemonic: The boat that oversees other boats, land, and people is usually a warship. They're the big boats that oversee everything around them. And if anyone steps out of line, a warship can take care of it.

readings.mnemonic: This huge warship is run by Genghis Khan (かん), the famous warlord. Really, what did you expect? Who else is strong enough to captain a warship but him?

meaning.mnemonic: You use your fingers to dig through the trash in the light of the moon in winter because you're going through withdrawal. You need your fix and you need it now, so you're willing to freeze your fingers off digging through moonlit trash to get it.

readings.mnemonic: The withdrawal makes you withdraw a 鉄 (てつ) and try to eat it. The taste of the 鉄 fills your entire mouth.

meaning.mnemonic: Each tree needs its drum measurement done before you can say it's really made of wood.

readings.mnemonic: If you're still not sure if the tree is really made of wood, just take out a small juice (じゅ) box and start drinking it. A wooden tree will show no interest in the juice box at all.

meaning.mnemonic: The wrap radical and the wrap kanji are the same!

readings.mnemonic: Think about being wrapped up, nice and warm and safe in your home (ほう). Home is where you wrap yourself in a blanket, in the warmth of the fireplace, in the arms of those you love.

meaning.mnemonic: You hit a tree with an axe so you can do some analysis on it. To do the analysis on the tree, a cross section needs to be obtained, so you must chop it in half with your axe.

readings.mnemonic: The person who is doing this analysis is very sexy (せき). Who is this sexy person? Why it’s you of course, you sexy beast. I love watching you do analysis on trees. It’s so sexy.

meaning.mnemonic: Shoot a melon out of a bow and it will fly in a steep arc. Melons are too heavy to fly straight, after all.

readings.mnemonic: Shooting melons in an arc is something little 子's (こ) love to do. It also helps that when they come down from the arc they smash all over the place.

meaning.mnemonic: The mole has a knife ready for your arrival. You get out of your airplane, you step on the ground and... ouch! You stepped right on the knife, and there's the mole, sticking it out of the ground. "I checked the schedule for your arrival!" it squeaks happily, and disappears.

readings.mnemonic: Your arrival to とうきょう is now ruined. And your next stop is now going to be an arrival at a とうきょう hospital to get this mole knife out.

meaning.mnemonic: For a car, the reason why it works is because its wheels spin on their axis. That is, they have axles.

readings.mnemonic: Your friend's car doesn't have axles, but he loves it anyway. He's all like, "Isn't this a cool car?" You reply: "Gee, cool" (じく) very sarcastically.

meaning.mnemonic: If you take a thread and wrap up a bunch of it, so much it becomes a hill of thread, you're going to have a lot of thread. You can wrap some of that thread around other thread to create a much thicker thread. This thread is a cable.

readings.mnemonic: You use this cable to swing down from a building but you need to do it soon (つな)! You're being chased by some bad guys and they've almost caught you, so if you're gonna swing to safety with this cable, you need to do it soon.

meaning.mnemonic: When your fingers move like that, you know it's an omen of a challenge that will face you soon in the future.

readings.mnemonic: In your finger, you see a challenge. And... if you look closely, you can see the fast movements of your fingers forming the outline of Mrs. Chou's (ちょう) face. Oh no, the challenge is going to be Mrs. Chou!

meaning.mnemonic: You take a turkey and try to boil it but you char it instead. That's what happens when you throw meat into a pot on high with no water in there.

readings.mnemonic: You're staring sadly at the charred turkey when you suddenly sense the Shougun (しょう) looming behind you. You were supposed to be cooking this turkey for him and now he looks really, really mad.

meaning.mnemonic: You see a flag near the exit, so you use your fingers to dig there. Most flags mark something, and this exit is pretty obvious, so there must be something under here. At least that's what you think to yourself as you dig.

readings.mnemonic: You dig until you finally hit something. It's a bunch of buried old coots (くつ). They're in an underground room for old coots. One yells up at you, "Whatcha doing to our roof, ya whipper snapper?! Stop digging in our lawn!"

meaning.mnemonic: Take this thread and look at this part. Now look at this part! Now look at this part. You don't know where to look! Haha, I have distracted you!

readings.mnemonic: Despite how distracted you are, that was indeed a lot of fun (ふん).

meaning.mnemonic: This bamboo can be whittled into an example of anything. See, here's a car. Here's a snake. I can make so many examples just with bamboo.

readings.mnemonic: One last example for you. Now I'm going to take this bamboo and whittle it into an example of Han (はん) Solo!

meaning.mnemonic: Someone's fingers touch your tongue and fasten it together. You can't talk. All you can do is make sad tongue-less sounds as you try to figure out who would fasten your tongue like this.

readings.mnemonic: Only one creature could use its fingers to fasten your tongue like this: cats (かつ). Cats are notorious for fastening tongues so that people can't speak. Haven't you ever heard the phrase, "Cat got your tongue?"

meaning.mnemonic: Under the canopy, you use a tree for your floor. It also becomes your bed, because hey, what is a floor but the original bed?

readings.mnemonic: News of your amazing floor / bed spreads and reaches the Shougun (しょう), who wants to come see it. He's impressed, and asks you to build floor beds out of trees laying under this canopy in all of his buildings.

meaning.mnemonic: You use your fingers in a shop to grip what you want to buy.

readings.mnemonic: You have a really strong grip thanks to acupuncture (あく)! All your fingers are primed for buying things. You can grip anything at a shop—pineapples, tires, even live turtles. All thanks to some well-placed needles.

meaning.mnemonic: In the tree district of town you can buy a lot of tree products, including doors. With those doors, though, you always need hinges.

readings.mnemonic: You buy an awesome hinge and try it out. Instead of working properly, it just falls apart and the door falls on you, crushing your lower body. You yell out (and you have to yell) "I'm GOING TO SUUUUEEE (すう) YOU!"

meaning.mnemonic: If you have fingers it's easy to hoist things above your head. If you don't have fingers, well, it's not so easy.

readings.mnemonic: Today, you have to hoist so much stuff. "Ah!" you say, "So much hoisting to do." Better get to it!

meaning.mnemonic: A tsunami crashes into the sun (breaking it in half) and creating a different wing of the tsunami all together. This wing crashes down and creates a lagoon.

readings.mnemonic: This lagoon was created on purpose by a really angry dude and his catapult (かた). He wanted a nice place to lounge that's tropical, but not too bright. So he came up with a plan: use a giant catapult to send a tsunami into the sun!

meaning.mnemonic: There are flowers and hills in your front lawn. Your lawn is pretty big and it is covered with both flowers and hills. It’s very pretty.

readings.mnemonic: You are the proud owner of a Shiba (しば) Inu, y’know, the Japanese dog? Well, this Shiba Inu of yours loves to run around in your lawn and through the flowers and over the hills. This is the perfect lawn for your Shiba.

meaning.mnemonic: If the moon is dry, it's good for your liver! Haha, get it? Because there's no moonshine to ruin your liver. Don't drink, kids.

readings.mnemonic: As you pat your liver suddenly a strange feeling bubbles up and the ghost of Genghis Khan (かん) comes out! Right out of your liver.

meaning.mnemonic: What do you eat if you’re wearing horns and surrounded by lanterns? Mochi (or sticky rice cakes) of course!

readings.mnemonic: The reading of mochi is mochi (もち). Yay!

meaning.mnemonic: Under the cross is a mouth and another mouth wearing special clothes because they're in mourning.

readings.mnemonic: As the mourning continues, the soul (そう) of the dead person rises out of the cross. The soul looks around at all of the mourners and nods. Yes, your mourning has pleased it.

meaning.mnemonic: You have a thread hill, but the hill is a bit weird looking (take a look at the hill radical in this kanji). It's not any normal hill, it's a weird lumpy hill that isn't quite right. That's because it is a thread hill of netting, and parts of the nets have caught things, like fish and cats, so there's weird abnormal lumps in them.

readings.mnemonic: There's so much netting that it's out of control. You decide to take your lawn mower to mow (もう) it all down.

meaning.mnemonic: Even though you’ve old legs, you overcome your disability. These old legs of yours don’t work very well, but you overcome the odds and you run a marathon!

readings.mnemonic: When you pass the finish line and finally overcome the limits of your old legs, someone hands you an ice cold Coke (こく) as a reward. Mmm, such a refreshing Coke.

meaning.mnemonic: The tsunami that is white is the most scary tsunami of all. It doesn't come in and destroy everything. No, it comes in, goes inside your door, then stays at your place overnight, without even asking!

readings.mnemonic: Your cat walks up to the white tsunami that's staying overnight and decides it doesn't like it, so it hacks (はく) up a hairball on it. Even that doesn't get the tsunami to leave.

meaning.mnemonic: If you have one stool and another stool, you have a pair of stools. Look at this pair of stools. Look at it.

readings.mnemonic: This pair of stools shares a soul (そう). Even if you tried to separate them, they'd eventually find their way back together.

meaning.mnemonic: You walk up to a tree and put dynamite on it. Then you set it off. BOOM. It explodes, but doesn't do what you'd expect. Instead of blowing the tree up, it blasts a very beautiful pattern into the side of it as well as the ground around it.

readings.mnemonic: The pattern is so beautiful that you want to put it on your garage (がら). So, you do.

meaning.mnemonic: Put an axe in your mouth with your fingers to express your philosophy. Your philosophy of putting weapons in your mouth. Everyone else seems to think it's a stupid philosophy, so you're showing them that it's not with actions!

readings.mnemonic: Your philosophy on weapons in mouths means you're always tasting 鉄 (てつ). They say blood tastes like copper, well weapons taste like iron.

meaning.mnemonic: Use simultaneous jackhammers to perform the purification ritual. Two jackhammers running perfectly in sync will purify your body, mind, and soul! (And the ground around you that's being jackhammered.)

readings.mnemonic: This purification ritual is supposed to help you forget your cyborg (さい). It's been a while, but you can't seem to get it out of your head.

meaning.mnemonic: You keep your substitute clothes in a sack. The clothes in the sack are just substitute clothes, so they only come out in emergencies.

readings.mnemonic: You need your substitute clothes so you take out your substitute clothes sack. You open it up to grab your substitute clothes, only to find out that there is a ton of salmon roe inside your sack. Oh man, you forgot all about putting that in there. You yell: F**K ROE (ふくろ) because that roe destroyed all your clothes and made it nasty.

meaning.mnemonic: You grab a satellite with your fingers and shake it! You're an astronaut and it's your job. Don't worry, the satellite won't break or anything, it's strong for space travel. Just do as you're told and shake the sucker.

readings.mnemonic: You need to shake it because this satellite is full of yogurt (よう). And you only like yogurt that's been well shook. And who can resist space yogurt? Huh? Anyone?

meaning.mnemonic: A tsunami breaks your bones, not from hitting you, but from making the ground slippery. The water from the tsunami made all the sidewalks and stairs too slippery to walk on, but you tried anyway, slipped, and broke a couple bones.

readings.mnemonic: As you struggle on the slippery ground you hear a loud yowling sound. You turn and see a bunch of stray cats (かつ) slipping and sliding too. They're coming right for you, uh oh!

meaning.mnemonic: A servant secures a stool in the dirt so that it is a solid sitting device. If you just throw a stool on the ground it will flop over easily. But if you have a servant to dig it into the dirt a bit, it becomes nice and solid and safe for sitting!

readings.mnemonic: You need this stool to be extra solid because you're using it to test your new catapult (かた). If it isn't solid, when you launch it and yourself in the catapult, the stool might fall over, killing you both. And you don't want that, now do you?

meaning.mnemonic: To your car you take an axe. The sun has broken your car for good this time (you think). You're so angry at your car. You think this is permanent. Turns out, though, that it's not permanent. It's just like that temporarily. You did make it permanent by taking an axe to your car, though.

readings.mnemonic: You were driving around in Zanzibar (ざん) when this happened, too, so now you're stuck in Zanzibar, a foreign place, and you have no idea what to do next.

meaning.mnemonic: Thread and vines alone are too weak to hold anything up. You need to twist them together to make them strong.

readings.mnemonic: As you twist the thread and vines together, suddenly you feel a lump. You look down and see a cucumber (きゅう) twisted into it.

meaning.mnemonic: Flowers find their death in a river out in the wild. Flowers live on water, but this river drowns the flowers to death. The wild is a dangerous place.

readings.mnemonic: Ah (あ), the flowers in the wild have been claimed à la (あら) the great flood. Ah, you don’t think so? Well I do.

meaning.mnemonic: Imperial clothes allow you to perform an ancient attack that cannot be repelled.

readings.mnemonic: The attack's power is concentrated in the shoes (しゅう) in this imperial outfit. You attack with your feet, kicking the enemy with your old, fancy shoes.

meaning.mnemonic: A tsunami can't resist the call of a bog. Whenever a tsunami is headed toward land, a bog will always call out to it, "Hey tsunami, don't you want to hit me with your water? Come this way~"

readings.mnemonic: As you listen to the bog's call you realize it looks just like the Numa (ぬま) Numa guy in your mind. You open your eyes and it's just a bog. You close your eyes, and there he is. The Numa Numa guy.

meaning.mnemonic: A good moon is a bright moon. Not just in terms of light, but in mood as well. Like, gee wiz, what a bright, happy moon.

readings.mnemonic: It's so bright that you can see all the roe (ろう) in the sea glowing and reflecting the light like stars. And the tiny baby fishies inside the roe are smiling brightly back up at the moon!

meaning.mnemonic: Below the canopy of trees is a hand. The hand is just there to chafe against the trees.

readings.mnemonic: As the hand chafes on the trees, it says mama (ま), mama.

meaning.mnemonic: You have to run, put your ear on the stool, then run back. That's the charm of this game.

readings.mnemonic: The added charm of this game is that there's this big chute (しゅ) at the end. It's so charming because you love chutes.

meaning.mnemonic: The loitering mountain king who hangs around during winter to provide an indication (this kanji uses the "indication" kanji as its top 2/3rds) of things to come now looks into your heart, and only sees bad things. So, he chastises you about it.

readings.mnemonic: Why is he chastising you, really, though? He foretold Mrs. Chou coming back in a previous mnemonic, but you saved Mrs. Chou on the beach (once again, in a previous mnemonic), so you could have prevented her second coming. He is chastising you for saving Mrs. Chou (ちょう).

meaning.mnemonic: We put a flag to remember where we tried to use a jackhammer to measure your friend's heart. Granted, it was a terrible idea, but hopefully that flag of remembrance is some kind of consolation?

readings.mnemonic: Even though you weren't happy with the flag, you were even more frustrated to watch an eagle (い) swoop down and grab the flag and fly away with it.

meaning.mnemonic: A badger, at the root of its heart, is a courteous creature.

readings.mnemonic: Badgers are especially courteous to condors (こん). Condors live in the trees while badgers live in burrows under those trees. When humans tear down the condor's homes, the badgers who live below them always let them stay over until they get back on their feet.

meaning.mnemonic: A bamboo stalk looks the same as a big ol' cylinder.

readings.mnemonic: Picture a cylinder shaped とうきょう. All the buildings are cylinders. The city itself is cylinder shaped too. Even... gasp! The people of とうきょう!

meaning.mnemonic: Hit by a tsunami the drunkard is propelled down a slide where he hits the ground which is covered in fire. He is immediately destroyed.

readings.mnemonic: One could say this drunkard met (めつ) his fate.

meaning.mnemonic: A foot on a giant is a pretty long distance for a normal person to walk. Giants have big feet and can travel large distances very quickly.

readings.mnemonic: Going to Little Kyoto (きょ) is a short distance for a giant but a long distance for you.

meaning.mnemonic: People had to ride their bamboo plows long ago to enroll in things. There were no cars yet, so they would hitch a cow to their bamboo plow, and dig their way to the government office or school to enroll.

readings.mnemonic: If you enroll in something new people will find you very sexy (せき). This was true long ago too. There's nothing sexier than trying to improve yourself.

meaning.mnemonic: If the rain touches your foot and gives it a little rain kiss, you know that part of your foot is exposed to the elements. You can also see some dew forming on your exposed foot. So that's what rain kisses are!

readings.mnemonic: You run along the road (ろ), trying to get out of the rain, but the road keeps going and going, with walls on both sides.

meaning.mnemonic: A fire door is a door that leads to something full of fire. That thing is a furnace.

readings.mnemonic: You're using the furnace to melt tar to put on the road (ろ).

meaning.mnemonic: You've been ordered to spear this tree but you decide to be really gentle instead.

readings.mnemonic: You're being really gentle to the tree when a jewel (じゅう) falls out of its branches and hits you on the head.

meaning.mnemonic: You hold the roof of the festival up with your fingers but it grates on them. The roof is heavy, and you have to walk to keep up, so the roof is grating on them really, really badly.

readings.mnemonic: Just when you thought the grating couldn't get worse, someone sat (さつ) down on the roof! AHG! It hurts!

meaning.mnemonic: Two kings are here right now! We need to entertain them otherwise who knows what they'll do. Get out the harp, or the zither, or something.

readings.mnemonic: You don't even know how to do the 事 (こと, action) of playing the harp, yet you're doing it.

meaning.mnemonic: Look at the dirt on the ground at dawn and you'll be able to see all the hedges growing in the area really well. At any other time of day, hedges tend to blend into their surroundings. But at dawn, the shadows the sun makes really helps them stand out.

readings.mnemonic: You're looking intently at one particular hedge because yesterday you dropped your car keys (かき) behind it. Now that you know where the hedge is you're going to need to search it to find your car keys.

meaning.mnemonic: The root of a stamp is to get an instant picture down. Back in the olden days, people had to make seals and draw out things by hand, so stamps came about so you can—BAM—just stamp it and have what you want in an instant.

readings.mnemonic: Think about the thing you want to make instant. I'd want instant socks (そく)! Don't waste time searching for a matching pair or pulling them on. Just take out a pair of instant socks, add water, and the socks are already on your feet. In an instant!

meaning.mnemonic: A drunkard goes down a slide, hits the ground and bumps into a woman. Who is that woman? It's none other than her majesty.

readings.mnemonic: After you run into her majesty, her guardian eagle (い) swoops on you and pulls you off of her.

meaning.mnemonic: A (fresh water) tsunami. Some horns. The ground. A bunch of poop. Combine these together and let them decompose a while. You'll have yourself some very nourishing soil.

readings.mnemonic: This is the kind of nourishing soil that Jesus (じ) would make if he was into making soil, probably.

meaning.mnemonic: A cow in the winter doesn't like to leave the barn to go to the pasture. It has to, though, because a cow's gotta eat.

readings.mnemonic: ぼく is one of the common ways to say "I" in Japanese (which you should remember!). In this case, you're a boy... a cowboy, and you say, "ぼく will take these cows out to pasture!"

meaning.mnemonic: The sound of spring water always puts you at peace.

readings.mnemonic: You want to feel this peace all the time, not just in spring, so you dip your tie (たい) in the spring water. Now your tie is making the peaceful dripping sounds you love.

meaning.mnemonic: Take your spoon to the sun to be able to take a bite. It's delicious, you hear. That's the point of the spoon.

readings.mnemonic: This delicious taste is... familiar somehow. You take a few more bites and then scream. It tastes like sheep (し)!
