meaning.mnemonic: You take out a flag, lay a towel below it, and use your knife to carve the pattern through them both. Voila! This is exactly how old printing presses used to work.

readings.mnemonic: As you're working on printing your own flag onto this towel you look over and see someone else just sat (さつ) down on theirs. "Excuse me, where is your knife?" you ask. "Oh, this way is slower, but it's less work. I'm just pressing them together with my bum."

meaning.mnemonic: The king's hat, not to mention the hair stuck to said hat, is incredibly rare. If you have your hands on either of these things, you'll be a rich duck.

readings.mnemonic: Then you look closer at the hat. It's about to get even rarer. Attached to the hair is the king's chin (ちん).

meaning.mnemonic: You need to make a measurement of an area so you take two clumps of dirt to seal in each side of your measuring tape, so it stays on the ground. This is the way people used to seal things back in the day, back when we didn't have fancy things like tape and glue.

readings.mnemonic: You can also seal food (ふう) in dirt to make it last longer. That's how jerky came about, you know. Seal some meat underground and in a few months you'll have some tasty dried meats to chew.

meaning.mnemonic: The simultaneous radical and the simultaneous kanji are the same!

readings.mnemonic: What simultaneously protects and kills? Your holy blue saber (せい).

meaning.mnemonic: If a tsunami hits a pirate they are going to sink no matter how good of a pirate captain they are.

readings.mnemonic: As the tsunami comes to sink the pirate, the pirate holds his chin (ちん) up high. He will die with dignity.

meaning.mnemonic: Put your fingers in somebody's business by slapping them! This method also works if someone is getting too involved in your business. Slaps are basically your way of doing business with your fingers.

readings.mnemonic: ぼく is one way to say "I" in Japanese, usually used by dudes. But you're going to use it now when you slap this guy. Who's in everybody's business, slapping them? ぼく.

meaning.mnemonic: When a yakuza takes a knife to clothes, it will of course cause a split or tear.

readings.mnemonic: "I want to split and tear that." You agree, so you say Let's (れつ) do it.

meaning.mnemonic: A small tsunami comes in the morning with the moon. That just means the ocean gets bigger when the moon's out, and that my friends is simply the tide.

readings.mnemonic: You go check out the tide. The water is coming in a little stronger, and something washes up on the shore. It's a body! You roll the body over and it is Mrs. Chou (ちょう)!

meaning.mnemonic: This construction project made from shellfish will act as a tribute to the Crabigator.

readings.mnemonic: This great tribute is being commissioned by Emperor こういち.

meaning.mnemonic: Who will say turkey? Who? WHO???

readings.mnemonic: Then, someone says turkey. "Who said turkey? You? How dare (だれ) you."

meaning.mnemonic: The radical blade and the kanji blade are exactly the same.

readings.mnemonic: When you stab your blade into an enemy you shout "Ha (は)!" It's just the normal "thrusting with blade" sound.

meaning.mnemonic: The radical can is the same as the kanji can. Usually when we talk about a can with this kanji we mean a tin can, though.

readings.mnemonic: The reading for a can is かん, which seems impossibly easy. If that isn't close enough for you, picture this:

meaning.mnemonic: You put a stone into a wrap of some kind. This wrap happens to be a cannon, and you're shooting off the stone, just like I used to do to boats with the cannon we had growing up for some reason.

readings.mnemonic: You aim the cannon at your own home (ほう). You don't want to have a home anymore, you want to become a pirate, live on a boat, and (of course) shoot cannons all day long.

meaning.mnemonic: A bamboo thing you put on your head to stand taller would probably be a hat. A bamboo hat is probably one of those hats you think of when you think of rice farmers, a conical hat.

readings.mnemonic: A conical hat is kind of like an umbrella on your head. What's the reading for "umbrella" in Japanese? Why, it's kasa (かさ)!

meaning.mnemonic: The dragon radical is the same as this kanji, which is dragon.

readings.mnemonic: Imagine a dragon. You are talking to it, which is already pretty strange, but as you're talking, he turns into the Street Fighter character Ryuu (りゅう).

meaning.mnemonic: Your fingers told you that a flood last evening seemed to be imminent, and that there was nothing you could do to stop it. You felt it draw close, coming in the darkness of the evening.

readings.mnemonic: As the flood began to draw close you knew there was nothing you could do, so you sat (さつ) down  and waited.

meaning.mnemonic: There's a thread tying wolverine to a pig, balancing them over the edge of a cliff together.

readings.mnemonic: Suddenly, the pig squeals, pulls the thread, and sends them both over the edge. Straight to their end (えん).

meaning.mnemonic: If someone puts a blade to your heart, you're going to have a rough time. They leave it there, for a long long time. They aren't going to cut you, but you can't move. You have to endure the pain and uncomfortableness of the situation.

readings.mnemonic: This is all a part of your ninja (にん) training. You must learn to stay totally still, without breathing. This is how they train you. If you can endure this you can endure anything, plus you can stay really still, which is good for ninjas.

meaning.mnemonic: A gold pool is where you're going to go fishing. Because, if the pool is gold, hopefully the fish are too.

readings.mnemonic: You caught a couple of gold fish. Two (つ) gold fish, actually!

meaning.mnemonic: The good luck radical and the good luck kanji are the same!

readings.mnemonic: For good luck, you keep special kits (きつ) in your kitchen (きち). These kitchen kits contain good luck charms.

meaning.mnemonic: The part of rice that stands up tall in the air (at the end of the stalks) is the grains.

readings.mnemonic: You have a box of grains. Ryuu (りゅう) from Street Fighter is doing training by punching the grains to strengthen his fingers.

meaning.mnemonic: Your long hair is your friend. It's your hair and you're so proud of it.

readings.mnemonic: Who gave you this hair? Probably the great 神 (かみ) of hair. You deserve this great hair.

meaning.mnemonic: An axe is stuck into the ground on a hill.

readings.mnemonic: You reach the top of the hill and realize the entire hill is covered in cucumbers (きゅう). The axe has a little note on it that says "Cucumber Hill Axe - Please Use."

meaning.mnemonic: The leader of a big rice paddy is standing in the middle of said rice paddy with an umbrella. Who is this wacky leader? Why, it is I. It is me.

readings.mnemonic: Why am I standing in the middle of this rice paddy with an umbrella? I'm digging for ore (おれ).

meaning.mnemonic: The ladle radical and the ladle kanji are the same!

readings.mnemonic: You use a ladle to distribute soup. But as you're ladling you find something odd floating in the soup. It's... a toe (と)! You scream, dropping the ladle and the toe on the ground.

meaning.mnemonic: The measurement radical and the measurement kanji are exactly the same.

readings.mnemonic: You want to measure something... something that will make you famous. You decide you'll measure the biggest mass in our solar system. We're talking about the sun (すん).

meaning.mnemonic: The tree has an omen growing from it, one single peach that is the size of a house. Inside is a child who will save the village from demons.

readings.mnemonic: If momotaro (もも) wasn't enough, think about the peach growing larger and larger. You want it to grow bigger, so you yell at it: "MORE! MORE!" (もも).

meaning.mnemonic: The grain you cut off a tree with a knife is a pear. I don't know if you've ever seen Asian pears, but they're pretty big and sturdy. You can't just pick them off of the tree, you need the help of a knife. That's why this is a pear, and not an apple or peach or something else.

readings.mnemonic: As you cut the pears down, you can't help but gnash (なし) your teeth. You want to eat these pears right now. You gnash and grind and wait though, because you want to have them all down before you start the feast.

meaning.mnemonic: The woman servant is the lower ranking princess. The queen is no servant. Hecks no. Just the princess, because she's a servant to what her parents tell her to do.

readings.mnemonic: The princess goes on to do whatever she wants. She tells the real servants, "Don't tell my daddy, the king, I did this. He may (ひめ) not like it."

meaning.mnemonic: You use your fingers when you're in private to use an arrow to push open things.

readings.mnemonic: Your favorite thing to push open is your own eye (あい). You take the arrow into your fingers and gently push each lid open until you can see.

meaning.mnemonic: A woman loves her catapult for some good ol' fashioned recreation.

readings.mnemonic: Her favorite thing to shoot at with her catapult for recreation is Godzilla (ご).

meaning.mnemonic: I say, which weighs more: a kilogram of scooters or a kilogram of rice? This is a riddle!

readings.mnemonic: Did you figure out the answer to this riddle? Say your answer aloud to the screen right now.... not so (なぞ)! You're wrong.

meaning.mnemonic: The leader of the temple isn't a monk like you'd expect. It's a samurai, who protects the monks in return for prayers that keep him safe.

readings.mnemonic: The reading is samurai, which should be easy enough to remember.

meaning.mnemonic: From my mouth I have told you seven times not to do that. Now I have to scold you.

readings.mnemonic: What were you doing wrong that caused me to scold you? You were feeding the 鹿 (しか). If you feed them they'll never be able to feed themselves!

meaning.mnemonic: A tree with two moons on either side, holding the tree up in a horizontal angle, is a shelf.

readings.mnemonic: Your moon shelf is great. It's also huge, because moons are really big. That means you can store a ton-a-stuff (たな) on it.

meaning.mnemonic: You have mouth vines, so you shout! It's hard for you to talk normally, and even harder for people to understand you unless you shout.

readings.mnemonic: You need to shout so that people can understand you through the mouth vines. You shout, "きょうと!" because you hear there is a temple there for people with your condition.

meaning.mnemonic: In the cage there are some legs. They are the legs attached to a small animal.

readings.mnemonic: You look up through the cloth, and see a hairless cat. This small animal is hairless, but most surprisingly is covered in hickies (ひき).

meaning.mnemonic: The spicy radical and spicy kanji are exactly the same! Hot!

readings.mnemonic: Imagine eating this spicy food, becoming blinded by the spicy heat, and knocking your shin (しん) on something while you bumble around.

meaning.mnemonic: A flowers fang is the bud that comes out of the ground. It's like a little fang, coming from the earth, and it will become a flower someday. This is a little sprout.

readings.mnemonic: When the sprout gets out of the ground and opens up, instead of a flower there is a human-looking 目 (め), looking right at you.

meaning.mnemonic: The mountain wind coming down from the mountains is very fierce. It is so fierce it's a lot like a storm. Well, it is a storm, really.

readings.mnemonic: A storm is nothing to scoff at. If you get hit by the storm and get all wet and nasty and electrocuted, you're bound to get a rash (あらし).

meaning.mnemonic: A tsunami goes through a little door, and plops down a big drop on your face. This tsunami is your tears inside your eye area. The door is your tear duct. The big drop is the teardrop coming down your eye.

readings.mnemonic: Your teardrops always come at the worst times, ruining (るい) serious and/or happy moments. You can't stop crying. It is ruining your life!

meaning.mnemonic: Rain on a rice paddy means only one thing... thunder! Get off the rice paddy! There's nothing but you to attract the thunder!

readings.mnemonic: You can't run fast enough to escape the thunder so you hitch a ride (らい) from someone driving by.

meaning.mnemonic: When dirt and flowers suit one another, the flowers grow so tall that they make a tower! A flower tower made of flower power!

readings.mnemonic: The only place flowers grow into towers like this is in とうきょう. とうきょう dirt is the best. とうきょう flowers are the best. Thus, you end up with a lot of とうきょう towers.

meaning.mnemonic: The slide to get off this jet is a beautiful, brilliant vermillion color.

readings.mnemonic: You jump onto the vermillion slide. It's actually more of a steep chute (しゅ). And... oh... urp... it's making you sick.

meaning.mnemonic: A feather is on a rice paddy, and they are attached together. You put a feather on a rice paddy to create a giant airplane. Flawed, sure. But, this rice paddy + feather is going to be one wing of your amazing aircraft.

readings.mnemonic: To make the feather and rice paddy stick together you need some kind of sticking agent. This time we find the original bird that the feather came from and grab its eggs. We break the eggs open and use the yolk (よく). It's pretty sticky, but still probably not aircraft safe.

meaning.mnemonic: A spoon to measure a geoduck is a very approximate measurement. Geoducks are big, spoons are small. Still, we'll get the approximation going, right?

readings.mnemonic: Maybe this is too much geoduck, even if we're going for an approximate. So, you take the core (ころ) of the geoduck and measure that instead.

meaning.mnemonic: When you leave grains in your mouth for long enough, they'll turn into flowers of bacteria. These aren't the nice, pretty flowers you'd give your mom on Mother's Day. These are little bacteria flowers that are taking over your mouth. Maybe brush your teeth next time.

readings.mnemonic: There is a lot of this bacteria in the King (きん) of England's mouth. He eats a lot of grains, and he won't let anyone touch his mouth to clean it, but he refuses to do things himself... so it's absolutely chock full of bacteria.

meaning.mnemonic: Something made of gold stands in a village. It's a bell!  The village bell.

readings.mnemonic: The bell rings whenever the Shougun (しょう) arrives in the village. Its ringing echoes throughout the entire village so everyone knows they have to come out and pay their respects.

meaning.mnemonic: The boat radical and the boat kanji are the same!

readings.mnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji 船, though there's an extra reading there as well, ふな. They're close, so you should be able to remember it based off of ふね.

meaning.mnemonic: The woman who makes your house a home is your bride.

readings.mnemonic: Now that you have a bride in your house, you can get rid of your maid (よめ), since your bride will do all the cleaning.

meaning.mnemonic: Looking up to the cliff, you see the trees, and the sun shining down on them. Using the sun and the trees (up there on the cliff), you've devised a method to tell what time of the year it is, based on where the shadow from the trees fall. After a while, you develop a bigger system. This system is a whole calendar.

readings.mnemonic: Remember the word 歴史, which means "history"? Using a calendar, you too can remember history (otherwise, who knows when these things happened). So, the reading for this kanji is the same as the reading for 歴史's beginning, because they're related.

meaning.mnemonic: The sun is being blocked by a rain cloud, making it cloudy.

readings.mnemonic: Remember 雲? It means "cloud" and has the same reading as "cloudy," making them both くも.

meaning.mnemonic: An alligator is considerably dangerous. Considerably terrifying too. Considerably [put your scary adjective here].

readings.mnemonic: Speaking of considerably terrifying, that place known as Narnia (なり) is pretty terrifying. Not sure why children want to go there.

meaning.mnemonic: There's a sock circle in the dirt on your way to cram school. Every day after school you walk straight until you get to the sock circle, you run around it, and then head off in any direction. Somehow it always leads to cram school.

readings.mnemonic: The sock circle seems to have a bit of a gravitational pull, so to make sure you get to cram school on time you have to juke (じゅく) around it every day, to make sure you can get past it.

meaning.mnemonic: From the mouth of your older brother comes... a curse!

readings.mnemonic: Turns out, he put the no road (のろ) curse on you, meaning you can never walk on roads.

meaning.mnemonic: After the tsunami the sun comes out again and shines on these spikes. They were super wet before, but you figure the sun probably dried them off. You lean down to touch them and nope, they's still damp.

readings.mnemonic: As you're looking at the damp spikes, a shih tzu (しつ) prances over, slips on the damp ground, and falls right on the spike! Oh nooo!

meaning.mnemonic: The grains you have stored in your house reflect on your earnings. If you earn a lot of money, you have more grains.

readings.mnemonic: Another way to check someone's earnings is to see if they have a car (か). Would someone who doesn't make a lot of money have a car? No!

meaning.mnemonic: I have sick in my skin. Just look at it, it doesn't look too good. Whenever I have sickness in my skin, I know that I'm probably exhausted.

readings.mnemonic: When you're exhausted, your muscles are all probably worn out. Being this worn out, you can probably imagine that your body is all heated (ひ) up, from all the exercising.

meaning.mnemonic: A sheep with feathers (and presumably wings, too) is able to fly.

readings.mnemonic: Using this sheep that can fly, you're going to get rich! But there's a problem... you have to catch the sheep. So, you get some cake (かけ) and use it to lure the sheep to your trap, where you catch it!

meaning.mnemonic: I'm putting all my shellfish on someone, hoping they'll win the race! This is a gamble and you're gambling.

readings.mnemonic: If you win this gamble you'll have enough shellfish to buy a brand new car (か)!

meaning.mnemonic: Coming down with the rain is two spikes. They go right through two ghosts.

readings.mnemonic: You come across the ghosts, who are stabbed into the ground. "Please," they beg. "Please use that ray (れい) gun that's in that row (りょう) boat and end our suffering."

meaning.mnemonic: Tsunami vs lifeguard. Who will win? After the water drains away, we find the lifeguard in the gutter.

readings.mnemonic: In the gutter is a lifeguard, so Emperor こういち decides to survey the damage.

meaning.mnemonic: I protect my own animals by going to hunt other animals... like wolves and cougars and such.

readings.mnemonic: I also do all my hunts using a car (か). I just run those animals down with my car. Kind of cheating, but vroom vroom anyways.

meaning.mnemonic: If you've been to the moon in the past, you had to get the special stamp on your leg.

readings.mnemonic: You've only met one other person with the same mark on their leg and it was Kyaku (きゃく) the customer. Kyaku visits many places all over the world, so it only makes sense that they've also been off-world too.

meaning.mnemonic: When the tsunami struck, it hit your tent full of beans. When you lost your tent of beans, you had a moment of lucidity. You don't need so much stuff, you can live without it!

readings.mnemonic: Your lucidity is clear to everyone because you wear a suit (す). Everyone knows that lucid people wear suits!

meaning.mnemonic: A dirt demon is just a lump. Just like a dust bunny is just a clump of dust.

readings.mnemonic: Have you ever heard of the game "Katamari Damacy?" That game is about a little guy who rolls a ball around, turning it into a bigger and bigger lump. What do you think the Katamari (かたまり) part means? It means lump, of course.

meaning.mnemonic: The animal king? He's just this guy who lives in the forest and thinks he's king of all the animals. He's a lunatic, though.

readings.mnemonic: You might see that crazy lunatic hanging around the outskirts of きょうと. He'll lurk near your trash cans and scream, "I AM THE ANIMAL KING!" and run away with some orange peels.

meaning.mnemonic: A woman who is a nurse should be called miss.

readings.mnemonic: "Call me Miss Jourm (じょう)," Jourm says to you.

meaning.mnemonic: If you're showing me your "spirit fruit" then you are just naked. You're nude.

readings.mnemonic: Known for being naked (and showing you his spirit fruit) is the ancient Egyptian god Ra (ら).

meaning.mnemonic: An axe is sticking in the ground on top of a mountain. It's sticking into the very peak. Because why would you bother to stick your axe anywhere else on the mountain to prove you climbed it?

readings.mnemonic: You can't help but gawk (がく) at the peak. Somehow it looks even higher now.

meaning.mnemonic: Below this canopy of trees is a stone. Since it's the only stone here, you make sure to polish it.

readings.mnemonic: You polish the stone due to your meager (みが) lifestyle.

meaning.mnemonic: This building now has a cloud over it, creating shade.

readings.mnemonic: The building that's getting this nice shade is the inn (いん) you're staying at.

meaning.mnemonic: The moon table is a table that's made entirely of skin. You thought the table was made of moon, with all those pores and such, but when you look more closely, you realize it's skin. Disgusting, porous, skin.

readings.mnemonic: But, when you go to touch this "moon table" made of skin, you realize that it's harder (はだ) than you expected.

meaning.mnemonic: The cloud floating above a demon has its soul in it. If you can manage to get through to the demon, to make it see that it doesn't have to be evil, it might remember who it is and return to the spirit it once was.

readings.mnemonic: You shout out and beg its soul for help until, finally, you see the cloud take the shape of a condor (こん). Aha! "You were a condor before you became a demon! Remember who you are and turn back!"

meaning.mnemonic: The spear radical and the spear kanji are the same!

readings.mnemonic: You take this spear and stab it into a cow. "MOO (む)!" it cries. The cow bites the spear out of your hands and stabs you back. "MOO!" you scream.

meaning.mnemonic: When your eye catches an omen, it's only natural that you will stare at it.

readings.mnemonic: As you stare at the omen, you see Mrs. Chou (ちょう) knocking down buildings, putting nails on the street, and making herself way longer than you ever thought possible. Oh, and there she is, destroying the world.

meaning.mnemonic: You feel like a stone (again!). When you feel like a stone, your body is feeling very stiff.

readings.mnemonic: You remember how you used to cure these stiff body times: your old friend こういち would just massage them out for you.

meaning.mnemonic: The toe is early. I hate it when the toes show up early. Well, if the toes are going to show up this early, I guess it's best to put them on the table.

readings.mnemonic: What do all the early toes on the table do while they're waiting until it's the right time? They just sit around on their table, talking (たく).

meaning.mnemonic: If there's a treasure chest, there's always a villain too. The villain is trying to get to the treasure chest before the hero of the story.

readings.mnemonic: The villain beat you all the way to きょうと to get this particular treasure chest.

meaning.mnemonic: A tsunami in the shape of a dragon flies off the cliff, then comes crashing down to the ground. This skinny tsunami of water flying down to the ground is a waterfall.

readings.mnemonic: Despite how cool a dragon waterfall is, to be honest it's also pretty tacky (たき).

meaning.mnemonic: The well radical and the well kanji are the same.

readings.mnemonic: There is a single well in each and every town thanks to the Shougun (しょう). One of the first things he decreed when he came to power was that all people have the right to easy and central access to water.

meaning.mnemonic: You use black dirt to make black ink. That's what you use to write in black!

readings.mnemonic: Be careful that you don't spill black ink on anyone or anything. If you do, you have to own it. Imagine spilling black ink on someone, and when they confront you, you yell, "Yeah I got black ink on you, so sue me (すみ)!"

meaning.mnemonic: Your eye gets kicked with a cleat that came careening toward your forehead when it popped off someone doing a dance, and you blink.

readings.mnemonic: You blink and blink and soon (しゅん) there are tears coming out of them too. You try to blink them away but it's not working. Soon you're crying and blinking and crying some more.

meaning.mnemonic: If a tsunami wraps around itself, the resulting wave will create a lot of bubbles. You know how tsunamis wrap around once gravity kicks in, right? Well when that wave crashes, a whole lot of bubbles are created.

readings.mnemonic: One of the biggest bubbles heads straight for your home (ほう), engulfs it, and picks it up into the air!

meaning.mnemonic: Some grains get stuck in his cleat, and Wolverine's heart grows calm. Wolverine had been screaming and yelling and stomping around, but when the grains entered his cleat he realized where he was. He was finally able to calm down.

readings.mnemonic: Now that Wolverine is calm, tears come to his eyes. Being calm has given him perspective on what his anger has done. Oh, wait no. There are just some onions (おん) in his cleats too, and they're making calm tears trickle down his eyes.

meaning.mnemonic: You see a child with an umbrella in front of you. Suddenly, they fall straight down into a cavity in the road. It's a big hole!

readings.mnemonic: "Into my cavity you go!" yells a voice. It is こういち.

meaning.mnemonic: This tree is very odd, to say the least. The shape is all crazy, like a lightning bolt stuck into the ground, or something. Oh wait, look at this. I can sit on it really nicely. It's just like a chair!

readings.mnemonic: But, this odd tree chair is also home to an eagle (い). It swoops down upon you as you sit down, gouging your eyes out.

meaning.mnemonic: If you pick certain rice or flowers you'll be put in prison. The most famous of these is the chrysanthemum. Chrysanthemums are super important in Japan because they're the symbol of the imperial family. They're even on the cover of Japanese passports. If you get caught picking a chrysanthemum, you're going to prison.

readings.mnemonic: If you go to prison for chrysanthemum picking, everyone in the prison is going to kick (きく) you nonstop. You broke the chrysanthemum picking law, so kicking is your punishment. And believe me, you don't want these kicks.

meaning.mnemonic: A tsunami causes the capital to become very cool. The capital was already a pretty cool temperature, but with the addition of the water from the tsunami, the capital is now very cool.

readings.mnemonic: You don’t like how cool it is in the capital now so you decide to get in your row (りょう) boat and row away to some place that is not so cool. Get in your row boat and row away!

meaning.mnemonic: The white thread in your towel comes from cotton. We use cotton to make lots of things, like clothes and bedsheets. But white towels are always made from soft, fluffy cotton.

readings.mnemonic: This cotton is made by men (めん).

meaning.mnemonic: Below the canopy of trees is a demon. This demon is a devil.

readings.mnemonic: Why is the devil under a canopy of trees? Because he's looking for his mama (ま).

meaning.mnemonic: You need to bring charcoal under this roof to heat the dormitory. You live in this dormitory with a bunch of other kids, and you all have to take turns bringing in the charcoal from outside to heat it.

readings.mnemonic: The dormitory is on an island, so when you go out to get the charcoal you have to take a row (りょう) boat. You row and row and row until you reach the shed with all the charcoal. Then you row and row and row it back to the dormitory.

meaning.mnemonic: There are nine birds and one of them is a dove and another is a pigeon. These nine birds are a flock of all kinds, but the dove and the pigeon are the leaders.

readings.mnemonic: Take a look at the pigeon in front of you. Now, grab it, tear it in half, and grab the heart (はと) from its little body.

meaning.mnemonic: Make barracks out of gold and they will get dull quickly. Gold is soft, it's okay for jewelry and delicate things that aren't used much, but barracks for soldiers? Those are used constantly, and they get worn out easily. What was once shiny gold will go dull in days.

readings.mnemonic: As you stare sadly at the dull barracks, the don (どん) shows up out of nowhere, and he's pissed. He turns his angry gaze toward you and says, "How did my barracks get so dull? Are you at fault? This is bad, this is very bad. Someone will pay for this."

meaning.mnemonic: You want to turn your gold comb into a weapon, so you throw it into the forge.

readings.mnemonic: You're trying to work the forge, but it's harder than you thought. You end up forging outside all day and get a wicked tan (たん).

meaning.mnemonic: A crab moves a stone because he is playing the game Go. You know this game, right? You put black or white stones on a board until you win the game. This is the Japanese game known as Go. This crab is pretty good.

readings.mnemonic: Go is pronounced Go (ご) in Japanese, too. How convenient is that? Like, super convenient. So easy even a crab could remember!

meaning.mnemonic: When you get sick you always eat a hot pepper. It's a habit you've picked up and you can't seem to shake it. One sniffle, one cough, and before you know it, you're eating a hot pepper or two.

readings.mnemonic: Everyone you know has a different habit when they get sick. Instead, they eat couscous (くせ). But you think couscous is gross. It's bland and does nothing for your stuffy noses and scratchy throats. I wonder how you can convince them to replace their habit with your own.

meaning.mnemonic: The part of the grain people favor the most is the head of the plant. You don't eat the stems and leaves of rice or wheat plants, right? You eat the head where the grains are.

readings.mnemonic: When you want to harvest the head of the plant you'd like to eat, you need to use a hoe (ほ). Using a hoe, you can dig up the bottom of the plant without injuring the head.

meaning.mnemonic: I have five things in my mouth and I need them all for me. I own these five things, and I keep them in my mouth so people like you cannot take them from me.

readings.mnemonic: Me, personally, I am quite thirsty so I ask for some “waga” (わが). I have five things in my mouth, so it is hard for me to pronounce the word “water”. So it sounds like “waga” when I ask for it. “Coulg I pweash hab sum waga?! I deed waga!!”

meaning.mnemonic: You take some gold and cover your yoga brush in it, turning it into a key. You shove the brush you normally use for yoga into the lock to your car and pour the gold over it. Now it's the right shape to be a key!

readings.mnemonic: This key has to be perfect, because if it isn't the car guillotine (かぎ) will come down and chop off your hand!

meaning.mnemonic: I found part of a plate at the lantern festival, and put it on a tray to keep it safe. There is a legendary plate broken into three parts. One part of the plate I found was at the lantern festival. The lantern festival was pretty cool, but I’m really glad I found the part of that plate I was looking for.

readings.mnemonic: The plate part you found at the lantern festival (and put on the tray) is made out of bone (ぼん) china. How fancy. Is bone china made from real bones? Bones found in China? Probably not, huh.

meaning.mnemonic: You're standing under a canopy when you see something strange sticking out of the dirt. You pull it, but it won't budge. You pull harder and harder until the dirt starts rumbling and a giant manor starts rising out of the ground with you on top!

readings.mnemonic: The beautiful manor begins to shake and the shougun bursts out of the front door. "WHO HAS UNEARTHED MY SECRET MANOR?!" he screams.

meaning.mnemonic: An animal that kicks dirt into people's mouths is a monkey. Monkeys are naughty little things. You should be happy it was just dirt it kicked into your mouth, and not something worse.

readings.mnemonic: You spit the dirt out of your mouth and look back at the monkey to see that it's saluting (さる) you. Is... is it mocking you?

meaning.mnemonic: There’s a tree in the east that looks like a pillar. The tree is tall and straight and does not have any leaves or branches. The tree is basically a big wooden pillar that just happens to be alive still.

readings.mnemonic: That pillar happens to be in the center of とうきょう. If you need to find east (which is where とうきょう is), you just look for the pillar.

meaning.mnemonic: "Say 'big,' ground beggar! Have pride!"

readings.mnemonic: After giving some pride to the ground beggar, he looks up at you and tears off his beard and skin. "I am a 子 (こ) again, thanks to you!"

meaning.mnemonic: Inside your eye stands a tiny village that makes up your pupil. That's the black part of your eye!

readings.mnemonic: All of the people in your pupil eat doughnuts (どう) all day long. That's why your eye is shaped like a doughnut, with the "hole" (village) as their home.

meaning.mnemonic: On the roof is your heart. OR! In a net in the street. Which would you rather?

readings.mnemonic: As you try to decide which you'd rather have, your neighbors (ねい) come out and grab the heart out of your hands.

meaning.mnemonic: The leader of your sad life aims a kick at the sack you are holding. This leader is in charge of making your life sad. The next step in the leader making your life suck is attempting to kick your sack out of your hands. Your sack holds all your valuables, so it’s not something you want to have kicked.

readings.mnemonic: You manage to get your sack out of the way as you shout “Heyo (ひょう)! Look, you missed! Heyo!” Unfortunately your leader’s friend was standing behind you and he kicks your sack as you move it out of the way. “Heyo!” he shouts, mockingly.

meaning.mnemonic: Poop Poop Mountain is covered in poop because it is such a secluded place.

readings.mnemonic: The secluded Poop Poop Mountain is a favorite of youths (ゆう). They go there to get away from their phones to get in touch with nature again.

meaning.mnemonic: With the power of your mouth you command a tree to become a shelf. Most of the time one would have to use their hands and tools to turn a tree into a shelf, but you are capable of turning a tree into a shelf by using the power of your mouth.

readings.mnemonic: Once you turn the tree into a shelf you put the shelf in your car (か) and sell it at a local pawn shop. You keep doing this over and over again until you are rich. You command the trees to turn into shelves and then you take the shelves in your car to sell them. Easy money.

meaning.mnemonic: Your village wants to take the village dog and boil it, and you can think of no other response than SHUT UP!

readings.mnemonic: The villagers are mad that you told them to shut up, and they start to mock (もく) you. They put their hands on their hips, lean forward, cross their eyes, and yell "SHUT UP!" back.

meaning.mnemonic: You use your car and an axe to slice down a pedestrian. This innocent guy is just walking along the road when you drive up to him in your car and axe him to death with your axe. You’re all like, VROOM! AXE! Now this guy is dead because you sliced him down in cold blood.

readings.mnemonic: You were driving around in Zanzibar (ざん) when you sliced down this man. Luckily, Zanzibar has no laws at all, so you won’t get arrested for slicing down this guy with your axe.

meaning.mnemonic: You stand your towel up so everyone can see it. This announces that you are the sovereign ruler of this bathroom.

readings.mnemonic: As the sovereign ruler of this bathroom, you must choose a monogram to represent your rule. For this, you choose the symbol of the food that passes through you the most: The mighty tater (てい) tot!

meaning.mnemonic: Someone with a top hat comes and tells you that your grains are going to be taxed from now on. Top hat man says there is a tariff that's been enacted on grains. Rice? Triple the price. Wheat? Quadruple.

readings.mnemonic: You're listening to all the things in this tariff and you finally get fed up and ask what isn't being taxed now. The top hat man looks at you and smiles, holding out his hand. In his hand is some soap (そ).

meaning.mnemonic: The gold from the east needs tempering before it can be sold. The gold from the east is good, it just needs some tempering before it’s entirely presentable. You know, tempering like you’d do in a forge.

readings.mnemonic: The smithy where you’re doing the tempering is pretty fancy, but it’s just a rental (れん). You haven’t sold enough gold to own a smithy as nice as this one yet, so for now, you rent one. It is pretty swanky though, even for a rental.

meaning.mnemonic: If you see a building wearing a giant top hat, beware! This building is a fake and it's trying to thwart all of the plans the people in other buildings have.

readings.mnemonic: The building next door is being painted, and the top hat building is jealous. It thwarts the painting plans by dumping soap (そ) out of its windows and onto the painters and the building!

meaning.mnemonic: You need to stop a drunkard from going down a slide with a jackhammer to ask him how many years old he is. He's doing a lot of dangerous things right now, and they all have age limits.

readings.mnemonic: When you ask him how many years old he is, he turns to you and screams, "I'M A MILLION YEARS OLD AND YOU'LL NEVER STOP ME!" That's obviously not how old this kid is, so you take out your holy blue saber (せい) and slice the slide in half. Then the jackhammer. Then the kid's metal arm—wait! This kid is a cyborg (さい)!

meaning.mnemonic: You get rain orders. Your orders are to make sure there is zero spill.

readings.mnemonic: The best way to make sure there is zero spill when it rains is to get rid of the rain. You use a special ray (れい) gun and zap the rain right out of the sky. There will be zero spills because there will be zero rain.

meaning.mnemonic: That penguin over there seems to have a towel stuffed with cash.

readings.mnemonic: Your eyes follow the cash, and you watch as the penguin stuffs it, towel and all, into a hay (へい) stack. What a smart penguin, people don't look for cash in hay, they're too busy looking for needles.

meaning.mnemonic: You give bamboo to someone and they make them into chopsticks. They are very talented at turning bamboo into bamboo chopsticks. This someone is an expert at their profession.

readings.mnemonic: Now use those chopsticks to eat some delicious hash (はし) browns! That's what chopsticks were made for. That's what they're always made for.

meaning.mnemonic: Rub charcoal under your eyes if you want to see clearly. Sports players also rub charcoal under their eyes to see nice and clear in the bright sun.

readings.mnemonic: You have to have clear vision because you're about to go out in your row (りょう) boat. The light off the water shines right into your eyes and you need the charcoal to clear that up for you. Otherwise you'll end up crashing into the shore or going over a waterfall to your death.

meaning.mnemonic: There is a mountain on top of a bunch of dirt with a steep cliff. This is a bit redundant, but the mountain and the dirt just make the cliff even bigger and steeper and scarier.

readings.mnemonic: As you’re peering over this tall cliff, somebody behind you shouts, “Hey, guy (がい)!” This startles you and you tumble down the cliff. Apparently so did he, because you can hear him saying, "Hey guy! OOF! Are you okay? OOF! Guy? Guy!!!” as you both fall.

meaning.mnemonic: Without a fire, you will lack the ability to cook anything. You really need a fire to cook properly. Having a fire will make sure any cooking endeavors you attempt will not fail.

readings.mnemonic: You cook your meal evenly by swinging (すい) it back and forth over the fire. You swing it left, you swing it right. You swing it to, you swing it fro. All this swinging ensures a properly cooked meal.

meaning.mnemonic: Sitting safely under your canopy you take rice and dirt, mix it up, and create unique cosmetics for your face.

readings.mnemonic: You need these cosmetics because you have a meeting with the Shougun (しょう) coming up. You want to impress him, and you don't want anyone to copy your look.

meaning.mnemonic: A pig with horns runs into a building and makes it fall into the dirt. This makes a loud crash sound. I mean, how could it not? The building literally crashed to the ground when the horned pig attacked it.

readings.mnemonic: You're worried about the pig, that was a pretty big crash, after all. So you yell, "SOOEY (つい)!" Here pig pig pig. SOOEEEYYY! You know—the universal call for pigs

meaning.mnemonic: A crab will try to hide what it lacks with deceit. Lying, stealing, faking things—no type of deceit is too much for a crab.

readings.mnemonic: Deceit can only take you so far, and soon the crab is caught, tried for its crimes and coverups, and sentenced to death via guillotine (ぎ).

meaning.mnemonic: A tsunami hits your mohawk and it begins to drip. The water from the tsunami continues to drip from your mohawk long after the tsunami has passed. There’s a lot of water in your hair now, so it’s probably going to drip for a while.

readings.mnemonic: Luckily, you’re a self-proclaimed techie (てき), so you develop a device to stop the drip drip dripping. This techie device of yours is like a hair dryer helmet. You put it over your mohawk, it does its thing, and your hair is dry! Being a techie sure does have its benefits.

meaning.mnemonic: In the dirt there are flags and horns lined up with a lantern attached to them, making a fence. It's a little weird looking, but these things are definitely supposed to fence something in.

readings.mnemonic: You want to know what this fence is fencing in, so you take a step closer. As the light from the lantern gets brighter you see that the fence is around a ton of hay (へい).

meaning.mnemonic: It's raining on your spear that has winter power. When the warm rain hits your cold, winter spear, it creates fog.

readings.mnemonic: Through the fog you see the shape of a mythical kirin (きり). You can only see the outline through the fog, but you know it's there.

meaning.mnemonic: After passing through a door, you use a feather to put the finishing touches on a folding fan. The door leads to your folding fan workshop where you make all your folding fans. This folding fan is now complete that you’ve added a feather to it. How lovely it is.

readings.mnemonic: Your biggest folding fan customer is a centaur (せん). This centaur just loves your folding fans and this one you just made with the feather was for the centaur’s latest order. You go back out your door and deliver this folding fan to the centaur.

meaning.mnemonic: The door a criminal will get into is the front door. Now hold on, you may be thinking, wouldn't they go for the back door? No! 99% of home invasions happen when you leave your own front door unlocked!

readings.mnemonic: To protect your front door from criminals you plan to fill it with heat (ひ). Oh yeah, we're gonna Kevin McCallister this.

meaning.mnemonic: A soul will only inhabit a root if it's holding a grudge. Have you ever seen a nice, haunted tree? No! They're always angry and trying to get someone back for something.

readings.mnemonic: If you see one of these grudge trees, it's probably inhabited by the soul of a condor (こん). Humans tend to kill condors and take their trees away to build houses and make toilet paper. So condors hold pretty bad grudges against us, and so their souls end up stuck in a lot of trees.

meaning.mnemonic: You take a towel and wrap it around your head to keep the sun out of your eyes. You've invented... the hat!

readings.mnemonic: People see you wearing this fancy new hat thing and start asking you to share. You grab all your extra towels, roll them up, and bowl (ぼう) them down the street toward everyone who asks for one.

meaning.mnemonic: The soul mask helps you to see the deepest part of anyone's soul. You look around and in all the people you only see hate.

readings.mnemonic: It turns out you're not looking at normal people. You see so much hate because all the people you're looking at are actually just a group of zombies (ぞう).

meaning.mnemonic: The leader of a narwhal construction crew needs all the help he can get. The narwhals are beginning construction on an underwater city. The leader knows the narwhals are hard construction workers, but they’ll need some help building this city.

readings.mnemonic: Then you discover a saw (さ) who would be a great big help. This saw is very strong and would help you and your narwhal construction team out a lot. You should make use of this saw right away.

meaning.mnemonic: You have fingers in the thousands and while looking up at the sun you decide you want to insert them in there.

readings.mnemonic: You insert one finger, it burns up immediately, and its soul (そう) comes flying out screaming for a moment before it disappears. Hmm. You insert another finger and as it burns up, another little soul comes out screeching, "WHY WOULD YOU INSERT ME IN THERE!" and is gone.

meaning.mnemonic: A leader and Wolverine take a slide to Italy. Wolverine’s leader is Professor X, and they are both sliding down a big slide to Italy. How fun!

readings.mnemonic: Before Professor X can get off the slide into Italy, a large eagle (い) swoops down and plucks him right out of his wheelchair. That eagle is very strong. Goodbye, Professor X!

meaning.mnemonic: They say the key to telling a lie is to totally believe the lie yourself. They say that if you believe your own lie, others will believe it as well. This is key.

readings.mnemonic: The lie you told was about not stealing your buddy’s saw (さ). You actually did steal his saw. He saw you steal his saw, but now you are trying to lie your way out of it. It’s not going well.

meaning.mnemonic: With a woman's mouth, you have a likeness to me.

readings.mnemonic: You have a likeness to Jo-Anne (じょ) when you wear that mouth.

meaning.mnemonic: A landslide came out of your mouth and created your lips. Before the landslide, you just had a wide open mouth hole.

readings.mnemonic: Now you can use your new lips to enjoy a nice, cold Kuchi beer (くちびる). The Kuchi people are Afghan Pashtun nomads. They are lesser known for their amazing beer. And you've never been able to get this delicious beer into your mouth, but now that you have lips you can get it all in there.

meaning.mnemonic: A Viking moves your mouth with his hand to manipulate it. He sticks his hand into your mouth. With the Viking's hand in your mouth, he can make you look like you’re saying anything he wants.

readings.mnemonic: The Viking is manipulating you so that he can manipulate the Shougun (しょう)! You and the Shougun have grown pretty close over the last year or so, and this Viking is going to take advantage!

meaning.mnemonic: A wave crashes into a woman, transforming her into an old woman! The wave washes away all of the woman’s makeup, revealing her to be an old woman. The makeup she had on made her appear to be a much younger woman, but once the wave washed away her makeup, she was revealed for the old woman she is.

readings.mnemonic: In an attempt to distract you from the fact that she is actually an old woman, the old woman starts to baa (ば) and act like a sheep. The old woman goes “Baa! Baa!” and hops around on all fours like a sheep.

meaning.mnemonic: With a lid, you hit yourself in the mouth and then kick it like a pathetic loser. You kick the lid, even though it is your fault that you hit yourself in the mouth with it. It’s not the lid’s fault. You don’t need to kick it. You’re being pathetic.

readings.mnemonic: You kick the lid one last time and it bounces off the wall and hits you in the eye (あい). How pathetic. You are a pathetic mess. You should have never kicked the lid. Now both your eye and your mouth are in pain, you pathetic fool, you.

meaning.mnemonic: An insect specializing in construction builds a rainbow. Did you ever wonder where rainbows come from? Construction insects build them. Construction insects build rainbows.

readings.mnemonic: This rainbow building insect is so needy (にじ). He is needy because he needs everyone to look at his rainbow and praise him for what he’s done. “Look at my rainbow! Look at how good it is and I am! I’m so needy! Needy for praise and recognition!”

meaning.mnemonic: A big treasure treasure treasure treasure is refreshing! Sorry, I can’t say treasure treasure treasure treasure without saying it four times. See? I did it again. Anyway, this big treasure treasure treasure treasure is really refreshing. It’s been a long time since you found a treasure treasure treasure treasure, so finding this big one is really refreshing.

readings.mnemonic: You’d had a sour (さわ) taste in your mouth for not being able to find any treasure treasure treasure treasure for such a long time, but now that you found this big one, the sour taste is totally gone and it’s sooooo refreshing!

meaning.mnemonic: You keep your tongue to your self to give your heart a rest. You’ve been talking and moving your tongue around all day expressing your feelings. This has tired both your tongue and your heart out, so you stop your tongue moving and decide that you need some self rest time.

readings.mnemonic: What better way to rest than to eat some cake (けい)! No talking necessary. Just enjoy the delicious taste of cake on your tongue and feel your heart let out a sigh of relief.

meaning.mnemonic: Before you boil something, make sure that you roast it.

readings.mnemonic: Now you roast yourself some centaur (せん). Roasted centaur goes well with tea.

meaning.mnemonic: This shrimp is the exact length of a shaku, or Japanese foot. That’s how they came up with this form of measurement. They measured the length of this shrimp and it was the length of a Japanese foot which they deemed the shaku. It’s equal to 30.3cm, very close to one imperial foot.

readings.mnemonic: How is shaku, the Japanese foot, pronounced by Shaq (しゃく) in Japanese? Why Shaq pronounces it shaku. It’s pronounced shaku in both English and Japanese.

meaning.mnemonic: Take this stone and throw it at nine crosses to smash them! It's like old-fashioned bowling, but instead of rolling this stone to knock down the crosses, you want to completely smash them to bits!

readings.mnemonic: As you smash these crosses, you think of your cyborg (さい) and how much you want to smash the people who took it away from you. Your cyborg was so good at smashing things too. You could be smashing together, if you didn't have to sell it.

meaning.mnemonic: Your rice fortune is sticky. Rice is sticky. So is your rice fortune. Your fortune of rice is sticky because it is made up entirely of sticky rice.

readings.mnemonic: This rice is so sticky that you are able to sculpt nendoroids (ねん) from it. Your rice fortune is worth even more now that you are hand making limited edition nendoroids from it.

meaning.mnemonic: In the rice paddy there is a forehead with a top hat. It sits atop an area of tatami mats.

readings.mnemonic: Who made this creepy tatami mat altar? It was Jourm (じょう) the increasingly concerning farmhand who lives in your village.

meaning.mnemonic: The moon is the same as your torso. You must have a really huge torso for it to be the same as the moon.

readings.mnemonic: Your torso got so big because of all the doughnuts (どう) you ate. You ate so many doughnuts that your torso got to be the size of the moon and then you floated away into space with your own gravitational pull and everything. Doughnuts are dangerous things.

meaning.mnemonic: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for towel first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means towel as well.

readings.mnemonic: You know who loves towels? The King (きん) of England. He loves towels so much that he went around and put きん on every towel in the land, so you think of him whenever you use one.

meaning.mnemonic: There are flowers growing around a heart with a wick sticking out of it. The heart is a sacrifice to the old gods and the life energy bleeds from the burning wick to feed the flowers. The wick burns, releasing the power of the heart which spreads into the ground around the heart causing the flowers to grow.

readings.mnemonic: Sometimes the wick burning the heart isn’t enough for the flowers to grow properly and they get thirsty for the blood from your shin (しん). So, you slice open your shin with a sacrificial knife and drip your blood over the thirsty demon flowers.

meaning.mnemonic: A tree that is stamped with one pattern, then stamped with another pattern, over and over, is the willow tree.

readings.mnemonic: Ryu (りゅう) from Street Fighter really loves willow trees. Ryu loves them so much that he makes out with them. Ryu is open mouth kissing a willow tree. You are watching this. It is happening.

meaning.mnemonic: A scooter with horns with a pig riding on it will be able to accomplish anything.

readings.mnemonic: It was even able to successfully accomplish a feat that involved it jumping its scooter right into a swing (すい), swinging back and forth, then jumping off.

meaning.mnemonic: Flowers are mysteriously appearing in the rice paddy. No matter what you do to them, they continue to amass.

readings.mnemonic: As the flowers amass it starts attracting wildlife. Soon thousands of baby chicks (ちく) are amassing in the rice paddy as well.

meaning.mnemonic: The moon has a lot of power that is power it gets from the power of every armpit of every human on earth! Why does your armpit smell? It’s because the moon is draining the power from your armpit. The moon saps power from your armpit and that power is sucked up into the sky where the moon collects the power for its own devices.

readings.mnemonic: This is a pretty wacky (わき) armpit image isn’t it? Seeing lines of power traveling from your armpit to the moon. Definitely wacky. Have you ever seen something this wacky in real life?

meaning.mnemonic: Give a district weapons and it will assault other districts.

readings.mnemonic: This assault is all the 王's (おう) fault. The 王 gave the weapons to each of the districts on purpose so this would happen.

meaning.mnemonic: Having a foul mouth and horns will prevent you from getting into Heaven where you would blossom into an angel. If you have horns, you are not meant for Heaven and will not blossom there. To blossom in Heaven, you must not have horns or a foul mouth.

readings.mnemonic: You don’t want to blossom into a demon so you saw (さ) off your horns with a saw. If you saw off your horns, maybe you can beg for forgiveness and have your foul mouth forgiven.

meaning.mnemonic: Cast a book in gold to make a bowl. Books can be bent into the shape of a bowl, so then all you have to do is pour gold over it to keep it in that shape and ta-da! A bowl has been born!

readings.mnemonic: The gold bowl has a hatch (はち) attached to it, which used to be the book's back cover. That's fine, you use the hatch as a lid for the bowl!

meaning.mnemonic: Your servant uses a stool to break open shellfish. You know how much work shucking shellfish is so this method is really clever.

readings.mnemonic: "More clever than you!" your servant yells, tearing off his wig. "It is I, Ken (けん) the samurai. I saw you take this shellfish from my master's lands."

meaning.mnemonic: You use a cleat to climb a tree and your hair gets the same coloring as the foliage because your hair is like a chameleon. The coloring of your hair changes to whatever color is around you, so you use your cleats to climb trees to make your hair turn green and brown, and in the fall, yellow and orange and red!

readings.mnemonic: This cool coloring can only happen because you turned yourself into a cyborg (さい). Your hair and scalp are now made of high tech parts, not human ones.

meaning.mnemonic: In this building there's a small sun that's small. They keep this small, small sun inside of a crevice.

readings.mnemonic: They keep the sun in the crevice because this is a place where people ski (すき).

meaning.mnemonic: You need to put a clown in the dirt if you want to cultivate good crops there. Clowns act as a natural fertilizer, and this will make it super easy to cultivate any crops you could ever want in this dirt. Isn't nature amazing?

readings.mnemonic: Before you can start this whole cultivation process however, you have to say bye (ばい) to the clown. Say bye to him, then bash his head in, and drop him in the dirt.

meaning.mnemonic: Your foot, as your mama says, was given the task to dance. Shake those two foots your mama gave you and dance dance dance!

readings.mnemonic: You both dance so much that you develop an odor (おど). Not just any odor, an odor particular to stinky dancing feet.

meaning.mnemonic: This gate makes the sound of darkness. The gate looks like darkness, but it’s even more creepy that it sounds like darkness too.

readings.mnemonic: You decide to taste the darkness and discover that it is so yummy (やみ)! Who knew that darkness was so yummy? Mmm… this darkness tastes so yummy!

meaning.mnemonic: You have a surplus of ladles laid out diagonally in front of you. Why are they diagonal? And why do you have so many ladles? Why the surplus? Hang on, we'll get there.

readings.mnemonic: In front of this diagonal pattern is a shaman (しゃ) who is currently staring at you. You slowly reach down and turn one of the ladles around, diagonally, and look back up. The shaman's eyes are wide, and now they're scribbling on in a notebook.

meaning.mnemonic: You see shrimp on ice at the market in the morning. "I'll get some on the way home" you think to yourself. Later that evening, you see no shrimp, just ice. The supply of shrimp has been exhausted. It's all gone!

readings.mnemonic: How could the store exhaust its shrimp supply so quickly? Suddenly you notice the worker behind the fish counter has shrimp stuffed into their jeans (じん) . Aha! The culprit!

meaning.mnemonic: Rain falls off a tree and lands in your eye where it turns to frost. It turns to frost because it’s super cold outside and your body is freezing. The rain that fell off the tree turns to frost as soon as it hits your eye.

readings.mnemonic: This whole description is pretty emo. You came up with this whole emo frost idea because you are a shemo (しも). An emo who goes by she pronouns.

meaning.mnemonic: You need to feed this grain to a flower wearing turkey on a stool so you start the harvest. Grains don't pick themselves, you have to harvest them.

readings.mnemonic: You're just starting to harvest the grains when an angry cock (かく) shows up! He's mad because these are his grains and you're about to harvest them and feed them to a turkey instead of him.

meaning.mnemonic: This canopy of trees isn't actually a canopy of trees at all. When you look closely, you see these trees are actually giant stalks of hemp.

readings.mnemonic: Who planted all this hemp? Your mama (ま) did.

meaning.mnemonic: An odd horse is still a horse. It may look a little funny, but that doesn't change what it is on the inside.

readings.mnemonic: This horse is particularly odd because it knows how to use a key (き). It carries a key around its neck and uses it to get in and out of its stable.

meaning.mnemonic: The landslide measurement humiliates you. You told everyone you couldn't come to work, that your house had been destroyed and your car was carried away, but then scientists measured the landslide, and it only went a few feet.

readings.mnemonic: Your friends and coworkers humiliate you more by making jokes (じょく). "Uh oh, I heard it might rain later, I hope you don't drown in the inch of water that's coming!"

meaning.mnemonic: Fire you use to light up the street needs to go in a lamp. Campfires, matches? No, none of those work. You need bright, safe lamps to keep the street nice at night.

readings.mnemonic: These street lamps were first used in とうきょう. It was the most advanced city after all. And more people were out at night in とうきょう than anywhere else in Japan. So they needed lamps to light things up!

meaning.mnemonic: In the mysterious rice paddy there is some livestock. This livestock is also mysterious because no one knows where it came from. The mysterious livestock are only seen in the mysterious rice paddy. How mysterious indeed.

readings.mnemonic: Your favorite member of the mysterious livestock crew is a little chick (ちく). The chick is very cute and little. The chick is also very mysterious because it floats about without even flapping its little wings.

meaning.mnemonic: The tsunami hits your form and you begin to melt. You are a witch and water makes you melt. The tsunami is a lot of water, so once it touches your form, you begin to melt.

readings.mnemonic: The only way to reverse the melt process is to eat some yogurt (よう). The yogurt counteracts the melting from the water and your form will become whole again. Quick, eat some yogurt!

meaning.mnemonic: The type of insect that ruins your writing is the mosquito. You're trying to write, when you hear that horrible high-pitched mosquito noise in your ear. You jerk your head and swat and it's gone. But when you look down, there's lines all over what you were writing.

readings.mnemonic: That mosquito noise sounds like it's driving a tiny car (か) in your ear. How are you supposed to write with a bug driving around going bzzz bzzz like a revving car?

meaning.mnemonic: Take your towel and make it long. It has to be longer than that! For this will be your notebook, which you will write all your notes in.

readings.mnemonic: Inside your long towel notebook you just write the same name over and over again: "Mrs. Chou" (ちょう).

meaning.mnemonic: A tsunami surplus will cover all the dirt with paint. The surplus of tsunamis will strike the paint factories first (everyone knows paint factories are built close to the ocean). Then the paint will flow over all the dirt and paint it a ton of rainbow colors.

readings.mnemonic: You touch the paint in the dirt with your toe (と) to see if it's still wet. It is. The paint is still very wet and now your toe looks like a tiny rainbow.

meaning.mnemonic: Your shellfish are worth a fortune because you decided to paste your fortune to the shellfish.

readings.mnemonic: You're a little crazy, which is why you decided to use paste to paste your entire fortune to these shellfish, and as you paste each one you yell out, "Ha (は)!" Paste.

meaning.mnemonic: The sunlight shines on your forehead in your car with a great radiance. The car you are in is a convertible, so the sunlight shines right onto your big bald forehead. The sun has a pretty powerful radiance as it is, but the sheen from the sunlight hitting your forehead is the most powerful radiance ever witnessed by man.

readings.mnemonic: This radiance is the key (き) to powering your car. Your car runs on reflected solar energy, and the radiance coming from your forehead is the most powerful source of radiant sunlight ever imagined. Your forehead is a perfect key for this car.

meaning.mnemonic: When your soul has an idea it's just a recollection of something you already know. Only your brain can have original ideas, so when your soul tries to come up with one, it's just a recollection of something you thought before now.

readings.mnemonic: Your soul is sending you a recollection right now of... your past life as a farmer in Oklahoma (おく). You see yourself farming and sweating and living a wonderful life. Hmm, maybe you should move to Oklahoma and live the simple life again.

meaning.mnemonic: If you try to put your soul into everything, you'll regret it. It's not so much that putting your soul into things is bad, but every single thing? You'll burn out immediately. You won't be able to be good at any of those things. And you'll regret all the time you wasted trying to be the best at everything.

readings.mnemonic: The regret is too strong for you to ignore, so you decide to drop everything but kayaking (かい). If there's one thing you refuse to regret, it's your bright orange kayak and all the friends you made at kayaking club.

meaning.mnemonic: You take a rake in for a measurement but it is resistant. The rake doesn’t want to have its measurements taken. The rake is resistant to have any measurement taken because it feels inferior to the other rakes and doesn’t want to be embarrassed if it ends up being smaller than the others.

readings.mnemonic: Because the rake is persistently resistant, you eventually tie it to the table with your neck tie (たい). The tie won’t hold for long, so you need to take each measurement quickly.

meaning.mnemonic: On a cliff, the pope is holding a shield. The pope is near the edge of the cliff and is using the shield to fend off demons. The demons want to shove the pope off the cliff, but the pope is using his holy shield of popery to fend them off.

readings.mnemonic: The light of the pope's shield begins to fade. The shield's holy power is waning! Just as the demons are about to push him off the cliff, the sun begins to rise. That's right! It's June (じゅん) and summer has just begun. The pope's shield reflects the power of June's bright sun into the eyes of the demons, casting them off the cliff behind him and back into hell!

meaning.mnemonic: There is an insect on the roof in a spoon. It's there for the eating, and it's how you plan to attract a snake to your roof.

readings.mnemonic: Why don't you just bring a snake up to the roof yourself? Because snakes are heavy (へび).

meaning.mnemonic: If the king gives you a knife you become part of his squad. Every king has a knife squad or two protecting him and making sure his subjects keep in line.

readings.mnemonic: This squad is led by Han (はん) Solo, so it's basically a 50/50 shot that the king is gonna die.

meaning.mnemonic: You’re so hungry that you eat a table so you won’t starve. If you don’t eat this table, you will most definitely starve, so you eat the table to stay alive.

readings.mnemonic: After you finish the table, you still feel like you might starve so you decide to eat every key (き) off your key ring. One by one, you eat each and every key so you don’t starve.

meaning.mnemonic: If you have nothing to eat but your ego, you'll starve. You can't eat it, and your ego is keeping you from accepting actual food or help from other people.

readings.mnemonic: You starve (thanks ego) and turn into a gargoyle (が). As your stomach aches, your skin turns gray and you slowly harden into a crouched position.

meaning.mnemonic: You drive your scooter off this cliff, holding your cross tight to your chest, at a swift speed.

readings.mnemonic: Because you had such a swift take off, you didn't notice that your jeans (じん) were ripped right off your body. Until now.

meaning.mnemonic: There's power, power, and power stacked on top of the moon, threatening to bring it down!

readings.mnemonic: This extra power-filled moon is now trying to threaten the safety of きょうと. All of きょうと is shaking and getting dark as the moon comes closer and closer.

meaning.mnemonic: Bite a tree's root with your fang to get an approximation on its age. It won't be exact, this isn't scientific or anything, but it will be pretty close.

readings.mnemonic: As you're recording your approximation down,  somebody comes up and shouts, “Hey guy (がい)! I’ll give you $10,000 for that tree there, guy!” This guy must be crazy. That’s much more than your approximation of the value of this thing. But you sell it to the guy anyway.

meaning.mnemonic: You run your fingers along the words of a  paragraph. You are learning about the law because you plan to arrest somebody.

readings.mnemonic: Who do you want to arrest? You want to arrest こういち. Even though he's started wars, created a religion, and trapped a child in a cavity, it's going to be tricky to arrest him because he's the emperor now.

meaning.mnemonic: If someone wants to boil, you let them boil!

readings.mnemonic: Welp, the pot is at a rolling boil and your knee (に) is in there. The person wasn't saying they wanted to boil, they said they wanted to boil someone. And that meant you. Well, your knee anyway.

meaning.mnemonic: If a helicopter loiters near a black hole then it's going to capsize. I mean, yeah, it's not a boat, but just look, that's what's happening! That helicopter is going down!

readings.mnemonic: You're doing your best to cover the black hole to stop the helicopter from capsizing but it's not working! “F**k you (ふく) black hole!" you shout. You just want to cover it up! You just want to do the right thing!

meaning.mnemonic: The horse who can write a paragraph gets to be a chess piece. Only the most erudite of horses gets selected to be a chess piece. The knight’s chess piece is represented by a horse, and for a horse to earn this honor, they must first write a paragraph explaining why they deserve the honor.

readings.mnemonic: Upon being told that he will never be a chess piece, the horse slips into a coma (こま). The horse will never awaken from this coma as he knows he will never fulfill his dream of becoming a chess piece, so he has nothing to live for.

meaning.mnemonic: Your soul connects to five different mouths, enhancing your comprehension. You can easily comprehend what each of those souls belonging to those mouths wants and feels deep down.

readings.mnemonic: Your comprehension is the strongest with the fifth mouth, belonging to Godzilla (ご). You finally get why he wants to destroy buildings and cities.

meaning.mnemonic: Your soul is going wild because you're confused. If you're confused, it's usually because you don't know what's going on or what to do. This makes the soul inside your body go absolutely wild!

readings.mnemonic: Whenever you're confused, こういち appears to offer you guidance. He's confused a lot, so he knows how to help. And knowledge offered by こういち is the best medicine for confusion.

meaning.mnemonic: Watch what you say to what appears to be a sweet tree, because that tree will 100% conspire against you.

readings.mnemonic: Now you're getting it! That tree is trying to conspire against you and take you down. Take your bowling (ぼう) ball and bowl it and all its friends down!

meaning.mnemonic: On the roof there's some type of turkey bird, but thinner and longer. You look closer and realize it's a crane.

readings.mnemonic: The crane leans down toward you from its roof perch and squawks, "Too rude (つる)!" You're shocked! You didn't know the crane could speak English, but even worse, it knew you called it a turkey bird.

meaning.mnemonic: You use your fingers and a stone to begin cultivation of the land. You use your fingers to till the soil, the stone to flatten the ground, and you carefully poke the seeds into the dirt and then use the stone to smash them further down.

readings.mnemonic: Cultivation is suddenly halted because a tack (たく) sticks into your finger. You pull the tack out, throw it away and start cultivation again when... ouch! There's another tack. This field is full of tacks!

meaning.mnemonic: You take a lid, and aiming it at the sun you kick it into the air and eventually it begins to decline and crashes into the sun, causing it to supernova. Imagine kicking this lid so hard that it flies into space. See it fly up to the peak of its arch, then watch as it begins the decline until it finally collides with the sun.

readings.mnemonic: As the lid begins to decline in the sky, you realize what’s going to happen so you attempt to swing (すい) to safety. Swing on some vines in the direction opposite of the sun. You know that once that lid finishes its decline and collides with the sun, there’s gonna be trouble.

meaning.mnemonic: A commander who's big will use his size to encourage his troops.

readings.mnemonic: He encourages the Shougun (しょう) too! You've never seen the Shougun express any emotion other than intense indifference or intense dislike.

meaning.mnemonic: A tsunami and a couple fires run into each other. They cancel each other out completely, and the remainder left behind is a faint remnant of what was once there.

readings.mnemonic: Just like the tsunami and fire canceling each other out, leaving a faint remainder of what was, your tan (たん) is extremely faint as well.

meaning.mnemonic: There’s a stone, a tree, another tree, and a coat rack. That stone and two trees will make the perfect foundation, or cornerstone, for a house to put that coat rack in! This stone is flat and heavy and both of the trees are flexible and durable.

readings.mnemonic: After you finish the foundation, the only step that's left is to wash the entire thing with soap (そ).

meaning.mnemonic: Compare a building to some dirt and you'll see the difference between you and His and Her Highness. You live outside and sleep on the dirt. But His and Her Highness both live in a huge building.

readings.mnemonic: I bet His Highness has never had to sleep in hay (へい) either, like you do every night. Hay is what you use as a pillow, mattress, blanket. Basically hay and dirt are all you have. Unlike His Highness.

meaning.mnemonic: In the event of a tsunami, Wolverine, your forehead, and a stool will all be immersed in it. You will become immersed in the tsunami after it hits because tsunamis are gigantic and bring a lot of water. Now you and your forehead are immersed in the tsunami along with Wolverine and a stool.

readings.mnemonic: Still immersed, the stool floats over and hits you in the shin (しん). The tsunami gave the stool a good push and while it was fully immersed, it ran into your shin. It really hurts.

meaning.mnemonic: The few members of society without power suffer from severe inferiority complexes. Most people in this world have lots of power, so the few that do not feel quite inferior. It is this feeling of inferiority that fuels their inferiority complexes.

readings.mnemonic: Since you suffer from such extreme feelings of inferiority, when someone offers you and your friends the chance to gain power, you yell “Let’s (れつ) go!” without a second thought. “Let’s go, guys! Come on! Power awaits us!”

meaning.mnemonic: This crab trap has the power of intuition. By the power of intuition, this crab trap can trap like, every crab. Through intuition, it knows where the crabs will go and how they will react, so it is much easier to trap them.

readings.mnemonic: This crab trap's intuition powers were extracted from Genghis Khan (かん) himself. And as we all know by now, Genghis Khan was the absolute master of intuition, he always knew what his enemies and his allies were about to do.

meaning.mnemonic: A building that has a bully will isolate itself. Building have feelings like people, you know.

readings.mnemonic: The isolated building only has one companion, and it's the cock (かく) that lives inside of it.

meaning.mnemonic: In the foot capital, it's tough to be a dog because you're always getting kicked.

readings.mnemonic: When you kick a dog, there's an explosion of 毛 (け).

meaning.mnemonic: You take a stool, another stool, and yet another stool and stack them on top of a tree to make a mulberry bush. This is how mulberry bushes are made. You take three stools and you put them atop a tree.

readings.mnemonic: You then eat a mulberry because a mulberry will cure (くわ) any and all ailments. A mulberry is the cure-all of nature.

meaning.mnemonic: You give a flag and a spoon to a nun as an offering. You give her this flag and this spoon because they are very precious to you and you want to show the nun how serious you are about repenting for your evil deeds.

readings.mnemonic: You’re getting down on one knee (に) as you present the flag and the spoon to the nun. The nun accepts your offer and takes your flag and spoon from you. Your soul is saved!

meaning.mnemonic: The king takes his slide into his private jet and is given a pearl as a gift, by you! He's letting you ride in his jet today, and you were told the king should be presented with a pearl as soon as he boards.

readings.mnemonic: The king takes the pearl and tosses it into a chute (しゅ) next to the slide he took to get into the jet. You watch as the pearl goes down, down, down until it lands into a huge vat of pearls.

meaning.mnemonic: Your fingers give you a good reason to pluck things. You pluck flowers out of the ground. You pluck a cat out of a tree. Why? Because you have fingers! That's your reason.

readings.mnemonic: Now that you have a reason to pluck things (you have fingers, after all) you decide you want to pluck all the fur off of Chewbacca (ちゅう). He is very furry, and you want to know what he looks like under there.

meaning.mnemonic: On the dirt there is a lid trying to cover the number of times the dawn has risen here. You walk over and pull the lid off and the whole thing transforms into a podium. A podium for the dawn to tell you how many times it's risen over this dirt over and over again. It just keeps going and you realize the lid was here because this dang podium can't seem to keep a lid on it! (Get it? Figure of speech!)

readings.mnemonic: You listen to what the podium has to say for so long you finally can't help but ask, "Who are you?" "I'm the dawn (だん), of course!" And this is my podium where I spread the good news about the dawn!

meaning.mnemonic: The only type of can you'll be building in prison is one made of pottery. Do you honestly think they would let you have anything made of metal or plastic? No, too dangerous. You have to make all of your cans and plates and underpants the old-fashioned pottery way.

readings.mnemonic: You get so good at pottery that the guards start to notice and offer to sell what you make in とうきょう. とうきょう is a big pottery town, after all. You'll make a fortune! Well... the guards will at least.

meaning.mnemonic: A woman sees herself (oneself) as a princess or a queen. As women should!

readings.mnemonic: All of us princesses and queens share a special heat (ひ). When we see another princess or queen that heat passes through us and we nod to one another.

meaning.mnemonic: Take your greatest treasure, hold a knife nice and close to it, and prune away all the weak and dead bits.

readings.mnemonic: Currently, you want to prune your greatest treasure: your car (か). Your car is made of wood, and it keeps trying to grow new buds and branches, so you have to prune them off.

meaning.mnemonic: You stop a spoon from moving by tying it with thread that's purple. The spoon wouldn't stop moving around, so you had to use your favorite purple thread to make it stop. It's the strongest thread you have.

readings.mnemonic: You have to use all of your purple thread, and now you need more. You go into the back yard and call over your purple sheep (し).

meaning.mnemonic: The mouth of that turkey is solely his. It’s very unique, so that mouth could belong to no other turkey but him. That mouth is solely his.

readings.mnemonic: You traveled a long way to see this turkey and the mouth that is solely his but you missed your exit on the highway and you have to hang a U-ey (ゆい).
