You know what hang a U-ey means, right? It’s making a U-turn. Well, you have to hang a U-ey on the highway so you can get off at the right spot to see this turkey and the mouth that is solely his.

meaning.mnemonic: A hill knife is the most sturdy knife you can find.

readings.mnemonic: This sturdy (but strangely shaped) knife is used by ごういち.

meaning.mnemonic: If someone loiters it's correct to subjugate them.

readings.mnemonic: You subjugate these loiterers with your holy blue saber (せい)! It's the correct thing to do, after all, and you were given this saber all those levels ago because you did the correct thing.

meaning.mnemonic: With your fingers under an axe, you say a vow. A vow is a sacred promise, so you have to be really serious when you say one. That's why you do it with an axe hovering above your fingers—it's a reminder that if you break this vow your fingers are gonna get chopped off.

readings.mnemonic: When you finish your vow, you take out your holy blue saber (せい) and cut the axe in half! You know you're never going to break your vow, and if you do, you'll use your own saber to cut off your fingers.

meaning.mnemonic: The leader of this valley is very vulgar. The name of the valley is Vulgar Valley, so it makes sense for its leader to be very vulgar.

readings.mnemonic: This vulgar leader leads his Bosozoku (ぞく) bike gang through Vulgar Valley, patrolling the area and spreading vulgarity as he goes.

meaning.mnemonic: A tsunami at the gate of the king makes sure all of his plants get watered. The gate prevents the tsunami from damaging anything inside the king’s home, and the plants around the gate get watered by the water of the tsunami.

readings.mnemonic: These plants are getting watered in June (じゅん), the month they need watering the most. June is a hot month, so it’s good that this tsunami came and got the king’s plants watered when it did.

meaning.mnemonic: The leader, Master Splinter (the rat from Ninja Turtles) isn't even supposed to exist. He exists because someone accidentally poured ooze on him.

readings.mnemonic: But really, if you do something accidentally, it's probably a good (ぐう) thing in a way. You learn a bit about how you can improve yourself so you don't do it again, or in Splinter's case, it's just a good mistake!

meaning.mnemonic: The construction beggar is one who begs for construction projects. He doesn't do it for money or fame, he begs for construction because he is so adept at what he does.

readings.mnemonic: "The most adept at construction in all the land is me," says the construction beggar to emperor こういち.

meaning.mnemonic: A fish in its mouth and in the other mouth is half a beggar (the head is cut off). The other half is on the ground. The animal that has fishes and beggars in its mouth, is an alligator.

readings.mnemonic: The reading is the same as the わに in "Wanikani." Ever heard of it?

meaning.mnemonic: Put your fingers on the bed, grasp the sheets and bundle them up. Now you can do the laundry!

readings.mnemonic: In between grasping and bundle-ing, you shout HA (は)! That's when the sheets come off the bed.

meaning.mnemonic: A horse that is fat is a burdensome animal.

readings.mnemonic: But you have to be nice to the burdensome horse because this horse is your dad (だ).

meaning.mnemonic: A tsunami is the same as a cave. Because, if a wave is big enough, it will curl over on itself, creating a sort of cave within the wave. That's why it's the same as a cave!

readings.mnemonic: Best way to remember the reading for this kanji is to think about how the shape of a cave is the shape of a doughnut (どう).

meaning.mnemonic: The leader all in white is the chief. All the other leaders are wearing some other color, but that's how you tell the chief apart from the other leaders.

readings.mnemonic: The reading is the same as 白, which is included in this kanji. The other reading is お, and it's like the honorific 御, in a way. You'd want to be polite to someone who is the chief ______, right? That's why it could be お, too.

meaning.mnemonic: Under a canopy, someone thinking with a brush in their mouth has a sudden thought, and uses the brush to write the word "China". Thus, China was born.

readings.mnemonic: Believe it or not, this sudden invention of China happened in とうきょう. Well, it wasn't とうきょう yet. And it was a traveling Chinese person who did it. But you know legends, they're just all over the place.

meaning.mnemonic: You want to write a chapter about hair in your new book so you have to make sure it's really clear. Clear enough so that ANYbody can read it.

readings.mnemonic: Your clear writing got the attention of the Shougun (しょう) and now he's at your door once again. Although, this time he's angrier than usual. His hair also looks awful. He took your advice after reading the book and cut his entire ponytail off.

meaning.mnemonic: Watch what you say to the next mouth over, because they hired you to consult them.

readings.mnemonic: You panic, and consult the man into buying a sheep (し).

meaning.mnemonic: The Yoga King presides over all courts: law, imperial, and so forth. In this case, you've met him in the court of law, where he is judge, jury, and executioner.

readings.mnemonic: The court of the Yoga King is against you. You have to turn this around, so you start pushing tater (てい) tots into his tater-tot-hole shaped mouth.

meaning.mnemonic: This is an animal with an angled sword claw that's filled with cow meat but looks like an insect. What kind of animal is that? It's a crab.

readings.mnemonic: The reading is the same as the かに in WaniKani.

meaning.mnemonic: The sun hits this and breaks into three suns. What can split the sun in three directions? A crystal!

readings.mnemonic: Who is hoarding and harnessing the power of these crystals? That would be the Shougun (しょう).

meaning.mnemonic: A woman is making a dirt cage in the sun. She's using it to trap water, making this a dirt dam. If you think about it, dams are just dirt cages anyway.

readings.mnemonic: Something about the woman working hard to build this dam makes her super sexy (せき) to you. Maybe it's because the sun is so bright, making her shine, or maybe it's because hard work is attractive. Who knows.

meaning.mnemonic: If a tsunami hits your helicopter while you are jackhammering, it will drift out to sea. What were you doing with a jackhammer at a time like this? Now your helicopter is drifting away!

readings.mnemonic: As it drifts away you shout, "Heyooo! (ひょう)." You know the helicopter probably can't hear you (or understand you) but maybe it will turn on and stop drifting away if you shout it enough.

meaning.mnemonic: A tsunami hits a roof and then corrects itself. This causes it to swirl around, creating an eddy.

readings.mnemonic: There is a person trying to create an eddy with a tsunami, and when their roof correction device is shown to be effective, they sing: "This is how you do (よど) it."

meaning.mnemonic: The correct way to block the sun with dirt is with an embankment. Build a huge, sloping embankment correctly and the sun won't be able to bother you ever again!

readings.mnemonic: Unfortunately, building a correct embankment doesn't just take dirt, but tater (てい) tots too. You pile up the dirt and the tater tots so the embankment can be nice and high.

meaning.mnemonic: You walk out on a cliff, where you find in the ground a mouth poking out. It speaks: "It is me, the empress of these lands!"

readings.mnemonic: When you finish unburying the empress, the first thing she says to you is: "Please, you must hurry and take me to Emperor こういち."

meaning.mnemonic: Turn a sickness into a weapon and it becomes an epidemic. This sickness spreads to everyone and it's all your fault because you put it in the water supply.

readings.mnemonic: These epidemics spread by 駅 (えき). Each train takes the sickness and shoots off in a different direction, spreading it further.

meaning.mnemonic: You have a numbered feather. Pick your favorite number and put it on the feather. Then, put the numbered feather on your head. When you put it on, you're able to flip and flip over and over.

readings.mnemonic: You're pretty good at your flip technique, but you're not that good. You really need to practice and hone (ほん) your skills and get better.

meaning.mnemonic: A tree can be a tree, but it can also be a psychopath. The tree goes from being a regular tree to being a psychopath. Such mood swings are so rough. Especially when the tree slips to gloom.

readings.mnemonic: Then the tree switches from gloom to being super excited (these moodswings!). The super excited tree starts doing dubstep. Uts (うつ) uts uts uts uts ♬.

meaning.mnemonic: There is a tsunami coming up over a cliff made of dirt. You can see this happening very far away because it's right on the horizon.

readings.mnemonic: You squint into the horizon and see something else. There's some guy (がい) up there. And he's... he's being swept away by the tsunami. The guy disappears into the horizon. The guy is gone.

meaning.mnemonic: A gold name on this piece of wood is the inscription that shows the artist's signature.

readings.mnemonic: The inscription is a name written on something, right? Remember the kanji for "name"? It is 名, and it shares the reading with this kanji as well, making both names めい.

meaning.mnemonic: The leader cat pirate is the greatest cat pirate of them all. It leads all the cat pirate leaders, even! This is truly a cat pirate to look up to.

readings.mnemonic: Your job is to bring this leader of cat pirates (whom you look up to) its favorite food: gyoza (ぎょう).

meaning.mnemonic: A tsunami crashes into the sun, which is then caught in a net tied to a stool! Wait a second... this doesn't sound realistic, this is from that pirate manga you're always reading!

readings.mnemonic: Manga starts with man (まん)!

meaning.mnemonic: A bamboo tsunami's specialty is to crush everything in front of it, smash down, and turn into multiple record books.

readings.mnemonic: A record book is a book (ぼ), when it comes down to it.

meaning.mnemonic: The restaurant radical and the restaurant kanji are the same!

readings.mnemonic: This restaurant only serves tater (てい) tots. Really, would you ever want to go to a restaurant that didn't have tater tots? No.

meaning.mnemonic: What you say on the street needs to be revised. Your words need to be polished, you can't publish improv. Revise your street word inspiration before you share it again.

readings.mnemonic: You want to revise the song you wrote about tater (てい) tots at lunch today. But it needs a lot of revising.

meaning.mnemonic: A samurai who can fight with icicles on him is more robust than regular samurai. Can you imagine how robust you'd have to be to fight in weather cold enough to form icicles on your body?

readings.mnemonic: You may think it's just his robust body, but it's actually the samurai's robust soul (そう) that keeps him fighting through the cold and the icicles.

meaning.mnemonic: There are nine cars all driving in the same place. With so many cars driving in the same place, they create a rut.

readings.mnemonic: To get out of the rut you have to put in a second key (き) that turns on the thrusters. You put in the key and press the "take off" button.

meaning.mnemonic: A big turkey in the rice paddy is getting all stirred up. He's kicking up all the rice. Who stirred him up?

readings.mnemonic: While the turkey is stirred up, it also looks like it's having a lot of fun (ふん).

meaning.mnemonic: At the top of the mountain is a signpost to tell you you've reached the summit. Literally every mountain that humans have reached the top of has one of these summit signs.

readings.mnemonic: At the summit, you decide to build your new home (ほう). It's been destroyed so many times, and you're sick of it. Maybe if you build you home at the summit of this mountain it will be safer.

meaning.mnemonic: There's a cross in the dirt and the dirt is surrounded by flowers and shells from shellfish. This is a tomb. The flowers and shellfish were put here as decorations and to honor the dead that currently lay under the dirt. And the cross marks the tomb, obviously.

readings.mnemonic: This may be a tomb, but it feels really fun (ふん). It is decorated, after all. This tomb isn't a sad place, it's a fun place to remember the people you loved.

meaning.mnemonic: With your fingers you put some weapons in a boat for transport. This is a transport boat and its your job to get these weapons from one place to another.

readings.mnemonic: Hey! You're transporting weapons just like Han (はん) Solo! I mean, it was a spaceship, not technically a boat, but he definitely used the Millennium Falcon as a transport.

meaning.mnemonic: A fang on a building shows that it's wicked. Something wicked probably lives in the building too.

readings.mnemonic: You peek inside the wicked building and a wicked jaguar (じゃ) suddenly pounces at you! You let out a sigh of relief when it's stopped by the window, but then... the window opens?! What a wicked building! It's letting the jaguar get you!

meaning.mnemonic: You're sitting on your stool again!!?

readings.mnemonic: Your friends are starting to worry about you, because you're always sitting on that stool. "What is the matter (また) with you?" they scream! You might want to imagine that all your friends have Jamaican and/or British accents to make this one fit a bit better!

meaning.mnemonic: We must stop the moon. That, at least, we can come to an agreement on.

readings.mnemonic: "We have agreement," the world's leaders all say. "We will work together to stop the moon, and we have agreement on who we will follow, Emperor こういち.

meaning.mnemonic: If you want to have a tsunami at your wedding, you need to make sure you have it at the bay. Anywhere more inland, and the tsunami won't reach it in time.

readings.mnemonic: How did you get a tsunami to show up in the bay in the first place? By throwing a bunch of uranium (うら) in there, of course! Its highly unstable nature can make any body of water, especially a calm bay, turn violent.

meaning.mnemonic: Your fingers have husband horns. They are there right between each of your fingers.

readings.mnemonic: What is between your fingers? Your husband (はさ) horns.

meaning.mnemonic: If a tsunami hits a dollar the water will instantly start to boil!

readings.mnemonic: The boiling water crashes onto the land and you realize your foot is in it! No, not one foot, both your foots (ふつ)! It hurts so much that you can't even remember the word for two foots.

meaning.mnemonic: A lantern with horns that can hold ten thousand drops of water is sitting on the ground. You get closer and realize it's not a lantern, it's a bottle. It's got horns, and a weird handle, but it's definitely a bottle with water inside of it.

readings.mnemonic: Even though you're not the one who left this bottle here, you decide to do the right thing and throw it in the trash bin (びん). It's not right to leave a bottle just sitting on the ground, you know.

meaning.mnemonic: The call radical and the call kanji are the same. This kanji can also mean eat, because why would you call someone if not to ask them to eat with you?!

readings.mnemonic: You are called to come eat by the Shougun (しょう). He's been really impressed with you lately and he wants to chat over drinks, he says on the phone.

meaning.mnemonic: You try to put your toe inside a shellfish, but it just won't open. That's because this shellfish has sworn an oath of chastity.

readings.mnemonic: "Chastity is really important to me," the shellfish says. "But, maybe if you give me a tater (てい) tot, I'll change my mind."

meaning.mnemonic: There is a special type of meditation where you put a lid on your mouth and touch your forehead down to your legs. If you can do this pose, everything in life will become completely clear. Everything will clear out of your head too. You should try it.

readings.mnemonic: Your mind is as clear as a sparkling clear pond. On this pond you see yourself in a row (りょう) boat. A single row boat on the clear pond that is now your mind.

meaning.mnemonic: The spirits of the two trees you destroyed with your jackhammer live on in the collar you made out of them.

readings.mnemonic: The collar keeps whispering, "Eric (えり)!" into your ear. Your name isn't Eric (I mean it could be, in that case wow, weird, right?), so you assume one of the trees you killed was named Eric. But that's the only name you hear, so maybe they were both named Eric? It's weird.

meaning.mnemonic: So my building has a big splinter, right in the corner. So what?

readings.mnemonic: That corner is dangerous, but what are you going to do, sue me (すみ)?

meaning.mnemonic: The buddy building is in the next county. If it was in your county then it wouldn't be a buddy, it would be a neighbor. You're aware of this building, but they aren't that close, so they're just a buddy.

readings.mnemonic: Your county is everything you can reach when shooting a gun (ぐん). If the bullet can't reach a building you know, it's a buddy building in another county.

meaning.mnemonic: Put syrup too close to fire and it will dry up. Put any liquid substance near fire and it will dry up actually, but syrup especially. It goes from being sticky and gooey and yummy to a pile of hard, dry sugar. Not so yummy.

readings.mnemonic: If you dry up syrup like this, you're removing its soul (そう). Have you ever seen dry syrup before? No soul in that. In fact, you probably have no soul if you can dry out syrup like this without feeling bad about it.

meaning.mnemonic: Kill a shrimp with a sickle and you'll need a really good explanation for yourself. What did that shrimp do to you? Why use a sickle? Well? What's your explanation?

readings.mnemonic: In your explanation you blame everything on Shaq (しゃく). He told you to do it! It's all Shaq's fault, you explain.

meaning.mnemonic: If you eat both the moon and the sun with a spoon you'll get fat. Maybe if you only ate one you could get away with it, but you wanted both and now you're pretty fat.

readings.mnemonic: Once you're nice and fat, you look in the mirror to admire your new girth. But that's not you... it's a sheep (し)!

meaning.mnemonic: The leader of Korea is destined for greatness.

readings.mnemonic: The greatness radiates off of the leader of Korea, so much so that you can hardly look. Just when you're about to close your eyes to shield them from the greatness, a great eagle (い) soars over them, letting out a cry.

meaning.mnemonic: Your car is dry because you kept it under the eaves of your house.

readings.mnemonic: On top of the eaves of your house Ken (けん) the samurai is counting houses too.

meaning.mnemonic: You put flowers on your scooter and your car. The flowers you put on them are lotus flowers.

readings.mnemonic: You're putting a lotus on both your scooter and car because they are rentals (れん).

meaning.mnemonic: A person with horns has you on the ground and lets loose two poops over your heart. "Mercy! Mercy!" You cry, but the horned dude doesn't stop until there are two gross poops sitting on your heart. "M-mercy..." is the only thing you can think to say.

readings.mnemonic: As you shout "Mercy!" one more time, suddenly Jesus (じ) appears out of no where and punches the horned guy into the stratosphere. Jesus snaps his fingers and the poop is gone and you're off the ground. Your heart is safe.

meaning.mnemonic: The dirt on the forehead of a pig makes a small mound. Picture it, if you will. A pig is rooting through the dirt. It lifts its head and there is a mound of dirt right on its forehead.

readings.mnemonic: The pig's forehead dirt mound keeps getting bigger until it's the size of two cars (つか)! Pigs are big, but you didn't think one could balance a mound the size of two cars on its forehead and not fall over.

meaning.mnemonic: The mysterious radical and the mysterious kanji are the same!

readings.mnemonic: There is no one more mysterious than Genji (げん). He's tall, dark, handsome, and most of all... 〜mysterious〜!

meaning.mnemonic: When the moon faces the right direction, everyone on earth becomes obese. The pull of the moon moves all the water on earth as well as inside us, so when it faces the right way, we all get super fat.

readings.mnemonic: You look around and everyone is obese like you. You try to reach out to them, but you roll over like a big bowling (ぼう) ball. The person next to you does too. Soon you're all rolling around like helpless, obese bowling balls.

meaning.mnemonic: You have a plow and a (water) well. These are the two things you need in order to plow.

readings.mnemonic: plowing all the fields are こういちs. Not Emperor こういち. These are the こういち clones the government made, and now they're being put to use.

meaning.mnemonic: Everyone knows that when a woman plays football she becomes a princess. Thats how princesses are made.

readings.mnemonic: Remember the word 姫? It means princess too. If you remember the ひめ from 姫, you'll be able to remember this one too.

meaning.mnemonic: Your clan is breaking ground and building your new residence. You're all working together to make you a new home!

readings.mnemonic: Your new residence is complete! You step closer and the smell of tater (てい) tots hits your nose. Someone is making you tater tots in your new residence. Wait, no they aren't. Your residence is MADE of tater tots! Thank you, clan!

meaning.mnemonic: You wake up in prison and there is a big mouth full of legs coming really, really close to your own mouth so you scream! Scream because this is terrifying. Scream because it's all you can think to do.

readings.mnemonic: You scream and scream and scream until a door bursts open. It's Genghis Khan (かん) and he looks mad. Apparently your screaming is bothering him and now he's gonna give you a real reason to scream.

meaning.mnemonic: Flowers that grow in a rice paddy only live to be seedlings. Once they sprout, they're plucked away to make room for more rice. Poor little seedlings.

readings.mnemonic: The seedlings try their best to blend in by referring to themselves as myou (みょう), you know, me and you combined. That's myou.

meaning.mnemonic: A turkey sitting on a stool is something every ship has in its crow's nest. That's why the universal ship counter is a turkey on a stool. Not a crow.

readings.mnemonic: Once you become the best ship counter in the world everyone will think you are super sexy (せき)! Nothing is sexier than being able to count, and counting ships is the sexiest thing you can count.

meaning.mnemonic: If you look in a tiger's stomach you'll find a bunch of skin. It's really gross but what else did you think you'd find? Everyone knows tigers can't digest the skin of the things it eats.

readings.mnemonic: The only person who would try to take skin from a tiger's stomach is a fool (ふ). You'll probably get your head bitten off looking for skin that way.

meaning.mnemonic: A car that's lacking is really soft. Cars need to be hard so that things like bugs and other cars wont hurt the people inside when you hit them. But if your car is lacking the hardness it needs, you'll have a really soft, useless car.

readings.mnemonic: This car is probably so soft because it's made entirely of naan (なん). Naan may be delicious, but it makes a really crappy car. No wonder it was so soft (and yummy).

meaning.mnemonic: If you mix a bunch of buildings together, you have yourself a suburb.

readings.mnemonic: "Suburbs are what we need!" says Emperor こういち.

meaning.mnemonic: Take the street all the way to that geoduck, way up there. When you reach it, you will have made it to the summit. You humbly present the road to the geoduck and bow before it.

readings.mnemonic: You are at the top, the summit of everything! You humbly survey your surroundings from the top of the geoduck, only to see someone on the street, running toward you. It is Mrs. Chou (ちょう), and she looks angry.

meaning.mnemonic: You need to throw your two wolverines and your turkey into the oncoming tsunami if you want to wash them at the same time. It's the only way you can get them clean at once without the wolverines fighting over the turkey and somebody getting hurt. The tsunami is big enough to wash them all before anything bad happens.

readings.mnemonic: Once they're nice and washed you need to subdue them by poking each of them with a tack (たく). The tack has special sleeping medicine on it, so once they're nice and clean you can put them back in their cages without them trying to eat each other.

meaning.mnemonic: If you put two mustaches on either side of a tsunami it won't know which way to go and spin back and forth until it becomes a whirlpool. Mustaches are pretty gross, so I don't blame the tsunami for avoiding them.

readings.mnemonic: The whirlpool is huge, and it starts pulling things into itself. Oh no, is that my car (か)? Hey, wait! Whirlpool give my car back!

meaning.mnemonic: If you have an ear for the public's heart, you must be very wise. You can understand everything the people want, and you know how to give it to them because you listen to their hearts so well.

readings.mnemonic: All of these wise things are stored in your soul (そう), not your brain. That's where all of these kinds of intuitive feelings live.

meaning.mnemonic: When a tree grows old, it will wither.

readings.mnemonic: This withered tree's best friend is a human 子 (こ). Imagine the child hugging the tree.

meaning.mnemonic: When a spirit lives in a sheep it becomes the most auspicious creature on the planet. Lights shine out of it and the whole world weeps at its beauty. Look at the sheep's fluffy glowing head. Nothing could be more auspicious and glorious than this.

readings.mnemonic: The spirit sheep is so auspicious that the Shougun (しょう) declares this day to be the most auspicious of all days. The day when the spirit sheep appeared.

meaning.mnemonic: I hope all you're doing in the bathtub is taking a bath. I mean, you can do other things if you want I guess. But bathtubs were made just for baths!

readings.mnemonic: When do you miss taking a bath the most? When you're on the road (ろ). Traveling is fun and all, but when you're stuck in a car, traveling down a dirt road for days, all you want to do is take a nice long bath.

meaning.mnemonic: The leader of the library thinks that all the books in their library are better than everyone else's books. He's a very biased person. If he wasn't the leader of that specific library he'd probably feel differently.

readings.mnemonic: You decide to give in to his biased recommendations and look at what he has in his library. It doesn't take long until you realize that these books are all about hens (へん) and hen care. This guy is so biased about his favorite books that he only filled his library with what HE wants to read. And apparently that thing is taking care of hens... weird.

meaning.mnemonic: If you look at flowers the first thing you notice are the leaves and petals themselves, then the next thing you notice are the briars. You never see thorns first, only after you've looked at the flowers.

readings.mnemonic: When you see the briars you can't help but yell, Eee! Ba riars! (いばら)! You pause funny because you prick your finger on one while you're yelling. Ouch!

meaning.mnemonic: This building was a former prison until the cave in. You see, prisons aren't built very carefully, they just try to get them done fast enough to stuff people in there. So while you can tell this was once a building, it definitely isn't a prison anymore, since the whole thing caved in.

readings.mnemonic: You keep picturing the cave in and you see Genghis Khan (かん) climbing over the rubble. He's the one who took down this prison! And he's coming for your town next!

meaning.mnemonic: The famous gold triceratops shellfish is good for only one thing, and that's being made into chains. They link their triceratops horns together and form an unbreakable gold chain. You can't eat them, because they're gold. So they're only really good for their chaining together ability.

readings.mnemonic: However, the only way to break the chain is to saw (さ) it open. Once the triceratops shellfish start holding on, they never let go. So when you want to take the chain off you have to really hack at it with your saw.

meaning.mnemonic: You give a bunch of shellfish to a clown as compensation. The clown did you some favors, and everyone knows clowns only accept shellfish as a form of currency. So your compensation is a pile of random shellfish.

readings.mnemonic: Once the clown has been properly compensated, he looks you in the eyes, one hand full of shellfish, the other in the air, and waves, "Bye (ばい)" he says. "Bye, bye."

meaning.mnemonic: Your soul is like the ground or the dawn. It is constant, never changing.

readings.mnemonic: Also constant is the Emperor こういち, who will surely rule for a thousand more years!

meaning.mnemonic: You're sewing something with thread but you and your creation get frostbite while you're still working. Luckily the snowflakes freeze themselves into the cloth and turn into a pretty design. They swirl around and press a unique snowy design into the fabric. This is nice for you because you can't sew anymore with your frostbitten hands.

readings.mnemonic: As you watch the snowflake design form you see letters appearing in the corner! They form the name Aya (あや), our artist here at WaniKani. Somehow she's magically putting together this beautiful pattern!

meaning.mnemonic: If you figure out how to use a tsunami as a weapon, everyone is going to die. You can't control a tsunami, you fool. Now you've doomed us all.

readings.mnemonic: The only way to maybe not die is to find boats (ぼつ). As long as the boats don't get smashed by the tsunami, you might be able to cheat death by holding onto the boats and not drowning.

meaning.mnemonic: Your fingers grasp this lid and when you raise it you see a poop turkey (a turkey covered in poop). You can't help yourself, you embrace the turkey.

readings.mnemonic: As you embrace the sad turkey it makes a funny sound and suddenly starts pooping yogurt (よう) all over you. But you don't want to stop embracing it! It's probably just scared still. But the more you squeeze, the faster the yogurt comes out of it!

meaning.mnemonic: When you ride your scooter on the ground listening to music under the sun, you're bound to encounter a bunch of new people! They hear your music playing as you scoot by and they come out to meet you.

readings.mnemonic: Everyone you encounter wants to bare their soul (そう) to you, literally. They're all coming out to meet you, pulling back their skin and showing you the soul ghosts inside of them.

meaning.mnemonic: From your mouth comes a cross, some flowers, and shellfish. It all erupts from your mouth!

readings.mnemonic: When do inanimate objects erupt from your mouth? Mostly when you're having fun (ふん).

meaning.mnemonic: If the yakuza slide you into a jet, things are especially bad for you. Not just normal bad, like, especially bad.

readings.mnemonic: You're especially worried now, because they're putting you in some kind of chute (しゅ). You already took a slide in here, and now you're teetering over the edge of a dark, steep chute into who knows where!

meaning.mnemonic: A leader puts their hat on the ground next to a bookshelf. This is a test in ethics.

readings.mnemonic: To test your ethics even more, the leader puts down a ring (りん) as well.

meaning.mnemonic: The building to the east is an exhibit.

readings.mnemonic: Right now the exhibit has a bunch of chins (ちん) on display. Animal chins, human chins, every chin you can think of is in the exhibit.

meaning.mnemonic: If you tie a cross to a turkey you can trick everyone into thinking it's a falcon. The cross will stretch its wings out just enough for it to stop looking so fat and turkey like, into a super cool bird of prey.

readings.mnemonic: You decide to name this new falcon after your favorite falcon-like ninja. Ryu Hayabusa (はやぶさ) from Ninja Gaiden! Picture your fat turkey falcon and Ryu Hayabusa teaming up Banjo and Kazooey style. Yeah, that's the dream right there.

meaning.mnemonic: What do stairs do? They take you from where you were, to somewhere else. They're a way to get from place to place.

readings.mnemonic: If you're going from place to place, make sure you have some nori (の) seaweed on you, in case you get hungry. Nori is a great source of energy.

meaning.mnemonic: If you want to have your wedding in a car you're going to need a lot of help. Cars are pretty small compared to weddings, so if you don't get help from everyone you know you won't be able to pull it off.

readings.mnemonic: You can't just ask for help on the day of the wedding, either. You have to schedule (すけ) getting your friends' help ahead of time. They might have pretty tight schedules too, so make sure you plan early!

meaning.mnemonic: There is an animal in the grass and your horrible task is to go hunting for it.

readings.mnemonic: You're currently hunting in a row (りょう) boat and you have to row as quietly and carefully as you can or the animal will run away.

meaning.mnemonic: If you have spiders in your mouth, then you're going to instigate fights between people. Mostly because the spider in your mouth makes you grumpy, but also because the spider keeps telling you to be an instigator with its little mouth inside your own mouth.

readings.mnemonic: The spider in your mouth tells you to instigate a fight by sawing (さ) the other person's leg off. It even whispers where you can find a nice big saw.

meaning.mnemonic: If you give a machine a heart it will get lazy. Hearts give us emotions and with emotions we become weak. Why would a machine with a heart want to work anymore? Nah. It's lazy time now.

readings.mnemonic: The machine is so lazy it won't even wear its tie (たい) anymore. That was the only official thing left about it, but now it's as lazy as a human. Would a lazy human put on a tie? I don't think so.

meaning.mnemonic: In its soul, a narwhal that's supposed to do construction under the moon, will be too lazy to do it. And when your soul is lazy, there's no way you'll be able to get something done.

readings.mnemonic: You can't tell the lazy narwhal he's being lazy because he's your dad (だ). If he was anyone else you'd tell him off for being lazy, but you can't tell off your dad. That's just not right.

meaning.mnemonic: Take a leather helicopter to the moon to prove your excellent leadership. Some people called you crazy, but you'll show them, as you lead an entire crew of leather helicopter pilots on their first mission to space!

readings.mnemonic: Under your superior leadership you and your leather helicopter crew are able to make it to the moon. The moon! Your crew is so impressed by your leadership, and their lack of being very dead, and they all start laughing, "Ha (は) ha ha ha!" They thought they were going to die but you lead them to the moon safely!

meaning.mnemonic: Shaving the hair off a geoduck before you try to eat it is absolutely necessary. If you don't, the hair will get caught in your throat and you'll choke. It is necessary that you remove the hair.

readings.mnemonic: It is also necessary that you wear a suit (す) when eating shaved geoduck. It's a super fancy meal so a suit is necessary for you to enjoy it correctly.

meaning.mnemonic: If you take a cow's life you're turning it into an offering. In the old days, cows' lives were given to the gods as offerings pretty often.

readings.mnemonic: You prepare the offering with your holy blue saber (せい). Normally this would be gruesome, but your saber glows and the cow's life shoots up into the sky without you laying a hand on it.

meaning.mnemonic: If a grain has a fault, it needs to be put back in order. Grains must be perfectly identical at all times, otherwise they'll be thrown out. That's why special people will go out and check them to confirm their regularity. Keeping order is a tough job!

readings.mnemonic: You can always tell if a company keeps order or if it cheats (ちつ) just by looking at the grains.

meaning.mnemonic: There was once a melon child, that is, a child with the body of a melon. When he was born, his parents didn't want him, so he became an orphan.

readings.mnemonic: The orphan melon boy is but a 子 (こ).

meaning.mnemonic: If you point flowers in the same direction you'll be able to smell their wonderful perfume. The best way to get perfume out of flowers is to make them face the same way. Then the smell will go the same direction, making you smell great.

readings.mnemonic: You decide to perfume your entire home (ほう) by planting flowers all the way around it, all facing in toward it.

meaning.mnemonic: Under the window, you place a shellfish, then slam the window shut to pierce its tough shell. This is the best way to pierce a member of the shellfish family, I promise.

readings.mnemonic: Now that your shellfish is properly pierced and turned into sushi counters, you can serve them to Genghis Khan (かん) and his men. I really hope you counted them correctly too, because there are a lot of them.

meaning.mnemonic: The rice that's prepared at dawn by the village are provisions for the army. The army is scheduled to arrive right after dawn, so all of the village's provisions for them have to be ready by then.

readings.mnemonic: Once all of the provisions are ready, the soldiers show up in their row (りょう) boats and load it all up. But they aren't done there. "Rice isn't enough, we need roe (ろう) so we will have the strength to row our row boats back." And so the village brings them all of their roe too.

meaning.mnemonic: If you stand in the wind it will be really quick to knock you over. So quick that you probably won't even know the wind did it. You'll end up standing up again just to be knocked over again, just as quick.

readings.mnemonic: The wind was so quick to knock you down that you sat (さつ) down instead. The wind may be quick, but it can't knock you down if you've already sat yourself.

meaning.mnemonic: If your soul is acting like the sun trapped in a net sitting on a stool, then people will ridicule you for your laziness. You're just sitting there, trapped and not moving.

readings.mnemonic: When people ridicule you, when you can't stop the laziness, you read manga (まん). Manga helps you feel better about the mean things people say. Manga helps you feel like you're doing something, and that you aren't just a lazy person.

meaning.mnemonic: Play your drum under the moon and your hair will swell! The more you play and the longer it's under the moon, the larger your hair will swell.

readings.mnemonic: Using this method, your hair swells so much it looks like a giant bowling (ぼう) ball is sitting on top of your head. It's all round, and well... swollen is probably the only word that fits.

meaning.mnemonic: Your scooter gave you a splinter, so you had to go in for treatment.

readings.mnemonic: After you get treatment, you feel really good (ぐう).

meaning.mnemonic: If you try to say something to the Death Star, it would only admonish you. It was made to destroy planets, after all, so I don't know why you'd expect it to have anything nice to say. It just admonishes you about everything you've ever done wrong until you can't stop crying.

readings.mnemonic: Right now you're being admonished about living in a yurt (ゆ). The Death Star bellows, "What, am I too big and safe for you? I'm easy to move too, you know. You're a disgrace! You should be ashamed!"

meaning.mnemonic: How many buildings have scooters? All of them!

readings.mnemonic: All of these scooters have a specific sound they make as they burst out of the buildings: zuwee (ずい).

meaning.mnemonic: The old moon (the moon we had before the current moon) was actually just a huge barbarian floating in the sky.

readings.mnemonic: At least, this is the kind of story you told your 子 (こ) when they asked you where the moon came from.

meaning.mnemonic: In your fingers are flowers which really suit you. But you throw them to the people waving to you from below, as you board your ship. The flowers fall, unneeded. You're embarking on a new life, a new journey. There will be more flowers where you're going.

readings.mnemonic: You board a ship to とうきょう, bound for your new life, of course!

meaning.mnemonic: You weave gold and white patterns into this towel, turning it into brocade. It's beautiful, elegant, and worth way more than when it was just a plain towel.

readings.mnemonic: You want to keep your brocade fabrics safe, so you lock them away and seal them in with a niche key (にしき). It's niche because brocade is a very niche kind of thing.

meaning.mnemonic: If you're in Japan, the fish in your village are carp. You may know them as koi, too.

readings.mnemonic: A carp is called a koi (こい) in Japanese. We've used that word before so I hope you know it by now. A koi is a koi, you know?

meaning.mnemonic: Take the moon and wrap it in a bag and it will look just like a cell. It's a circle in a bigger circle. The moon is the nucleus. Yes! Science is happening!

readings.mnemonic: As you learn about cells you realize they're all over your home (ほう). Without ever noticing it, your home has been slowly filling with dead skin cells. And now that you know what they look like (the moon with a plastic wrap bag around it) you can see them everywhere.

meaning.mnemonic: Tsunami of conflict will cleanse and purify the lands of people, homes, and culture.

readings.mnemonic: The cleanse of your lands was caused by Jourm (じょう). Why did the slow farmhand bring an army to the village, and why is he yelling about, "The cleanse," while destroying everything? Jourm?! Weren't we friends?

meaning.mnemonic: There's a drop of bear on this towel. A true commander can notice little things like this.

readings.mnemonic: You watch the commander in all his glory... going back and forth on a swing (すい).

meaning.mnemonic: If you say something the same way they say it in the capital, everyone in the whole country will be able to comprehend what you're trying to say. If you try to speak in your hometown's dialect no one will. But everyone can comprehend what you want if you use the capital's dialect to say it.

readings.mnemonic: Now that the townspeople finally comprehend what you were trying to say, they sell you the row (りょう) boat you were trying to buy. You were using the wrong word, but りょう is what they needed to hear to understand you, and now you can row your way back home.

meaning.mnemonic: Flowers are growing out of the ground and over your pet pig's forehead and it's causing the poor thing to live in total darkness. The flowers are hanging down over its eyes and won't let any light in at all. And some of the flowers seem to be growing directly out of the pig's forehead too. The pig has just been wandering and bumping into things all day because of it.

readings.mnemonic: To end the darkness you mow (もう) the flowers. You have to drive your lawnmower over its head too, because they're growing out of its forehead too. They'll grow back soon though and cover your pig's world in darkness once again and you'll have to do it all over again.

meaning.mnemonic: The sun is rising and there is a net covering someone, who's being forced to watch as dawn appears. They've never seen dawn before, and they didn't want to, but you're making them.

readings.mnemonic: The someone who saw dawn for the first time goes on to become sumo wrestling champ Akebono Taro (あけぼの). He always gazes at the sunrise at dawn before he wrestles and it fills him with strength.

meaning.mnemonic: If you get a big hair stuck in your private soul it will be a disaster! Have you ever gotten a hair in your eye or your mouth that you just couldn't get out? You cough, your eyes water, it's awful! You can't focus on anything until it's gone. Now imagine if a big 'ol hair got stuck in your own private soul!!! Disaster!!!

readings.mnemonic: This disaster is so huge that even Santa-san (さん) left his vacation in Zanzibar (ざん) to come tell you you're on the naughty list for being such a disaster person. WHAT?! Even you Santa-san?

meaning.mnemonic: When what you're writing is as tall as the grains growing outside, you know you're done with your first draft. Some teachers want papers to be a certain number of words or pages, but that's silly. You should measure your draft in grains!

readings.mnemonic: Who asked you to write such a tall draft in the first place? Emperor こういち, who wants you to draft up the world's largest book about how great of an emperor he is.

meaning.mnemonic: If you can find the door in winter shaped like a mouth it will enlighten you.

readings.mnemonic: The door enlightened you by opening up and revealing the cake (けい) in its door-mouth. "Cake is the key to enlightenment, my child. Now eat it from my mouth."

meaning.mnemonic: Press your fingers in someone's skin to expose what's underneath. This is pretty gross, but sometimes it's more important that you expose the cause of the problem, than avoiding something uncomfortable.

readings.mnemonic: You expose a small hole under their skin and heat (ひ) comes pouring out. Aha! You knew there was something wrong under here. Apparently there's something under this person's skin that's exuding way too much heat.

meaning.mnemonic: A drunkard crosses thread across special spikes to separate the fibers. The best way to separate the fibers of thread is to get a drunkard to do it. If you're too precise it will just snap. You gotta be loose with it! Just flop them onto the spikes and the fibers will come apart by themselves!

readings.mnemonic: You stare at the fibers easily coming apart when you realize that this drunkard seems to have a few extra legs... and hair and a tail? This isn't just a drunk guy, it's a centaur (せん). Maybe separating fibers is really a centaur trick, and that's why normal people can't do it...

meaning.mnemonic: If you loiter around a surplus of anything, you need to be gentle and touch everything gently.

readings.mnemonic: You have to be gentle and handle these things gently because they belong to Jo-Anne (じょ). You're loitering around her surplus of (whatever you decided to imagine).

meaning.mnemonic: Flowers that are thought to be little tents sent from heaven are hollyhocks. They're shaped almost like little teepees and would make the perfect tent for a faerie or a little yokai!

readings.mnemonic: Hollyhocks are mostly あおい (blue) because they copy the color of the heavens, where they came from.

meaning.mnemonic: While the moon is out, a gladiator is riding a horse, yelling about inflation. No one would listen to him during the day, so he waited for the moon to rise so he could complain about prices doing the same.

readings.mnemonic: Inflation rises the most in とうきょう, and the gladiator knows that because that's where most of them live and fight (and die).

meaning.mnemonic: You use your fingers to take down the old flag and install a new one. Flags get old, just like computers and furniture and people. So when one gets too old, you have to get on up there and install a new one in its place.

readings.mnemonic: You've decided to install a suit (す) where the old flag used to be. I mean, a suit is probably more durable than a flag, am I right? This way you won't have to install flags as often.

meaning.mnemonic: You cut the flowers off the grain with your knife. The flowers that fall off are jasmine flowers.

readings.mnemonic: The jasmine is growing out of everything, not just grain! It's also growing out of the reeds (り)!

meaning.mnemonic: The thread that goes through Korea is the latitude line splitting up North and South Korea.

readings.mnemonic: The only way you can see this latitude line is to ride an eagle (い) over it. The line isn't visible from a car, you're too close, and a plane is too high. You have to see it from an eagle's point of view.

meaning.mnemonic: The melon radical and the melon kanji are exactly the same! Wahoo!

readings.mnemonic: What's the best use for a melon? Not eating it, but running over it in your car (か)! Melons make a nice big splat sound when you drive over them, and that's what you plan to do to every melon you see.

meaning.mnemonic: Tigers and wolverines have one big thing in common and it's that the government likes to oppress them. It doesn't matter if you're the animal or a mutant X-Men hybrid. The government will go out of its way to oppress you if you are one.

readings.mnemonic: Tiger and wolverine people are so oppressed that the only thing they're allowed to amuse themselves with is Gak (ぎゃく). You know, that weird goo they made us play with when we were kids? Well that's not so fun when it's all you have.

meaning.mnemonic: A cross carrying drunkard wants you to go to a rice paddy together so you can receive something from them.

readings.mnemonic: Against your better judgement, you decided to go and receive the thing. You close your eyes, hold out your hands, and feel a silky, light tie (たい) being placed in them.

meaning.mnemonic: A boat owned by a Yoga King needs to be able to let him keep doing his exercises while he's on it. That's why his boat is a rowboat, so he can work on his yoga arms as he gets around.

readings.mnemonic: As he rows the rowboat with his butt, you see the Yoga King eating something with his toes. They're tater tots (てい). Tater tots are the perfect snack for a rowboat. They're small, delicious, and they float if you drop them in the water.

meaning.mnemonic: This is a boat, but it's missing some pieces. That's because it's really rusty, so parts are falling off of it and it looks rust colored. In ancient Chinese literature, this rusty red color represented sincerity, and you'll often see this kanji take that meaning in jukugo words.

readings.mnemonic: The rust colored boat has inspired you, so you sit down next to it in the sun and tan (たん). You want to be the exact same rust color as the boat, and in a few hours you're sure you'll match.

meaning.mnemonic: The threads a criminal wears will always be scarlet. Scarlet is the color of freshly spilt blood, which is why bad guys wear it so much.

readings.mnemonic: This scarlet color holds a lot of heat (ひ). Scarlet is the color of fire, and it has the heat of fire too.

meaning.mnemonic: Put a turkey on ice and it will only get semi frozen. You add more ice, and it stays the same. Only some of it will freeze. What the heck!

readings.mnemonic: Finally you realize it will only semi freeze because it's June (じゅん)! It's too hot out for your turkey to freeze all the way. The ice keeps melting off the top and semi thawing it!

meaning.mnemonic: You want to have a quaint cottage wedding, so you have to go to the cottage wedding shop to get everything you need. This shop is the only place you can buy everything you need. It's not like you can make a cottage from scratch!

readings.mnemonic: You're browsing everything in the shop when a garden hoe (ほ) catches your eye. Yes. This will make your cottage wedding the absolute best one. The hoe will give you away at your wedding.

meaning.mnemonic: A dirt nurse is someone who nurses dirt. When nursed, dirt becomes soil.

readings.mnemonic: Soil is a thing Jourm (じょう) the huge farmhand works on improving. If he makes the soil better, the farm will yield more crops.

meaning.mnemonic: When a horse sees a spider it will start running at a speed no one ever thought a horse could go! Horses are super afraid of spiders, you see, so if they see one, they'll bolt and reach top speed! That's actually the only way to get a horse to run that fast.

readings.mnemonic: Once people realize that they can increase the speed of their horses, soon (しゅん) everyone will be taking spiders with them to scare their horses into running faster. I say soon because it hasn't quite caught on yet. But if you help to spread the word it can happen even sooner.

meaning.mnemonic: There's so much grain in your mouth you need to use a knife to remove it. Only when there is a surplus can you put that much grain in your mouth.

readings.mnemonic: The surplus is thanks to the hard work of folks like Jourm (じょう) the big farmhand. He worked hard to make sure there was a surplus of grain this year.

meaning.mnemonic: The roof flowers see everything. But, they only see. That is because they learned the art of tolerance.

readings.mnemonic: Tolerance is one thing that Genghis Khan (かん) had a surprising amount of.

meaning.mnemonic: Who goes into their yurt to boil things? All the people you've ever known. You don't boil things outside, are you crazy?

readings.mnemonic: Here, all the people I know do this, so just let me show (しょ) you how. First you go into your yurt, hey! Pay attention and watch what I'm showing you.

meaning.mnemonic: If you want to wear a top hat you also have to wear a suit to go with it. You can't just wear a top hat, that just doesn't look right. When you think top hat, think about what you also need with it.

readings.mnemonic: You have a top hat and all the clothes that go with it but you also need a nice car (か) too! You can't just get all dressed up and then have no way to get anywhere to show it off.

meaning.mnemonic: When the sun comes up the spikes of geoducks appear.

readings.mnemonic: You watch these spikes appear and suddenly Ken (けん)the samurai also appears next to you. "I DID IT!" he shouts, "I've learned how to appear out of thin air!"

meaning.mnemonic: What does a tree make that you'd want to put in your mouth? An apricot! Apricots are also about the size of an open mouth, so they kind of look like mouths hanging down under the trees. You can bite them right off the tree with your own mouth!

readings.mnemonic: After you put the apricot in your mouth you realize that this tastes really familiar, but not pleasant. It tastes just like the anchovies (あん) from the zoo (ず) smell. How did that happen? You don't like apricots anymore.

meaning.mnemonic: Dry an already dry tree to create a bookmark. The more you dry the tree, the flatter it becomes, making it the perfect way to mark your spot in a book without needing to fold a page or write on it.

readings.mnemonic: What are you bookmarking anyway? Look down and see yourself putting one of the tree bookmarks on a page in your notebook that says "She owes me reeds (しおり)." Oh yeah, you had to make this bookmark in the first place because your friend took your reed bookmarks and didn't give them back.

meaning.mnemonic: You see a bunch of trees lined up outside of the gate to the east and realize they look like perfect columns. It seems like a building or a castle should be resting above them.

readings.mnemonic: Out of the tree columns bursts professional wrestler Randy (らん) Savage! "Oooh I'm talking about columns that I like mmmm oh yeaah. The Macho Man loves columns MMm OOHH YEAAH~!"

meaning.mnemonic: Your forehead is the origin for the measurement for your crown! If you measure somewhere else on your head for a crown it won't fit.

readings.mnemonic: You want your crown to be just like Genghis Khan's (かん), which was more of a cap. He's your hero though, because he ruled over the most people, so you want yours to match his measurements.

meaning.mnemonic: If you announce that alcohol is illegal you're just being cruel. Honestly, saying no one can have any alcohol at all is totally unjust. They tried that in the 1920s and it didn't work then either, so cut it out! Let people drink what they want to drink!

readings.mnemonic: After this cruel announcement is made everyone will turn to the next best thing after alcohol. Coke (こく)! It's not a replacement, but if this unjust law won't change, then coke sales are going to go through the roof.

meaning.mnemonic: The surplus stool, please describe it.

readings.mnemonic: You describe the features of the stool to Jo-Anne (じょ).

meaning.mnemonic: Jump on a scooter to excuse yourself from answering a question and you've successfully deviated from that nosey person's plan! You've also been able to elude them pretty well.

readings.mnemonic: You deviate from the plan a little too well, and as you're scooting, what you've done eats (いつ) away at you. You feel guilty for eluding them...

meaning.mnemonic: You use thread and writing to sew our family crest. You've been sewing your family crest since you were a kid, you could do it today with your eyes closed.

readings.mnemonic: Your family crest is of a monster! And the writing says "Our Family Monster."

meaning.mnemonic: You see a building with a lip ring and it's just so cute you have to flatter it. "That lip ring looks wonderful on you, Buildingさん," you say.

readings.mnemonic: The building is flattered and you hear it shout, "Ah (あ)!" and blush. The entire building turns red.

meaning.mnemonic: If you give Splinter your heart you'll feel pretty foolish afterwards. His heart belongs to the art of ninjutsu!

readings.mnemonic: Splinter tells you to your face how foolish you are and you feel your heart turn to goo (ぐ). Now you can't even give it to someone else. No one wants goo.

meaning.mnemonic: A triceratops with a mustache will go on talking forever. Every time you think he's done he says, "Furthermore..." and keeps going. Something about a mustache on a dinosaur makes him kind of a jerk, but he's held in such high esteem that no one ever interrupts him.

readings.mnemonic: Why don't you just interrupt this mustache triceratops while he's saying furthermore? Because he's the Shougun's (しょう) pet. If you interrupt him you'll probably be put to death or something. Just let him keep going and hope he runs out of furthermores to talk about.

meaning.mnemonic: A mouth with a sword is threatening to cut off your fingers because they've kidnapped you! You can't see anything about them, since they're all covered up. All you see is their angry mouth and the sword they keep putting near your fingers.

readings.mnemonic: You've been kidnapped and your kidnapper has asked for one thing in exchange for your safe return: a kayak (かい). Kayaks are expensive. And it's way easier for this dude to kidnap you and demand your family buy one and give it to them than for them to work for one.

meaning.mnemonic: The leader who usually hits you with a stick in winter finds it in his heart to give you some leisure time.

readings.mnemonic: You're just about to start your leisure time when a group of youths (ゆう) appears with their own sticks. You look back for the leader, and he's wearing a bathrobe, sunglasses, and is drinking some hot cocoa. Wait... this is leisure time for... HIM?! OH NO!

meaning.mnemonic: You're in a really important position, heavy with power, but you can't carry all of that around with you, so you boil it all down to just a few merits.

readings.mnemonic: The only problem with consolidating your merits like this is that raccoons (くん) are always trying to steal them. Raccoons really like shiny, small things. Like, say, the physical representation of all your personal and professional merits.

meaning.mnemonic: A coat rack will turn into a bundle of sticks if you neglect it. When you neglect a coat rack, the weight from the coats will pull all of the arms off, leaving it as a sparse stick.

readings.mnemonic: You go up to the neglected coat rack and try to make things right by cleaning it with soap (そ). But no matter how much you scrub, it won't get clean, the arms won't go back on.

meaning.mnemonic: Whatever you say through a satellite turns into Noh chanting. It gets all drawn out and distorted from going through the satellite, which makes it SOUND like Noh chanting at least.

readings.mnemonic: While you're fake Noh chanting you have to pause every few minutes to take a bite of yogurt (よう). Yogurt is good for the throat! At least you think it is. It's not like you're actually chanting, the satellite is doing all the real work.

meaning.mnemonic: After your wedding you have a baby and it uses its mouth to nurse from your post-marriage boobs. Yes, babies nurse from breasts. Get over it, kids.

readings.mnemonic: The baby wants to nurse all day and the only thing you can seem to do at the same time is hoe (ほ) your garden. You hold the baby to your breast with one arm and hoe little rows with the other. It's actually a great workout and a nice way to spend time!

meaning.mnemonic: A drunkard gets his hands on a plow and starts planting right away. Drunk people are surprisingly good at planting, especially when they have machines to help them do it.

readings.mnemonic: He keeps planting and planting... a little too much. You walk over and realize this drunkard isn't just any guy... he's YOUR CYBORG (さい)!

meaning.mnemonic: You put your foot on the bar at the gymnasium at your very first practice. That's a big accomplishment since you're here learning how to walk on that long bar like all the cool gymnasts. But you can't just start right away, you need lots of practice so that's why you're here in this class. But so far you got your foot on the bar already, good for you!

readings.mnemonic: This type of practice is especially hard for you because you're a centaur (せん). You only have hooves for feet, and balancing on a bar is going to be a huge hurdle. But your teacher promised if you practiced enough you could make it, and here you are! With your hoofed foot on the bar!

meaning.mnemonic: The Mouth King, who is just one big mouth, has one skill, and that is to present. That big mouth is always presenting something.

readings.mnemonic: "I will present to you a presentation about mouths, but I require energy. Please fill my giant mouth body with delicious tater (てい) tots.

meaning.mnemonic: Your leader managed to find the right direction home using marks in the dirt in the middle of winter. This makes you so proud! You're proud because this resourceful leader is YOUR resourceful leader.

readings.mnemonic: This leader you're so proud of is old man ごういち. He's been getting a bit slow over the years, and you really didn't think he'd make it back. But, by gum, he did it.

meaning.mnemonic: A sickness that hits you like an arrow will do its gross work rapidly. It's not a good thing, you're gonna get really sick really fast.

readings.mnemonic: This rapid sickness makes your head pound like there's a shih tzu (しつ) yapping and barking nonstop. And it's making you sh*t a lot.

meaning.mnemonic: Flowers that grow in the west are colored by the sun setting so they turn bright red. That's why red flowers that grow in the west are used to make red dye. They're the closest to the actual color of the red sun, so they're prized by painters and other artists for their perfect color for dye.

readings.mnemonic: As you're smashing the flowers into red dye, a little girl comes up to you and points at the paste. She says, "赤ね (あかね)?" (That's red, right?) You look down at the red dye on your fingers and nod. She's right, it is red.

meaning.mnemonic: You took someone's alcohol and drop drop drop'd it all into the river. Now you have to repay them. Alcohol costs a lot of money, you know.

readings.mnemonic: In order to repay them for the alcohol you wasted, you offer to give them your shoes (しゅう). They don't want your shoes though, so you have to bring them to a store and watch them try on a bunch of different pairs so you can repay them that way.

meaning.mnemonic: You see a mouth coming out of the top of a tree so you go into shock. Your brain just can't comprehend what's in front of you.

readings.mnemonic: The shock you've suffered results in you needing to stay home (ほう) from now on. You don't get to travel, explore, or even get groceries. You're homebound from now on, buddy.

meaning.mnemonic: You cast the Mona Lisa in gold and attach it to a stick to turn it into a sickle! It's really big and bulky, but when you swing it fast enough your new sickle cuts lots of wheat! Just don't tell anyone what you did with the famous Mona Lisa painting and you should be able to get away with this!

readings.mnemonic: Now that you've turned the Mona Lisa into a sickle, you have to change the little description under its name in the Louvre. You draw a giant comma (かま) next to "Mona Lisa" and write "THE SICKLE." Then you shove it back on the wall as best you can.

meaning.mnemonic: A wolverine that sticks its legs in rice will become very solemn, very fast. This is weird to you because wolverines always seem so happy. Well his dad died from his legs getting stuck in rice, so just leave the poor solemn creature alone.

readings.mnemonic: Remember how solemn wolverine looked when his dad died? You hated seeing him like this so you ran up and shook (しゅく) him. You shook the solemn sadness right out of him! You should do that again now!

meaning.mnemonic: When you leave flowers on a tombstone they look good at first, but after a few days or some harsh weather, there's nothing left but stems. That's why you have to replace flowers on tombstones all the time. If you don't it will look like you only left the stems there, and that's pretty disrespectful.

readings.mnemonic: You have an idea that can make these tombstones look better than just having leftover stems all over them. You brought cookies (くき)! Cookies don't fall apart in the wind, and everyone loves cookies, alive or dead. You replace the stems with the cookies and everything looks a lot nicer.

meaning.mnemonic: You're sick because you put an arrow in your mouth and tried to eat it. To be honest, that's just really stupid. You have to be stupid to try to eat an arrow. You deserve to be sick.

readings.mnemonic: The only way to cure this serious case of stupid is to make you eat cheese (ち). Not only will it fix your sick stomach by cushioning all the arrows that you shoved in your stupid mouth, but it should send smart cheese waves to your brain and cure you of that stupid all together.

meaning.mnemonic: Clearing his flowers of icicles, the samurai returns home to his villa.

readings.mnemonic: Once the samurai enters the villa, he lets his soul (そう) go. He's been fighting for long enough and this villa was always where he wanted to go.

meaning.mnemonic: If you travel to the fish capital, you'll find the leader of all fish, the mighty whale! Okay, so a whale isn't technically a fish, but that's why it makes such a good leader. You can usually only find whales hanging around near the capital because they really enjoy ruling over all the other fish. They are the biggest, after all.

readings.mnemonic: The whale who resides over the capital just happens to be gay (げい). You only know this because his husband is a man whale too. Actually, now that you think about it, all the whales you've ever met have been gay.

meaning.mnemonic: You should stop to buy stamps at noon because that's the only time they're being sold at wholesale price. Everyone's so busy eating and working and being at school, that they miss this awesome deal, but not you. Everyday at noon you stock up on wholesale stamps. Do you send a lot of mail? No, you probably just collect them. But they were cheap, so who cares!

readings.mnemonic: Oh, one more thing. Going at noon isn't enough, you have to say the password to get them at wholesale price too. The password is "Oh Roshi" (おろし). Okay, so maybe that's just the name of the guy there, but it always works when I want to get stamps wholesale so you should do it too!

meaning.mnemonic: You start growing thread in your rice paddy to accumulate more. You didn't want to have to buy any, so you're just trying to grow thread with your rice. That seems like a good way to accumulate more to you.

readings.mnemonic: Sadly, this is a terrible way to accumulate anything thread related and you ended up ruining (るい) your rice paddy too. I guess if you want to accumulate thread this isn't the way to do it.

meaning.mnemonic: When you meet the leader dog you have to bow to show your respect. Dogs are pretty great, so the leader of all dogs must be the greatest! You should bow really deeply to this one.

readings.mnemonic: You bow as low as you can, but you lose your balance and fall over. "F**k you (ふく)!" the leader dog barks. Oh no. You messed up and now the leader dog is super mad. Saying f**k you is a little harsh for falling over though, you think.

meaning.mnemonic: When a man meets a tiger he makes the tiger his captive. Men are pretty crappy like that. They see tigers and they want to put them in cages, so the poor tiger becomes a captive of the man.

readings.mnemonic: The captive tiger is even sadder because the man put him in a robe (りょ) and is making him act like a human. Tigers look good in robes, but they don't really enjoy being forced into people clothing.

meaning.mnemonic: If you want to loiter on a cliff with the pope you better be ready to move in perfect circulation with him. The pope is wearing really heavy robes and it's hot up here on this cliff, so you both need to walk in circles to keep cool.

readings.mnemonic: This circulation wouldn't have to even be happening if it wasn't June (じゅん). The cliffs are so hot in June, and in any other month the two of you would have just sat down and had a chat. But in June you have to do this weird circulation dance.

meaning.mnemonic: If you find some rice in a top hat it's going to be really coarse and rough. Probably because it's not the kind that's meant to be eaten.

readings.mnemonic: You take the coarse rice and try to wash it with soap (そ).

meaning.mnemonic: If you try to turn something into ice while having doubts, it will just congeal instead. It will freeze, but it will get kinda yucky too. Your doubts will affect the ice-making process, so try not to be so worried and unsure next time you want normal ice.

readings.mnemonic: You always end up congealing your gyoza (ぎょう) this way. You want to freeze your leftover gyoza so you can enjoy it later, but you doubt it will turn out all right and it always congeals in a gross, half-frozen gyoza block. Yuck!

meaning.mnemonic: The king has a hat that's made from a tree but the more you look at it, the more it looks like it's just a big cork. It's a big, wooden plug that he's just placed on his head. It can hardly be called a hat.

readings.mnemonic: It turned out this cork hat was given to him by a centaur (せん). You look into it and it turned out it IS a really big cork that centaurs use on their big wine casks. But the king didn't understand, and thought it was a hat. The centaurs are probably still laughing.

meaning.mnemonic: The king of the flowers in the center (of England, if you remember) has a special crystal. The king crystal.

readings.mnemonic: The king thinks everyone wants his crystal so he hides it in the giant acorn (えい) in the center of the flowers in England. There's a tiny hole in the bottom of the acorn, and that's where this crystal stays hidden.

meaning.mnemonic: The dawn radical and the dawn kanji are the same!

readings.mnemonic: Dawn is dawn (だん)! It's also a great time to get a tan (たん). The sun is bright at dawn, but not so much that it will send skin cancer rays into you.

meaning.mnemonic: When spring is dry you need to dedicate your time and effort somewhere else. You can't plant flowers or vegetables, it's too dry. You can't play outside, your skin will flake. So you need to dedicate yourself to something inside.

readings.mnemonic: You decide to dedicate yourself to your home (ほう). You don't want to be outside in the dry spring air, so you focus on home activities. You can clean the kitchen, build a shelf, or dedicate your time to your home internet system.

meaning.mnemonic: You got off your scooter to load some charcoal onto it, when it suddenly took off to a distant place! That's some powerful charcoal.

readings.mnemonic: You chase the scooter to that distant place, but then you see it heading for a lake. Oh good, it should be stopped by the water. But wait! In the distance you see your scooter drive onto a row (りょう) boat and... row itself through the water?! No!!

meaning.mnemonic: Put a sock in a building and it turns into an enclosure.

readings.mnemonic: Now that you have an enclosure, let's go deeper. Put a cock (かく) in the sock and it becomes an enclosure inside an enclosure.

meaning.mnemonic: Put your fingers in a jet if you want to erase them from existence. You aren't just chopping or burning them off. There's like, no trace of them at all. Your parents can't even remember if you were born with fingers or not. Jets are that powerful.

readings.mnemonic: You're almost done erasing your fingers when the jet starts sucking all of you in. You would try to grab the closest thing to you, but your fingers don't exist anymore, so you hold onto the mats (まつ) at your feet with your toes. The mats are super strong (they're made for jets, after all) and you manage to save yourself!

meaning.mnemonic: A leader gets double the dirt to build on if he's the most excellent and most skilled of all the leaders. You don't think dirt is so great? Well what if I took the dirt you own away from you? Your house is on that dirt. It's mine now. Get outta here.

readings.mnemonic: This excellent leader is going to use all this dirt to store her excellent cars (か)! Excellent people have to have cars in equal or greater than excellent-ness than themselves.

meaning.mnemonic: Your soul long ago was very frugal, which is why you get to have too much in this life!

readings.mnemonic: You know what being frugal is? Sexy (せき). You save money, you use less resources, that's the sexiest thing I can think of.

meaning.mnemonic: A hundred foreheads lower themselves to their hearts in winter in grief. There were once many of their kind, the forehead peoples, but now there are only a hundred left after this harsh winter took the rest of them. Their grief is immense.

readings.mnemonic: Their grief intensifies because all of the foreheads they lost belonged to youths (ゆう). Dead youths everywhere. Now there's no one left to repopulate the world.

meaning.mnemonic: The soul in your toe leaves early. You grieve and mourn for your now-dead toe.

readings.mnemonic: You decide to grieve in とうきょう. Your toe always wanted to walk in とうきょう, and now you can at least fulfill its dying wish.

meaning.mnemonic: The sick Death Star needs its heart cured. If it doesn't get healing soon, it will die.

readings.mnemonic: You realized that the only way to cure the Death Star is to turn it back into a yurt (ゆ). Then it won't be able to do any more harm, and its outside will reflect its pleasant self on the inside!

meaning.mnemonic: You see a tree growing on a cliff and it has ten thousand horse chestnuts growing on it. These trees are rare, only grow on cliffs, and they always have exactly ten thousand horse chestnuts on each one.

readings.mnemonic: You decide to take a bite of a horse chestnut because it looks yummy, and there are ten thousand, so it's not like anyone will notice. You crack it open and take a nice big bite to find out that it tastes like toe cheese (とち)! UHG! It's the worst thing you've ever tasted. Like hot, moldy toe cheese! Ewwww!

meaning.mnemonic: The imperial radical and the imperial kanji are exactly the same! Wahoo!

readings.mnemonic: Who is the coolest imperial you know? Ryu (りゅう) from Street Fighter. Wait what? You mean he FIGHTS imperials? Oh, okay. Looks like Ryu is the coolest imperial FIGHTER you know!

meaning.mnemonic: Go from a bow to a small gun and you're increasing in fire power! Even though the gun is small, it's still a step up from a bow.

readings.mnemonic: You keep trading in weapons to get increasingly stronger gear, when you realize that at the top of the list is... a Yankee's (や) baseball bat? Huh. I would have gone for a tank or a bazooka. But I guess if this will increase your power level, you have to go for it.

meaning.mnemonic: Your bones have a scooter that moves through the bone marrow inside them.

readings.mnemonic: If you put your ear really close to a bone with marrow still in it, you'll hear the scooters going zuwee (ずい) as they move the blood around inside there.

meaning.mnemonic: A wing is something you must not do anything with. Wings are fragile (think bird's wings and butterfly's wings) and sometimes dangerous (like the wings of a plane) and you must not touch them, or even go near them! You MUST NOT. You. MUST. NOT.

readings.mnemonic: Apart from staying away from wings, the other thing you must not do is eat mochi (もち). Okay, they're not fragile or dangerous, but I love mochi and I don't want you eating them.

meaning.mnemonic: The leader is standing funny, facing a direction nearby. He can't go far because there's obviously something wrong with his feet. He's stuck nearby, very close to your side.

readings.mnemonic: You decide to bring the leader to a nearby bowling (ぼう) alley. It's really close and you can stay right by his side as he throws bowling balls and gets his anger out.

meaning.mnemonic: The soul of the Death Star is actually quite pleasant. And if you think about it, it's the people who control the Death Star that are evil and kill.

readings.mnemonic: The pleasant soul within the Death Star actually looks like a yurt (ゆ), not a big angry, metal ball.

meaning.mnemonic: You need to run on your toes if you want to proceed down this road. If you can't run on your toes, well then you're out of luck, and you won't be able to move on at all. I didn't make this rule, I just enforce it. Now run!

readings.mnemonic: If you find that you can't proceed, you're a fool (ふ). Everyone can run on their toes. Don't you know that? No? Then you're an even bigger fool, now get outta here!

meaning.mnemonic: The sun is the reason why crops grow and people can get out of bed in the morning. But on planets with two suns, they can get even more done and it makes them way more prosperous than us. They work all day, then as the first sun sets, the second one rises and they get a new burst of energy. The whole planet lives in a state of prosperity because of the two suns.

readings.mnemonic: The person on this planet with two suns who benefits from the prosperity the most is the Shougun (しょう). Yes, this planet still has a shougun as their leader, but everything is going so well that they didn't see a need to change. The shogun will be in charge of this prosperous world forever. No one ever thinks of revolt when everyone has everything they could ever need.

meaning.mnemonic: The only feeling a dead soul will have is remorse. Remorse for the people it left behind. Regrets for the things it did and didn't do.

readings.mnemonic: The soul with the most regrets is Genghis Khan (かん). Everyone knows to stay away from him in the spirit world because he's so sad. Not because of his own actions, but because of the state of his people now.

meaning.mnemonic: You decide to carve a tree into a giant replica of your big toe because you think it will be really simple. Once you're done though, it looks like a really crude attempt at a fat, lumpy blob. Maybe carving isn't as simple as you thought.

readings.mnemonic: You're admiring your simple looking toe tree when a lumberjack runs up and asks who created it. ぼく, you say. As in "I" said it, in a manly dude, way. He doesn't seem to believe you, so you say it a few more times. ぼく ぼく ぼく!

meaning.mnemonic: If you put two two pound weights on a person on the moon they'll increase in stature when they come back down. Everything is lighter on the moon so the person won't even feel the weights. Then when they come back to earth they'll have grown a whole two inches taller!
