readings.mnemonic: Getting a taller stature will also make you seem super sexy (せき) on the moon and back home on earth. If you stay on the moon long enough, you'll be the tallest person in the galaxy and who wouldn't find that sexy?! Huh?

meaning.mnemonic: You want to slice what you say in half so that people focus on the above text first. The above is what you want them to see! So slice what you say!

readings.mnemonic: As you focus on the above words you realize a guy (がい) is trying to push the rest of the things you're saying back up with the rest of them. No! The above text is all that matters! Go away guy!

meaning.mnemonic: How do you make a mnemonic for the word this? You don’t. But, we can try. You climb many hills. On top of one of the hills is a little drop of water. You pick it up and say “THIS… THIS IS WHAT I WAS LOOKING FOR!”

readings.mnemonic: This particular drop of water hold the core (これ) of the universe. If you didn't find this very droplet, we all would have died and this universe would be gone.

meaning.mnemonic: The reality of gold is that it has the power to tranquilize anyone who gets their hands on it. Gold may seem cool to have in movies and songs, but in reality, it has the power to mess you up!

readings.mnemonic: You've been tranquilized and now drool is running down your chin (ちん). It's actually really gross. But you don't care, look at all this gold! No one will care about your chin when you're rich!

meaning.mnemonic: When you go to the pool or lake to swim, you'll see a flag stuck somewhere in the water. That flag is there so you know it's okay to pee in that area of the pool. Everyone knows urine dilutes in water, and if everyone just pees in one place, it won't be gross. So go pee over by that flag when you have to go. Don't bother getting out of the water.

readings.mnemonic: Right as you start to pee, you hear the life guard start to yell, "NYOOOOOO! (にょう)" and he's pointing at you! You were just peeing by the pee flag! Why is he mad?

meaning.mnemonic: Between the roof and the ground there are few shellfish. This is because we invited some VIP guests into our home and they ate all our shellfish.

readings.mnemonic: These VIP guests are part of a Hindu (ひん) envoy.

meaning.mnemonic: You're holding a sword in front two buildings. What will you do?

readings.mnemonic: A. What is, stab the building on the left? You stab the building on the left with your sword and what comes out is... a plate of delicious nachos (な)!

meaning.mnemonic: There is a cage with an axe in it above your house to show that you are an artisan. All of the artisans have to have this special sign somewhere near where they live to show they make things.

readings.mnemonic: Artisans have to be marked this way because the Shougun (しょう) says so. The Shougun doesn't want to have to put any effort into finding people to make things for him, so he created this new system.

meaning.mnemonic: You're tapping your fingers against a white wall when you realize the sound you're making is actually a sick beat. You keep going and start singing along. Boo boo boop. Boo do do do doop! Finger beats!

readings.mnemonic: This beat is sick, but as you tap you realize you're hacking (はく) up the wall! Slowly but surely, your fingers are hacking out little bits of the wall. And the beats don't sound as good until you move to a new, clean white area.

meaning.mnemonic: Your specialty is dropping people with thread by binding them! You can drop anyone as long as you have enough thread to restrain them. It doesn't matter how much they fight, you'll get them to drop!

readings.mnemonic: If you're going to be a weirdo who likes to bind people, at least make sure that they land on their backs (ばく) when they DO drop. Landing on your head or your boobs really hurts. So please at least try to make them land on their backs!

meaning.mnemonic: You eat and then wrap yourself into a ball because you're bored. You're also sated, because you ate just the right amount, but now you have nothing to do and it's soooo booooring.

readings.mnemonic: So now you're bored and stuck at home (ほう). You aren't hungry. There's nothing on TV. And you don't want to have to leave your home to do something, even though that would probably solve your boredom problem.

meaning.mnemonic: If you could stop spooning water onto that tree we could use it for brushwood. But if you don't stop, then it will be too wet to burn at all! Stop already!

readings.mnemonic: You finally set the brushwood on fire and suddenly a Shiba (しば) Inu jumps out of the flames. So that's why they named this wood after them or... or vice versa?

meaning.mnemonic: The insect that is amongst all the world's trees is the butterfly. They are always hanging around trees, those butterflies.

readings.mnemonic: As you look at a butterfly, fluttering around a tree, a hand reaches out from the tree and grabs it, then starts plucking the wings off. An evil laugh comes from inside the tree, and you know it's Mrs. Chou (ちょう).

meaning.mnemonic: The mysterious sound that comes from a bowstring when you pluck it is called a chord. It's still a bowstring though. You need strings to make chords, after all.

readings.mnemonic: The chord you're hearing right now is being played by Genji (げん). He's sitting under your window plucking bowstrings and singing.

meaning.mnemonic: You're trying to open the lid of a manhole that's covered in ice by jackhammering it a bunch of times but it's not working because it's just too cold. It's so cold that your jackhammer is starting to ice up too. But you need to get this lid open so you try time after time after time!

readings.mnemonic: Each time the jackhammer hits the freezing cold ice it makes a high pitched ringing (りん) sound. It's actually really annoying to listen to but you really need to crack this ice open so you have to keep listening to it.

meaning.mnemonic: Under this canopy you have a brush and a task to complete with it. This is totally common.

readings.mnemonic: This is so common and familiar to you that you finish your task early and eat some yogurt (よう) while you wait for the guy to come back.

meaning.mnemonic: When you drive a car, everyone under your roof is putting their life in your hands, even if they don't say it with their mouth—it's still under your control.

readings.mnemonic: You have to maintain control of your car or you'll hit a bunch of cats (かつ). The roads are full of cats at all times. And if you lose control of your car for just a second, you'll hit at least two or three cats.

meaning.mnemonic: If you can guard your soul from bad things you'll always feel delight and joy. It's hard to guard your soul from everything though, so take all the joy you can, while you can.

readings.mnemonic: The delight you feel is so great that it becomes permanently etched (えつ) in your soul and even your face.

meaning.mnemonic: Put a hole in someone's body with a bow and they'll become destitute. You put a hole in them. They can't work. They can't take care of their house or their kids. They've lost it all.

readings.mnemonic: You see this destitute person and decide to give them a cucumber (きゅう). They don't even remember that they're supposed to eat those, so they shove it in the hole you made with your bow.

meaning.mnemonic: If when you speak it sounds like the power of a drum is coming out of your mouth, then people will hold you in high esteem. Anyone who has a loud, booming, powerful voice will be held in high esteem in this day and age. Look at all those awesome musicians who have booming voices!

readings.mnemonic: You hold them in such high esteem that you give them your car (か). I ... I said you give them your car! Give them your car. Hey, hey!

meaning.mnemonic: Twenty penguins together are always evil. Penguins are seen in groups a lot, sure, but did you know that any time there are exactly twenty penguins in a group they're plotting evil things? Evil things like global warming. And how to eat all the fish in the world so humans can't have any.

readings.mnemonic: The evil penguins can't let you tell the other human's what you've seen, so they murder you and hide your body in a haystack (へい). Your family will never know what happened to you. The penguins will get away with their evil plans.

meaning.mnemonic: There is a scooter that is a satellite, but it is far off and far away.

readings.mnemonic: The scooter satellite is far off, but you can still hear it's horn go "har (はる) har har."

meaning.mnemonic: A tsunami together with another tsunami is going to cause a massive flood.

readings.mnemonic: After the terrible flood, Emperor こういち comes to survey the destruction and offer hope to his people. But, instead he just tells the people that this flood happened because they didn't believe in the Crabigator's words, and because they weren't doing their kanji reviews.

meaning.mnemonic: Your threads are humble and that makes you a perfect gentleman. You don't have to have fancy clothes to be a gentleman, just humble ones that don't stand out and show off too much. That shows how polite you are.

readings.mnemonic: Unfortunately, as a gentleman who dresses humbly, you're always getting kicked in the shins (しん) by rude kids (and occasionally rude adults).

meaning.mnemonic: You've learned that you can catapult things to give them to other people! Don't catapult rocks at buildings and walls, catapult gifts to the people you love.

readings.mnemonic: Give food to your new friend Godzilla (ご) with the catapult! You and Godzilla understand each other now. He's just hungry.

meaning.mnemonic: A samurai hits the foreheads of grains with his weapon so the grains will pop off and into his mouth. He doesn't want to kill the plants, so he's just skimming the grain's foreheads so they'll fall off and he can eat them.

readings.mnemonic: Phew, all of this grain is making the samurai thirsty, so he reaches in his bag and pulls out an ice cold, refreshing Coke (こく).

meaning.mnemonic: Put your fingers in your ears when there's an explosion in addition to all the other things you were told to do. You have to crouch under a desk, you have to stay away from windows, you have to close your eyes. But in addition to that, you need to protect your ears!

readings.mnemonic: In addition to all the steps you have to take to protect yourself, you can't forget that ears come in sets (せつ). You can't just stick one finger in one ear and have that be the end. You have a set of ears to worry about!

meaning.mnemonic: On the roof above, is a small stool. Anyone who sits in that stool will be lonely.

readings.mnemonic: You're so lonely, you make up an imaginary friend: Jack (じゃく). Jack doesn't get rid of the lonely feeling because he isn't real, but he is a distraction at least.

meaning.mnemonic: Your roof is spicy because you're the manager. You're always testing new recipes in your house to share with everyone who works under you, but that makes all the spice stick to your roof (since it doesn't have good ventilation like a restaurant or a lab would).

readings.mnemonic: You've finally done it. You're now the manager of a bunch of spicy new cyborgs (さい). You've been toiling away for over a year, but you've finally replaced the cyborg you lost, and now you can manage them properly without anyone getting in the way.

meaning.mnemonic: The only building you'll get frostbite in is a mausoleum. Mausoleums and tombs weren't made for living people, so they aren't insulated from the cold. No one cares if a dead body gets frostbite.

readings.mnemonic: You need to escape this mausoleum now but the only way out is on a row (りょう) boat over a creepy frozen pond. You've heard of these mausoleum row boats before, and you're pretty sure they're cursed.

meaning.mnemonic: You go to buy a table but it looks it has water damage from drops of water hitting it. This makes it a pretty mediocre table. The water drops haven't really damaged it that much, it still stands and you can use it, but it's kinda ugly, so it's just mediocre.

readings.mnemonic: You weren't expecting to see such a mediocre table so you go up to the guy who's selling it and say, "Hey, I have a bone (ぼん) to pick with you!" But he doesn't think there is a bone to pick at all, he doesn't think the table is mediocre like you do.

meaning.mnemonic: Who loves their flag, using jackhammers, and precise measurements? Your military officer! He's always saluting the flag, jackhammering near all the new recruits to test them, and checking the measurement between the floor and their pants. Who else could it be?

readings.mnemonic: That military officer's favorite bird is an eagle (い)! That should be obvious because the eagle is the bird of America! And that's the country he fights for!

meaning.mnemonic: This was pure gold long ago, but now it's not. It's mixed with something else.

readings.mnemonic: It's mixed (and not pure anymore) because it was put in that sack (さく) filled with various other things.

meaning.mnemonic: Stand staring up at the blue sky and you'll feel more peaceful than you ever have. Blue is a color that promotes peaceful thoughts and feelings. That's why all the social media sites are blue. To stop you from being a jerk.

readings.mnemonic: Now if someone asks you if the color blue makes you peaceful you should say "YES! (やす)" And you'll have us to thank for that! All those peaceful blue radicals. They're the easiest thing on the site, and if someone asks you if radicals make you feel peaceful say YES again!

meaning.mnemonic: When small drops of water work together they gain respect for one another. If you end up working with someone long enough, and they end up being really great, you'll respect them too!

readings.mnemonic: If you respect someone enough you'll even take up their hobbies. The person you respect most loves the Yankees. You don't really feel the same, but you respect that about them so you chant, "Ooh Yankees, Ooh Yankees うやうや with them during each game.

meaning.mnemonic: You take some thread, put your scooter up to a signpost, and sew them together. You don't have a lock, so sewing your scooter up to the signpost to keep it safe is all you can think of.

readings.mnemonic: You usually only sew at home (ほう), so this is a big exception for you. You're usually worried that if you sew in public people will judge your stitches, so this is a big step for you!

meaning.mnemonic: A boat that's white isn't just a boat, it's a ship.

readings.mnemonic: A white-painted ship is a kind of hack (はく). It makes the ship more visible without costing much.

meaning.mnemonic: If you want to fit your fingers into a key hole, you have to squeeze them in. Fingers aren't exactly supposed to fit in key holes... they're for keys, after all. But you want to squeeze your finger on in there anyway to unlock the door.

readings.mnemonic: Once you've squeezed your finger in the key hole to unlock this door you squeeze all the money and jewels and treasures you can fit into your sack (さく). Your stealing sack.

meaning.mnemonic: An animal with horns is drinking our alcohol? Still?

readings.mnemonic: The animal with horns that is still drinking your alcohol is no animal at all. It is actually one of the local youths (ゆう) dressed up like a horned animal so they can drink as long as they want and you'll be too scared to shoo them away.

meaning.mnemonic: Take a mole out of its hole and it will suffocate. They need to be in tight quarters, unlike us humans. So when you take one out of its nice, safe hole, it thinks it can't breathe and suffocates.

readings.mnemonic: As the mole suffocates it cheats (ちつ) and shoves its head into your closed hand. You realize what it's doing and squeeze your hand tighter so it's more like a hole. You can feel the mole breathing again now.

meaning.mnemonic: A stone drops from the sky into a rice paddy and then a cross drops on top of it. They've combined to form a tombstone! Wait, does that mean a body fell from the sky first and you just didn't see it?

readings.mnemonic: Now you're curious about what's under there but when you try to touch the tombstone it's radiating with intense heat (ひ)! It must have come from outer space and this heat is from when it entered our atmosphere!

meaning.mnemonic: You shoot an arrow at the mouth of the sun so that it will grant you a gift of wisdom. You heard about a Greek hero doing this and the god in the sun gave him the wisdom to see everything. You're hoping it will work for you too.

readings.mnemonic: You're standing around waiting for the wisdom to hit you when something else does. In the head. Ouch! You look down and it's a wheel of cheese (ち)! At first you're angry, until you realize that this must be a sign. Cheese IS wisdom. And the key to wisdom is eating a lot of cheese!

meaning.mnemonic: The death of your eyes means that you've gone blind.

readings.mnemonic: When you're blind you probably shouldn't drive anymore because if you do you'll mow (もう) everyone over. Actually, don't mow your lawn either. Blind people probably shouldn't be driving anything.

meaning.mnemonic: An alcohol nurse is someone who nurses alcohol. In other words, they brew it.

readings.mnemonic: A brew of alcohol is what Jourm (じょう) loves most after a long day.

meaning.mnemonic: The concave radical and the concave kanji are the same!

readings.mnemonic: If you call someone concave the 王 (おう) will find out and he'll have his guards turn you concave.

meaning.mnemonic: You give a bow and a stick to your friend's family. This is because your friend died, and he loved bows and sticks. You give this to his family, to give our condolences.

readings.mnemonic: More than a condolence, you want to avenge your friend's death. He was killed by Mrs. Chou (ちょう), and she broke his stick and bow, which is why you got the family a new set.

meaning.mnemonic: The convex radical and the convex kanji are the same, so hopefully you now just know them both.

readings.mnemonic: Is this convex? It's totes (とつ) convex!

meaning.mnemonic: An altered bird is a crow! They look like birds but they're bigger and darker and smarter!

readings.mnemonic: If you can't tell just from looking at it that it's a crow and not a bird, walk up to it and caress (からす) it with your hand! If it caresses you back, it's a crow! If it freaks out and flies away or pecks your face, it's a normal bird. Crows are really smart and like affection. That's what makes them so cool!

meaning.mnemonic: An elf who ventures outside in winter has a lot of daring. Elf ears are very, very delicate, and the winter cold can really mess them up. So if you see an elf adventuring in winter, know that that particular elf is a really daring dude.

readings.mnemonic: The amount of daring you'd need is about equal to the amount Genghis Khan (かん) had. And he was really daring!

meaning.mnemonic: Even if you have a building, it will eventually turn back into dirt. Everything will degenerate eventually. A brick falls off here, a door comes loose there. Nothing can last forever.

readings.mnemonic: As you watch the building degenerate, you can't help but think of your dad (だ). You had to watch him waste away the same way of a degenerative disease. Why do people have to die, dad?

meaning.mnemonic: You take a drum and a branch and... well, what else would you do? You would drum or beat them together.

readings.mnemonic: Who loves to drum things together and make a huge racket? 子s (こ), of course.

meaning.mnemonic: You go to a big rice paddy and establish a prison right in the middle of it to restore the equilibrium of the area.

readings.mnemonic: To restore equilibrium in these parts, you throw all the 耕ing こういち clones into the prison.

meaning.mnemonic: If the leader of your gang is a drunkard he'll try to have you fell trees thinking they're rival gang members. You all know they aren't but you can't argue with your leader, especially if he's drunk. Go ahead and attack the trees anyway.

readings.mnemonic: As you attack the innocent trees with your chains and sticks, a bunch of bats (ばつ) come flying out and attack YOU! You have your own kind of bats so now you're all trying to fell the bats with YOUR bats!

meaning.mnemonic: Alcohol is a good teacher on the process of fermentation.

readings.mnemonic: Using fermentation, you are indeed making some alcohol. It will be drunk at a party put on by Emperor こういち.

meaning.mnemonic: Put a guard at your gate to get a good inspection of your neighborhood going. The guard will stand there all day inspecting everything and then report it all back to you. You won't have to do any of the inspection yourself!

readings.mnemonic: His inspection is complete, but it looks like he's used an etch (えつ) a sketch to record all the results. That's not really helpful. If you shake it all the inspection results will disappear!

meaning.mnemonic: You're riding your scooter toward your yurt as fast as you can because someone is trying to get in there to boil your water and you want to intercept them.

readings.mnemonic: You manage to intercept the shaman (しゃ) who was just about to open the door to your yurt, and instead you crash right into him.

meaning.mnemonic: The moon is easy tonight, so you decide to cut it open. But, the moon wasn't the moon, it was your big, pale, round tummy. You just cut it open, and now you can see your intestines.

readings.mnemonic: All over the world, people are cutting their bellies open, because they think its an easy moon (versus a normal moon, or hard moon, presumably). This is because they have fallen victim to a spell by Mrs. Chou (ちょう).

meaning.mnemonic: The king will send his men with swords into your private rice paddy if you come across lapis lazuli. Even though this is your private land, he wants that lapis lazuli to make some new crowns and thrones for himself. Plus he's the king, so he can do whatever he wants.

readings.mnemonic: You run up and ask how this lapis lazuli thievery isn't illegal and one of the swordsmen just shouts, "Loophole (る)!" What? What loophole? What law says that the king gets to steal your stuff?

meaning.mnemonic: Your nose isn't the first thing people see about your face, it's the latter. They see your eyes THEN your nose, then your mouth, in order going down. Just label them A B and C and you'll never forget!

readings.mnemonic: If you don't have any cereal you have to eat your B breakfast option. Oats (おつ). You don't hate oats, but they're definitely not your first choice.

meaning.mnemonic: A tree that does well in the wind is a maple tree. Maple trees don't have fruit so the wind can't knock anything off of it. That's why they thrive well in windy places!

readings.mnemonic: When the wind goes through the maple tree you know it's kite day (かえで)!

meaning.mnemonic: If you trap the moon in a greenhouse it will grow a creepy membrane around itself. The moon isn't used to the heat it would be exposed to in a greenhouse so that membrane is there to protect it. It's really gross looking though.

readings.mnemonic: You decide to open the greenhouse to check this moon membrane out but when you open the door the smell of big macs (まく) hits you in the face. Eww. Why does this membrane smell like a big mac... or does that mean big macs smell like a festering moon?

meaning.mnemonic: If you want to turn your thread into a sweet color you just HAVE to go with navy or dark blue. That's the sweetest color in existence, everyone knows that. After all, blue raspberry flavor is dark blue and it's super sweet.

readings.mnemonic: Now that your threads are navy colored you need to be careful that condors (こん) don't try to steal it for their nests. Condors love dark blue things and thread is perfect for a condor nest.

meaning.mnemonic: Flowers grown in a warehouse will be very pale. They never see the sun, so they don't grow to have bright colors.

readings.mnemonic: When you grow pale flowers like this, they don't grow a soul (そう). Soul adds color to plants and flowers. That's probably why ghosts and dead bodies are pale too.

meaning.mnemonic: Tsunamis get blamed because they pickle everything in their path. That means that everything smells of pickles after a tsunami.

readings.mnemonic: Looking at all those pickles, you bend down and pick up two (つ) of them. One in each hand. You look at the pickles in your hand and wonder whether to try one.

meaning.mnemonic: A drunkard has dirt in his mouth as he tries to talk to you. You walk over and he spits a question mark into your hand. It's covered in dirt and spit. Um... does this mean he's confused? He probably doesn't even know where he is. But how did he make this question mark and why was it in his mouth?

readings.mnemonic: The drunkard takes the question mark back and presses it to his head. He's wearing a Yankee's (や) cap. Oh come on. "Do you just want to know the Yankee's score in the game?" The drunkard nods.

meaning.mnemonic: To the mountains you took your horned husband for you two to get married. (Society wouldn't accept a horned husband!) To hide even more from the prying eyes of society, you take your horned husband into a ravine.

readings.mnemonic: The ravine is still in きょうと though, because if you went outside the city your marriage wouldn't be legal. So you found a secluded, local ravine.

meaning.mnemonic: When a shellfish becomes a drunkard and sees a cross, they'll become a robber. Because they'll steal the cross!

readings.mnemonic: Once the shellfish has a taste for being a robber, he'll join a Bosozoku (ぞく) bike gang so he can keep stealing more and more crosses. He'll drink more, steal more, and get to ride cool motorcycles.

meaning.mnemonic: Move your coat rack in one direction by shooting it with a gun. Then you can keep shooting it to get a good rotation going. If you think there is a better way to make your coat rack make revolutions, you're probably wrong.

readings.mnemonic: As you watch your coat rack's rotations a centaur (せん) barges in and takes the gun from you, stops the rotating coat rack and leaves. How rude! I guess centaurs don't like when things rotate.

meaning.mnemonic: The leader says spring is looking dry, so you'll need your salary in advance.

readings.mnemonic: Your salary is sent straight to your home (ほう) instead of the bank. Okay, something is definitely fishy here.

meaning.mnemonic: If you put your spoon in the sun while you're in prison, a mouth will appear to scold you. You can never see who the mouth belongs to, but considering you're in prison it's probably a guard. Either way, that person doesn't like what you're doing and they keep scolding you when you put your spoon out into the sun.

readings.mnemonic: One day you finally get fed up. You need to know who the mouth of the person who's scolding you is. You stick your spoon out into the sun and the mouth appears, scolding you right on time. You reach out and grab them. But in your hand is a pile of cats (かつ).

meaning.mnemonic: You have a net of thread for catching a turkey. But, it must be spread out and you must arrange it first.

readings.mnemonic: You spread out your net and arrange it just so. You expect it to catch a turkey, but instead you catch the ancient Egyptian god Ra (ら).

meaning.mnemonic: You have to put flowers in a bright place if you want them to sprout. If they're left in the shade they'll just rot.

readings.mnemonic: You want to grow these sprouts in your home (ほう), not outside. So you need to find the windows in your house that are the brightest.

meaning.mnemonic: A tree melts into the ground after listening to loud music in the hot sun, so you have to find a nice big tank to scoop the melted tree into. The music made the tree vibrate at juuust the right frequency that it, combined with the hot sun, made the tree turn into a puddle. You can't just leave it being all blobby on the ground, so you find a tank for it.

readings.mnemonic: You're staring at the big tank when an eerie sound comes out, "Oooh I am the soul (そう) of the tree! You've trapped me in this tank and now I'm going to haunt it!" You don't want to be haunted by a tank with a soul stuck in it.

meaning.mnemonic: The amount of dirt you need to get some peace is a two mat area. Two tatami mats, that is. This is a pretty common measurement in Japan, so you should get really familiar with the amount of space that two tatami mats take up together.

readings.mnemonic: A two mat area also happens to be big enough to hold two bodies (つぼ). That's enough space to bring peace to two living, or dead, bodies!

meaning.mnemonic: Riding a scooter to the library is a universal experience. People young and old have all, at some point, taken a scooter to the library, picked up a book, used the internet, sat in the comfy chairs, then left via that same scooter.

readings.mnemonic: Riding a scooter to the library is so universal, even hens (へん) do it.

meaning.mnemonic: The machine in your body that is powered by the moon is your womb, also called your uterus! Haven't you ever wondered why periods happen with the revolutions of the moon? That's because it powers your uterus and tells it what to do!

readings.mnemonic: It kind of sucks, but there is no way to sever this uterus - moon tie (たい). But if you find a way please tell me, I can't take this anymore.

meaning.mnemonic: The building clown is the only clown allowed to accompany you. You hate all clowns, and so does the rest of your town. But this clown is really good at building buildings, and he's allowed to leave his part of town and accompany you while you fix buildings together.

readings.mnemonic: He can only accompany you for so long though and soon it's time to say bye (ばい) again.

meaning.mnemonic: Put your fingers on your husband to aid him. There's something about a spouse's touch that just makes you feel better. Have you ever had someone rub your back while you were hurt or sick or sad? It's nice, right?

readings.mnemonic: Unfortunately, your husband wouldn't need your aid if he wasn't such a fool (ふ). He walks into doors, he falls down the stairs, he touches the plate when the waiter says it's hot. And every single time your fool husband hurts himself, you aid him.

meaning.mnemonic: When your scooter has a fault, you need to get an alternate. Hopefully your insurance will cover it too.

readings.mnemonic: The alternate scooter is made entirely of 鉄 (てつ). It's hard and cold and not very comfortable when you sit on it. That's why you chose to keep it as an alternate and not as your everyday scooter.

meaning.mnemonic: Your husband was wearing his cleats when he accidentally stepped on a bird. Luckily this particular bird is a chicken, and chickens are really durable!

readings.mnemonic: The only way to stop the chicken from putting on your husband's cleats and stepping on him to death in revenge is to feed it the cake (けい) you were making.

meaning.mnemonic: The king raked all the mountains down into flat land so he could see everyone in the kingdom from his castle windows. You should share your congratulations with him. Now, quick tell him this was a great idea.

readings.mnemonic: The moment you say "Congratulations!" you've already started to miss (みず) those beautiful mountains. But you can't let missing them ruin your congratulations! Don't let the king know!

meaning.mnemonic: Gamblers usually only see the sun at dawn. They gamble all day and through the night, and if they leave it's at the crack of dawn to get home, clean up, and then go back. I haven't known a gambler who's seen the sun ... well ever!

readings.mnemonic: If you're up at dawn you'll also see the あか (red) つき (moon). The あかつき only happens as the sun comes up at dawn so usually only gamblers see it. But if you get up early, you can see it too!

meaning.mnemonic: A clown takes a knife and divides himself. First he divides himself into two pieces, then he's in four pieces, then... oh why won't he stop?!

readings.mnemonic: The clown finally stops trying to divide himself, and you can't stand to look at all of him. You grab a bowling (ぼう) ball and bowl all of his divided parts over!

meaning.mnemonic: If you touch ice for too long you'll get frostbite and that's a really hard thing to endure. A lot of people can't, and die. Then again, you managed to endure touching ice long enough to get frostbite in the first place, so maybe this is baby stuff for you.

readings.mnemonic: The best people in the world at being able to endure the pain are the shinobi (しの) ninjas! They train by hanging out in frozen areas all the time and don't complain at all. Maybe if the pain gets to be too much you can go ask them for advice.

meaning.mnemonic: You have to reach a certain number of flowers and tsunamis hits to become a legitimate fiefdom. At least in the old days. If you don't meet one of these conditions, like if you get hit by tsunamis all the time but you only have two or three flowers that will grow, you can't be your own fiefdom.

readings.mnemonic: The most famous fiefdom checker is Han (はん) Solo. He takes his Millennium Falcon and swoops around checking for flowers and signs of past tsunamis and then he'll either say you can or cannot be your own fiefdom. Thanks Han Solo!

meaning.mnemonic: If you say the lineup of your family members that have lived on this earth under the sun, you're really explaining your genealogy.

readings.mnemonic: if you can't tell the difference between your genealogy and a game's score you're a fool (ふ) and I can't help you. You aren't a fool, are you? You know the difference.

meaning.mnemonic: The king wants you to make a rocket that looks glassy. It won't be very stable, and it probably won't work, but making it glassy and pretty is the only way to make the king approve.

readings.mnemonic: You take the glassy rocket and try to stuff some thin reeds (り) inside to support it. But because it's clear and glassy the king sees them at the last second.

meaning.mnemonic: You can only manage to avoid a tsunami by standing above it on a small stool if you are very graceful. If you aren't graceful enough the tsunami will knock you and the stool over and you'll be swept away like everyone else.

readings.mnemonic: No matter how graceful you are, the still tsunami shook (しゅく) the small stool. That's where your gracefulness came in. The stool shook, but you didn't. You balanced yourself and refused to go down.

meaning.mnemonic: The leader does a dance on top of the tree to show his greatness to everyone around. If he dances all the way up there on top of the tree, then no one can deny his excellence!

readings.mnemonic: If you don't recognize the leader's greatness he will throw ketsup (けつ) all over you (it's a special mix of ketchup and catsup). And it's ketsup because it looks like blood. The blood he'll spill if you don't look up and clap at his great dancing.

meaning.mnemonic: A samurai puts his forehead on the table next to his weapon. He is just a husk of his former self. This shell of a samurai has nothing left.

readings.mnemonic: The only way to bring a husk of a samurai back to life is to have a cock (かく) crow right in his ear.

meaning.mnemonic: This is a gold roof, correct? It's important to lock it up, then.

readings.mnemonic: The person who locked the gold roof was Jourm (じょう).

meaning.mnemonic: A sweet woman sits under a tree and works as a mediator. If you're having a fight with someone, bring them to the sweet woman under the tree and she'll mediate for the two of you. Problem solved! Thanks sweet lady!

readings.mnemonic: You go to pay the woman for being your mediator for you two but she just says, "Bye ばい)." You try to hand her some money and she stares into your eyes. "Bye." Oh... okay, bye then.

meaning.mnemonic: If a tsunami gets into a net that's imprisoning a bunch of insects, the insects are going to get all muddy. The net gets dragged along with the tsunami water and the insects can't escape, so they just get covered in the yucky stuff.

readings.mnemonic: Unfortunately for the insects, these muddy conditions have created the perfect habitat for ducks (だく). And muddy insects already imprisoned in a muddy net is a duck's favorite treat!

meaning.mnemonic: The only tree a turkey will live in is an oak tree. They really only do this because oak trees have really yummy acorns and turkeys loooove acorns.

readings.mnemonic: If you see a bunch of oaks but no turkeys just yell, "SOOEY (つい)!" and they'll all come jumping out! Just because you can't see a turkey in there doesn't mean there isn't one!

meaning.mnemonic: If you spill something red on yourself in winter you should pardon yourself immediately and try to find something else to wear. It's very dangerous to wear red in winter, and even if it seems rude, make sure you pardon yourself right away and get that taken care of!

readings.mnemonic: If you don't pardon yourself fast enough the winter shaman (しゃ) will burst in and cast a spell on you, taking away all the clothes that have red on them! Now you have to pardon yourself for being naked!

meaning.mnemonic: Throw a drunkard in a cage with a tiger and some spikes and the tiger will have the time of its life playing with them! Think of all the tiger play time possibilities!

readings.mnemonic: If you aren't the tiger, watching it play is a little like watching someone's head get cut off with a guillotine (ぎ). In fact, you don't want to watch it play at all anymore.

meaning.mnemonic: If someone gives you a sock you should receive it and thank them. You can't just say no or put the sock on the ground and walk away. You should always receive a sock properly, with both hands, when it's handed to you.

readings.mnemonic: The best place to receive a sock is in きょうと. They're famous for their sock stores and schoolgirls who have too many socks. If you walk down the street someone is bound to try to hand you a sock in きょうと, and you should receive it happily.

meaning.mnemonic: If you want to take a flag out of the mouth of a mantis you have to make a formal request first. Mantises don't like to just give things away, and they're kind of mean so if you try to steal the flag it will probably bite you. So make a formal, polite request if you want it.

readings.mnemonic: After you request the mantis give you its flag it shocks (しょく) you by actually spitting it out of its mouth at your feet. You didn't think your request would work, or even if the mantis understood human speech, but it shocked you by doing exactly what you asked!

meaning.mnemonic: You see a triceratops standing in front of a full moon and you can't help but see a really strong resemblance. The triceratops has that round frill thing behind its horns and it looks just like the round full moon. Who knew that a triceratops would resemble the moon!

readings.mnemonic: The first person to see this resemblance was the Shougun (しょう). That's why he decided to put a triceratops head with the moon behind it on his mon (family crest). Now he's known as the full moon dinosaur shogun, and he's very famous.

meaning.mnemonic: You see a soul on a cross covered in flowers with shellfish at its feet and you suddenly resent them. It's not like you want to be the one up there on the cross, but so many people left flowers and shellfish for them. It should have been you...

readings.mnemonic: You realize you resent them because it looks like they're having fun (ふん). You aren't having fun, and you wanna be! How dare they have fun when you aren't!

meaning.mnemonic: A tree is stuck in a prison under the ground and it's starting to rot and decay.

readings.mnemonic: You get close to the rotting tree and see some rotten cucumbers (きゅう) hanging from its branches. No!

meaning.mnemonic: You're walking down the street when you see twenty big crosses lined up in front of you. Crosses creep you out and this is way too many for you to keep walking so you decide to run as fast as you can to get past them.

readings.mnemonic: You figure since you're already on the run that you might as well hone (ほん) your running skills while you make your way down this scary, cross lined street.

meaning.mnemonic: You hoist your towel above your table, drop into the water and sail away. You turned the towel into an actual sail and you're balancing on top of the table, which is now a boat.

readings.mnemonic: As you sail off into the ocean you hear a familiar voice shout out, "Ahoy!" Han (はん) Solo calls. He's also got a towel sail, but it's on the Millennium Falcon, which is half-submerged in the water.

meaning.mnemonic: The flowers that grow on your roof that look like a sleeping bear is sedge. Sedge grow all over the world!

readings.mnemonic: The next time you see a sedge bite into it. It tastes like sugar (すが)! Luckily, it don't taste like bear.

meaning.mnemonic: Pour all of your alcohol in the pool to serve all your guests at once! They can all help themselves to as much or as little alcohol as they want! What a great idea!

readings.mnemonic: As you serve your guests (and yourself) you look over and see Shaq (しゃく) also trying to serve them. And by serving I mean getting served because he's throwing them into the pool.

meaning.mnemonic: Deep in your soul, you feel like you want to pull your fangs out by the root, but instead you let out a loud sigh. You're one of the only people you know that has fangs, and it weighs heavily on your soul.

readings.mnemonic: You sigh again and say, "I wish I was just a normal guy (がい)." I swear the rest of me is a guy like the rest of you. *sigh*

meaning.mnemonic: Put thread in the mouth of a worm while the moon is out and it will poop out some silk. That's why they call them silkworms, didn't you know? But it has to be while the moon is out, otherwise normal thread will come right back out the other end of the worm. The moon is what makes the magic happen.

readings.mnemonic: The biggest fan of silk is Ken (けん) the samurai. Everything he wears is silk, even his armor.

meaning.mnemonic: You see seven swords just sitting in a hole and so you decide to steal them. They were just left in that hole after all, it's not like anyone was using them. And even if they were, they'll never know you were the one to steal them, right?

readings.mnemonic: You steal the swords and realize they aren't just seven random swords, they're from the famous sword sets (せつ) they sell online. This particular set is from the Seven Samurai movie. Yes! What a great steal!

meaning.mnemonic: There are stones that smell like trash in the river. You reach in and realize these rocks are made of sulfur. Even the flow of this water can't hide the stink of these sulfur rocks.

readings.mnemonic: You throw the sulfur rock as hard as you can, but it hits someone in the back of the head. Oh no, it's Ryu (りゅう) from Street Fighter. You try to apologize and explain that you just didn't want this stinky trash rock, I mean, sulfur rock near you. You didn't know he was there.

meaning.mnemonic: The kanji and the radical that look like this are exactly the same. They are both Asia.

readings.mnemonic: What's the first sound in Asia? It's A (あ). Nice and easy!

meaning.mnemonic: The barracks radical and the barracks kanji are the same!

readings.mnemonic: Barracks are pretty big, so they weigh a ton (とん). And they probably take tons of materials to build.

meaning.mnemonic: You see a mountain in the shape of a turtle shell sticking out into the ocean. It's a cape! No, not the kind you wear, the geographical kind. When you're on land, most capes look like turtle shell mountains sticking out into the sea. Do you know any capes like that near where you live?

readings.mnemonic: You decide to walk along this cape because it looks like the perfect place to get rid of your old meat sack (みさき). It's starting to smell, but the ocean breeze from the cape pulls the meat sack out of your hands and off into the sky (then probably into the sea too).

meaning.mnemonic: Take three measurements of gold and slide them into a mold to make a cast! You'll have cast three gold swords, or goblets, or ducks. Just make sure you follow those directions, or your casting won't come out right.

readings.mnemonic: You open the cast to reveal your gold statue of Chewbacca (ちゅう)! It's life-size and now you have three! Your new gold Chewbacca casts are going to guard the entrance to your house.

meaning.mnemonic: You have to use your fingers to make an exit because you're so clumsy. You can't seem to get the door to open, your hands just slip around on the knob uselessly. Instead, you take your fingers and stick them into the door frame, pulling the whole thing off the hinges so you can leave.

readings.mnemonic: After you make your clumsy mistake you realize that these doors come in sets (せつ). And now you have to try to open another door. And another door. So many sets of doors!

meaning.mnemonic: If you want to say how eternity sounds you have to compose a poem. Or an essay. Or a song. Recite those deep thoughts about eternity and impress everyone who hears it.

readings.mnemonic: You decide to compose a poem about an acorn (えい). The tiny acorn is the perfect vessel for you to say how eternity feels to you.

meaning.mnemonic: If a pilot manages to land under a canopy with a helicopter that's pierced with a sideways barb in the heart of winter you should congratulate them! People should always be congratulated for doing good things, and this is one of the best things you've ever heard of!

readings.mnemonic: Congratulate the pilot with cake (けい)!

meaning.mnemonic: You can only give a kiss of alcohol to dairy. If you add anymore than a kiss the dairy will curdle and you won't be able to drink it anymore. Bleh.

readings.mnemonic: Dairy isn't kept with other drinks, it needs to be placed on a rack (らく). I hope you've been using your dairy rack to store your dairy. If you haven't you should get one right away!

meaning.mnemonic: If someone makes a bamboo horse, you know it's deliberate. You can't accidentally make an entire horse out of bamboo.

readings.mnemonic: As you admire all the deliberate details in this bamboo horse, the ghost of Tokugawa (とく) Ieyasu appears before you! "I deliberately made this horse to show you how important being deliberate is. You should be absolutely certain and decisive about your decisions."

meaning.mnemonic: Every leader will come to despise their followers. In the beginning everything is fine and dandy, but eventually the leader's followers will ask for more and more things, eventually ridiculous things, and the leader will really despise them for it.

readings.mnemonic: The more you despise them, the more booze (ぶ) you drink. This is not smart or healthy, but it's what this kind of hate does to people.

meaning.mnemonic: If there is dirt in a crab trap, it's a lot for the crabs to endure.

readings.mnemonic: You decide to make the little crab that endured being stuck in a dirty crab trap your pet, and put a collar (こら) round its little neck.

meaning.mnemonic: A spirit wearing two mustaches must be evil. Everyone knows a mustache makes you evil, but two? And on a spirit? Yup, definitely evil.

readings.mnemonic: You're watching the evil mustache spirit when it starts to float toward your car (か). And it's... hey! It's trashing your car! You knew this guy was evil!

meaning.mnemonic: If you can stop a turkey by putting a spoon in its face you'll know it's a female turkey. A male turkey will peck the spoon out of your hand and run away. But a female turkey will wonder why you're putting a spoon there, stop, and look up at you wondering if you're okay.

readings.mnemonic: The female turkey then runs around making a mess (めす) of things trying to figure out what's wrong with you. She kicks around her hay, water bowl, and scratches at your pants, making more mess marks on them. But you don't move and she gets even more worried.

meaning.mnemonic: If you see someone eyeing your womb you're probably going to be weirded out by how friendly they're acting. You only let people who are really, really close to you look at your womb. So if this guy is acting that friendly he should have introduced himself first.

readings.mnemonic: This friendly guy comes up to you and start to introduce himself, "ぼく-" but you stop him. He's been getting way too friendly with your womb and you don't want to hear who he is. He can ぼく at someone else, you're out.

meaning.mnemonic: If you stay up for so long that you get to watch the moon go down and the dawn come, then people will say you have serious guts. Staying up that late is really hard, and not everyone can do it. If you don't have the guts to stay up, you'll just fall asleep and never see the moon and the sun switch places in the sky.

readings.mnemonic: You were outside for so long, proving you had guts, that you also got a sweet tan (たん) out of it! It's a really deep tan though, and you probably need more guts if you ever want to do all that again.

meaning.mnemonic: You try to use your fingers to cast doubt on people by using them to imitate each other. Right now you're using your fingers as finger puppets, imitating one of your friends to the others.

readings.mnemonic: Everyone thinks the friend you were trying to imitate is the imitation now and they have them in a guillotine (ぎ). You even doubt if they're an imitation or if your fingers are the imitation.

meaning.mnemonic: What kind of tree is spicy? A Japanese birch, or birch, obviously. There's nothing spicier than a Japanese birch!

readings.mnemonic: You can only cut down a Japanese birch using a zoo saw (あずさ) because a regular saw can't handle how spicy these trees are.

meaning.mnemonic: A tsunami hits a tree and your hat protects you from the water, but the hat itself is now covered in lacquer. You take it off and see that it's shiny and hard and protected.

readings.mnemonic: You decide to scoop up the rest of the lacquer water and use it on your furniture to protect it from your shih tzu (しつ). Now it can't bite or scratch or ruin any of your things anymore!

meaning.mnemonic: You see a gate with a tree growing through it and it reminds you that you need more leisure time. You walk up to the gate tree and curl up under its branches. No one will bother you because the tree is blocking the gate from being used.

readings.mnemonic: As you leisurely nap, you hear a gruff voice, "Ah, you're done too, huh?" It's Genghis Khan (かん)! He's spending his leisure time relaxing under this abandoned gate just like you.

meaning.mnemonic: Your soul stands in the village you long for. It's the village you're from, and no matter how far you go, no matter how old you get, your soul is still there, and you yearn for it.

readings.mnemonic: No matter how much you long for it, you can't go back because a cougar (あこが) is in the way. Whenever you try to return to your village to be reunited with the soul you yearn for, a cougar is back, and won't let you in.

meaning.mnemonic: You drop to the ground in a rice paddy, and then drop down in front of the cross you keep on you because you're trying to make yourself as lowly as you can in front of God. He said to lower yourself and this is the only way you can interpret that.

readings.mnemonic: The only problem about being lowly is the heat (ひ). Everyone always told you that heat rises, but not here. The rice paddy is incredibly hot... unless oh no. Is that the heat of hell?

meaning.mnemonic: You meet a woman whose mouth is big and you instantly know this is the person you want to marry.

readings.mnemonic: You marry this woman right away and you both go straight to an inn (いん) together!

meaning.mnemonic: If you only let oneself (yourself) into your heart, you'll end up mourning all of the loves and friendships you could have had but didn't let in.

readings.mnemonic: While you're in mourning, you feel a sharp pain in your crying eyes. A key (き) comes sliding out with your tears. You look around wildly, but you're still alone. Is this... the key of mourning?

meaning.mnemonic: When underground music makes it out into the light of the sun (the public), it finally becomes official. Music isn't really real unless people hear it outside of those secret underground concerts.

readings.mnemonic: Once the music is official, you'll feel it in your soul (そう). When you listen to it outside, under the bright sun, your soul gets to finally hear it too.

meaning.mnemonic: If you're on a mountain looking from above to below that means you're on the peak of the mountain.

readings.mnemonic: It's only on this type of mountain peak that you'll be able to find the rare and adorable Tokyo gecko (とうげ). These tiny little critters can only be found on the ridges going above and below the mountains in Tokyo. There are like six mountains in Tokyo, so the next time you're scaling the ridges keep your eyes open for the Tokyo gecko!

meaning.mnemonic: We want you to say things with your mouth right now because it's recital time! Go, perform please. What do you mean you didn't know the recital was right now? Well, tough luck. Recite!

readings.mnemonic: Here, if you are too afraid to start the recital now drink this gin (ぎん) to get your courage up. But once you're done drinking it the recital starts!

meaning.mnemonic: The stone that looks like a turkey boiling underwater is just a reef.

readings.mnemonic: The reef is the Shougun's (しょう) favorite place to be nowadays. He sits next to the water, and stares down into it for hours.

meaning.mnemonic: People think tsunamis are only made of water but they have a few pieces of sand in there too. There's actually more sand in the ocean than most people think. And tsunamis can't just have water and sharks in them. A few grains of sand will always slip in.

readings.mnemonic: How do I know there's sand in there? Because I saw (さ) them!

meaning.mnemonic: In a flowers net a drunkard slides down like a drop. There they stay, an icon of scorn and neglect.

readings.mnemonic: Every time you receive scorn and neglect from someone walking by, you say in your drunken voice: "I bets you (べつ) I can get up if I want. I bets you I can."

meaning.mnemonic: If the tsunami that's heading for your village is fat you should try to select a different one to hit instead. You don't want to select fat tsunamis because they do more damage.

readings.mnemonic: If you're having trouble selecting which one is the least fat just check to see which tsunamis are eating tacos (た). Only fat tsunamis will be eating them, so just look for one without a taco.

meaning.mnemonic: Move thread in the right direction and you'll end up spinning it into yarn. Then you can spin that yarn into a sweater or a scarf with your favorite half tofu half fugu mascot on it!

readings.mnemonic: While you're spinning you realize that you've always wanted to make your own bowling (ぼう) ball. And bowling ball cover. And bowling ball shoes.

meaning.mnemonic: Going from a scooter to a helicopter that's big even for yourself (oneself), is huge transition.

readings.mnemonic: You decide one transition isn't enough, so you transition to a centaur (せん) too. Now you're a big half horse-half human creature and you'll fit in the big helicopter better.

meaning.mnemonic: There were lots of things that were above you when you were small that you would need a stool to reach, so you just asked your aunt or uncle to get them for you.

readings.mnemonic: You ask your aunt and uncle to help you reach your special obi (お) from high up in the closet.

meaning.mnemonic: Making a mnemonic for a crab trap is VERY hard. So hard that I couldn't come up with one. But it's very possible that one of you will!

readings.mnemonic: You know what else is very something? Jeans (じん). Jeans are very expensive. Jeans are very tight. Jeans are very popular. Jeans are very a lot of things.

meaning.mnemonic: The tsunami that is good. This fabled creature has never been seen, but you wander the lands in search of it.

readings.mnemonic: As you wander, you come across a clue. It is fish roe (ろう).

meaning.mnemonic: Under the mountain's roof are people using jackhammers to worship the gods. The noise from their jackhammering echos up through the mountain and up toward the sky where the gods live. As long as each person uses their own jackhammer, the sound will be loud enough to reach them.

readings.mnemonic: Unfortunately, the people who live around here can also hear you and the others worship in the mountain and they're going to sue (すう) you for the noise.

meaning.mnemonic: Set fire to a geoduck if you want to annoy it. Fire won't kill a geoduck, but have you ever been on fire? It's not really pleasant. So you'll just annoy it pretty badly.

readings.mnemonic: You know who loves annoying geoducks more than anyone else in the universe? Han (はん) Solo! If you watch Star Wars closely enough you can see him shooting geoducks with his blaster and catching them on fire for fun.

meaning.mnemonic: "For the  samurai, it is a jackhammer that they will lack." That is the latest article of the law written about samurai, hundreds of years after katana were taken away. This article was written with great sincerity by the government.

readings.mnemonic: The one who wrote these articles with such sincerity was Genghis Khan (かん).

meaning.mnemonic: Red insects only bite barbarians. If a red insect bites you then you have barbarian blood! Waaay back a barbarian was your aunt or uncle or great great grand pappy! But the insects kinda hurt, so it's a bit of a downside I guess.

readings.mnemonic: You follow the red insect and see it bite someone who must be a barbarian! You look up at their face but all you can see are giant Ray-Ban (ばん) sunglasses. You really want to look at his face to see what a barbarian looks like but those darn things are in the way!

meaning.mnemonic: Under this canopy is the Mona Lisa, being sold for cheap, what a great bargain! You never know what kind of bargains you'll find when you look under a canopy at the wares of a traveling salesperson.

readings.mnemonic: You want to make sure this bargain is as good as it seems, so you ask if you can get this Mona Lisa as a rental (れん). Just for now, so you can make sure it's real before you buy it at that low, low price.

meaning.mnemonic: If you want to slice the power out of someone just censure them. Then they'll be cut down in front of everyone and they'll feel super embarrassed. It's the best way to slice them down without actually cutting them and getting arrested.

readings.mnemonic: Once you censure them and they lose all their power, they'll be just another guy (がい). A normal guy with everything lost to him. HAHAHA!

meaning.mnemonic: If you think a tree looks sweet you have to be certain before you bite into it. Trees are really hard, and usually pretty bitter (believe me) so if you don't want a mouthful of broken teeth, sap, and sadness, you really need to be sure it's the one before you start munching.

readings.mnemonic: If you really want to be certain, and not just guess, take out your bowling (ぼう) ball and roll it as hard as you can into the tree. If its the right one it will let out a sweet smell, if it's not the tree will punch you.

meaning.mnemonic: An arrow is shot from heaven and hits right between your mouth and your mustache to correct your crooked smile. It also straightens your teeth and the crooked cut of your mustache too. Who told you that looked good? Well, it doesn't matter. The heaven arrow corrected it for you.

readings.mnemonic: These heavenly correcting arrows actually come from きょうと. They hate seeing people with crooked mustaches, so they shoot them out on the regular. It just looks like they're coming from heaven because they fall out of the sky.

meaning.mnemonic: Inside this giant mouth is a person, trapped, because they're a criminal. They did something bad (they touched the mouth of another person without consent) and now they're in mouth jail for criminals.

readings.mnemonic: The criminal is only wearing shoes (しゅう). They're completely naked otherwise. They have to wear shoes because the mouth jail would be too slippery for them to stand otherwise.

meaning.mnemonic: You ate some grains that made you so sick it feels like a knife is stabbing in your guts and all your poop is falling out. This is called diarrhea. Everyone's had diarrhea before, so you should know this feeling by now.

readings.mnemonic: The diarrhea is here. It's happening. And it smells so awful you can't breathe. You have to take some hollow reeds (り) and shove them up your nose and out the bathroom door so you can get some fresh air in you.

meaning.mnemonic: If you ride a scooter with your fingers around an axe you're going to die. I mean, probably. There's a 99% chance you'll die.

readings.mnemonic: You slip. The axe collides with your face. You die. But... wait! There's a bright, blue glow and suddenly you're un-dead. You watch in slow motion as your holy blue saber (せい) brings you back to life and takes the hit from the axe instead.

meaning.mnemonic: The animal that hangs out in melon patches is the elusive fox! They like to steal melons then come back into town disguised as human melon sellers. Foxes are tricky like that.

readings.mnemonic: If you want to stop foxes from stealing your melons you can get one of those kits that neigh (きつね) when one is around. The kits neigh when they sense a fox, but because it sounds like a horse the fox won't run. But you'll be able to get out there and take your melons back!

meaning.mnemonic: You're stuck in your car during a tsunami and all you have to break out is an axe. You whack and whack but you're only gradually making progress. You thought an axe would be an easy way to get out of a car but it's not working like you'd planned! You have to make more than gradual progress if you don't want to drown.

readings.mnemonic: As you're gradually making your door open with the axe you look up to see the New York Yankees floating by on top of their bus. You yell, "YO YANKEES (ようや) to get their attention. They see your gradual progress and start throwing balls at your car to help dent it open.

meaning.mnemonic: You see twenty slides lined up like a grid. You don't know who put them here, but they almost look like the grid paper you do your maths homework in. But who would use a slide as grid paper?

readings.mnemonic: As you stare at the slide grid you see some people come out and overhear them talk about their mass maths (ます) tournament happening later today. Oohhh it IS a giant grid. And they're going to use it to do maths later!

meaning.mnemonic: Have you heard the tale of the woman who fell in love with a coat rack during a full moon and made him her groom? It's a true story! She even had a wedding ceremony and had more coat racks sitting in the grooms side. The moon will make people do craaaazy things.

readings.mnemonic: The best part of the story is that the only coat on the coat rack groom was a moose coat (むこ). So the groom was a really skinny stick with a giant moose hair coat hanging down it.

meaning.mnemonic: This cage is full of flowers on the right side to hide the fact that you're in here too.

readings.mnemonic: As you hide the ghost of Tokugawa (とく) Ieyasu appears before you, inside the cage! His arms are crossed and he's shaking his head at you. "Do you think I managed to become the first shougun of Japan by hiding?"

meaning.mnemonic: You say something to a boot when you want to be humble. You're down there because you're bowing in front of the person you're humbling yourself before. Because of that, your face is really close to their boots and you're speaking directly at them, instead of at the person's face, so it's more discreet.

readings.mnemonic: You're being humble like this because those boots belong to the King (きん) of England. You can't just say whatever you want at eye level to a king. He'll have your head chopped off for insolence, or worse!

meaning.mnemonic: Flowers that you oversee are always indigo. You aren't sure why though...

readings.mnemonic: Wait, maybe these flowers are only indigo because there is something wrong with your eyes (あい)! Maybe your eyes are indigo and that's why it's all you see!

meaning.mnemonic: Carve a tree into a bar and lay it sticking out into the water to make a jetty or a pier. Now you can walk out on the jetty and go further into the water without needing a boat or getting wet.

readings.mnemonic: You made this jetty so it would be easier for Santa-san (さん) to dock his sleigh. Oh, you didn't know? His sleigh is more of a speed boat now, so he needs a jetty to give you presents, not a chimney anymore.

meaning.mnemonic: Put a yakuza member in a prison on the sun and he'll become a martyr to all the other yakuza still on earth. He died up there so the rest of them wouldn't have to. Because they definitely aren't getting caught now, if the penalty is a burning death in the new sun prison.

readings.mnemonic: The only reason he ended up a martyr in the first place is because they put him up there in June (じゅん). Everyone knows the sun is way too hot for humans in June. It's summer!

meaning.mnemonic: In the dirt, you find a lid under the table. You lift it to reveal a deep pit. Why is there a hole under your table?

readings.mnemonic: When you reach the bottom of the pit, you hear someone scuffling around and the sounds of chains. You light a match and inch closer to see what it is. In the darkness, you see こういち, starved and chained in a pit under your table.

meaning.mnemonic: You're in a net but you have the ability to quit playing along and leave at any time.

readings.mnemonic: You don't know if you want to quit this charade until you feel an uncomfortable heat (ひ). You look down and the net you're in is being hung above a large fire.

meaning.mnemonic: If the death of a woman occurs it's because she was being reckless. People don't just die out of nowhere! They have to have done something super crazy to cause it. Right? Yes... right.

readings.mnemonic: As you watch the news about this reckless woman you find out that she died from mowing (もう) her lawn. You're not sure how, but now you really believe that she had to be doing it really recklessly to die doing it.

meaning.mnemonic: As the tsunami hits your scooter and your car, it alters the wave, creating ripples.

readings.mnemonic: Ripples come off of your scooter and car from when they were hit by a tsunami. More importantly, those things were rentals (れん), so ripples or not, it doesn't matter if they were hit by a tsunami.

meaning.mnemonic: The flowers that wash up on shore in tsunamis that we make into syrup is seaweed. Okay, so it's more like soup or tea than syrup, but you can make them both out of seaweed.

readings.mnemonic: Seaweed is true soul (そう) food. Which means it's good for your soul. Didn't you ever read those books about chicken soup being good for your soul? Well that was a lie. Miso soup with seaweed is what's really good for your soul.

meaning.mnemonic: Tsunami's have a certain tendency to secrete things as they go back out to sea. When they bash themselves onto the land they just throw a bunch of sea water around, but there are only certain things that they'll secrete when they're leaving.

readings.mnemonic: Most tsunami's secrete heat (ひ). It takes a lot of energy for a tsunami to crash onto the land so the water is really really hot, and it has to secrete that heat as it's going back out to sea.

meaning.mnemonic: Use your mouth to sing and a shellfish to stroke your shamisen, and you'll be performing a shamisen song just like that! Yes, it's that easy. Just go find a shell, open your mouth, and you'll be singing one too in no time!

readings.mnemonic: A shamisen song is just an 歌 (うた) but with a shamisen. They're still songs so they're said the exact same way!

meaning.mnemonic: Half of a rice paddy is always on the shore. Japan is surrounded by water, after all. So it only makes sense that half of every rice paddy is right next to the ocean shore, right?

readings.mnemonic: You decide to walk along this shore when you see Han (はん) Solo lounging in the sand. He's waving for you to join him! You get to lay on the shore with Han!!

meaning.mnemonic: The leader squid tells all of its squid people to be thrifty.

readings.mnemonic: Who is a thrifty squid? Ken (けん) the samurai's squid buddy, who gets carried around in a bucket and never pays rent.

meaning.mnemonic: You put your fingers in the coffin to tickle the beggar inside. What you're doing is a new form of torture.

readings.mnemonic: The beggar you will coffin tickle torture is ごういち, a.k.a. Grandpa Koichi. He is a frail old man, and doesn't like to be tickled.

meaning.mnemonic: Give alcohol to a demon and you'll see how ugly it really is. Demons need to concentrate to keep their disguises going. Even if it looked pretty when you met it, like super handsome, give it a few drinks and its facade will slide off and reveal its super gross demon face.

readings.mnemonic: The ugly demon is drunk and taking off his shoes (しゅう) and swinging them around his head. And, oh no, he's drinking more alcohol out of the shoes.

meaning.mnemonic: Your forehead is in the sun, and you start seeing those creatures with lids for heads and  fins for feet again. Where on earth did they come from? They must have come from the underworld. Nothing like that exists in this life.

readings.mnemonic: The sun is unusually hot for the month of May (めい), which must be why those underworld creatures are running around.

meaning.mnemonic: The tsunami swept away one of the cleats your husband just bought and creates an entire valley with it.

readings.mnemonic: When the water clears, you and your husband go to the valley to look for the cleat and instead you find a bunch of cake (けい)! Maybe this is the tsunami's way of saying, "Thanks for letting me steal your cleat so I could make this valley shortcut."

meaning.mnemonic: When you see a tsunami coming courage wells up inside you and you gain the power to save everyone you meet before they get washed away! Feel that courage boil and spread throughout all your limbs. You feel like you have super strength. This tsunami isn't going to hurt anyone while you're alive to stop it!

readings.mnemonic: Who does that courage well up inside? You (ゆう)! In fact, YOU feel like there is a never ending well of courage bursting out of you now. You are going to be a hero!

meaning.mnemonic: Under your own roof, a geoduck jumps out of the ground with a sword and stabs your husband/wife/marriage partner to death. Now you're a widow.

readings.mnemonic: You may be a widow, but that doesn't make you weak. You run outside, jump into your car (か), and run your entire house and the geoduck over.

meaning.mnemonic: You're walking in a greenhouse when you see a small drop of water fall and it makes you yearn for the person you adore. You haven't seen them in so long. But something about being in this greenhouse and seeing that tiny water droplet made your heart burst with longing.

readings.mnemonic: As you yearn for that person from your past, you look back at the drop and see... Bobo (ぼ) the clown?! Uhg. Apparently Bobo dropped that small drop of water.
